column2: Mrs. Kate Holman, of No. 241 East Seventy-fifth-street, whose son had the smallpox three weeks ago, went to Sanitary Headquarters yesterday with a rash on her face. Dr. Purcell sent her to the Reception Hospital. Cases of the disease were also round on East One Hundred and Third, East Eightieth, West Fiftieth, and West Fifty-fifth streets, and the sufferers were sent to the Reception or North Brother Island Hospitals.

An international exhibition of railways and of industries connected therewith will be held in Paris, from May to November next.
ODESSA, Feb. 14.--The guard of a mail cart going from Voronej to Taganrog has been murdered and 20,000 rubles stolen from the mail.

The Prince of Wales has done well to dash a douche of cold water on the silly, snobbish desire of the Edinburgh students to elect him Lord Rector of their university. So idiotic a proposal ought to kill the office, for which political or literary eminence was formerly considered to be an indispensable qualification.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 14.--The condition of Mary C. Anderson, who lies at her home with a pistol ball in her brain, has apparently improved since Sunday's operation when fragments of the skull were removed from the wound.

MOBILE, Ala., Feb. 14.--Capt. William Cottrill, the well known thoroughbred horse raiser and owner, died this morning at Magnolia, just below this city, after a long and painful illness. He was born in England, May, 1815, and came to Mobile by ship in 1841.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 14.--The annual Winter carnival under the auspices of the Burlington Coasting Club opened to-day under most favorable conditins.

For the past few days the little settlement of Yorktown, in the northern outskirts of Westchester County, has been in a fever over a wedding which was to have come off, but did not, because the bridegroom-elect failed to put in an appearance.

LONDON, Feb. 14.--In the House of Lords to-day Baron Inchiquin (Conservative) demanded that the Government take immediate measures to deal with the lawlessness in Ireland. He said that the League was carrying terror throughout the country, and should be instantly suppressed.

Moen, the Worcester millionaire manufacturer, and "Doe" Levi Wilson, the illiterate, but shrewd, laborer, is as far from being solved as ever, although the legal contest between them has just reached a formal ending. Although the leaders of the freight handlers and longshoremen still asserted yesterday that the men would only go back to work in bodies, as they had gone out, the great majority of the strikers broke ranks and tried to make the best of the situation.

ALBANY, Feb. 14.--Railroad Commissioner Rogers has received many complimentary letters from business men, expressive of their satisfaction with his official conduct and of their hope that he would be renominated by Gov. Hill.

Sam Jones, the Georgia evangelist, lectured on "Character and Character Building" last evening to an audience which filled Association Hall and signified its hearty approval of what it heard.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14.--Gustave A. Sattig, who until recently was the proprietor of a drug store on Dixwell-avenue, bade his wife good-bye two weeks ago to-night, saying he was going to look for work.

BANGOR, Penn., Feb. 14.--The East Bangor Consolidated State Company is shutdown, the men all having gone out on strike for more wages, and the company is suffering a severe loss by reason of unfulfilled contracts. The strike, it is feared, may extend to other quarries. A meeting of the stockholders will be held in Philadelphia to-day to consider the situation. Bangor is the centre of the slate region.

The annual meetings of the two Central Park museums were held yesterday. At each of them the consideration of the question of whether the treasures shall be opened for the free inspection of the public Sunday afternoons was postponed.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14.--Father Agnew, a prominent priest here, to-day confirmed a report that no child will be permitted to take its first communion unless on the basis of attending the parochial schools from now on. There was, he said, nothing new in the course of procedure.

Any law that will drive the pistol out of the hip pockets of men in Texas will be a benefit to the State. The pistol is worn, primarily, as an advantage over other men, and he who would take this advantage is a bad citizen and should be punished.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 14.--Secretary of State Griffin to-day affixed a certificate to the certificate prepared by Gen. Gray, of the election of Mr. Turpie to the United States Senate. The certificate recites simply that the signature of Isaac P. Gray is the true signature of the Governor of the State. Mr. Griffin did this under an opinion from the Attorney-General that the law made it his duty to attest the genuineness of the Gubernatorial signature.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Feb. 14.--Frank A. Deighan, Postmaster at Castalia, was arrested to-day on a charge of abstracting letters from the mails. The Post Office authorities have documentary evidence in Deighan's own handwriting, that certain letters were received in the mails at his office, which letters the parties to whom they were addressed say they never received. Deighan was taken to Toledo today in charge of a United States Marshal for a hearing.

John M. Smith recently resigned his position as Dockmaster. Mr. Smith was also Drum Major of the Seventh Regiment. His resignation caused some surprise, as there was apparently no particular reason for his taking this step.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 15.--Portland wants some pefenses and gives good reasons for the desire. The city is as defenseless as when the British rained six pound shots upon it and left it in ruins. It is in the very van in case of unpleasantness with Canada or England. It has $33,000,000, worth of property assessed, and sometimes its goods in stock, vessels, and manufactories reaches $70,000,000. It thinks about $5,305,500 should be spent in fortifications.

De Witt Talmage, to Mr. Allan Edloe Donnan, a young merchant of Richmond, Va., was solemnized last evening, and the Brooklyn Tabernacle was thronged. PEKIN, Ill., Feb. 15.--Gottlieb and Catherine Sancsi, charged with horrible cruelty to their 10year-old son, were found guilty to-day and sentenced to five years in the penitentiary, the extreme penalty of the law. The child, whose feet and part of whose body were amputated, has been taken in charge by a clergyman.

The January salaries of the school teachers in the Nineteenth Ward were paid yesterday, so the Grievance Committee which had been appointed to complain to the Board of Education that payments had of late been delayed long after the 15th found themselves without a mission. TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 15.--The Abbett men breathe more freely to-night, and are profoundly grateful that another day is nearly ended without developing any more disagreeable surprises. They feel like singing, with mutual wonder, "And are we yet alive?"

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 15.--John W. Schemerhorn, of Nottawa, St. Joseph County, dealer in general merchandise, made an assignment to Charles W. Palmer this morning for the benefit of his creditors. His indebtedness is estimated at about $30,000 to $35,000, and his assets are placed at $25,000 to $30 000. The cause of the failure was the building of a large double store and other improvements on too much borrowed capital.

The dinner of the Lafayette College Alumni Association of New-York will be given to-morrow evening at the Hotel Brunswick at 7 o'clock.

A meeting was held yesterday at No. 3 Washington-square for the purpose of forming a, Building Employers' Protective Association. Chairman Charles Buek in opening the meeting explained that the new association would not be opposed workingmen's interests.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16.--The board of Reconstruction of the Reading Railroad met today at the general office, all the members with the exception of Alfred Sully being present.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Feb. 16.--The police to-day arrested J. E. Stiles and H. C. Dean, the alleged perpetrators of the recent dynamite outrages on the Sutter and Geary streets cable lines. The former was captured early this morning while on his way to put dynamite on the track.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 16.--The first meeting of the American Publishers' Association opened at Powers's Hotel, in this city, at noon to-day.

Although Controller CHAPIN'S suggestions in regard to a tax on life insurance companies, in a special report submitted to the Legislature yesterday, have reference only to collections under an existing law, he takes occasion to justify the policy of taxing these corporations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--The House Naval Committee has reported unfavorably the bill making an appropriation for two composite screw vessels of modern type for the training squadron of the navy.

About 200 Columbia College graduates filled the lecture room in the library building last night and proceeded to celebrate the semiannual reunion of the Alumni Association. They wisely mingled a little mental pabulum with the gastronomic features of the occasion, and Prof. J.K. Rees delivered an entertaining illustrated lecture on "Telescopes."

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 17.--Commissioner Fink's interpretation of the Inter-State commerce law does not meet the views of the Western managers and they do not propose to act in accordance therewith. They consider Mr. Fink's interpretation an ingenious plea to make the new law, so far as the long and short haul is concerned, ineffective, and force shippers to seek redress in the courts.

BOSTON, Feb. 17.--The American colony in Canada has been deprived of one of its members by the very shrewd work of a Boston detective. William P. Spear, an elderly gentleman of Boston, was until the day before Christmas last a collector for R.H. White Co.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 17.--The festivities of carnival season were opened to-night by the parade of the Knights of Momus. The brilliant pageantry burst into view at 8 o'clock, on Canal street, near Claiborne; marched through Camp, Julia, St. Charles, Royal, and Toulouse streets, and disappeared within the large portals of the French Opera House, where a ball, varied ...
LYNCHBURG, Va., Feb. 17.--The Lynchburg Virginian, one of the oldest paper in the State, established 1808, announces its suspension of publication this morning.

Mr. Richard S. Newcombe, counsel for Messrs. Pomeroy and Plummer, appeared in the Court of Common Pleas before Judge Larremore on Wednesday and made serious charges against employes of the County Clerk's office. In september, 1883, Ferdinand Mayer failed to the amount of $2,500,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 17.--A reminder of the Constitutional Convention of 1867 was brought before the State officials to-day, the Executors of Horace Greeley's estate applying to the State Treasurer for the balance of his salary unpaid.

The investigating committee appointed some months ago by Collector Magone, with instructions to make a thorough examination of all the departments, and in its report to make such recommendations as would tend to the improvement of the Customs Service at this port, is nearing the end of its work. A.K. Tingle, John M. Comstock, and John A. Mason compose the committee.
Another experiment as to the possibility of heating a moderately long train of railroad cars with steam from the locomotive will soon be made on the New-York Central and Hudson River Road.

The Senate yesterday passed, as we predicted, the Hale Naval bill. It is complementary to that of Mr. CAMERON for cruisers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--In accordance with suggestions from Messrs. Day, of the New-York Baseball Club, and Spalding, of the Chicagos, President Young this afternoon issued a call for a meeting of the special committee of the League at Pittsburg next Monday to consider the question of the eighth club in the League for the ensuing season.
ALBANY, Feb. 17.--Secretary Manning called on Gov. Hill at the Capitol to-day and spent some time with him in private conversation. He will probably return to Washington on Saturday.
The Women's Home Missionary Society held its first all-day meeting in New-York yesterday at the Washington-Square Methodist Episcopal Church.

The steamers Sorrento, from Hamburg, and Dorset, from Bristol, which arrived here yesterday, both encountered heavy weather during the voyage, but were brought through without damage. Oil bags were hung from the bow of the Sorrento on Feb. 7 and 8, when a terrific storm was raging, and that method of securing safety for storm-tossed vessels has gained another advocate.
The furniture and effects of Falmouth House, Newmarket, the residence of the late Fred Archer, were yesterday offered to public auction by Mr. George Hone, of Cheltenham.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 17.--The American Publishers' Convention is again in session here today and will continue until to-morrow. To-day rules to govern the organization and various matters of interest to publishers are being considered.
BOSTON, Feb. 17.--The resignation of the Hon. E.R. Hoar as President of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, was tendered and accepted at a special meeting of the board to-day.

The liveliest place in yachting circles just now is the little screw dock at the foot of Market-street, where the schooner Dauntless in fitting for her race across the ocean with the Coronet. She is surrounded every day by a crowd of people who intently study her rigging and hull.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--The trunk of a human body, minus head, legs, and arms, was found in Mann's Pond, near Eddington, Bucks County, on the Bristol and Philadelphia turnpike, this morning.
The sale of Mr. Charles F. Hazeltine's collection of paintings was finished last evening at Moore's gallery, on Fifth-avenue. The bidding was dull, and few people were present.

NAVASOTA, Texas, Feb. 17.--Word has just reached here from Dodias that Deputy Sheriff Upchurch was shot by Jim Richards, a negro, Monday. Upchurch had Richards under arrest, and the latter, watching his opportunity, jerked Upchurch's pistol out of its scabbard and inflicted the fatal wound. About sundown Monday evening over 75 masked men, armed to the teeth, took Richards from the custody of the guards and swung him to a neighboring tree.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 17.--There died in this city suddenly this morning Mrs. Mary Amelia, wife of Arthur Ambrose Maginnis, and eldest daughter of the late William M. Tweed, of New-York, aged 36 years.
PITTSBURG, Feb. 17.--A remarkable faith cure was reported from Banksville, a mining town two miles southwest of this city, to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 17.--What was "John O'Brien's Greatest Ten-cent Show on Earth" last Summer was sold at auction to-day at Adam Forepaugh's Winter circus headquarters, Lehigh-avenue and Edgeworth-street.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 17.--Rumors have been in circulation here for several days affecting the integrity of Judge Thomas M. Joseph, for several years Treasurer of the Grand Lodge of Odd Fellows of this State.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 17.--A letter has been received in this city from Mr. M.H. Chase, one of the Portland party of Sinaloa colonists. It was written on Jan. 9, and was addressed to Mr. Chase's brother.

George Tallcot, a wealthy patent medicine dealer, lives with his family in a big double frame house at No. 439 First-street, near Seventh-avenue, Brooklyn. In the house with him live Mrs. Tallcot, an invalid about 60 years of age. The nurse, Mrs. Kate Booth, a respectablelooking woman about 40 years of age, sleeps with Mrs. Tallcot.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 17.--The rejoicings of the Republicans over their brilliant successes yesterday in organizing and controlling the joint meeting have been short-lived. They have given way to-day to a sadness that is almost despondency. The victories to-day have all been with Mr. Abbett, and of the most important character at that.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 17.--The Boston and Maine bill to allow the purchase of certain other railroads, has not yet been reported from the Railway Committee. It will not be for some time. Some members of the committee think they see things about it which are not as they should be, and have decided to give another hearing on the bill on Thursday of next week. COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 17.--Cicero Randall fired at Henry Cox, of the Salvation Army, in Greenville, S.C., this morning. The ball struck Cox in the side, hitting one of the official papers of the army, which stayed its course, saving, the man's life. The "army" is making great capital out of the affair, and preacher after preacher is alluding to it as evidence of providential connection with the army.

NEWARK, Ohio, Feb. 17.--It has just been discovered that Sister Genevieve, the Superior of the convent attached to St. Francis de Sales, of that city, has left the institution and gone to her friends. The causes are said to be disagreement and dissatisfaction. She has been a nun for 20 years. Her real name is Mary Hewitt, and she is supposed to be in Chillicothe.

Coburn. The former sum is to be applied to the payment of the State debt, and the State Treasurer will issue an unnegotiable registered interest-bearing bond for the amount to run 30 years.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 17.--The schooner Ocean King, engaged in fishing, has been lost on the Banks. The crew were rescued by a Portland schooner and landed there. The Ocean King was insured for $5,000. She was of 78 tons.

Harry D. McTighe, Willie Teed, and Eugene Gretsinger, the three little choir boys of the Garden City Cathedral who were drowned on Sunday last, were buried yesterday afternoon from St. Luke's Church, on Clintonavenue, near Fulton-street.

SUAKIN, Feb. 17.--Advices from Massowah say that 800 Italian troops, with Gatling guns, landed there on the 15th inst., and that 2,000 more men were expected.

LAVANT, Ontario, Feb. 17.--Five men, named respectively John Benton, Thomas woodruff, Julius Bagot, William Carver, and James MaCormack, were killed to-day and two others seriously injured at the Wilbur Mines by a fall of earth from the roof.

It is stated that one of the swift ocean steamers recently cut the sea serpent in half. This statement, while new, is obviously untrue in respect of time. The sea serpent was not cut up recently, but a long time ago.

BOSTON, Feb. 17.--The Cambridge Road opened the branch line to Watertown to-day and ran cars to Harvard-square up to a late hour this evening. The attacks of the hoodlums were repeated during the evening, several cars having windows smashed by volleys of stones from behind fences at the more secluded portions of the route traversed.

Police Commissioner McClave recently wrote to the Hon. Everett P. Wheeler, Chairman of the Civil service Advisory Board, asking for his construction of Civil Service Regulation No. 53, which provides that to enter a competitive examination for promotion a man must have a certificate from the Police Board that his efficiency and conduct during his service have been "in all respects satisfactory."

PARIS, Feb. 17.--The Matin says: "The Vatican has been informed that Prince Bismarck a sure of a majority in the new Reichstag." The paper adds that when the Pope received this information he replied that it afforded him happiness to know that such a result would be due to his assistance. The Matin states that his Holiness now says peace is assured.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 17.--John W. Norton, manager of the Grand Opera House and Olympic Theatre of this city, and lessee of the Chicago Opera House, is at death's door, and his physician announces that he will die before morning.

The places that have known Tom Gould will know him no more for the present. The climate of this city became too severe for him some days ago. His friends have heard many times lately that his health was declining.
ERIE, Penn., Feb. 17.--Political circles are greatly agitated this evening over the outcome of the recent Mayoralty contest.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 17.--An unexpected turn was taken by the Senate this morning when the bill which had been passed by the lower house "to prohibit the sale of intoxicating liquors and drinks within the State" came up for its passage.

BRADFORD, Penn., Feb. 17.--The compound works of A. Dean, at Eldred, blew up at 4:30 to-day. The works manufactures a species of dynamite.
The twelfth annual Charity Ball in aid of the Smith Infirmary on Staten Island was given last evening in the German Club Room at Stapleton.

Public indignation over the attempt in the Assembly on Tuesday to saddle with an amendment the princely trust left by Samuel J. Tilden to found in this city the greatest public library in the world was sharpened and intensified by the narrative in yesterday's TIMES.
LIVERPOOL, Feb. 17.--The steamship Great Eastern was sold at auction here to-day for $130,000.

LONDON, Feb. 17.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Lewis L. Dillwyn, Liberal, moved to adjourn the debate on the address in reply to the Queen's speech for the purpose of discussing irregularities in the conspiracy trial at Dublin by which the interests of certain members of the House were prejudiced.
There is nothing surprising in the announcement that the district messengers have formed a trades union of their own and propose to affiliate themselves upon the Knights of Labor.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The jury in the smith case, after deliberating 22 hours, returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the second degree, the penalty for which is lite imprisonment.
The kirmess at Orange, N.J., closed last evening with a crowded house. Aisles and lobbies were filled, and many were unable to gain admission.

The will of S. Foster Dewey, which was hastily written on the back of a sheet of blue note paper half an hour before he died on Tuesday morning, was admitted for probate yesterday. The handwriting is large and bold, but shows signs of nervousness in the writer. For brevity it is a model:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 17.--City Assessor James B. Larkin, brother-in-law of Bartley Campbell, the insane playwriter, has just returned home from a visit to the institution at Middletown, N.J., in which Mr. Campbell is confined. He speaks most encouragingly of Mr. Campbell.

ALBANY, Feb. 17.--The erection of monuments on the historic field of Gettysburg to mark the spots occupied by the New-York regiments is a subject upon which the Legislature will be called upon to act. It will doubtless be of interest to every veteran in the State. A commission to investigate the matter was appointed a year ago under an act passed by Senator Raines.
JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 17.--The funeral of Bishop William Mercer Green took place at 1 o'clock this afternoon from St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 17.--Gov. Lounsbury nominated to-day Col. A.H. Fenn, of Winsted, to be Judge of the Superior Court for eight years, to succeed Judge Beardslee, whose nomination to the Supreme Bench was confirmed by the House this morning in concurrence with the action of the Senate yesterday.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 17.--Gov. Gordon, Mayor Cooper, the Hon. Evan P. Howell, and the members of the Board of Trade, tendered Mr. H.I. Kimball, of New-York, a banquet in the Kimball House last night. It was the most notable social and business event of the year.
The police of the First Precinct kept "one eye" on Mahoney Co.'s pool room at No. 56 New-street yesterday and blocked their business.

The latest news from the Southwest is that the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe has bought the Denver and New-Orleans Road, under the name of the Denver, Texas and Gulf, and has also purchased, or is in hot negotiation for, the Texas, Santa Fe and Northern, thus endeavoring to cover the entire Territory of NewMexico.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 17.--Daniel J. Campail, of Detroit, the promoter of the movement to establish a new American trotting association, states in an interview, that the arrangements for the new organization are progressing nicely.

ATLANTA, Gla., Feb.17.--Joe Smith, the Decatur sexton, who was found guilty some time ago of robbing the graves in his care, was buried to-day by the Atlanta Medical College, which he had served. Before dying he willed his body to the college for dissection, but the doctors declined to make that use of it, and buried him in West View.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 17.--The Labor Convention, which is to assemble next Tuesday, is now the absorbing topic in all political circles.
John Pede, a negro, who was found sick with smallpox at his residence, No. 137 West Thirty-third-street, on Wednesday, was removed to the Riverside Hospital on North Brother Island late that night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--When Mr. Pruden, the President's messenger to the Senate, brings nominations to the Capitol from the White House he alway submits to the press a manifold list of the names of persons nominated and the offices they are chosen to fill.
There was a large crowd in attendance at the pool tournament in Fifth-Avenue Music Hall yesterday afternoon and last evening. The first game was between Balbo and King.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17.--It is semiofficially stated that the relations between Austria and Russia are so much improved that it is no longer expected that Austria would make a Russian occupation of Bulgaria a casus belli.
The fourth public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society's current season took place yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

It was a big family party that occupied the banquet room at Delmonico's last night. The fact that the menus made the formidable announcement that Universistatis Brunensis Sodalitas was dining proved nothing.

MINDEN, La., Feb. 18.--Late yesterday afternoon the 4-year-old son of G.L.P. Wren was decoyed into the woods and killed by Jim Cornelius, colored, aged 14 years. Cornelius broke the child's skull with a pine knot. The cause of the crime is unknown. The murderer has been placed in jail.

"Lorraine," which is to be produced by Col. McCaull's company at the Star Theatre a week from Monday, is meeting with remarkable success in Boston, in spite of the liveliest kind of opposition. Entire new scenery will be used at the Star, and that for the first act, which includes a practical waterfall and a charmine set of Autumn scenery, will be as handsome as anything seen at city theatres in years.
Steamship Tallahassee, Fisher, Savannah, 3 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Henry Yonge, Jr. Steamship Amicitia, (Norw.,) Reimers, Baracoa 6 ds., with fruit to H. Dumois.

William C. Rogers, wholesale dealer in liquors at No. 510 Broadway, made an assignment yesterday to Joseph Shannon, giving preferences of $3,250.

A circular signed by Nathaniel Jay Rice, Chairman of the Legislative Committee, NewYork State Division Travelers' Protective Association, has been sent to the members of Congress representing this State, urging the passage of the James Commercial Travelers bill before the session closes.
The most ridiculous strike recorded yet occurred Thursday at J.M.O. Martin Sons' brush factory, No. 107 Fulton-street.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 18.--It is semi officially stated that in Russian Government circles the conviction is gaining ground that war between France and Germany is inevitable.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 18.--Charles D. Clark, of this city, Administrator of Lieut. Kislingbury, is endeavoring to arouse opposition to the confirmation by the Senate of Capt. A.W. Greely to be Chief of the Signal Service. The reason given is Capt. Greely's reported ill-treatment of Lieut. Kislingbury in the arctic regions.

LONDON, Feb. 18.--An explosion has occurred in the Catch Colliery in the Rhondda Valley. There are 52 men entombed in the mine. Cries oan be heard at the mouth of the shaft, and it is hoped that the men will be saved. The mouth of the pit is surrounded by the relatives of the miners, and the scene is heartrending.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 18.--A strike at the Junction Iron Works, Mingo, Ohio, threatens to cause serious trouble between the Knights of Labor and the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 18.--Judgment given to-day in the case of Thomas Blackstone, who robbed the National Bank of Portland, Me., of $80,000, refuses the extradition of the prisoner on the ground that the offense is not forgery under the common law, but only embezzlement. The prisoner was released.
The special Assembly committee appointed to investigate the causes of the recent strike and the advance in the price of coal met again at the City Hall yesterday and concluded its inquiry.

ERIE, Feb. 18.--The Erie County Board of Auditors creator a sensation to-day in official circles by exposing irregularities in the affairs of the Erie County Poor Directors to the extent of $10,000. The money has been expended in excess of lawful salaries, in machinery unlawfully sold to the county by a member of the board, and in the purchase of a farm at a high figure and for which they had no legal sanction.
SHARPE, Ky., Feb. 18.--The discovery of a large cave by two young men while engaged in preparing a piece of new land for a crop is the latest excitement here.

The testimony in the trial of Capt. Edward Unger for the murder of Bohle was all given yesterday, and at 4:30 P.M. the case was given to the jury. At 11:30 o'clock it had not agreed and was locked up for the night.
The supporters of this year's River and Harbor bill suppressed debate upon it in the House by a parliamentary trick. It was passed as reported by the committee.
When the dog days come again there will be a huge swimming bath and a lot of other watery luxuries in the basement of the Produce Exchange Building.
PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 18.--There is a hitch reported in the settlement of matters between the heirs of Philander Coburn and those of Abner, ex-Governor of Maine.
PORT ADELAIDE, Feb. 18.--The wheat crop of South Australia shows a surplus of 175,000 tons.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Feb. 18.--While the north-bound express train on the Northern Central Railway was approaching this city at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, E.E. Hoopes, of the Wilmington News, was awakened in his berth by smoke which filled the coach.

ALBANY, Feb. 18.--Woman was the subject of much discussion in the Assembly to-day and devotion to her cause led to an exhibition of one of those parliamentary sleight of hand performances for which Speaker Husted is somewhat famous and by comparison with which the feats of Heller and Herrmann sink to a very common level.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 18.--Late last night people living on Water-street saw a man topple from the railroad bridge which crosses over the street and fall a distance of 50 feet. The man was picked up, and was found to be a German named George Pleitner. His leg was broken and his ribs crushed. The doctors do not think he can live.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 18.--Three pickpockets arrested last evening were arraigned today and gave their names as G.P. Wilcox, C.L. McElroy, and Jack Harper, all claiming to come from Montreal.

READING, Penn., Feb. 18.--Mahlon Wolf, aged 17, lost his life on the Reading Railroad, near Shoemakersville, last evening. He with a companion attempted to board a south-bound coal train to a neighboring village. Wolf was not missed until his friend reached his destination. This morning the lad was found lying dead on the tracks near the station his head having been crushed to a jelly by the car wheels.
Longshoremen's Union No. 2 has formally admitted that it would be unwise to refuse to work on piers where non-union men were employed, as that would only prolong the sufferings of the union men.

ASSINABOINE, Montana, Feb. 18.--For the last six weeks unprecedented snows, blizzards, and gales of wind have ranged through the Northern and Western portions of Montana, until man's only safety depended upon his remaining within the house, and even the oldest settlers acknowledged that the Winter is the most severe of any for the last 10 years.
OTTAWA, Feb. 18.--It is almost certain that Spring will see a line of steamships running regularly between British Columbia and the Australian colonies.
Some 600 members of the Benevolent Order of Buffaloes, including members of the order in this city and a large number from Philadelphia, visited the Wild West show last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18.--Mrs. Hettie Green, of Georgia, came to Philadelphia from New-York today and deposited $1,000,000 in Philadelphia and Reading Railroad securities under the requirements of the reorganization plan.
There were four series played in the pool tournament yesterday. In the afternoon little Frey easily defeated Charles Manning, winning by a score of 11 to 7.
In to-day's issue of the Medical Record an interesting paper appears by Samuel Sexton, M.D., on "Injury of the Ear Caused by the Blast of a Bursting Shell."

The Hobart Alumni, to the number of about 50, had their sixth annual dinner at Clark's on Thursday evening.

Two men who acted suspiciously and endeavored to avoid observation were told to halt at One Hundred and Seventy-second-street and Third-avenue at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning by two officers of the Tremont police squad.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 18.--This was the last day of Brassfield Co.'s great combination sale of trotters. The number sold in the four days was 252. The amount realized was $89,190, an average of $354. This was considered a good sale. To-day 64 head were sold for $12,560.

DURANGO, Col., Feb. 18.--The Jicarilla Apaches have become dissatisfied, and are leaving their reservation in Southern New-Mexico in large numbers for their old reservation in Southwestern Colorado. Their agent seems to have little or no influence in the matter, and two companies of cavalry have been ordered from Fort Lewis to Amargo to intercept them. Trouble between the Indians and settlers is anticipated.
The Legislature has adjourned until next Wednesday evening. It is given out that the Excise Committee of the Assembly will give no further consideration to the High License bill before Thursday.
A complaint has been filed in the County Clerk's office by Prescott Hall Butler, who is about to bring suit in the Supreme Court to set aside the will of Cornelia M. Stewart, widow of A.T. Stewart.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18.--A letter received from McKeesport contains a challenge from Albert Hamm and John Teemer to row Wallace Ross and George W. Lee a three-mile double scull race. the latter crew to have five seconds' start, for $500 or $1,000 a side. Hanlan and mate are also challenged to race at an even start for the same amount.
CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--A movement toward consolidating the Stock Exchange and the Open Board of Trade into one institution for trading in stocks is on foot and has already made good progress.
Of course Tom Gould, the keeper of the resort on West Thirty-first street known as the Sans Souci, did not appear for examination before Justice streng, in Hoboken, yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--Mrs. Logan, accompanied by her son, arrived in this city to day and will be the guest of Col. R.S. Tuthill during her 10 or 12 days' visit to Chicago.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 18.--The day has been a bad one for Mary Anderson. When THE TIMES'S reporter saw her to-night her temperature and respiration indicated that her condition was more critical than at any time since the operation last Sunday.

The Enrollment Board of the Eleventh District Republicans met again last evening to consider the challenges made against several men who had enrolled recently and who, it was claimed, had no right to do so.

In Commissioner Fink's office yesterday a meeting of the Executive Committee of the trunk lines and of representatives of the principal traffic associations was held to discuss the provisions of the inter-State commerce law and the interpretation to be put upon them.
One vast storm cloud in a murky canopy overhung the city yesterday and spouted down fountains of warm rain in drenching streams and rebounding sprays.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 18.--A largely attended meeting of merchants and other business men was held at the Merchants' Exchange to-day to take action in regard to the proposed Tennessee Midland Railroad.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 18.--George W. Carter, engaged in the pianoforte business, has been arrested on a charge of misusing to the extent of $1,500 trust funds of a small estate of which he is Administrator.

At a convention of workingmen at Jersey City last night a Labor Party was formed in opposition to the existing political parties. Four hundred delegates were present. Labor candidates will be put in the field for the April election.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 18.--At about noon to-day people in the vicinity of the Courtstreet bridge, near the centre of the city, were startled by a crash, and people were seen running from both entrances to the bridge.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 18.--A cloud portending a railway rate war has arisen in the horizon here and threatens to burst soon.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18.--The works of the Goodyear Metallic Rubber Shoe Company, at Naugatuck, will close down to-morrow for an indefinite period. They are reported to have $1,500,000 worth of finished stock on hand.

BOSTON, Feb. 18--To-day marked the beginning of the end of the South Boston strike. Shortly after noon an old conductor walked into the superintendent's office, asked for a car, and said he was ready to go to work.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 18.--There was an interesting incident at the big banquet of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Association last night which all the papers to-day handle very gingerly.
Two reports as to the best means of indexing deeds, mortgages, and other instruments relating to property were read to the Bar Association last night.

HARTFORD, Feb. 18.--The Committee on Railroads to-day reported favorably a substitute bill to regulate the running of Sunday trains. It provides that no railroad company shall run any train on Sunday, except from necessity or mercy.

The dispute between the Atlantic-Avenue and Broadway Railroad Companies as to the right to build a road along Central-avenue, in Brooklyn, became more involved than ever yesterday, and the police came near arresting Commissioner Conner.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 18.--Henry Watterson is in the city, and was last evening dined by a number of friends at the Queen City Club. To an Enquirer reporter who remarked that the Courier-Journal continued to rap President Cleveland hard, Mr. Watterson replied: "Yes, but it is only a family chastisement."

WILMINGTON, N.C., Feb. 18.--Spirits of Turpentine firm at 36c.; Resin firm; Strained, 75c.; good Strained, 80c. Tar steady at $1.05. Crude Turpentine firm; Hard, $1; Yellow Dip and Virgin, $1.90. Corn steady; prime White, 53c.; Mixed, 51c.

The parishioners of St. Stephen's who sympathize with Dr. McGlynn held their accustomed enthusiastic and crowded weekly meeting in the International Assembly Rooms, on East Twentyseventh-street, last evening.

FREDERICKTOWN, Mo., Feb. 18.--A very heavy shock of earthquake passed through this section of the country last night. The force was severe enough to overturn furniture and displace plastering on the walls.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18.--The General Passengers Agents of the Southwestern, Western, and Northwestern Passenger Associations, after having been in session since last Monday formulating rules for carrying on their business under the inter-State commerce law, concluded their labors to-day.
The reputation of Prof. George W. Maynard, the mining engineer, has been for many years widespread among scientists.
PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 18.--Charles Gifford, the fireman so severely injured last September, has sued the Maine Central for $10,000 damages claiming entire disability as the result of his injuries.
The storm was responsible for many vacant chairs in the large banquet hall at the Hotel Brunswick last night.

In the Chancellor's Court, at Newark, yesterday, the will of Wilson Read, of Colt's Neck, was submitted for construction. Some years ago Henry Patterson, brother of the Keeper of the State Prison, married a daughter of Wilson Read, a wealthy resident of Colt's Neck.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 18.--Arrests of those indicted by the Grand Jury recently in session for frauds committed at the election in this city on Nov. 2 last still continue.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18.--The municipal authorities of Stratford-on-Avon have just decided upon the site and the design for a drinking fountain, which is the jubilee gift of Mr. George W. Childs to Shakespeare's town.

A test of a new hot-water heater for use in railroad cars was made at the Forty-fifthstreet bridge, north of the Grand Central Railway Station, at noon yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 18.--The North German Gazette, Prince Bismarck's organ, says that the Reichstag will be again dissolved unless the Government secures a majority in the coming elections.
ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 18.--The long-expected break between Gov. Gordon and the convict lessees has taken place, and henceforth the Governor may be relied upon as the firm opponent of the lease system.
LONDON, Feb. 18.--The London papers fully approve the action of the Speaker of the House of Commons in closing the "tiresome and obstructive debate" on the address in reply to the Queen's speech.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 15.--What does it cost to make a ton of pig iron in Alabama? There is the question that has much, if not everything, to do with the lasting prosperity of this iron-making section of the new South.
The inquest in the case of Mrs. Annie Jarkowski, the young woman who recently died from the effects of vitrol thrown in her face, was held yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 18.--The Franklin Milling Company, in which Attorney-General Koehler has an interest, has assigned. The Assignee's bond is $22,000. Assets and liabilities are said to be about equal.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Feb. 18.--Charles O. Walton and John A. Snowden, champion fivemile skater of America, met in the Casino rink to-night and skated a five-mile race for a diamond belt and championship, a large number of spectators being present.

The officials in the County Clerk's office were greatly surprised yesterday by the story published exclusively in THE TIMES of erasures and other changes in books and documents in the case of the judgments against the firm of Mayer Brothers.
The ante-Lent festivities of Orange. N. J., came to a close last night with a grand ball given in the Music Hall by the Orange Club, for which 700 invitations were issued.
By direction of the Park Board Montgomery A. Kellogg, constructing engineer of the department, has prepared plans and estimates for some needed improvements in the Park system.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 18.--Petroleum dull, but steady; National Transit Certificates opened at 60 ; closed at 60 ; highest, 61 ; lowest, 60 5/8.
UTICA, N.Y., Feb. 18.--The State Convention of the Young Men's Christian Association, which is being held in this city, was attended by upward of 500 delegates this forenoon.

Milton B. Sweet, in the Winter of 1883, became enamored of Bridget Dalton, a pretty waiter girl employed in his restaurant iu Fulton-street, and in July, 1884, one month after a child had been born to them, married her. At his request she changed her first name to Gabrielle.
Engineer Martin, of the Brooklyn Bridge, was in Albany Thursday urging the passage of a bill allowing the bridge authorities to further extend the railroad track across Centre-street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18.--The only definite information obtained to-night in regard to the vacant Cabinet office is that the President has not yet offered it to anybody and that he has not decided whether it will be necessary to take a Western rather than an Eastern man as Mr. Manning's successor.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 18.--The Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company has equipped two passenger trains between Chicago and Milwaukee with apparatus for heating by steam from locomotives. The experiment has so far proved successful, but it has not yet had the test of severe weather. The company is also building an iron heating car to carry a boiler for generating steam for heating the train and to run next to the engine.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Feb. 18.--The money appropriated for repairing the roads in this township is exhausted, but the road from the county iron bridge to Wreck Pond is still in an unsafe condition.
Only two weeks have passed since the appalling accident at White River occurred, but in that time great progress has been made toward the substitution of steam heat for stove heat in railway cars.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 18.--The Republicans voted for the Hon. John A. Hutchinson to-day, he receiving 38 votes to 37 for Camden, Judge Alphens A. Haymond was honored by the kickers with 11 votes, and D.D. Johnson, Okey Johnson, and A.W. Campbell, one of the proprietors of the Wheeling Intelligencer, received 1 vote each.
LONDON, Feb. 18.--The steamship Entella, (Ital.,) Capt. Condu, sld. from Palermo for New-York on Feb. 12.

Cameron against the Tribune Association, which was on trial before Judge Ingraham and a jury in the Supreme Court, Part IV., from Monday morning until last night, a verdict was rendered in favor of the plaintiff for $9,000 and costs and an extra allowance of $250 for counsel fees was accorded him.
ELMIRA, Feb. 18.--Some years ago Gideon Pratt, a prominent business man of this city, removed to Colorado and engaged in farming.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 19.--The committee appointed by the House to investigate the prosecution of David Fotheringham, the Adams Express messenger, will commence their inquiry next Monday at the Southern Hotel in St. Louis. The committee is composed of five members and is empowered to summon witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The President sent two messages to the Senate to-day vetoing acts granting pensions to Charlotte O'Neal and John Reed, Sr. The first named bill proposed to grant a pension to the widow of Richard O'Neal, late Colonel of the Twenty-sixth Regiment Indiana Volunteers.

After nightfall wild ducks infest the grain fields in the vicinity of Putah Creek, Alameda County, in great numbers. They have nearly devastated 400 acres on the Curry farm. Henry Goodman, the foreman, after experimenting with numerous devices to frighten them away, at last hit upon the project of burning candles during the night. These are protected from the wind by sacks, and the fields are kept comparatively clear of ducks.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19.--The Morning session of the Young Men's Christian Association was devoted to a discussion of special topics by delegates from the various colleges.

ELMIRA, Feb. 19.--The jury in the case of Van Brunt, charged with the murder of Will Roy, went out at 3:15 P.M., and returned at 6:30 P.M. with a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree. The court sentenced him to be hanged on Friday, the 15th day of April next, between the hours of 10 and 4 o'clock.

BERLIN, Feb. 19.--There is a pause in the intensity of the electoral conflict pending Monday's polling. The committees everywhere continue active, but there is a momentary lull in the public agitation. There is also a significant subsidence in war rumors.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 19.--The condition of Mary Anderson, who was shot, it is supposed, by her lover, Barclay Peak, has been very alarming today. Her entire right side is paralyzed from the effect of the wound, the result of an effusion of blood on the brain, and she is unconscious the most of the time. It is thought by her physician that she cannot live until morning.

NEENAH, Wis., Feb. 19.--A freight train on the Wisconsin Central struck a broken rail near Medila Junction, just west of this city, this morning, throwing 18 cars off the track. All passenger trains doing either way will be unable to get by until late this afternoon.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 19.--Proposals were received to-day at the Mayor's office for the five-hundred-thousand-dollar loan for the construction of public parks. The loan was awarded to E. Rollins, Morse Co., who will take the whole sum at $1.1152 for each $100.

Harry Miner has been negotiating for a new theatre up in Harlem and may get it yet. He wants the Third-Avenue Railroad Company to tear down the present Mount Morris Theatre and put up a new one in its place, built according to plans of his own. If this is done he promises to take a ten years' lease of the house, running it as a combination theatre.
Much anxiety is felt in commercial and official circles owing to the attitude of the Chinese authorities in the matter of opium duties.
The Park Board proposes to make an effort this Summer to clear away the cesspools beyond the Harlem and make that part of the city a healthy place for residence.

Among the first of the passengers who tripped with more or less lightness down the gangplank of the Cunarder Etruria yesterday morning was a gentleman well known to New-Yorkers--ex-Judge Edwards Pierrepont. If the ex-Judge had suffered from the tossings of the Atlantic--the great non-respecter of persons-- he did not show it.

ERIE, Penn., Feb. 19.--A syndicate of the bondholders of the Shenango and Allegheny Valley and the West Pennsylvania Railroad has organized, with a capital of several millions, and has purchased the rights and franchises of the Ohio River and Lake Erie Railroad from Miss Sarah Reed, the owner.

One of the Indians in Buffalo Bill's troops was missing from his usual place in the "Wild West" show yesterday. It was Mazza or, in English, Iron, a young Sioux, who received news yesterday from his home at Pine Ridge, Dakota, that his brother had died. Accordingly Mazza mourned after the fashion of his people.
Edward Unger's case has been passed upon by the jury, and the slayer of August Bonle will probably pass the remainder of his life in safe custody at Sing Sing Prison.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--East-bound freight rates are much demoralized, and there is but little chance that the situation will improve before the opening of navigation.
A morning paper stated yesterday that the night signal of the New-York Yacht Club, a green-red-green Coston light, was all wrong.

"Ruddigore" will be produced at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre to-morrow evening, according to previous announcement. The company, 58 in number, with Mr. D'Oyly Carte's representative, Miss Helen Lenoir, arrived yesterday ...
As Rudolph Reese, a, German resident of Pamrapo, was hurrying home about 9 o'clock Friday night he stumbled over the body of a man lying partly in the gutter at Forty-seventhstreet and Avenue C.

BERLIN, Feb. 20.--The authorities forcibly stopped a New Liberal meeting here to-day just as Herr Richter was about to speak. The audience, numbering several thousand persons, afterward marched through the streets cheering for Richter. Many were arrested.

The American Geographical Society will hold a meeting this evening in Chickering Hall, at Eighteenth-street and Fifth-avenue, to listen to a lecture by the Hon. Clarence Pullen, who will speak upon New-Mexico.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 20.--Coroner Lepper, of Seneca County, will file to-morrow his verdict in the case of the Baltimore and Ohio Railway disaster of Jan. 4 near Republic. It is a very long document.

HELENA, Montana, Feb. 20.--The account of the signing of the treaty with the Piegans, at Blackfoot Agency, Feb. 10, has just been received. On the 9th the Indians assembled in council. Mr. Wright, Chairman of the commission, presented the proposition for a reduction of their reservation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 20.--George Tragesser, an iron worker, living in Allegheny City, was assaulted by footpads on the Tenth-street railroad bridge last night and so badly beaten that he died from his injuries this evening. He had only $2 in his possession, which the robbers got. His assailants are unknown. Tragesser was attacked on the same bridge five weeks ago and severly injured.
The appointment of the successor of Mr. MANNING is as important as any the President has been called on to make, hardly excepting the original one to the same position.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 20.--The floods in this State have reached their highest point, and are now everywhere and steadily subsiding. Throughout the entire southern half of the lower peninsula the streams have been swollen to a height seldom if ever reached, and much minor damage has been done in the way of sweeping off dams and bridges.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Feb. 20.--Edson Pease, 50 years old, bald headed, and with white mustache, was locked up in jail in this city last night to await the arrival of an officer to take him to Schuyler County. Pease has many aliases, including Charles Pease, Charles B. Thompson, and R.D. Norton.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 20.--When Lewis Applegate, Treasurer of the New-Brunswick Fire Insurance Company, was found to be short in his accounts a little less than a year ago ...
The National Opera Company arrived at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon by special train from Boston, followed by a special freight train bearing the scenery, costumes, properties, , of seven operas.
The contemplated complimentary benefit to Lester Wallack, the idea of which was originated by Mr. Augustin Daly, has not been given up, although the testimonial has been necessarily postponed.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 20.--At the meeting meeting of the State Board of Education a proposition to loan the money of the State school funds to municipalities for the erection of school buildings was very fully considered.

WARSAW, N.Y., Feb. 20.--This afternoon at about 3:30 o'clock William Nelson, a middle-aged, wealthy farmer, who resides on a fine farm one mile south of Attica, Wyoming County, had a Sunday afternoon quarrel with his wife.

Gen. Simon Cameron reached here from the Bermudas yesterday, and is now at the FifthAvenue Hotel. The General left this city for the tropics on Jan. 27, accompanied by "Larry" Jerome and Col. Duffy, of Marietta, Penn., both of whom have taken an annual trip to some Southern resort for years past.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Feb. 20.--The Mormon press here displays great hilarity over the passage of the Edmunds-Tucker bill, saying that it will amount to nothing.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20.--A capias to the amount of $18,000 has been taken out against Milton Pennington, merchant and manufacturers' agent, but he has escaped arrest and is believed to have fled to the States.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Feb. 20.--The following notice has been served on the soft coal miners in the Clearfield region, and is signed by the President, Secretary, and Executice Committee of the Arbitration Board:

Michael J. Kelly, the ball player, for whom the Boston Club paid the Chicagos $10,000, was seen yesterday by a TIMES reporter. He appeared to be well pleased at his change of base, and said he would play the best game of his life during the coming season.

In the preface the author states that "we are several thousand years too late to say anything new about morality," but never can we remind people too frequently what is decent conduct, and how we may make the world and ourselves happy by means of good manners.

ALBANY, Feb. 20.--One of the interesting pieces of gossip in political circles is that Gov. Hill has acquired stock in a New-York newspaper. Ever since he drew the Elmira Gazette out of the gift bag, a quarter of a century ago, the Governor has firmly believed that the columns of a newspaper are the best agency in the world for promoting political ambitions.
A Norwalk lady, who was married to a gentleman from Wisconsin a few months ago, tells, in a letter to her friends here, of her introduction to Western society.
CHICAGO, Feb. 20.--The meeting of Bakers Union No. 10 at Co-operative Hall, North Clarkstreet, ended in a bloody fight last evening.
Prof. O.R. Gleason, the horse tamer, will begin a six nights' engagement in MadisonSquare Garden next Thursday.

ALBANY, Feb. 20.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued a certificate to the People's Bank of Haverstraw authorizing it to transact business under the provisions of the State banking laws, with a paid up capital of $50,000.

Repentance of that sort which leads to conversion was Mr. Beeches's theme at Plymouth Church yesterday morning.

Richard Prindibell went to his home, at No. 107 Washington-street, Saturday night, with a friend, whom he had asked to sleep with him. Prindibell's step-daughter, Maria Bynne, objected to this invasion.

Judge Blodgett's preliminary decision in the libel suit of one A.H. Walker against the Tribune is highly valuable as showing the legal responsibilities that attach to the use of the term "crank" in public discussion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--The probable course of legislation by the Senate for the coming week, and in fact the remainder of the session, may best be judged by reference to the arrangement agreed upon by the caucus committees of both sides and ratified by the two caucuses of last week.
The twenty-third anniversary of its organization was celebrated yesterday by the Janes Methodist Episcopal Church in West Forty-fourth-street. Three services mere held during the day.

The pigeon shooters will have a lively time this week. Every day there is a contest of some sort. The first annual tournament of the Middlesex Gun Club will begin to-day at Dunellen, N.J., and will last until Friday.

What a queer old farrago is this memoir, written nearly 50 years ago! How carefully the author shields her heroine from every possible fault! Mrs. Cornwell Barron-Wilson is a writer of feminine biographies who understands her business thoroughly.
A strange case of absent-mindedness came to light yesterday in the office of the Recorder of Deeds.

Late Saturday night a rumor was circulated that an attempt had been made to shoot Police Justice Henry Murray. Some even said that the Justice had been killed. He was seen yesterday and said there was absolutely no foundation for the report.

The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher has decided to publish an autobiography. For some time many of his friends have expressed a desire that he should write such a book, knowing that, outside of the private life of the Pastor himself, ...
Changes, which will be so great as to practically amount to rebuilding, will be made in the old Mount Morris Theatre, in Harlem, by the Third-Avenue Railroad Company, which owns the property.
When two Scotch ministers advised their flocks to take advantage of any fine Sunday last Autumn to get their harvest in I thought we should hear something more about it.

POUGHBEEPSIE, Feb. 20.--The shocking murder of Mrs. O'Neil continues to be the main topic of conversation. Facts revealed since last night show almost to a certainty that her sonin-law, John Waters, committed the deed out of revenge, because Mrs. O'Neil, his wife's mother, took a sewing machine from Waters's boarding place, where he had left it for security for his board.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 20.--The powerful hand of the Standard Oil Company has been suddenly called upon to assert itself in pending legislation in Harrisburg to prevent the lessening of enormous profits on the pipe line and storage privileges which it enjoys under its monopoly of these interests in the State.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20.--Three of the big Chicago playhouses have done an excellent business during the last week, despite very bad weather and the fact that all had attractions coming into pretty direct competition with each other.
Declarations for the Coney Island Jockey Club Handicap received up to yesterday were few in number.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 20.--Facts have just come to light which give additional interest to the case of attempted resurrection by the prayer of faith of Cora Stickney, the young woman who died on Dec. 1, an account of which appeared in THE TIMES a few days since.

I am glad that the Times has at last discovered that the Emperor of Russia is not a lunatic who shoots his aides-de-camp like partridges. He is--as I have more than once stated --a narrow-minded, well-meaning man, and as despots go, by no means a bad one. His mistake is that ho does not perceive that despotism is out of date. This will very probably cost him his life.

The weather promises of Saturday were not kept yesterday. Relying upon them "Judge" Smith and "Gabe" Case leveled down the rough places in Jerome-avenue, and went to bed Saturday night with a supreme faith that the morning sun would dry out the moisture and make good traveling between Macomb's Dam Bridge and the Judge's.

The wife of a Canadian Judge, who read what Sir C. Tupper said upon the "Trutheries," has called to give me supplemental information about the past and present representatives of her Majesty at Ottawa. Lord Lansdowne, I was told, keeps up a fine show.
The famous Blue Grotto of Capri has given rise to one of the most curious lawsuits which have ever been heard.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--The fact that Speaker Carlisle spent a part of to-day in consultation with the President has revived the talk of his appointment to the office of Secretary of the Treasury, and his friends are inspired with the belief, which the Speaker does not encourage, that he has been offered the place.

The Rev. Dr. I.K. Funk, editor of the Voice, spoke on the "Rev. Dr. Crosby's Logie" at a crowded meeting of the Manhattan Temperance Association, at the Masonic Temple yesterday afternoon. He spoke of high license in Chicago as a delusion and a fraud. "Dr. Crosby," he said, "is making the mistake of his life.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20.--This week's Farmers' Review crop summary says: "Injury to Winter wheat by reason of the recent sleet storms and accompanying cold weather is reported from various portions of Illinois, Indiana, Missouri, and Kansas, but the general situation, as affecting the prospects of Winter wheat, continues to be favorable.
John Geraghty lives at No. 200 West Seventy-eighth street, but late Saturday night he was not there.
Cornelius Adams and Amanda Rooney were married about two weeks ago by a Methodist clergyman in East New-York.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 20.--The railway rate war has been averted by a compromise, which recognizes differential rates between here and New-York. The Lake Shore charges $13, the Pennsylvania $12.50, the Erie and Nickel Plate $12. It is not believed that these differences will be permitted to stand, and, although formally agreed to, the Local Passenger Agents' Association already shows signs of disintegration.
Gov. Hill will be in Brooklyn to-night to review the Twenty-third Regiment. Tomorrow night he will attend the dinner of the Young Men's Democratic Club at the Academy of Music.
The crew of the schooner Mary Bradford, which was wrecked off Bermuda Feb. 14, arrived at this port yesterday on the steamship Trinidad.

LONDON, Feb. 20.--Discount was in fair demand during the past week; three months was quoted at 3 and short at 3. On the Stock Exchange business was extremely inactive, but the tone is improving. Pending the issue of the German elections business is practically suspended.
Some months ago the New-York Tribune made the following declaration in regard to libel suits: "We intend and earnestly strive to avoid libeling anybody.

DUBOIS, Penn., Feb. 20.--John Bortmas, aced 70 years, lives alone in a small house in Oakland Township, Butler County. His neighbors have known for a long time that he kept several hundred dollars secreted in his house, but he would never consent to place it in a place of greater safety.

Though one may not have been an ardent partisan of woman suffrage, yet when he takes note of the sort of people who are shouting loudest with joy over the decision of the Supreme Court of Washington Territory against woman suffrage he will pretty surely be moved to regret that the decision was made.
We don't hear any more about the ice harvest, because all the houses are filled and a full crop has been obtained--over 3,000,000 tons.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 20.--Revenue officers to-day seized the wholesale liquor house of J.S. McCormick, the only concern in the city holding a county permit. McCormick's attorney, J.W. Ginnon of Davenport is here.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Feb. 20.--The schooner S.A. Paine, Capt. Hawes, from Rockland, via Plymouth, for New-York, arrived here to-day. Her Cargo, which is composed of lime, is on fire. The vessel has been sealed up.

The funeral of James W. Foshay, exPresident of the Broadway and Seventh-Avenue Railroad Company, who died somewhat suddenly last Thursday, took place yesterday afternoon from his residence, No. 50 West Fiftieth-street.
ERIE, Penn., Feb. 20.--The old fight between the Pennsylvania Company and the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway Company over their yard rights at Erie was renewed today.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 20.--The Rev. Galbraith Perry, Rector of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, has been directed by Bishop Paret, of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of the State, to cease using incense and not to wear a cope, the robe usually worn in the Roman Catholic Church.
TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 20.--Mr. Corbin, who has been voting for Cortlandt Parker for United States Senator, has been receiving appeals from every part of the State to support Gen. Sewell.
After the Government's neglect of coast defenses for nearly twenty years, some Congressmen seem disposed to go into the subject now with a most extravagant zeal.

BOSTON, Feb. 20.--The most startling feature of the South Boston strike was unearthed to-day. The Post has discovered what appears to have been a concerted plan to destroy both life and property should the horse cars of this line run after dark.
Charles A. Maubury, an actor, and one of the proprietors of "The Wages of Sin" company, was taken suddenly ill at a Newark theatre on Saturday afternoon and could not play in the evening.

The committee appointed by the Central Labor Union to raise money to aid the striking longshoremen reported yesterday at the meeting of that body that the Progressive Mechanics had contributed $15, the Cabinet Makers' Union No. 7, $10, the Brushmakers $25, the tin and sheet iron workers $50, and Typographical Union No. 6 $100.

BOSTON, Feb. 20.--The car troubles in Cambridge developed a good-sized riot to-day, during which Police Officer Skelley was seriously, if not fatally, injured, Officer Mullin badly pounded several other officers bruised and battered, and 10 men arrested and locked up.
St. Petersburg is very gay at present, and rejoicing in a Winter of almost unprecedented mildness.

An unusually large congregation was present at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. The celebrant was the Rev. Joseph N. McMahon, assisted by the Rev. Michael J. Mulhern, the Rev. Edward F. Slattery, and the Rev. James W. Kelly.
There has been introduced in the Illinois Legislature a bill providing that the rent of a telephone in that State shall not exceed $4 a month.

A Bangor commercial traveler, writing from Aroostook County, says that on some roads he passes houses from which no path of any sort can be seen leading to the road, and they have every appearance of not having been broken out this Winter. Paths are seen leading from the houses to the barns.
The Rev. Gawn Campbell, M.D., died yesterday of pneumonia at his residence, No. 422 West Forty-fourth-street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 20.--Papers have been filed in this city in an action brought by Gen. Isaac F. Quinby, City Surveyor of the city of Rochester, against the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company, the counterpart of which is probably wanting in the history of litigation.

The runaway marriage of Miss Fanny Patterson and Augustus Frick is the present absorbing topic in Red Bank, N.J. Miss Patterson is 21 years of age, and is a stanch young temperance woman, while Mr. Frick is manager of the business of M.A. Frick Co., a large wholesale liquor firm.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 17.--It was shown in my last letter that, according to accepted figures and statements from leading furnace owners, pig iron may be made here for about $10.25 per ton, though along with that estimate I chronicled the admission of one ironmaster that his product cost more than that sum, while at least one more big company was at an average expense of over $12.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20.--Zachariah Reynolds, a watchman in the Treasury Department, while making his rounds last night, walked through the open doorway of one of the freight elevatar shafts and fell to the bottom, killing himself instantly. The darkness of the passage in which the elevator is situated prevented his noticing that the doorway was open. He was about 60 years of age, and leaves a wife and family living im Wilmington, Del.

The lock-out at Gardiner Estes's shoe factory, which lasted six weeks, terminated yesterday, when the difficulty between the firm and its employes was adjusted by mutual concessions.

READING, Penn., Feb. 21.--It was discovered to-day that counterfeiters have been at work in this city the past few days. The bogus money consists of a well executed counterfeit silver dollar. The detection was made at the bank where some of the counterfeit coin was brought by depositors.

The marriage of Miss Minnie Spicer Vanderpoel, daughter of Mr. Frederic S. Vanderpoel, to Mr. Henry W.J. Telfair, took place last evening at Trinity Chapel, on West Twenty-fifthstreet. It was an unusually pretty affair, and the church was crowded to its utmost capacity.

FARGO, Dakota, Feb. 21.--The passenger train from the West due at Fargo yesterday morning ran into a freight on a side track 40 miles west. It struck the caboose, throwing that down the embankment on one side and the two engines of the passenger train rolled down the embankment on the other. The engineers and firemen were all badly bruised, but not fatally, and no passengers were hurt. The trains were delayed 10 hours.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 21.--Henry George lectured to-night in the Springer Music Hall to about 3,000 people, who paid an admission fee of 10 cents. He explained his land theories and was listened to attentively.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 21.--The Supreme Court to-day decided the druggist tax cases, involving $500,000, in favor of the State, holding all druggists in Tennessee liable for the retail liquor dealers' tax for the past five years, with interest.

Arthur Ridley, of Ridleys', in Grand-street, has lost a dog. Any man who will find the man who stole the dog and then find Mr. Ridley will also find $50 and also get the dog, thus making a total profit of $55.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 22.--The Rockland County Historical and Forestry Society, an organization embracing the wealthiest and most influential citizens of the county, held its annual meeting in the Universailst church of this place this afternoon.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 22.--Habersham County is just now the scene of unusual commotion caused by the escape of three murderers from the county jail. For several years the county had been in a bad financial condition. The funds were misappropriated, and it seemed as if prisoners when once arrested could not be held.
PROVIDECE, R.I., Feb. 22.--The State Chess Association met in annual meeting today. Gov. Howard's address was full of interest for lovers of the game and of plane for the success of the association.

There are two societies in the upper part of Westchester County for the detection of horse thieves and the recovery of property stolen by them. One is in Peekskill and the other is in the town of Somers.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 22.--The Industrial Labor Conference met here to-day in Music Hall. When the convention was called to order at 1 o'clook by R.S. Heath, of Chicago, there were about 300 delegates present, among whom were 10 ladies.

A very airy Frenchman, whose aristocratic drab melton top coat, brightly blacked shoes, and opera hat suggested the possession of means, left a Yonkers train at the Grand Central Station last night and was battled for by the hackmen outside.

BATH, Me., Feb. 22.--The steamer Winthrop, 1,300 tone, owned by the Maine Steamship Company, and built expressly for the Portland and NewYork route, was launched to-day. She was towed to the New-England Iron Works to receive her machinery. Her length is 192 feet, breadth 38 feet, and depth 23 feet. She will be ready to take her place on the route about June 1.

There have been introduced into the Legislature up to the present date six different bills providing for the holding of a Constitutional Convention, three by Republicans and three by Democrats, but no one of them conforms to the recommendation made by the Governor in his message.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 22.--The Judiciary Committee of the House of Representatives this afternoon heard argument on the Billingsley bill relative to the reduction of rates for the transportation and storage of petroleum.

The students of Manhattan College, at One Hundred and Thirty-first-street and the Boulevard, celebrate Washington's Birthday each year by holding the first of the annual contests for the Byrnes gold medal for oratory. Recitations are delivered, and the criticism is as to elocution and method of delivery.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 22.--The second annual banquet of the Michigan Club, a State organization whose object is to cultivate politics, especially of the Republican sort, and whose headquarters are in this city, took place to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22.--The committee having charge of the Whelen plan of reorganization of the Reading Railroad Company announces this afternoon that the plan has not recevied sufficient assents to carry it into effect. The announcement is also made that although the plan is abandoned an appeal will be taken to the Supreme Court from the Master's report in regard to the priority of liens when it is finally confirmed by the Circuit Court.
ZANZIBAR, Feb. 22.--Henry M. Stanley has arrived here.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 22.--Two Catholic churches and the Unitarian Church were broken into last night by professional burglars, who understood their business well enough to take solid silver and leave plated ware. From the Canadian Catholic Church their booty was valued at $66, and from the Irish Catholic Church $25.
RAHWAY, N.J., Feb. 22.--The Rev. George W. Pendleton died here early this morning. He was well known in the Baptist denomination, and up to within a few months had been in active service.

One hundred of the survivors of the First New-York Mounted Rifles held their ninth reunion and celebrated tho twenty-fifth anniversary of their organization into a regiment at Beethoven Hall last night.
The annual commemorative dinner of the Washington Heights Century Club was held last night in West One Hundred and Fifty-fifthstreet, near St. Nicholas-avenue.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 22.--Respecting the barbarities of the Southern Prison, the report of the committee, it is said, will contain testimony showing a state of affairs the details of which are too dreadful for publication.

BOSTON, Feb. 22.--The most notable wedding of the season occurred to-day, when the nuptials of Herbert Timmins and Miss Catherine Elizabeth Prescott, daughter of William G. Prescott, and granddaughter of William H. Prescott, the historian, were celebrated at Trinity Church.
A Washington's Birthday reception was given yesterday afternoon at the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society's Asylum for Children, Fifty-seventh-street and First avenue.

James H. Corey is President of the Board of Trustees of the village of Whitestone, Long Island, and is ex-officio Chief of Police, but he is not in good odor in the township of Flushing. On Monday he was arrested on complaint of Adolf Otto, a musician, for assault.
PITTSBURG, Feb. 22.--An explosion of natural gas at the Black Diamond Steel Works, late yesterday afternoon, probably fatally burned a workman named James Kerr, and seriously injured five others.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 22.--About a hundred persons, mostly officers of seminaries and colleges, assembled in Suydam Hall Chapel, connected with the Theological Seminary, this afternoon, in response to invitation, and celebrated Washington's Birthday by listening to Prof. Lansing talk on "Mummification." Then they watched him unwrap a mummy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 22.--In the United States Circuit Court, this morning, the case of Theodore W. Thompson, of Illinois against Judge Calvert, of Allen County, came up upon a demurrer by the plaintiff to the response in behalf of Calvert and Allen County.

The Controller of the Currency told some wholesome truths to the merchants at the dinner on Monday evening. The chief of them was that if the national banking system were not in existence to-day, it would hardly be established by the national representatives.

Washington's Birthday will be remembered as a red-letter day in the history of the theatres of New-York. Afternoon and evening performances were given at every theatre in the city, and at both performances the theatres were crowded to their utmost capacity.

On May 12, 1886, it was killed by a veto, to the great disappointment of thousands of consumers.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Feb. 22.--William F. jones a peddler, was found last night dead, with one foot caught on his wagon step. The horse had not started. It is supposed that he was stunned by falling and that his face lay in the mud until he was suffocated.
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 22.--Capt. A.H. Bogardus, champion wing shot, and Andy Meaders shot a championship match here to-day. The weather was bad, but nevertheless the attendance was large.
