DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 22.--Mrs. Ruth H. Harmon, grandmother of Mrs. Grover Clevaland, is dangerously sick, and fears are entertained that she may not recover. She is at the residence of her son, M. Harmon, in Jackson, this State.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Feb. 23.--The Carthage Landing Iceboat Association formally opened its now club house at Carthage Landing to-night. The main room is ceiled with hardwood strips and paneled. Near the centre of the main building is an arch with rope trimmings. Two wings are attached to the building.
ALBANY, Feb. 22.--The vanguard of the war veterans this evening took possession of the ground for the annual State encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic, which will begin to-morrow.
MASSOWAH, Feb. 22.--Rasaloula, the Abyssinian leader, has sent a letter to Gen. Gene, commander of the Italian forces at Massowah, in which he says: "I am not to blame.
CHICAGO, Feb. 22.--The Chicago Board of Trade, the open board, and the Produce Exchange were closed in commemoration of Washington's Birthday.

The advertisement of one Chong Fock published yesterday has brought to light a number of facts concerning the local Chinese which were not thitherto known. Chong Fock, to a TIMES representative yesterday explained his advertisement and then his business, both being essentially Chinese in method and character.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 22.--There was a foul attempt to assassinate John Fahey in this city last night. Fahey is about 20 years of age, and is one of the best natured and most peaceably disposed young men in the city.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 22.--Godfrey Knight, whose age and peculiarities have made him known throughout Western Michigan, died at his home in School Croft on Sunday, aged 100 years and 8 months. He was born in Roscommon County, Ireland, May 26, 1786.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22.--Mlle, Anna Barreta, one of the aerial performers of Gus Hill's "World of Novelties," now at Kernaff's Theatre, met with a serious accident this afternoon while doing her act at the matinee.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 22.--"The greatest sale since Glenview was the verdict accorded by trotting horse men at the close of the first day's sale of the National Horse and Cattle Exchange, $52,415 being received for 63 head offered, an average of $834.

James W. Weston, who died last Friday, was incinerated on Monday at the Fresh Pond Crematory. This was done in accordance with a provision of his will. So fearful was he before his death lest his wishes as to the disposal of his body might not be fulfilled that he had made a friend promise to be present on the occasion.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22.--Vice-President Reed, of the consolidated Road, explained to-day before the Railraod Committee of the Legisalture the plans for the new bridge of the Shore Line Road across the Connecticut River at Lyme.

TRENTON, Feb. 22.--The joint meeting to-day voted thus; Sewell, 34; Abbett, 34; Bodle, 3, (Baird, Chattle, Throckmorton;) Kays, 2; Erastus E. Potter, 2, (Carroll, Donohue,) and the rest scattering. The result was a disappointment to those who had expected a slight change. Only one ballot was taken. Messrs. Doran and Scott were absent and paired, or the Sewell and Abbett votes would each have been increased by 1.

The indications afforded by the returns already received of the elections to the Reichstag are not absolutely decisive. So far as they go they prefigure a small majority for the septennate. Seven years is a considerable space of time even in national and international affairs.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22.--Mary Tabbs has confessed that she carried the body of Waite Gaines to Eddington last Wednesday night and threw it into Col. William B. Mann's ice pond.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--Those ill-informed Democrats who are endeavoring to help the President to get a new Secretary of the Treasury and who are not anxious to have Mr. Fairchild appointed are betraying a degree of ignorant zeal that they will probably be ashamed of when Mr. Fairchild comes to take Mr. Manning's place.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 22.--James Forest, of No. 103 Lake-street, Allegheny, a brakeman on the Pittsburg, Fort Wayne and Chicago Railroad, will leave to-morrow evening for New-York to find out how many thousands of dollars he is to have from a fortune which was left by a relative of his, who died in France some time ago.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 22.--The bituminous coal operators of the Pittsburg, Hocking Valley, and Tuscarawas Valley regions held a secret conference in this city to-day to fix upon a scale of prices that would lead to a brotherly feeling among producers. The meeting lasted the entire day.
Mary Tyner has asked the Supreme Court to give her a limited divorce from her husband, Michael P. Tyner, for abandonment, and also to give her the custody of their two children, and alimony.

Mrs. Mary A. Hanley, widow of William J. Hanley, a dry goods merchant of Memphis, Tenn., who died several years ago, leaving her very rich, was at Police Headquarters at midnight in a condition bordering on distraction because of the disappearance of her niece.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 22.--The Senate to-day passed finally bells providing for the publication of a report on the birds of Pennsylvania; preventing Judges from receiving extra pay or mileage for work done in their own districts; authorizing and validating taxes levied ...

LONDON, Feb. 22.--In the House of Commons to-day Sir James Ferguson, Parliamentary Secretary of the Foreign Office, declined to explain the tenor of the dispatch from the Canadian Government suggesting a modus vivendi for a settlement of the fisheries dispute with the United States.

Perhaps it is true that philantropists usually fail of that gratitude and appreciation to which their services entitle them. In their youth and manhood they are attacking abuses, and are, of course, provoking hatred and derision upon all sides.

The Winter torpor of the picturesque little village of Whitestone, Long Island, has been broken by a sensation. For a long time the country gossips have commented upon the assiduous attentions of a slender young private in the. United States Engineer Corps, stationed at Willet's Point, to the plump and pretty daughter of Mr. John Hipple, one of the prominent citizens of the place.

The members of the conference of the Eastern societies of Delta Tau Delta Society were kept busy all day yesterday. Eight chapters of the fraternity were represented at the conference which met in the morning at the Hall of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen in East Sixteenth-street.

The first annual meeting of the Mount Holyoke Alumnae Association was held yesterday at the Broadway Tabernacle, with about 100 ladies present. These officers were unanimously elected for the coming year:
MANSFIELD, Penn., Feb. 22.--Annie Connors, a 15-year-old girl, whose home is near Sheridan Station, on the Panhandle Road, was bitten by a dog last Fall.

There is trouble brewing among the bigchested men of the aristocracy, and if the contentious forces now in action be not abated the prospect is that the Manhattan Athletic Club, whose emblem is the Cherry Diamond, and the New-York Athletic Club, which rallies round the Winged Foot of Mercury, will meet within the sanguinary confines of the 24-foot rope.

Peter Hanson, an artist, who had a studio in Room No. 59 on the fifth floor of No. 26 Church-street and lived at No. 220 Sixteenthstreet, Brooklyn, usually left his work about 4 o'clock every afternoon, and reached home between 5 and 6. Friday night he did not come home, and his wife waited for him until 6 o'clock yesterday morning.

TORONTO, Feb. 22.--T.H. Robinson has issued a challenge to Louis Rubenstein, of Montreal, to meet him in this city, skating figure for figure to a finish without a limit as to specialties. He offers the same terms to T.P. Good, of New-York promising to pay his traveling expenses and put up a fifty-dollar medal.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Feb. 22.--With but three days more of the session the Senatorial deadlock seems to be no nearer a solution than at the opening, and it is hopeless, in the opinion of those best acquainted with the situation, to look for an election.

DUBLIN, Feb. 22.--Mr. Ryder, sub-agent of the Clanricarde estates, intends resigning. Mr. Joyce, who has resigned as agent, intends to publish correspondence relating to his dealings with the tenants.
Buffalo Bill made his farewell bow to New-York audiences last evening, MadisonSquare Garden being uncomfortably well filled with a very enthusiastic audience.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 22.--The State Railroad Commission to-day announced its conclusions in relation to the Hartford Railroad disaster. The commission finds that 30 people lost their lives in the accident, and 37 persons were injured. Forty-one witnesses were examined, and the commission found that the accident was due to the breaking of the eighteenth rail from the south end of the bridge.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 22.--One of the partners in the large dry goods house of Church Phalen, whose failure was announced yesterday, says that the trouble started in 1884 with the brokerage firm of O.M. Bogart Co., of New-York, from whom the firm borrowed when starting in business $25,000, and had at intervals since borrowed largely.

BERLIN, Feb. 23.--Returns from 265 districts show the election of 44 Conservatives, 18 Imperialists, 43 Centrists, 83 National Liberals, 8 New-German Liberalis, 6 Socialists, 15 Alsatlans, and 4 Poles. In 44 districts new elections will be held. Septennists are returned throughout Saxony and in almost all the districts in Baden, Wurtemberg, and Hesse. A large majority for the Government is now assured.
There was a large attendance of chess players yesterday at the rooms of the New-York Club to witness the annual tournament for the championship of the State.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22.--About 600 students and their friends assembled in the old college chapel this morning to hear the orations on George Washington.

MONTREAL, Feb. 22.--The Federal elections are creating the greatest excitement. In the Province of Quebec the Government's majority of 35 will probably be wiped out. They have already lost nine seats and only gained one. Sir Hector Langevin, with all the influence of the Catholic Church at his back, only obtained a majority of 12.

Having tried his wings as a purveyor of news to the Government the Consul or Consul-General is consumed with the evil-sickness of writing.

Under the auspices of Charter Oak Council, No. 4, the Order of United American Mechanics celebrated Washington's Birthday at Steinway Hall yesterday in enthusiastic fashion. The hall was crowded with members and their friends, who enjoyed a long programme of music and recitations.
The two hundred and fiftieth performance of "Erminie" will ho given at the Casino to-night. "The Prophet," with Herr Schott as John of Leyden, will be sung at the Metropolitan Opera House to-night.

The second day of the pigeon shooting tournament of the Middlesex Gun Club at Dunellen, N.J., yesterday, attracted a very large attendance. It was a meeting of the giants in the shooting world.

Stockwell becomes a newspaper man, and through some ability, but more of self-assertion, rises fast in journalism.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 22.--A liverly interest has been awakened here by the vessel owners receiving from a Government engineer letters, with blanks to be filled out, which lead them to presume that the War Department is quietly preparing for possible trouble with Canada.
MOUNT HOLLYM, N.J., Feb. 22.--The consultation of leading physicians was held this afternoon at the house where Miss Mary Anderson, the victim of the recent mysterious shooting affair, is lying.

The congregation of B'nai Jeshurun, whose synagogue is at Madison-avenue and Sixtyfifth-street, will shortly make an application for the removal of the bodies interred in the old cemetery in Thirty-second-street, between sixth and seventh avenues, to Cypress Hills.

The American Athletic Club Harriers held their regular paper chase yesterday. The hares and hounds gathered at Pettit's Hotel, in Jamaica, Long Island, and at 11:25 o'clock the former were sent away, followed eight minutes later by the hounds. The hares were Messrs. Nolan and Bishop.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 22.--For several days past prominent bluestone dealers have held secret sessions in the Eagle Hotel with the view of forming a combination or pooling their issues.
The testimonial concert tendered to Prof. George F. Bristow by his friends in public and professional life took place at steinway Hall last evening.

The funeral of Mr. James B. Fisher, the talented young journalist, late on the staff of the Herald, will take place at 11 o'clock this morning at St. Leo's Church, in Twenty-eighthstreet, near Madison-avenue.

VIENNA, Feb. 23.--Diplomats here surmise that the statements of the Russian press that Russia will abstain from action in Bulgaria until the relations between France and Germany become more clearly defined are intented to divert the attention of the powers from Bulgaria, where startling surprises may be apprehended.

ALBANY, Feb. 23.--The State Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic opened most auspiciously, with a perfect February day, and the parade of the veterans through the streets in the morning was witnessed by great crowds.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 23.--The Board of Pardons to-day granted a rehearing in the cases of Milton Weston, the Chicago capitalist, now undergoing imprisonment in the Riverside Penitentiary for complicity in the Murraysville Gas Well riots, and John J. Johnston and James Newman, Washington County miners, convicted of conspiracy and riot.

Gov. Hill and the members of his staff received so many military salutes at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night that if they had not become accustomed to such honors their official heads would have been turned.

The United States Inspector of Steam Vessels reported to District Attorney Walker yesterday that many tug boats in New-York waters are running their boilers with a higher steam pressure than the inspectors' certificates permit.

In a letter to THE TIMES a correspondent complains that he has been unfairly treated by the National Agency, an employment office at No. 704 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23.--It is claimed by people in the trade that the whole of the 180,000 bushels of so-called No. 2 barley now in one of the Armour-Dole elevators in this city is off grade and ought to be declared not regular for delivery on contracts.
ROME, Feb. 23.--Two shocks of earthquake were felt at Nice at 6 o'clock this morning. Houses rocked, walls cracked, and in some cases frail tenements were thrown to the ground.
MANCHESTER, Feb. 23.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "The market is uniformly quiet. In only a few instances yesterday were the sales up to the average business of Tuesday.

READING, Penn., Feb. 23.--Another young woman was brutally shorn of her hair to-day, the outrage having been committed in the heart of the city at an early hour this morning.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Feb. 23.--The principal society event here to-day was the wedding of George A. Sanford, of Washington, D.C., and Sara E. Gouldy, daughter of Francis Gouldy, a wealthy retired merchant, formerly of and well known in NewYork City. Several hundred persons attended the wedding and reception at the Gouldy residence on Montgomery-street. The groom is General Secretary of the Washington Young Men's Christian Association.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23.--A large delegation of prominent citizens left for Jefferson City this morning to urge on the Legislature the passage of the Militia bill. The Governor still holds the resignations of 50 or 60 officers, and is working to have the measure recalled and passed. It is doubtful whether the Legislature will recall the bill, as the body feels piqued at the severe castigation it has received through the press.
It was reported at the Custom House yesterday that the Senate Committee on Commerce had reported favorably on Collector Magone's appointment. The Collector, however, had not heard the report.
NEW-ORLEANS, Feb. 23.--Corn higher; in sacks. 45c.@46c. Hog products firmer, but not quotably higher. Bran easier; at 77 c.@80c. Other articles unchanged. Clearings of the banks, $1,490,098.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23.--Society in North St. Louis is all agog over the elopement and marriage of James C. Branch, a wealthy young man of good family, to Emma Boehmer, a German servant girl, who served as a domestic for four years in his father's house.

Ash Wednesday services were not held in St. Paul's Episcopal Church at Englewood, N.J., yesterday on account of the tragic occurrence in the rectory early Tuesday morning, when the Rev. Charles W. Ward, during a fit of insanity, shot himself and wife, and tried to shoot his little daughter. A notice announcing that no services would be held was conspicuously placed on the church door.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23.--Ex-Gov. John Ireland, of Texas, testified before the outrage investigating committee to-day that there was a large negro element in Washington County, and that since the passage of the reconstruction laws there had been more or less disturbance in the county.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23.--To-day was the first day that Mary Anderson, at Mount Holly, N.J., failed to recognize her father and mother.

Henry Newbury, who is employed by the Adams Express Company in this city, and his sister Ellen were separated 10 years ago under peculiar circumstances.

DEROIT, Mich., Feb. 23.--Every two years Michigan has a general election in the Spring, at which a Judge of the Supreme Court and two Regents of the State University, the body which manages the finances and governs in a general way that institution, are chosen.

The Rev. David Gregg, who for 16 years has been Pastor of the Reformed Presbyterian Church, in West Twenty-third-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues, recently accepted a call from the Park-Street Church, (Congregational,) of Boston.
The tournament of the Middlesex Gun Club was continued yesterday at Dunellen, N. J. Messrs. C.W. Budd and Wagner won the first two matches at clay pigeons.
Francis S. Smith, who died recently in this city, had a country residence at Port Chester, Westchester County, and his will was yesterday filed in the Surrogate's office at White Plains for probate.

The New-York press seem agitated over the Phoenix Mine, in Arizona, which is very actively speculated upon in the Stock Exchange. Some say the mine is a great bonanza, improving each day as work progresses, and that the title thereto is perfect, while others claim that the title is not good.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 23.--The Industrial Labor Conference resumed its convention to-day. On motion of Mrs. Severance, of Wisconsin, the rules were suspended, and Mr. Crocker, of Kansas, was permitted to explain the Oklahoma movement, and to present a preamble and resolution in regard to that matter.

BERLIN, Feb. 23.--Taking all the results thus far known, together with a careful forecast of the results of the supplementary elections, it is estimated that the Reichstag will consist of 220 supporters of the Government and 177 opponents of all shades. The new Reischstag has been summoned to meet on March 3.
The latest proof of the need of continual and careful inspection of the engines on the elevated roads was given yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23.--The wonderful progress made by the Knights of Labor in this city during 1886 is shown in the annual report just issued by John J. Cummins, the Recording and Financial Secretary of District Assembly No.1.

A loving cup, a parting gift of New-York friends which Herr Anton Seidl, the musical conductor of the Metropolitan Opera House, will carry with him to Europe, was privately exhibited at Gorham Co.'s, Broadway and Nineteenth-street, yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Feb. 23.--For the second time one of the new employes of the Cambridge Road was the victim to-night of a serious and brutal assault. Driver Hastings had just started his car from Porter Station on North-avenue.

In response to the advertisement lately published by Col. McFarland, of the United States Engineers, calling for bids on the dredging to be undertaken in New-York Harbor, a number of proposals were received and were opened yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23.--The bulls in wheat had their first innings to-day since the middle of January, and, aided by frighthened shorts, boomed prices up 1 cents from the lowest point.

George B. Douglas presided yesterday at a meeting of the cheese trade of the Produce Exchange. It appears that Western cheese makers have been manufacturing cheese from skim milk, oleomargarine, and cottonseed oil.

BOSTON, Feb. 23.--At the annual meeting of the Boston Transcript Company to-day William Durant resigned the position of business manager, which he has held for many years, and Frederic B. Whitney was then chosen to fill the vacancy. Mr. Durant was then appointed Treasurer. Joseph E. Chamberlain, formerly of the Record, has been appointed associate editor of the Transcript.

An odd lawsuit is to be brought to trial before long in a town situated a little way from Hartford. A respectable man of the town obtained a divorce from his wife six years ago on the ground of adultery.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 23.--The Right Rev. W. W. Niles, Bishop of the Diocese of New-Hampshire, is seriously ill at his home in this city. Last week he was attacked with a hemorrhage from the nose, which again occurred during the service at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Sunday night. The bleeding has continued profusely at intervals since.

Gen. Thomas W. Egan was taken suddenly ill at the International Hotel on Wednesday evening and died yesterday afternoon in the Chambers-Street Hospital. He was about 55 years of age and had been in falling health for some years past. The cause of his death was epilepsy.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 25.--Jacob Schaefer, the champion billiardist, has challenged any man in the world to play a game of cushion carroms, 500 points, for $2,500 a side, the person accepting to have the privilege of naming the place of meeting.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 25.--Gov. Lounsbury to-day nominated O.R. Fyler, of Torrington, for In surance Commissioner, to fill the office until July 1, 1887, and also for four years from July 1, 1887.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 26.--The strikers at South Amboy have finally been obliged to surrender. This morning they all signed an agreement to go back to work at the old prices.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 25.--About 9 o'clock this morning Theodore Thompson, a farmer residing just south of Franklin, while at work in his fields, which have been flooded with back water from the Miami River, discovered the remains of a man that had been washed upon his fields by the high water.

The German bark Marie lay off the foot of Fortieth-street, South Brooklyn, last night, with her hold one great oven of flame. Murky clouds of smoke rolled out from every crevice and poured in dark masses from the hatches.

Four plays, "Separation," "Matrimony," "Paquita," and "Fairfax," were sold yesterday by Auctioneer C.F. Walters at the New-York Amusement Exchange, No. 1,162 Broadway. Their author, Bartley Campbell, is in the Asylum for the Insane at Middletown.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--The Senate was in session this evening discussing the House joint resolution for an investigation of the books of the Pacific railroads, with the Senate substitute therefor. Mr. McPherson moved to strike from the substitute, sections 4, 5, and 6.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25.--George W. Voice and P. O'Neil, the two policemen of East St. Louis who were recently arrested on the charge of murdering ex-Mayor John B. Bowman, of that city, on Nov. 20, 1885, were indicted by the Grand Jury at Belleville, Ill., this afternoon for murder in the first degree.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25.--The death of Judge Bently B. Benedict, of Rapid City, Dakota, which occurred very suddenly at Rock Island yesterday, excited such suspicious that an inquest was held today. A post mortem examination disclosed a business card lodged deep in the throat, and a chemical analysis showed that morphine had been taken. The deceased was Probate Judge of Pennington, County, Dakota.
"Rienzi" will be given at the Metropolitan Opera House this afternoon, the performance being the last of the season.

DUBLIN, Feb. 25.--The people of Dingle, County Kerry, were made aware of the arrival there to-day of an evicting party by the blowing of horns and the ringing of the chapel bell. A crowd of fully 2,000 persons quickly collected.

MORRIS, Ill., Feb. 25.--The preliminary examination of Newton Watt for the murder and robbery on the Rock Island Road last March was commenced this morning. The examination was held in the Court House, which was crowded almost to suffocation.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 25.--An official test of the steam-heating apparatus, as applied by the Milwaukee and St. Paul, was made yesterday upon that company's Short Line train, which runs between St. Paul and Minneapolis.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25.--The status of affairs remains as it was, with the exception that the Senate passed a resolution to-day setting out their side of the claims of Smith to act as Lieutenant-Governor, and proposing to submit the case to the Supreme Court as arbitrators.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 25.--The dramatic complications arising out of the matrimonial ventures of Louis Lichtenberger, a St. Louis brewer, are now perplexing the courts. He comes of a good family in Germany, but in 1873 married a woman opposed by his relatives, and was compelled to seek happiness in the United States.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Feb. 25.--At a meeting of the managers of the Battlefield Memorial Association held here to-day it was resolved not to permit the erection of any more monuments or memorials not of granite or real bronze on grounds controlled by the association.

LONDON, Feb. 26.--The Times's Paris dispatch, among other things, says: Emerging from these weeks of anxiety, the people are seeking a remedy for the situation created by Prince Bismarck's speech and the German elections.

The horde of seekers after a berth in the Inter-State Railroad Commission may be relieved to learn that Andrew D. White, ex-President of Cornell University, has removed himself from the list of persons who may be induced to accept a place on that board.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 25.--Some of the holders of the first and second mortgage bonds of the Troy and Boston Railroad have strenuously opposed the terms of the consolidation of that road with the Fitchburg Railroad.

VIENNA, Feb. 25.--Dr. Jahn, Director of the Imperial Opera, has gone to Milan to make arrangements for the production of Verdi's new opera "Otello" in this city.

Little Jimmy Boyle, while playing with matches in the apartments of his parents on the top floor of the five-story tenement house No. 333 East Seventy-fifth-street, set fire to the bed. In a moment the apartments were in a blaze.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 25.--Gov. Beaver has granted a reprieve for James McCabe, the Wayne County murderer, sentenced to be hanged on March 24. The execution of the sentence has been staid until April 21, in order to present his case again before the Pardon Board.

A fire broke out about 9 o'clock last night on the top floor of the box factory of P. Lorillard Co., on Bay-street, Jersey City, and for nearly two hours it looked as if the whole building, which occupies the greater part of a block, would be destroyed.

OTTAWA, Feb. 25.--An influx of politicians from the country has commenced, now that the elections are over. The indications are that the Government will have a majority of at least 25. Revised returns give several seats to the Opposition.
LONDON, Feb. 25.--The steamship Adriatic, (Br.,) Capt. Parsell, from New-York Feb. 17, for Liverpool, passed Brow Head this evening.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25.--A.P. Swineford, Governor of Alaska, was at the Grand Pacific yesterday. Concerning the charges that have recently been published against him Gov. Swineford says that he can refute every one of them.

BOSTON, Feb. 25.--Oscar E. Bliss, junior member of the firm of Lucas Bliss, grocers, , Middleborough, has, it is believed, eloped with Miss Minnie Earl, the daughter of a well known resident of that town. Minnie is pretty, blonde, and 20 years of age.

BOSTON, Feb. 25.--The Rev. James Freeman Clarke, the eminent Unitarian divine, has been suffering several days from a severe cold, which has confined him to his bed. At his house this morning he was said to be in a slightly weaker condition than yesterday, but no serious results were anticipated at present.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 25.--This was the fourth day of the combination sale of horses. Eighty-four head were sold for $19,035, the average being $226. In the four days 275 head were sold for $112,575. The sale concludes to-morrow.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 25.--Cooper Hewitt's Bedell Iron Mine, recently discovered and operated of Amity, N.J., near the New-York State line, ig said to furnish a grade of ore exceedingly valuable on account of its readiness of conversion into Bessemer steel.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25.--The Philadelphia Traction Company, which controls a number of the street car lines of the city, to-day announced that on and after April 1 the fare on all its lines will be 5 cents. Six cents is the present rate on all the Traction Company's lines.

ROME, Feb. 25.--Cardinal Jacobini was taken ill to-day with gout in the chest and his condition is hopeless. The Pope visited him this evening and afterward extreme unction was administered to the dying man.

NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 25.--This evening the steamer Chatham, outward bound for Boston, came in collision with the schooner Mary Freeland, light, which was anchored in the stream off Lambert's Point. The schooner was sunk. The Chatham proceeded on her trip.
The hull of the new steamboat for the day line to Albany was towed up to this city from Wilmington yesterday and tied up at the foot of West Twenty-second-street.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 25.--The residence of the late Moses Clearwater, of the town of Warwasing, in Ulster County, was destroyed by fire on Wednesday night last. The only inmate of the house at the time was Miss Sarah Jane Clearwater, an unmarried lady about 40 years of age. Miss Clearwater was burned to death before help arrived. The doors were found locked, but the victim had evidently made many attempts to escape from the flames.

Mr. Robert L. Cutting died early yesterday morning at his home, No. 141 Fifth-avenue. Mr. Cutting had been ill for several weeks and had not visited the office of Lee Warren, with which he was formerly connected and in which his son is a special partner, for some time.

BERLIN, Feb. 25.--The official returns show the election of 75 Conservatives, 34 Imperialists, 84 National Liberals, 90 Centrists, 14 New German Liberals, 6 Socialists, 15 Alsatians, 13 Poles, 2 Guelphs, 1 Dane, and 2 others whose views are as yet unknown. Sixty-one supplementary ballots are necessary.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 25.--United States authorities in this State have just succeeded in finding a gang of moonshiners who have for several years been doing an extensive illicit distillery business in Orange County. The manner in which they were discovered is remarkable.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 26.--Dr. Krueger, of the European Union of Astronomers, announces the discovery of an asteroid, No. 265, by Dr. Palisa, on Feb. 25, 47 75' Greenwich mean time, in right ascension 10 hours, 31 minutes, and 43.5 seconds; north 7 50' 45''. The asteroid is of the twelfth magnitude, and has a rapid southerly motion.

ELMIRA, Feb. 26.--Frank Brown, a young man of Thurston, Steuben County, was accidentally shot and killed near Cameron this morning by the accidental discharge of a comrade's gun while both men were hunting. The right side of Brown's face was almost blown off.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 26.--President Charles Green has called a meeting of the American Turf Congress at Louisville March 8. St. Louis will not be represented in the Detroit meeting of the trotting men who desire to withdraw from the National Association.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 26.--A new steel boiler at the shaft of the Coal Bluff Mining Company, at Carbon, 12 miles northeast, exploded this morning. A boy named Phillips was killed, and William B. Alton, the engineer, seriously injured, also his helper.

VANCOUVER, Washington Territory, Feb. 26.-- the Right Rev. A.M.A. Blanchet, Roman Catholic Bishop of Nesqually, died last evening, aged 90 years. He came to this Territory in 1845, and was prominently identified with the growth of the Catholic Church until age, 10 years ago, prevented him from longer actively superintending the affairs of the church. He resided continuously for nearly 40 years in this city.

ANSONIA, Conn., Feb. 26.--The Rev. Hugh T. Brady, aged 63, one of the oldest priests in Connecticut, was buried here this afternoon. Bishop McMahon, of Hartford, assisted by 60 clergymen, officiated. Yesterday was set apart in the Presbyterian Church for the annual collection for home missions. The Fourth-Avenue Presbyterian Church made special efforts to secure a large contribution to the fund, as it was the sixty-first birthday of their Pastor, Dr. Howard Crosby.

Nicholas Fletcher Palmer, the well known bank President of this city, died suddenly yesterday morning of heart disease at his home, No. 576 Madison-avenue. He had been in poor health for two years, and in consequence of its increase was compelled to relinquish his business last December.

The Fifth-Avenue Stage Company has decided to return to the old box system of collecting fares. The plan has not yet been put in operation, but will be shortly. The conductors will be discharged and change given by the drivers, as in old times.

SCOTTSBURG, Ind., Feb. 24.--A gray eagle measuring seven feet from tip to tip was killed five miles southwest of here yesterday by Mrs. John Rickard, who shot it with a rifle from a distance of 100 yards. It is now on exhibition at the Court House.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 27.--The jury in the case of Edson Magoon in the United States Court, charged with illicit distilling, who retired at 5:50 o'clock last night, did not agree on a verdict until about midnight, having in the meantime asked instructions of Judge Wheeler several times.

Perry Co.'s stove contract at Sing Sing Prison expires to-day, thus throwing about 700 convicts out of employment. Warden Brush says he does not know what he will do with them, except lock them up and march them to and from their meals for exercise. This the men dread.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--Discount was in good demand during the past week at 3 to 3 . On the Stock Exchange prices were firm, and rose throughout the week, but the advance was slow and hesitating, the public being still doubtful as to the maintenance of peace.

A little silver star glistened on the lapel of J.B. Gibbs's tightly buttoned frock coat yesterday afternoon when he walked upon the platform of Masonic Temple, and the bright bit of metal twinkled merrily as its bearer bowed and bowed in response to the applause that greeted him.
GAINESVILLE, Mo., Feb. 27.--The office of the County Treasurer of Ozark County was entered by burglars at 1 o'clock this morning and robbed of $18,000.

TRENTON, N.J. Feb. 27.--For three weeks the extraordinary spectacle has been presented here of a Legislature with a Democratic majority, and with what Leon Abbett has been all along claiming as a majority in favor of his election to the United States Senate, voting day after day for senator without effecting a choice.

Michael McDonald, the proprietor of a liquor store at No. 434 West Twenty-seventhstreet, gave up the store to his oldest son, Thomas, three months ago, taking a chattel mortgage on the establishment. One of the conditions was that Thomas should keep the place as a respectable liquor store.

Mr. W.A. Duer, son-in-law of Mr. William R. Travers, arrived yesterday from Bermuda on the steamship Orinoco. Mr. Duer says that the condition of Mr. Travers is about the same as it has been for some time past. He is quite cheerful, and talks freely.

The array of counsel which appeared before the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday to assist in the defense of THOMAS CLEARY indicates that all the resources of legal ingenuity are to be employed in an effort to prevent his conviction.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The General Passenger Agents of the roads in the Southwestern Passenger Association have just submitted to the General Managers their report regarding the interpretation and application of the InterState Commerce law as relating to passenger traffic.
Bushwick is an ugly place for a night mystery. It lies on the northern confines of Brooklyn, whence the low lands of Newtown Creek stretch away, bleak and frozen, to the East River.

They were chiefly young sports and "toughs" from the Fourth and Seventh Wards, with a few from the Ninth.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 28.--Trains are greatly delayed by snow and some small roads are badly blocked. Drifts from 10 to 20 feet high are reported, and on many country roads traveling with teams is impossible. On account of the deep snow teams are being taken from the woods, and the annual lumber cut will be curtailed. It has been Maine's toughest Winter for years. Heavy rains now would cause a freshet on many rivers.

Washington E. Connor came home from Europe yesterday on the Saale, after an absence from town since Dec. 4. He made the trip chiefly to see English yacht builders and obtain plans for the steam yacht which he wants to build. Except a quick journey to Paris and the South of France, Mr. Connor passed the most of his time in London, where nearly a score of boat builders consulted with him.

The Women's Conference of the City of New-York held its regular monthly meeting yesterday morning at the hall of the Industrial Education Association, No. 9 University-place. Miss Grace H. Dodge presided, and 250 ladies were present, including Mrs. Helen Campbell and Dr. Anna C. Daniels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--The Naval Appropriation bill, which was received from the House this morning, was laid before the Senate and read the first time. Mr. Edmunds objected to the second reading of the bill to-day.

Harrigan's Park Theatre looked as if a Democratic convention had taken possession of it last evening. The Narragansett Club had some 200 members present, with as many more friends, headed by Sheriff Grant, Congressmanelect Amos J. Cummings, Civil Justices Dessar, ...

PARIS, Feb. 28.--Mr. Sloane, of NewYork, who was at Nice during the earthquake, and who is now in Paris, says that before leaving Nice he was obliged to sleep in the open air for two nights. He says he was struck with the fact that each shock of earthquake was preceded by hot, heavy gusts of wind from the sea, lasting several minutes.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 28.--Seven of the eleven loaded coal barges swept from their moorings last evening by the high water were captured by the steamer Twilight near the foot of Neville Island. The other four, containing 576,000 bushels of coal, were lost, and are now at the bottom of the river. The three men who were pumping on the fleet at the time it was cast adrift were not injured.
The funeral of Robert Livingston Cutting took place at 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon at Grace Church. The Rev. Dr. Huntington, assisted by the Rev. George F. Nelson, conducted the services.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The statement is made on good authority that the extensive lumber district in the southwestern section of the city will soon be a thing of the past. Many of the large tracts of land now occupied by lumber yards have recently changed hands and the lumber dealers will seek other territory.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--It is now pretty certain that the open Board of Trade will be merged into the Chicago Stock Exchange. A joint committee composed of five members from each organization met to-day and agreed upon a plan of consolidation.

GALVESTON, Texas, Feb. 28.--P.D. Armour, John Plankinton, J.L. Newell, and the ladies comprising Mr. Armour's traveling party, passed the day in Galveston sightseeing and left in their special car this evening for San Antonio, en route to California.

Mr. McCaull's singers and comedians made known to a large assemblage at the Star Theatre last evening another of the new works in the line of opera comique that the energetic impresario is constantly importing from Europe to try upon the ears of the American public.

OTTAWA, Feb. 28.--Next Summer will witness D Company, Infantry School Corps, and C Battery organized, with headquarters at London, Ontario, and Victoria, British Columbia, respectively. The Minister of Militia will ask Parliament at the coming session to vote $100,000 for this purpose. The infantry school at London, at the date of organization, will consist of 100 men, exclusive of officers.

Policeman William J. Rourke, apparently no more affected than if before his Sergeant at roll call, stood before Recorder Smyth yesterday morning to hear what his punishment was to be for killing Roundsman Robert A. Montgomery.

The Board of Police Justices met last night at the Jefferson Market Building, Justices Kilbreth, Patterson, and Welde being the only ones absent. Henry C. Perley, Conrad M. Smyth, George W. Cregier, and John Tracey were re-elected chief clerks, their terms of office having expired on Feb. 1.
"E.K."--The Working Woman's Protective Union, No. 19 Clinton-place, this city, will, on application, attend to the case.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--The visible supply of grain on Feb. 26, as compiled by the Secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, shows a decrease of 2,260,000 bushels of wheat, 435,000 bushels Of corn, and 136,000 bushels of oats.
Miss Emma Juch is at the Hotel Vendome. Washington E. Connor is at the Bucking ham Hotel.

Ever since the Rev. Benjamin Staunton, once Pastor of the Fort Greene Church in Brooklyn, defended himself unsuccessfully in a suit for divorce brought by his wife in the Supreme Court, he has been preaching to a portion of his old congregation in Adelphi Hall, on Myrtleavenue.

BERLIN, Feb. 28.--A dispatch from Strasburg to the Berlin Post announces that the Government has issued an order for the dissolution of the union of Alsatian choral societies, it being suspected that the union has assisted the objects of the French League of Patriots.
Last Summer Thatcher, Primrose and West, the minstrels, made a contract with Messrs. Palmer and Mallory, of the MadisonSquare Theatre, to give a series of performances lasting from May 3 to July 31.

The Manhattan Railway Company is meeting with sturdy opposition to its project of building branches running from its main lines to the ferry landings. The Paine will case, which has been on trial before Surrogate Rollins for some months, is drawing to a close. Testimony for the Executor was closed yesterday, and an effort will be made by proponent's counsel to produce his remaining witnesses is rebuttal to-day and tomorrow.

There is a gap to-day between the Guion and Stonington Line piers, on the North River, at the foot of Charlton-street, which was before occupied by the pier of the Morgan Line of the Southern Pacific Company's system, of which Collis P. Huntington is President.

BOSTON, Feb. 28.--The old Colony Railroad Company's new passenger station in Milton was burned to-night. The loss is estimated at $20,000. The fire was caused be the explosion of a kerosene lamp. Only the brick walls are left standing.

The Brooklyn Aldermen made another attempt yesterday to get out of the bog into which they plunged by making contracts with the electric and gas companies for street lights to cost $410,000, while the appropriation for that purpose aggregated only $390,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28.--McCaull's Opera House was packed to-night to hear and see the first performance of "Ruddigore." That the opera is a great success here and another "Mikado" in prospective popularity there can be no question.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28.--A lamentable amount of gambling is being done just now among the students at Yale College, and it has been going on for the past three weeks. On the authority of one of the students, it is stated that nearly one-fourth of the students in the university have caught the fever.

During the silk weavers strike on Jersey City Heights and in West Hoboken last Summer, Poidebard's mill was regarded as especially obnoxious by the strikers, and the largely predominating Socialist element among them frequently menaced it with attack. The strike was settled, but the silk weavers have shown signs of restlessness lately, and rumors of another strike prevail.

James B. Young, who died on Sunday at his residence, No. 308 West Fifty-eighth-street, was well known in publishing circles in this city as an importer of English devotional books and a publisher of religious works, more especially of Bibles and Prayer Books.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 28.--Later developments in the Preece shooting case prove interesting. It seems not at all unlikely that Eleanor Preece will marry George Holman after all. An evidence of her affection for him is given by Detective Gregory who has returned from the Ashwells.

A fire was discovered at an early hour this morning in a three-story tenement at No. 110 Bloomfield-street, Hoboken. Mrs. Hartnett and Mrs. Doody, who lived in the top story, jumped from windows and were fatally injured.

Vast herds of antelope have been almost daily seen during the last two months along the line of the Union Pacific Railway in Wyoming. One herd seen near the Rock Springs was estimated to number at least ten thousand of these graceful creatures.

HERKIMER, N.Y., Feb. 28.--The county and the shire town of Herkimer are bereft of their nightmare. Roxalana Druse was hanged to-day in the county jail. Over 40 murders have been committed in the county, but this woman had the unenviable distinction of being the first to pay the legal penalty of her crime.

The Brooklyn Park Commissioners are in hot water continually, and Mr. Somers always seems to be responsible for it. A matter made public yesterday promises to cause the resignations of President James T. Easton and Commissioner Harteau.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 28.--A sensation has been produced in local religious circles by the unexpected resignation of the Rev. Rollo Ogden, for four years Pastor of the Case-Avenue Presbyterian Church, and previously Assistant Pastor of the First Presbyterian Church.

The fourth of the Aldermen of 1884, in the person of Thomas Cleary, was placed at the bar of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Judge Barrett presiding, yesterday, to answer to an indictment charging him with having agreed to accept a bribe for his vote in the granting of the Broadway Railroad franchise.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 28.--Britton Mayson, cotton merchants, have filed a suit against their creditors praying for a respite. The schedule shows assets of $60,000 and liabilities of $48,000. Inability to callect promptly outstanding, obligations is given as the cause for asking a respite.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 28.--It is not unlikely that Gov. Hill will in a short time have another application to dispose of in the case of a woman convicted of murder in the first degree.

The young woman who was found unconscious in the Philadelphia train which reached the Pennsylvania railway station at Jersey City on Sunday morning lay in a comatose condition at the Jersey City Charity Hospital almost all day yesterday.

A large number of the old members of the Chelsea Hook and Ladder Company No. 2, of the Volunteer Fire Department assembled in the club rooms of the Alaska Association, No. 292 Eighth-avenue, yesterday, for the purpose of reorganizing and bringing together companions of a quarter of a century ago. One of those present, James McNamee, has done fire duty for over 40 years.

PARIS, Feb. 28.--M. Rodat and M. Vignancour, both Republicans, have been elected to the Chamber of Deputies from Averon and the Lower Pyrenees respectively. Their election is a gain of two for the Republican Party in the Chamber.

James Cooney was sentenced on June 26, 1883, by Recorder Smyth to five years' imprisonment at Sing Sing and to pay a fine of $5,000. His crime was assault in the second degree in being an accomplice of Patrick McGowan, who shot Officer Delaney, of the Tombs squad, and was himself shot dead by the officer. By commutation for good behavior his sentence expired yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--Capts. Abner Haines, Jr., Second Infantry; Randolph Norwood, Second Cavalry, and M.W. Wood, Assistant Surgeon, have been ordered to Fort d'Alene, Idaho, as witnesses before the court of inquiry, to meet there March 14.

A few days ago Mrs. Kate Revere, sister of Mrs. Alfred Lawrence, of Tarrytown, went to Yonkers and got a prescription from Dr. Sarah E. Post, of No. 38 Warburton-avenue. She intended to send it to her sister, Mrs. B.H. Bishop, who lives near Poughkeepsie.

While the cold weather continues and the memory of the accident at Republic and White River Junction is still fresh, the railroad companies are busily testing the merits of the various devices for heating cars.

Conreid Herrman, of this city, have the American rights for the production, which may first be in German, though this has not yet been decided upon. It will certainly be produced here in some form next season.

Tom Gould, the proprietor of the Sans Souci, on Thirty-first-street, who fled pending his trial and was bailed by Justice Streng after being arrested in Hoboken, was to have appeared before the Justice for examination yesterday. Of course he did not do so, and on motion of his lawyer the hearing was postponed till Friday next.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 28.--Sigmar Cohen, formerly a Chicago diamond broker, but more recently a bookmaker and conductor of a racing stable, was robbed of $5,000 worth of diamonds on an Iron Mountain train this morning.

DANVILLE, Va., Feb. 28.--Antoine d'Arco Janish, the Austrian actress, announced for a performance at the Academy of Music in this place to-night, arrived with her company this morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28.--The Hill bill fixing the license fee for pawnbrokers at $150, and compelling them to give a two thousanddollar bond, passed the House to-night with only 7 votes in the negative. Mr. McDermitt expressed astonishment that any one should oppose the measure.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Feb. 28.--There was a good attendance at the races to-day. The weather was clear and cool and the track was in fair condition. Following is a summary of the different events:

READING, Penn., Feb. 28.--An old farmer of this county, Amos Conrath, who since the death of his wife has been a recluse, took his life by hanging himself from a rafter in his house. When the act was committed is not known. His only companion was a dog. He was last seen at Lester's mill several day's ago, when he bade the miller good-bye, saying he intended to kill himself.

LONDON, Feb. 28.--The Mark-Lane Express in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "Native wheat in both the London and provincial markets is steady at previous rates. The sales of English wheat during the week were 40,471 quarters at 32s. 7d. against 68,823 quarters at 29s. 3d. during the corresponding period last year.

The Commonwealth Club ate its third dinner in the large dining room of the Metropolitan Hotel last evening. About 120 of its members were present and the occasion was thoroughly enjoyable in all its features.

MILES CITY, Montana, Feb. 28.--Last Fall a young buck broke into the Post Office at Ashland, about 90 miles south of Miles City, and had not been arrested, although complaint was made, until last week, when the warrant was placed in the hands of a Deputy Sheriff, whom the United States Marshal had commissioned to make the arrest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--An investigation will probably be had into the mental condition of Henry Jansen, the wife murderer, under a life sentence now at the county jail. On Friday he attacked a guard and was placed under restraint. This morning, about 11 o'clock, he obtained possession of a heavy scoop shovel, with which he rushed at a visitor, who fled for his life.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 28.--M. de Giers, Foreign Minister, in an interview with the Turkish Ambassador, expressed the opinion that the European equilibrium would soon be restored, and that there would be no war.

The Dauntless lay at anchor off Tompkinsville yesterday afternoon. She did not look like a yacht, for she was well trimmed with ice foward and bore every evidence of having had a tussle with wintry weather. She had been for a little Sunday cruise outside the Hook.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28.--Some additional light was thrown on the murder of Wakefield Gaines yesterday by the finding of a hatchet stained with blood, in a pawnshop on South street.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 28.--Charles H. Baldwin, dealer in ladies' and gentlemen's furnishing goods, was arrested this afternoon charged with having committed arson in the first degree.

United States Revenue Collector Black, of Brooklyn, heard that an illicit distillery was in operation in a little shanty in Columbia-street, near Lorraine, and yesterday morning he took possession of the establishment. He found a very complete outfit and 1,500 barrels of mash. Gerald Nally, Michael Casey, and Thomas Collins, who were found at work in the building, were taken before Commissioner Benedict and held.

A special meeting of the managers of the Women's Board of Foreign Missions was held yesterday in the meeting room, No. 20 North Washington-square, in memory of the President of the board, Mrs. O.P. Hubbard, who died Sunday. A committee of three was appointed to draw up resolutions expressing the sorrow of the board.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--The ship owners of Suffolk County, scores of whom are distributed over the east end of Long Island, are as much dissatisfied as New-York merchants over the imposition of Quarantine fees upon the cemmerce of the port of New-York. From Sag Harbor, Greenport, Port Jefferson, ...

About 800 or 900 people responded last evening to the call issued by the Central Labor Union for a mass meeting at the Cooper Institute to urge the passage of the Tenement House Reform bill. James Archibald was elected Chairman.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 28.--The steamship Chattahoochee, of the Ocean Steamship Company, plying between New-York and Savannah, was libeled today for $22,000 damages by the owners of the British bark Pohona. The damages are claimed for a collision which occurred in Savannah River Jan. 26. Bond was given and the steamer released.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--Freight rates between Chicago and St. Paul and Minneapolis have completely collapsed. The west-bound rates on all classes of freight have been reduced by most of the lines about one-half. The following rates are being made:

Zophar Mills, the veteran fireman of this city, died suddenly last evening of heart disease. Mr. Mills was returning to his home, No. 310 Lexington-avenue, at 11:10 o'clock in the evening, and had got within three doors of his own house, when he suddenly reeled and fell heavily to the sidewalk.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--Steam was turned on to-day in the great deal in May pork by its mysterious manipulators, with results that, except in the one particular of failures, recalled the McGeoch days in 1883.
The New-York Academy of Music, Irvingplace and Fourteenth-street, will be sold to the highest bidder, at the Real Estate Exchange, in Liberty-street, to-day at noon.
SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 28.--The total earnings at Sing Sing Prison for February were $14,735 83; expenditures, $12,734 57, leaving a profit for the month of $2,001 26.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28.--The annual report of the Pennsylvania Railroad, to be read at the yearly meeting of the stockholders, March 8, shows gross earnings of main line and branches, $31,132,287; net earnings, $11,983,037, and ...

LONDON, Feb. 28.--The steamship Belgravia, (Br.,) Capt. Boothby, from New-York Feb. 16, for Glasgow, arr. at Moville to-day. The steamship Rugia, (Ger.,) Capt. Albers, from New-York Feb. 18, for Hamburg, passed the Lizard to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28.--An interesting petition was filed 10 days ago in the Nickel Plate foreclosure suit by Augustus Ward, charging that large sums aggregating $10,000,000 of the funds derived from the sale of the first and second mortgage bonds had been misappropriated by the officers and asking that the Receiver be ordered to bring suit to recover it.

The man who was arrested last Saturday night and charged by Peter Clarkin, of No. 245 West Fifty-third-street, with trying to abduct his little daughter Maggie, is John McMahon. He is a lawyer, has an office at No. 18 Broadway, ...
Miss Coghlan and her company are this week at the Theatre Comique, in Harlem. Miss Jennie Dutton will sing at the Thomas Popular Concert on Thursday afternoon.

F.F. Donovan, Commissioner of the State Board of Arbitration, has been trying to effect a settlement between the striking engravers and the Photo-Engraving Company. The strikers held a meeting yesterday at No. 2 Desbrossesstreet, and appointed a committee which in conjunction with Commissioner Donovan called at the office of the company.

EX-District Attorney Peter B. Olney called the Young Men's Democratic Club to order last evening at the club's headquarters on West Twenty-fourth-street. The object of the meeting was to act upon a resolution approving of the High License bill. Mr. G. Willett Van Nest spoke in favor of the resolution, saying that the High License bill would decrease the number of saloons in the city.
PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 28.--As time draws near the usual opening of the mackerel season, the stir of preparation among the fishermen begins.
The Jersey City police last night learned of a contemplated encounter between Joseph Larkins, champion amateur middle weight of New-Jersey, and an "Unknown," Harry Ulmer's pupil.

In the Queens County Surrogate's Court, at Jamaica, yesterday, notice was served on Surrogate Weller that the contest over the will of the late Horatio G. Onderdonk, the eccentric millionaire, had been discontinued. John Onderdonk, who was disinherited by his father, at the last hearing gave testimony which made the other heirs feel uncomfortable. He threatened to tell even more, and this is supposed to have led to a compromise.

The National Opera Company entered upon a five weeks' season at the Metropolitan last evening. Most of the boxes were tenanted by familiar and representative persons; the parquet seats were well filled, and the artists, as they appeared on the stage, were welcomed with ...

HARTFORD, Vt., Feb. 28.--H.G. Wilcox, of Bangor, N.Y., injured in the late railroad accident here, died this afternoon. Erysipelas setting in caused death. This makes the total deaths resulting from the accident 30.
At the meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration yesterday President Ulrich announced the committees for the ensuing year, as follows:
In the neighborhood of Dartmouth manners are strange. On the 5th of this month two magistrates met on their way to church. They at once proceeded to fight, and one of them was half killed.
One hundred doctors sat down last evening to partake of the seventh annual dinner of the Alumni Association of the Long Island College Hospital.

LONDON, March 1.--The fisherman in the harbor of Genoa on the night preceding the earthquake noticed that the sea had retreated a yard more than usual. Instinctively feeling that something was about to happen they remained the whole night in their boats.

Herr Anton Schott, late of the Metropolitan Opera Company, is at the Belvidere Hotel with his wife. He is arranging to give some song recitals before returning to Germany next month, and it is announced that he will appear here, in Boston, and Washington. It his venture succeeds, other cities will be favored by a visit from the tenor.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--A day of considerable progress in action upon supply bills in the House and in conference committees has led many legislators to modify their views of the probability of an extra session of Congress, and to-night it is conceded that the whole question rests with the Senate to decide.

Rapid as was the approach of a carriage to the Grand Central Station, early yesterday morning, it was not quick enough to escape a curious crowd which suddenly thronged the sidewalk from nobody knew whence. Two men jumped out and pushed the people back as two others, with steel-linked wrists, climbed out.

Louis and Joseph Karrar, brothers, 11 and 13 years old, who lived with their parents at 11 Kane-place, Brooklyn, went out to skate on a pond at Saratoga and St. Mark's avenues yesterday afternoon. The ice broke and Louis fell into the water. His brother tried to save him, but got in himself and was rescued with great difficulty by a stranger. Louis was drowned. The water in the pond was only 4 feet deep.

The funeral of Zophar Mills will take place to-morrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Church of the Covenant, on Park-avenue. On the following day the body will be interred in Greenwood Cemetery. Many calls were made yesterday by sympathizing friends at the house ...

EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 1.--The City Council this afternoon passed an ordinance to carry into effect their agreement with C.H. Vennor, a prominent Boston banker. It was definitely concluded Monday night, after three weeks of excited negotiation and controversy.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 1.--During the hearing to-day before the General Assembly on the bill introduced at this session providing for the abolition of the Shellfish Commission, Attorney John W. Alling, one of the counsel for the many oyster growers who petitioned for the abolition, made charges against the Commissioner which have created much excitement in Hartford.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1.--When the Senators anu Assemblymen met in joint session this noon the roll call showed that all were present except Mr. Mulvey. This caused temporary uneasiness among the Democrats, but while they were discussing a proposition to compel his attendance he walked in. A ballot for Senator was then taken, and the result ...

ATLANTA, Ga., March 1.--The Rev. Dr. J. G. Armstrong, the celebrated Protestant Episcopal clergyman who was suspended from the ministry for 10 years by judgment of an ecclesiastical court for alleged irregularities in Cincinnati, has withdrawn definitely from the ministry...

Whatever was the state of orchid knowledge of the visitor to the Eden Musee yesterday, every one left the exhibition a confirmed monomaniac on orchids in general. It was the first exhibition of the kind in America, and the Winter garden of the Eden Musee was made a floral enchantment, praise for which is due to Messrs. Siebracht Wadley, the horticulturists of NewRochelle.

This meeting, a reporter was told at its close, ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1.--The Committee of One Hundred, otherwise known as the Board of Industry and Improvement, permanently organized to-day, electing Gen. James Barnett President, Thomas Axworthy Vice-President, X.X. Crum Secretary, and Charles H. Bulkley Treasurer. The body then proceeded to vest all authority in an Executive Committee of Twenty-one, of which seven ...

The boycott declared against the pool brewers by the Central Body of the Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association was put into execution yesterday. The officers of the retailers' organization claimed that at least 400 of their 3,000 members stopped selling pool beer yesterday, while a tthe Brewers' Exchange it was said that only one of the independent dealers had quit his brewer.

BALTIMORE, March 1.--The Annapolis, Washington and Baltimore Railroad is the connecting link between Baltimore and Annapolis. Until now it has had a monopoly of all traffic, passenger and freight, to the State capital.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 1.--Beede Bray, lumber dealers, have assigned. The liabilities are variously estimated at from $90,000 to $150,000; assets unknown, but said by the firm to be adequate to meet obligations. The creditors are most Minneapolis parties.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 1.--When the wagons of the Baltimore and Ohio Express Company drove to the express station of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad this morning the wagons of the Adams Company were found driving away, having unloaded into the car which the Baltimore and Ohio Express officials expected to use.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 1.--The charter recently granted here for the Moosic Mountain and Carbondale Railroad is in the interest of the Erie Railway, and, when the new road is completed, it will become an important part of the Erie system.

The First Hussars, the only cavalry organization in the city, ate their first banquet last evening at Delmonico's. The members of the troop, which is soon to become duly incorporated in the National Guard, were dressed in picturesque uniform, booted and spurred.

VICTORIA, British, Columbia, March 1.-- The Legislature to-day suspended the rules and passed a bill to meet the emergency at Vancouver. The bill virtually suspends the city's charter and vests all power in the Legislature.
CHICAGO, March 1.--Although stricken of health and suffering severely from a fall he got in Washington a short time ago, Gen. B.F. Butler's mind and bank account are unimpaired.
CHICAGO, March 1.--The poisoning of another woman, making five in all, is to-night alleged against Lawrence Krug, who lies in the county jail suspected of murdering three wives and a stepdaughter.

ALBANY, March 1.--The annual report of Willis S. Paine, Superintendent of the Banking Department, relative to the savings banks and trust companies of this State, was transmitted to the Legislature to-day. It is a long document, covering 47 pages of type, and gives an exhaustive review of the operations of the savings banks during the year 1886, with many suggestions which will prove of practical value.

Miss Bessie Byrne is like the first Napoleon, of whom an orator once said: "Grand, gloomy, and peculiar, he sits a sceptred hermit, wrapped in the solitude of his own originality." Miss Byrne is nothing if not original. She appeared yesterday afternoon at the Union-Square Theatre in "Leah, the Forsaken," before an audience that was dumb with astonishment at her work. Sometimes people have wondered why Leah was forsaken.
BOSTON, March 1.--Henry T. Thomas, the "dead man alive" in the insurance conspiracy case of the United States Accident Association...

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., March 1.--The stockholders of the Mill River Button Company, of Leeds, voted to-day to put the concern in the hands of Trustees and close up the business. The company was incorporated in 1874 for the manufacture of vegetable ivory buttons. It was reorganized about a year ago by a voluntary assessment of 25 per cent., and employed over 150 hands. A new company will probably be organized.
The sale of trotting stock, comprising the Walnut Grove Stud, the property of the estate of Alden Goldsmith, began yesterday at the American Horse Exchange, under the auspices of P. C. Kellogg Co.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 1.--The will of William L. Douglass, a prosperous and prominent business man of Hackettstown, was admitted to probate here to-day. After devising $3,400 to relatives and $200 each to the Presbyterian churches of Mendham and Basking Ridge, the residue of his estate is divided between the Boards of Home and Foreign Missions of the Presbyterian Church. The value of the estate has as yet not been ascertained.

DANVILLE, Va., March 1.--The sales of leaf tobacco in this market since October amount to 9,030,176 pounds, at an average price of $8.88 per hundred, as against 13,485,711 pounds during the corresponding period last year, at an average of $10.26 per hundred.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 1.--One hundred and seventeen students of Roger Williams University, an institution situated near this city, and under the management of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, asked the Faculty to grant them an honorable dismissal on account of troubles of long standing.

Argument was heard yesterday on the application made to Judge Brown, in the United States District Court, by Johnes, Benner Wilcox, attorneys, for a writ of habeas corpus in the case of Robert B. Richard Braunschweig and Adolf Schenck, the Anarchists, who, with Johann Most, were last year sentenced to imprisonment on Black well's Island, were released yesterday morning, having served out their terms. They were taken across to the foot of Fifty-second-street.

There has for the past 10 days been in session in this city one of the most important railroad committees that ever convened in this country. It was organized on Saturday, Feb. 19, in pursuance of a resolution passed the day previous by a meeting of railroad representatives, held at Commissioner Fink's office.

LONDON, March 1.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. George Howell, member for Bethnal Green, an advanced Liberal, asked the Government to assent to the appointment of a committee to inquire into corrupt expenditures by the Corporation of London on bogus meetings, the audiences at which were hired to be present, for the purpose of defeating the bill for the reform of the London Government.

The three women who had such a terrible experience in a burning tenement house on Bloomfield-street, Hoboken, late Monday night, were reported to be recovering yesterday. They were Mrs. Margaret Doody, her daughter, ...

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 1.--The meeting of the conference committee of the American Racing Association, which was to have been held in this city today, has been postponed until March 15. The postponement is due to the absence of Col. Charles Greene, of the St. Louis Jockey Club, who is a member of the committee.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 1.--There was a frightful accident at Loudenville Station, on the Fort Wayne Road, this morning. A young man named Bender, son of a wealthy farmer, was driving a team of horses across the railroad track. Just as the horses approached the track the express train ...
Contract deliveries of grain, particularly of wheat, were very large on the Produce Exchange yesterday.

The fourth of the Thomas Popular Concerts took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The programme was not weighty, but was of an interesting description. The soloist of the evening was Miss Adele Margulies, an ambitious and hard-working pianist, who has of late been making some advance ...

Since the beginning of the new series, the Princeton Review has printed, as its leading article, several very noteworthy contributions. Mr. Lowell's essay on Gray and Charles Eliot Norton's Carlyle paper are among them. Another such paper appears in the March ...

BERLIN, March 1.--The split between the New German Liberals and the Socialists here is becoming pronounced. Herr Krueger, the Socialist leader, attends New German Liberal meetings and reproaches the Liberals for failing to adhere to the compact against the Government.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, March 1.--The Mayor and the Board of Public Affairs to-day gave final approval to an ordinance which will reduce the price of gas in Cincinnati for the next 10 years from $1.70 to $1.25 per 1,000 feet, with 10 cents per 1,000 discount for prompt payment.

Officer William Maloney, of the Fifteenth Precinct of Brooklyn, was a prisoner in Justice Massey's court yesterday, charged with attempting to assault Wilhelmina Rasenan, who is employed as a servant by Mrs. George Tartter, ...

ROME, March 1.--The American Bishops take a favorable view of the organization known in the United States as the Knights of Labor. Cardinal Gibbons has placed before the Vatican a formal statement as to the nature of the organization and the attitude which the church should adopt toward it.

The third and last of Herr Seidl's symphonic soirees took place at Steinway Hall last night, and it attracted a very large audience. If any disappointment was felt at the substitution of the "Eroica" for the promised Rubinstein symphony it was not indicated in the proportions of the assemblage or in its temper, which was decidedly enthusiastic.
In February, 1877, the customs receipts at the port of New-York were $8,287,435.51. The receipts for the same month for 10 years show the steady growth of the port's business.

ALBANY, March 1.--The Pitts bill giving women the right to vote in cities has been lying very close to the top of the heap, ready for passage, for several days. Mr. Erwin and other friends have allowed it to keep dropping down out of sight, for a great many Assemblymen have been absent, and it is realized that the bill will need all the votes it can get.

Braun, composing the firm of Marshall Lefferts Co., manufacturers of galvanized iron at 90 Beekman-street and 495 Cherry-street, made an assignment yesterday to James H. Fay, giving preferences amounting to $42,000. Mr. Lefferts has been in the metal trade for many ...
Steamship Knickerbocker, Kemble, New-Orleans 5 ds., with mdse. and passengers to Samuel H. Seaman.
Herr Anton Schott will give the first of two "song recitals" at Steinway Hall on Saturday afternoon.

Relief to the extent of $15,000 came to Constructor Pook yesterday, and the big force of men discharged a week ago will resume work in a few days. Several vessels in need of immediate repairs are lying in the yard.

A conference of the clergy of churches on the west side above Fourteenth-street and in Rockland, Ulster, Orange, and Sullivan Counties was held yesterday morning in the parochial school attached to the Church of St. Michael, on West Thirty-second-street. In the absence of Archbishop Corrigan the Right Rev. Mgr. ...
Sherman S. Rogers, of Buffalo, is at the Windsor Hotel. Dr. R.I. Gatling, of Hartford, is at the Hotel Normandie.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 1.--Gov. Lounsbury to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of William O. Seymour, of Ridgefield, to be Railroad Commissioner to succeed John W. Bacon, whose term expires this year. Mr. Seymour is an engineer and was for nine years chief engineer of the New-York and New-Haven Railroad.

DENVER, Col., March 1.--For some months past very hard feeling has existed between the citizens of Leoti and Coronado, two small towns in Wallace County, Kan., over the location of the county seat. The seat of the County Government is now ...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1.--Prof. Perrin lectured at A-de-lbert College this evening on the nature and origin of Greek tragedy, and afterward the College Glee Club sang in Greek the entrance chorus to OEdipus, as set to music by Prof. J.K. Paine, of Harvard.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 1.--One of the most hotly contested city elections ever known here occurred to-day. Republicans elected Gen. W.W. Henry Mayor by a majority of 215 over Alderman E.M. Sutton, Democratic candidate. The Democrats re-elected City Judge Hare and one out of five-Aldermen.

BRUSSELS, March 1.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Frere Orban, leader of the Opposition, opened an attack upon the Government's military policy, especially the projected fort works on the Meuse.
MAYSVILLE, Ky., March 1.--Moses Daulton Brothers' livery stable burned to-day, consuming 50 buggies and 13 horses, including one animal valued at $4,000. Total loss, $20,000. Insurance, $2,000.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1.--The Reading Railroad reorganization Trustees to-day received from Drexel Co. and Brown Brothers Co. reports of the deposits, at par value, of $109,252,646, out of the aggregate of $122,891,505, of the stock and securities of the company, which were requested to be deposited under the reorganization plan. Hercules L. Kittson sat in the Supreme Court yesterday with bowed head and clasped hands. There was nothing about him to suggest his illustrious mythical namesake, with the exception of his name. He is 25 years old.

The Academy of Music property, at Irvingplace and Fourteenth-street, was sold at auction, in the Real Estate Exchange yesterday, by Adrian H. Muller Son. Peter F. Meyer was the auctioneer, and when he climbed into the stand he faced such a crowd of big read estate buyers as to make him think the bidding would be brisk and first class.

ALBANY, March 1.--The Court of Appeals to-day decided that William S. Andrews, John Van Glahn, and Charles H. Woodman are the legal Excise Commissioners of New-York City. Nicholas Haughton, John J. Morris, and William P. Mitchell, who were confired Commissioners by the Board of Aldermen in May, 1883, questioned their right.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 1.--The steamer Gaelic, Capt. pearne, from China and Japan, via other outbreak of lava from Mauna Loa. All the craters were in a state of great activity when the steamer left Honolulu.

MOBILE, Ala., March 1.--The steamer W. H. Gardner, one of the largest boats plying on the Tombigbee River from Mobile, was burned this afternoon, three miles below Gainesville, Sumter County, Ala. PARIS, March 1.--In the Chamber of Deputies to-day Premier Goblet proposed a credit of 1,000,000f. for the relief of the earthquake sufferers.

CHICAGO, March 1.--The total shipments of dead freight from Chicago and common points through to seaboard ports by the eight pool lines last week amounted to 42,785 tons, against 36,307 tons for the week previous, an increase of 6,478 tons. This increase is entirely due to the heavy grain shipments caused by the very low freight rates now being made by most of the lines, and the prevailing low prices on grain.

The Police Commissioners, at their meeting yesterday, held another long and animated discussion in relation to the vacancies among the Inspectors and Captains. Commissioner McClave called up the resolution offered by Mr. Voorhis at the last meeting.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J. March 1.--It is stated here that another chapter of prison horror at Trenton will soon come to light, equal to that of the Laverty trial, of the same nature, and involving one of the under keepers.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 1.--Superintendent Stacey B. Opdyke, of the Northampton Road, who was recently convicted in the city court, with Assistant Superintendent William H. Wallace, of the Consolidated Road, for conspiracy ...

WASHINGTON, March 1.--The House met at 10 o'clock to-day, and, on motion of Mr. Belmont, of New-York, the Senate amendments to the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill were non-concurred in and a conference ordered.

The story of the murder of Antonio Cignaradi by his wife Chiara, which occurred in broad daylight at One Hundred and Tenth-street and First-avenue, was told again yesterday in the Court of General Sessions. Italian witnesses testified as to Chiara's following her husband down the avenue with a cocked rovolver.

The Paine will case entered upon an interesting phase yesterday when the claimant, John H. Wardwell, was called to the stand. He proved a fluent witness in his direct examination, but rather disappointed the large audience by his demeanor after he had been turned over to Judge Russell's tender mercies.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1.--The annual election of the Cleveland and Columbus Railway Company, the Bee Line, will take place to-morrow. None of the Vanderbilts will be present, but Chauncey M. Depew and others of their party are here.

Mr. RANDALL has met with a severe check in the House. We have already explained by what means he had managed to keep up the tradition of his authority and to defeat the will of the majority in the management of business.
