SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 1.--The Court of Appeals handed down a decision to-day which gives a new trial to Father John F. O'Sullivan, the "silenced" priest, who was convicted in June, 1886, of having committed a criminal assault upon his servant.

WASHINGTON, March 1.--Paymaster T.S. Thompson has been ordered as a member of the Board of Appraisement at the Washington Navy Yard. Lieut. James K. Cogswell has been detached from ordnance instruction at the Washington Navy Yard and ordered to duty as Inspector of Ordnance ...

ITHACA, N.Y., March 1.--At the charter election held here to-day D.W. Burdick, Republican, was elected Mayor. Three Republican Aldermen were also elected, which gives the board to the Republicans for the first time in five years. The Republican candidate for Recorder was also elected by a majority of over 100. The Republicans are very jubilant, and banquets and jollification meetings are being held to celebrate the downfall of Democratic misrule here.

If a man did not possess a vigorous sixfoot stature and an energetic one-hundred-andeighty-pound physique it would have been unwise for him while within hitting distance of the Brunswick banquet hall last night to have uttered any flippant remarks without selecting their object with great discrimination.

TRENTON, N.J., March 1.--Ex-Judge Shipmen, counsel for Janitor Titus, the slayer of Tillie Smith, presented an application to the Court of Pardons today for a commutation of the death sentence to imprisonment for life. The petition was numerously signed, and bore the signatures of some members of the Legislature. The court agreed to hear counsel on the subject on March 15.
LONDON, March 1.--The Inman Line steamship City of Chester, Capt. Lewis, from New-York Feb. 19, for Liverpool, passed Brow Head at 10 o'clock to-night.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 1.--Jacob Brown, (colored.) formerly a porter for the Housatonic Railroad Company in this city, but lately a bootblack, to-night, about 11 o'clock, shot his wife three times with a revolver at his home in Fairfield-avenue. He then made his escape.
BOSTON, March 1.--Manager John B. Schoeffel said to-night that Mrs. James Brown Potter had not signed a contract with the firm of Abbey Schoeffel.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 1.--John Smith, Treasurer of Jackson Township, has been missing since Friday, and his property was attached to-day on suspicion. He had considerable money, including township funds, when last seen, and his friends fear foul play.

The gloom in the cabin was thicker than the snow on the deck of the Dauntless yesterday morning. The dainty foam flyer, with her nightcap still on her binnacle and the robe de nuit unremoved from the wheel, lay placidly at anchor, a surplus of snow and a lack of wind having put the trial trip out of the question.

Gen. The Bar Association of this city is engaged just now in trying to determine whether it should recommend to the Legislature the lot or the block system of indexing as the basis upon which to build a reform in the methods of transferring title to land.

Yesterday occurred the death of Alexander Robinson, the well known circus owner and showman, at his home, 64 Whitesborough-street. Mr. Robinson was a native of Schenectady, and at the time of his death was 75 years of age.

BERLIN, March 1.--Buefer's new opera "Merlin" was produced here to-night. It is a great success. A sensation was caused by the refusal of the management to admit the pianist von Bulow to the theatre, though he was provided with a ticket. This action is attributed to the new Intendent, in revenge for von Bulow's spiteful criticism of the management of the theatre.

Through the co-operation of Mayor Hewitt, Acting Mayor Beekman, Public Works Commissioner Newton, and Corporation Counsel Lacombe, a bill has been drafted under which, if enacted, the work of constructing electrical subways and of compelling telegraph, telephone, and electric light companies to place their wires therein, will be placed in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment and the Commissioner of Public Works.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 1.--This morning all street car drivers in the city struck for $1.50 per day of 16 hours. They have been getting for some time $1.15. Three cars are running under police protection. There has been no violence offered.

LONDON, March 1.--Dispatches received here from Sofia say that the troops of the garrison of Silistria revolted yesterday evening and pronounced against the Regency. Troops are marching to Silistria from Rustchuk, Varna, and Shumla to quell the mutiny.

William P. Grovesteen has sent to the New-York Stock Exchange an open letter, taking the ground that that body should control its own stock quotations.

CHICAGO, March 1.--Timothy J. Wright, a former millionaire of Chicago, now living in NewYork, filed a bill some weeks ago against Thomas Lyman, a relative by marriage, for an accounting.
ROME, March 1.--Riots have occurred in Sardinia, arising out of the threatened failure of two workingmen's savings banks. The Government has sent experts to examine the books of the institutions.

The large room at Clarendon Hall was crowded last evening with unregenerate Anarchists, who had assembled to welcome their fellow-rebels against society and order, Braunschweig and Schenck, who were released Tuesday from the penitentiary, where they had been sent for inciting to riot and murder. At least 50 policemen in citizens' clothes were scattered among the crowd.

The furnishing goods store of Benjamin Bernstein, 791 Broadway, was entered by burglars early on Tuesday morning. One man climbed over the wire gate in front of the door and broke a large pane of glass in the front door.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--The Senate at 1 o'clock proceeded to the consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill. The first material amendment reported by the Committee on Appropriations was the insertion of an item of $12,000 for repairs of the naval training station, Coaster's Harbor Island, near Newport. It was agreed to.
The Jersey Central Directors met yesterday and elected J.R. Maxwell in place of R.S. Hays.

READING, Penn., March 2.--The marriage of Edward H. Stout, of Philadelphia, and Miss Kate Kerper, of this city, was celebrated this evening. The ceremony took place at the residence of the bride's parents. Mr. Stout is the son of Paymaster Stout, of the Reading Railroad.

A man, afterward identified as Charles Jimenez, of 133 South First-street, Brooklyn, accompanied by three others, entered the drug store at 58 Broadway Tuesday morning and bought court plaster, which his companions placed over a wound on Jimenez's scalp.

DETROIT, Mich., March 2.--There is a furious boiling of the political pot to-day consequent upon the failure of fusion yesterday. Subsequent to that event there was a good deal of "speaking out in meeting" in both conventions, and no little joy and relief expressed that the hateful and unnatural association was at an end.
ADELAIDE, March 2.--The South Australian Parliament has been dissolved. VIENNA, March 2.--Dr. Schmit von Tavera, the new Austrian Minister to the United States, left to-day for Washington.

Gentlemen high in the councils of the railroads thronged Commissioner Fink's office yesterday morning. Presidents, Managing Directors, Vice-Presidents, General Traffic Managers, and General Freight and Passenger Agents, representing most of the larger and more important roads east of the Mississippi, kept the two elevators busy, and when they were ready to begin their deliberations it taxed the utmost resources of the office to accommodate them.

A stated meeting of the Board of Education was held at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, all of the Commissioners being present. A communication was received from the Superintendents of Schools setting forth that under existing laws it was not legal to reduce their salaries.

The young woman who dropped in the waiting room of the Pennsylvania Railroad station, at Jersey City, Saturday, and has been in the City Hospital since in an unconscious condition, regained consciousness at 4 P.M. yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2.--No bill which has been introduced at this session of the Legislature seems to be so little understood and to have been the cause of more widespread misinformation as the bill of the Public Education Department establishing a system of uniform examinations for teachers and granting them State licenses.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 2.--Two men named Burhaus and Cragen had an encounter with a catamount near Brown's Station, in the Catskill Mountains, to-day. After a severe fight the animal was killed. This is the first large catamount that has been killed in the mountains in a number of years.

Yates Ferguson, one of the California pioneers of '49, died yesterday of heart disease at his residence, 52 West Twelfth-street. He was born in Westchester County in June, 1823. He returned from California in 1853. For some years past he has been engaged in exporting California wines and fruits. He leaves one daughter. His funeral will take place at his mother's residence, at Purdy's Station, to-morrow afternoon.

WHEELING, West Va., March 2.--William O'Neill, aged 26 years, is lying dead at the county hospital with four balls in him, the result of attempting to meddle with another man's wife--a former sweetheart. The shooting occurred at Elm Grove, a suburban village, about 4:30 P.M.

Much indignation is expressed by the members of the Ladies' Health Protective Association, of this city, over the introduction in the Senate by Senator Cullen of the bill which was defeated a year ago in the Assembly. The bill requires the Health Board to designate between Ninety-fifth and Ninety-seventh streets, First-avenue and East River, a spot where stable manure may be dumped.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 28.--Gen. J.J. Finley was to-day appointed by Gov. Perry as United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the expiration of Senator Jones's term on March 4.

ROME, March 2.--A severe shock of earthquake was felt to-day in Reggio di Calabria. Two slighter shocks occurred at Diano-Marino. The people fear further disasters because of the excessive heat and the fact that the sea has not returned to its ordinary level.

Mary Leaver, 52 years old, was carrying a lamp in her residence, 347 Lorimer-street, Brooklyn, last evening, when it exploded. The burning oil set fire to her clothing and burned her so severely that before an ambulance arrived she was burned to death. The fire did $1,500 damage to the building, which Mrs. Leaver owned.

The New-Jersey Kennel Club will hold its third bench show of dogs on March 22 to 25 at the Metropolitan Rink, Newark, N.J. The entry books will remain open until March 8, instead of closing on the 5th inst., as at first announced.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 2.--The Senate to-day adopted the minority report on the bill submitting to a popular vote the proposed constitutional amendment prohibiting the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquors, and also passed the bill on its final reading.

CORONA, Long Island, March 2.--Walter Hanan, of Church-street, Flushing, aged 22, shot and instantly killed himself at 8:30 this evening at his home. It is thought temporary insanity is the cause. He leaves a wife. Coroner Fetchner has been notified.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 2.--Mrs. Valentine Baker, an aged woman living alone in East Hempfield Township, was found on the floor of her residence this morning burned to a crisp. Her clothing is supposed to have caught fire from an exploded oil lamp.

The second of the series of three concerts of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place last evening at Steinway Hall, and proved, like the first entertainment, a very welcome addition to the season's outpour of musical refreshment. The Commencement exercises of the Long Island College Hospital attracted a large audience at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last evening, who listened to addresses and saw 30 young doctors receive diplomas. It was the twenty-eighth Commencement of the institution.

For several days unprecedented snowstorms have been raging over a great part of Spain. The frost has been so severe that the thermometer fell 10 below zero. In Catalonia the railway traffic was blocked for three days by the snow.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 2.--To-day the memorial of the Republican members of the General Assembly protesting against the election of Judge Turpie was presented and adopted. It is addressed to the United States Senate and is quite long.

BERLIN, March 2.--The second ballots for members of the Reichstag in the districts where candidates failed to receive majorities took place to-day. The contest in each district is between the two candidates who received the highest number of votes in the original polling. Returns from Lubeck and Waldenburg are as follows: In Lubeck Tebling, (National Liberal,) 7,206: Schwartz, Socialist, 5,200. In Waldenburg Websky, National Liberal, 10,980; Eberty, New German Liberal, 10,825.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--Sardou's "Fedora," the strongest drama written in recent years, with Sarah Bernhardt as the heroine--a character unquestionably suggested by the eccentric French actress's remarkable skill in the simulation of conflicting passions--presents a combination of ingenuity, constructive and dramatic eloquence that is not likely to be equaled on the stage within the knowledge of playgoers now living.
Apart altogether from the character of the result reached yesterday by the Legislature of New-Jersey, it is most gratifying that a result has been reached.
At the meeting of the Young Men's Democratic Club, on Monday evening, an objection to high license was referred to which has scarcely been mentioned in the newspaper discussions of the subject.
George Riggs, one of the old dry goods commission merchants, died yesterday at the age of 59.
HAVANA, Feb. 26.--Mr. Vanderbilt's steam yacht Alva has been in the harbor during the past week and has been visited by numerous residents, who were permitted by the owner to inspect the vessel.

TRENTON, N.J., March 2.--The Republicans compassed the defeat of Leon Abbett for United States Senator soon after 5 o'clock this afternoon. Thirty-seven of them agreed to vote for Rufus Blodgett, and Speaker Baird, with Assemblymen Kinney and Throckmorton and Senator Chattle, all of the Democratic Party, agreed to do the same thing. Forty-one were sufficient to elect, and as these men kept their word Blodgett was chosen.
TOULON, March 3.--The French frigate Iphigenie took fire here to-day and was scuttled and sunk in the roadstead.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, March 3.-- Miramichi, by which name the district including the northern counties of this province is known, is helpless in the grasp of snow. It is piled up to the second-story windows of houses in Newcastle and Chatham, the two principal towns.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 3.--Judge Fontaine J. Fox, a prominent lawyer of this city, was nominated for Governor by the Prohibition Convention here today. A ticket embracing all of the State offices was placed in nomination. Fifty counties were represented at the convention.

OMAHA, Neb., March 3.--Edward Kuehl, 69 years old, was found lying dead in a bed at 319 South Tenth-street early last evening. Kuehl was a well known and eccentric character about Omaha. He was a shoemaker by trade, but made a great deal...

The investigation of Brooklyn's City Government will begin at 10 o'clock this morning in the Common Council Chamber, at the City Hall, and Col. Bacon's Assembly committee will assist Messrs. Parsons, Goodrich, and Shepard, the lawyers, in overseeing the work.

The passage of the Field Civil Code in the Assembly yesterday was a triumph of enlightened ideas over prejudice and stolid conservatism, of reason over musty traditions, and--pace, Post--of the modern reforming spirit over the fetich of the common law.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 3.--Deputy Collector Frank Harding, of the Sixth Division, with headquarters here, has just discovered a remarkable case of long continued infraction of the internal revenue laws, and has reported the matter to the department at Washington for action.
BOSTON, March 3.--In the United States Circuit Court to-day an important motion was filed by the officers and counsel of the Bell Telephone Company in the case of the Government against that company.

WASHINGTON, March 3--.Senator Blackburn early this evening went to Baltimore to attend a dinner party given by President Garrett, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3.--When ex-Gov. Abbett was informed last evening that in the Republican caucus yesterday 37 out of the 38 members solemnly declared that under no circumstances would they ever vote for him for United States Senator he was surprised. "Why," said he. "I did not know the Republicans had such a personal feeling against me. How do you account for it?"
It is not surprising to find a majority of the "Knights of Labor" Representatives in the Legislature voting as the Gould lobby dictates. It generally happens that way.

BOSTON, March 3.--A ridiculous farce was acted at the City Hall to day, when a joint special committee of the City Council met to investigate very grave charges against Superintendent of Bridges Young.
BOSTON, March 3.--Employes of Bowker, Torrey Co., extensive marble workers, to the number of 300, have struck. It is understood that the cause of the strike is the employment of non-union hands.

DETROIT, March 3.--The Hon. Emil Breitung, who succeeded the Hon. Jay A. Hubbell for one term as member of Congress from the Lake Superior District of this State, lies hopelessely ill at Eastman, Ga., whither he had gone on account of his health. A telegram this evening states that he is lying in an unconscious condition and cannot possibly live beyond a few hours.

Officer Bruen, of the Newark police force, found two men fighting on the street Wednesday night and arrested them. One of them gave the name of Adolph Weideman, and said he was an agent for the Prudential Insurance Company.

DENVER, Col., March 3.--A Wallace (Kan.) special to the News says: The situation in the Coronado-Leoti war remains unchanged. Both towns are surrounded by a strong cordon of armed men, who permit no one to enter.

The County General Committee of the United Labor Party met last evening at Clarendon Hall, and spent a great deal of time in adopting various resolutions. Delegate Augustus Levy jumped up with a set of resolutions attacking Mayor Hewitt.

The funeral services of the veteran fireman, Zophar Mills, were held yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Church of the Covenant, corner Park-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, of which he had long been a member.

It does not require a microscopic eye to detect a strong and active market in real estate. Agents not only report lively times, but anybody can scent a mild sort of boom who seeks an interview with them. He will be a lucky visitor if he does not have to wait his turn.

TRENTON, N.J., March 3.--Anthony Comstock had his attention attracted to an advertisement last September; and he sent $2 to John A. Wilson, of the "Globe Publishing Company," at Paulsborough. N.J. Comstock wrote over a fictitious name from Tannersville, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, March 3.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day;

Charles Strahle, a well known freight broker and member of the Produce Exchange, spent yesterday and last night in the Tombs. Ho was arrested on a charge of forgery, and will be given a hearing this morning.

An explosion occurred in the sitting room of the Pennsylvania Railroad ferry house at midnight last night, and the building caught fire. The flames were soon extinguished. A tramp who came out of the room just after the explosion was arrested on suspicion. It was learned that the explosive was some sort of a liquid in a small glass bottle. The bottle was blown to pieces.

The coopers' strike extended somewhat yesterday, when the men left those shops in which the employers were given time to fill orders on condition that in the meantime they would not supply Jones Co. with barrels.

Louis Tronchet, the French fencer, left Paris some months ago and went to London. While in the English metropolis he was shown various American papers containing accounts of the skill of Regis Senac as a fencer, and dwelling upon the fact that he was the champion swordsman of North and South America.

Our esteemed contemporary the Herald amazed the community, and especially the Roman Catholic part of the community, yesterday by publishing what purported to be a report to the Propaganda by Cardinal GIBBONS touching the "Noble and Holy Order of the Knights of Labor."

ALBANY, March 3.--Assemblyman Eugene Semmes Ives, of New-York, is the greatest man in Albany at this present moment. The Governor's nominatton of yesterday dwindles into insignificance beside an act of Mr. Ives which marks this as the greatest day of his young life.

PHILADELPHIA, March 3.--Special Master Dallas to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court his audit of the account of the Receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Com pany for the month of January.

Signor Cappa and the Seventh Regiment Band filled Steinway Hall with the clamor of brass last night when they gave a farewell concert to Mme. Isidora Martinez, prior to her departure to South Amirica. The audience was of a fair size and a kindly disposition.

ROCKLAND, Me., March 3.--This place is disturbed over the proceedings of a mysterious incendiary, one of two fires occurring each week. Since July 9 of last year some 20 incendiary fires have occurred in the northern part of the city, all within a radius of half a mile.

The General Term of the Supreme Court has decided that Jonn Nugent, who was tried and acquitted of complicity in the Manhattan Bank robbery, shall nave the $1,100 which after several contests a jury awarded him as his pay as policeman while he was continued in the Tombs awaiting his trial for the robbery. The Policee Commissioners refused to pay him and he resorted to legal proceedings. He is now in the New-Jersey State Prison.

A "To Let" sign has been hanging from 37 Monroe-place, Brooklyn, for several days. This is an unusual thing in that neighborhood, one of the most fashionable on the Heights, and has set the residents to discussing the cause.
The sale of the collection of paintings by William M. Chase at Moore's art gallery, on Fifth-avenue, was completed last evening. The collection brought $8,646, making an average of a little over $90.

CHICAGO, March 3.--The report of Cardinal Gibbons to the Propaganda in reference to the Knights of Labor created quite a sensation among the leading Catholic Knights of Labor here.
CINCINNATI, March 3.--For a month the Ohio River has been so high that it has been impossible to get at the pumps in the water works,

PORTLAND, Me., March 3.--There is another hitch in the settlement of the Coburn estate which will prevent the immediate payment of $50,000 to the Maine Insane Hospital, $100,000 to the Maine State College, $150,000 to the Colby University, ...

DETROIT, March 3.--The Trustees of Kalamazoo College have elected the Rev. Monson A. Wilcox, Pastor of the Baptist Church at Oswego, N.Y., to the vacant Presidency of that institution. It is expected that he will accept, and that he will enter upon his duties July 1 next. The salary was fixed at $2,500.

The day's proceedings in the Cleary trial yesterday in the Court of Oyer and Terminer began with the prosecution's peremptory challenge of John J. Prince, the fifth juror in the box. Seventeen talesmen underwent the ordeal of examination before a juror was found to fill the empty chair.

WASHINGTON, March 3.--The Senate reassembled as in continuation of yesterday's session at 10 A.M. A motion to take up the Washington Cable Railway bill was negatived. At a few moments before 11 o'clock the Senate closed the legislative day of Wednesday by adjournment, and at 11 opened the last legislative day of the Forty-ninth congress.

BERLIN, March 3.--The new German Reichstag was opened to-day. The Emperor's speech was read from the throne. In it he says he is gratified at the benevolent disposition the Pope has shown toward the empire.
There will be an exhibition of billiards and pool playing by A.M. Frey and J.L. Malone this evening at the St. George Hotel.

WASHINGTON, March 3.--Mr. Hoar, of Massachusetts, is to-night a very much disgusted Senator. As Mr. Ingalls has said, there is nothing in the rules or precedents of the Senate requiring Senators to confine their remarks to the subject before the body, and Mr. Hoar took advantage of that fact.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 3.--The local freight business of the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railway is paralyzed here and at Youngstown by a strike of yard brakemen. Superintendent Staler held conferences to-day with the men at both points, but nothing was accomplished, and orders have been given to pay...

Ferdinand Jahn sold out his bar and restaurant at 531 Broadway to W.J. Lathan six months ago, and afterward opened a produce store at 837 Washington-street. This was closed a month ago, and yesterday an attachment was granted against Jahn's property.

The Assembly Rooms of the Metropolitan Opera House were crowded with ladies yesterday from 3 till 7 o'clock, the occasion being a Kaffee Klatsch given in aid of the free library of Orange, N.J.

CHICAGO, March 3.--The litigation involving the Illinois Central's claim to the harbor front of Chicago came up before Judge Gresham to-day, and he was about to give it his attention when a somewhat sensational incident occurred. GREENVILLE, Miss., March 3.--The water is running over the levee at Gaines Landing, Ark., with a very swift current. This will probably overflow a large portion of the secion of low lands from Bayon Mason to Tensas River. No breaks have so far occurred on either side of the river, and the levees on the Mississippi side are in excellent condition, and high enough to hold all the expected water.

Cornelius N. Bliss called the attention of the Chamber of Commerce to the subject of high license at its meeting yesterday. NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 3.--Several days ago the Supreme Court decided that all druggists were liable for the retail liquor dealers' tax for the sale of liquor during the past five years. The amount due the State under this decision is $500,000. The House to-day passed on its final reading a bill to relieve the druggists from this tax, and it is believed the Senate will also pass the bill.

LOCONIA, N.H., March 3.--Philbrick R. Loveitt died here to-day, aged 91 years. His military history dates back to 1814, when he was stationed at Fort Constitution, Portsmouth Harbor, and he remembered when the English fleet was lying off that point threatening the devastation of the town.

"Faust" will be given by the singers of the National Opera Company at the Metropolitan Opera House to-night. The production of Gounod's opera by this organization has been praised in other cities for completeness of ensemble and pictorial impressiveness.
BALTIMORE, Md., March 3.--Mr. Robert Garrett gave a dinner this evening to Messrs. George W. Childs and A.J. Drexel, of Philadelphia.

Dr. D.A. Currie, of Englewood, N.J., said last night that the Rev. Mr. Ward's wound was suppurating nicely at latest examination, and that his recovery might now be safely predicted. Col. Jameson, who is Chief of the local police, said he had authoritative information to the effect that Mrs. Ward's friends intend pressing the case against the Rector.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 3.--A man named John Murphy recently went to board with Samuel Belt, and made love to Mrs. Belt so effectually that she consented to elope with him. Mrs. Belt, her two children, and Murphy started to drive from the house yesterday, but Belt, whose suspicions had....

To-morrow Andrew G. Curtin retires to private life. The grand old man has outlived most of those who made up the noble band of war Governors, and now stands almost alone, like a towering oak whose forest mates have been felled. He will be long remembered by a grateful State and nation--for what he did 25 years ago.

The liquor dealers of the Twentieth Ward held a mass meeting at Mallon's Hall, on West Thirty-fourth-street, last night to protest against the High License bill now before the Logislature. and to organize against the pool brewers. Of the 600 dealers in the ward about 100 were present.

MONTREAl, March 8.--Word has been received here that on Tuesday last a large gang of men, together with two engines and a snowplow, was caught in a snow slide at Selkirk. Six of the men were smothered before they could be got out.

DETROIT, March 3.--The Directors of the new American Trotting Association to-day elected J.H. Stiner, of Philadelphia, Secretary and M.L. Williams, Cashier of the Commercial National Bank of this city, Treasurer. The next meeting of the association was ordered to be held in Chicago in 1889.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 3.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 23 cents, telegraphic, 30 cents.
The greatest stand of lithograph printing ever put up is now on the big boards around Madison-Square Garden. Strobridge Co. have been working on it since last October, night and day.

A remarkable feature of the hatting business is that it is rapidly scattering over different parts of the country. Three years ago there were but 11 places where fur hats were made. In addition to these we now have Yonkers, Matteawan, Newburg, Fall River, Haverhill, Bridgeport, and a shop in South Jersey, as well as one in St. Louis, Mo.
WARRENTON, Va., March 2.--The venerable ex-Gov. William Smith, now in his ninetieth year, is lying critically prostrated from extreme debility at his home at Warrenton.

Timothy Quinn, of District Assembly 49, of the Knights of Labor, and Thomas Shaw, representing the Reading and Philadelphia Railroad, held a meeting yesterday at the Astor House and drew up an agreement that the pay of the coal handlers should be 22 cents an hour.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 3.--A morning paper says: "Philadelphia capital has gone to Chicago again seeking investment. A gigantic syndicate has been formed for the purchase of the gas works of that city.

PHILADELPHIA, March, 3.--The management of the New-Jersey Central system has inaugurated a sweeping retrenchment of expenditures, and employes whose sevices can be dispensed with are being discharged by wholesale.

BOSTON, Mass., March 3.--The Hon. C.J. Brooks, as counsel for Mary Murphy, has brought suit against the Central Vermont Railroad Company for $20,000 damages for personal injuries received in the late accident on that road. The case is set for the April term of the Superior Court of Suffolk County. It is probable that the company will have the case removed to the United States Circuit Court and make of it a test case.

A year ago Gov. HILL appointed Quarantine Commissioners and a Health Officer for this port to succeed incumbents of those offices who had been holding over-after the expiration of their terms for three or four years.

TROY, N.Y., March 3.--What promises to be a remarkable and protracted contest of a will began in the Surrogate's Court to-day. Phillip Karner, a recluse, died Dec. 8 last in a mansion owned by him in the town of East Greenbush.

NYACK, N.Y., March 3.--The members of the Rockland Driving Park Association are forming plans for a lively season this year at the park, and at their annual meeting, held in the Kensington Hotel.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 25.--"When you get to Montgomery I'll bet you hat that the first thing the natives do for you will be to march you up to their Capitol Hill and show you the spot where Jeff Davis was sworn in as Confederate President, and when you've seen that you've seen all there is in Montgomery."

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3.--John D. Spreckels Brothers, agents for the Oceanic Steamship Company, to-day received a cablegram from New-Zealand saying that steamers carriying Australian mails would in future leave England one day earlier than hitherto. The departure of steamers for Australia from this port will therefore occur one day earlier, and the Postmaster at New-York has been nitified to that effect.

BOSTON, March 3.--The insurance conspiracy case of the Mutual Accident Association, of NewYork, ended to-day with a verdict of guilty as to Mrs. Leonard and Frost and a disagreement as to Bray.

The Brooklyn detectives continued their efforts yesterday to solve the mystery surrounding the disappearance of Maggie Kueblein, but without result. Whether the girl is alive or dead is still unknown.

Sixty of the butter and Cheese merchants of this city who have combined to put down the adulteration of cheese held a meeting yesterday at the New-York Mercantile Exchange, corner of Harrison and Hudson streets. William H Duckworth presided, and among the others present were Assistant Dairy Commissioner Van Vaikenbureh, John A. Willett, George P. Douglass, John Guth, W. Winsor, M. Folsom, and John A. Smith.

The first matinee, of a series to be given at Chickering Hall, by George W. Morgan, the organist, and Miss Maud Morgan, harpist, took place yesterday afternoon in the presence of an audience that quite filled the house.
MOBILE, March 3.--Beebe McCaw, the colored boy who is the hero of the Gardner disaster, reached here this afternoon. He is a bright mulatto, 19 years old.

LINCOLN, Feb., March 3.--A convention of delegates from Nebraska branches of the Irish National League of America met in the Opera House in this city this afternoon, for the purpose of organizing a State league. Two hundred Irishmen were present. Patrick Egan presided.

The whaling crews from Amagansett, which were successful in killing a large cow right whale Tuesday afternoon at East Hampton, Long Island, were unable to move the carcass of the monster yesterday. It had sunk to the bottom of the ocean in 20 fathoms...
PHILADELPHIA, March 3.--The Board of Street Railway Presidents to-day decided to reduced fares from 6 to 5 cents on all lines. The reduction will go into effect on Monday next.

A Frenchman bearing an illustrious name and rejoicing in the possession of an ancient title of nobility visited this country a few years since. He acquired some literary fame as the author of a book of travels in the United States. His manners were those of the ancien regime.

WASHINGTON, March 3.--Lieut.-Col. Edward Collins, Seventh Infantry, now awaiting orders at Milton, Mass., has been ordered to duty in the Department of the Platte; Major Edward Molae, First Infantry, to report by telegraph to the commanding General, Department of California, for assignment to station.

WASHINGTON, March 3.--Chairman Curtin, of the select committee created by the House of Representatives to inquire into the cause and extent of Western railroad strikes, to-day submitted the report of that committee.

MEDINA, N.Y., March 3.--Mrs. Sol Snell, one of the pioneer women of Orleans County, aged 86, used a piece of paper to light her pipe. The blazing paper in some way set fire to her apron, and she was almost instantly enveloped in flames. She was fatally burned before friends could extinguish the fire. She lingered several hours in terrible agony.

Copies of the petition in favor of the Crosby High License bill may be obtained at the offices of the Church Temperance Society, Annex Hall, 16 Fourth-avenue. It is important that they be largely signed and promptly forwarded to the above address.

ERIE, Penn., March 3.--Trouble broke out anew to-night between the warring railroads, the Lake Shore and the Pennsylvania Companies, and a riot is imminent at any moment. While the companies with 100 men a side were engaged in a violent contest for possession of the disputed track the Sheriff dropped upon the Lake Shore with an injunction.
BOMBAY, March 3.--News received from Afghanistan through native sources shows that the Ameer is making strenuous efforts to raise a new army.

MONTREAL, March 3.--The action to annul the election of the Board of Directors of the Montreal, Boston and Portland Railroad was heard before Justice Tascherau this morning. The first witness examined was Mr. George F. O'Halloran.

SOFIA, March 3.--The loyal troops of the Shumla garrison have suppressed the revolt at Silistria. The engagement was brief and almost bloodless. The insurgents occupy the citadel at Rustchuk, and are shelling the loyalists in the barracks.

Commissioner Fink's office was again the centre toward which railroad officials were drawn yesterday. Almost as may of them were there as on the previous day, when the report of the Freight Classification Committee had been received.

LONDON, March 3.--In the House of Commons to-night Mr. Dillon, commenting on the vote of 30,000 for the Irish police, pointed out that the claim was in addition to the $62,500 already voted for the police for extra pay and traveling expenses.

The Executive Committee of the Liquor Dealers' Association met yesterday afternoon at the store of Bode Brothers, at Sixth-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street, and received reports from the liquor dealers' organizations in various Assembly districts. In the First, Second, and Third Districts the associations were being strenghtened by the accession of new members.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 3.--George W. Kidd, of New-York, owner of the International Distillery here, has issued orders to the Superintendent to stop buying grain and to see that the amount on hand is disposed of either by consumption or sale by June 1. Mr. Kidd says he will close the distillery at that time, and not attempt to operate it further under the prohibition law. This closes the last distillery in Iowa.

ERIE, Penn., March 3.--The investigation of the charges of mismanagement and cruelty preferred against the management of the Soldiers and Sailors' Home is in progress. The charges were of the most aggravated nature and implied treatment which was inhuman. Capt. Burkert, a discharged inmate, who made the charges, failed to appear and his winesses exonerate the management of the home.

BUFFALO, March 3.--The week of February 14 Manager Hill's Margaret Mather Company did not fulfill its engagement at Boston because, as it was stated, the actress was tired out by a season's hard work and needed rest. As has been learned, Miss Mather spent that week in this city, and did something besides resting.

Many people who say they felt curious shakings and heard rumbling noises and saw buildings swaying on Long Island Wednesday afternoon have been discovered. It may be noted that most of them have all been discovered since the papers published accounts of the earthquake.

"The March mystery of Madison-square" is what Capt. Williams, of the Nineteenth Precinct, calls his latest sensation. He refers to the attempted assassination of George Condit Smith, son of the late Col. J. Condit Smith, briefly reported yesterday.

The Excise Commissioners yesterday transmitted to the Police Commissioners a list of 641 liquor dealers who hold licenses signed by Nicholas Haughton and John J. Morris, and issued by them as Excise Commissioners from May 3 to July 7, 1886, and which the present board have decided not to recognize as valid licenses.

The parlors and stairways at 4 Lexingtonavenue were filled with a throng of ladies and a sprinkling of oldish men last night when the regular monthly meeting of the New York City Woman Suffrage League was called to order.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 3.--Among the callers at the Governor's office this morning was Mr. J.H. Lester, of Henry County, an old gentleman 117 years of age.

PORTLAND, Me., March 4.--The opinion has just been receiced from the Supreme Court of this State refusing the discharge in insolvency to John Winslow Jones.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 4.--Levi Books, aged 40 years, living in Elizabeth Township, near the line of Lebanon County, was shot and instantly killed this morning by a woman named Mary Goshert. BUFFALO, N.Y., March 4.--Margaret Mather's marriage seems to have been as much a surprise to her family as to the public and the profession and probably Manager Hill. Her mother was interviewed at her home in this city to-day, ...

INDIANAPOLIS, March 4.--The Baseball Association to-night elected Louis Newberger, Frank Bird, and John T. Brush delegates to attend the League meeting in New-York on Monday. Twentyone thousand dollars have now been subscribed, and it is hoped to make Indianapolis a League city.

The gross earnings of the Illinois Central Railroad Company for 1886 were $12,529,493 15, a decrease from the earnings of 1885 of $91,770 89. The net earnings of the company for 1886 were $4,738,952 35, against $4,776,189 01 for 1885, a decrease of $37,236 66.

ALBANY, March 4.--Senator Dunham is the one New-York Senator who is outspoken against the practice of passing bills exempting property in New-York City from taxation. It is his belief that all kinds of property should bear their proportionate weight of the burden of taxation, and thus by its general distribution lighten the load now thrust on individual citizens.

FORT SMITH, Ark. March 4.--A report reached here to-day that James Fruin was killed in the Choctaw Nation Wednesday by one of his workmen. Fruin was a railroad contractor from St. Louis, and had large contracts on the Frisco Railroad, from Fort Smith to Paris, Texas.

A story was telegraphed to the afternoon papers from Louisville yesterday telling of the good luck of an Irish laborer of that city. He was represented as having fallen heir to $105,000, left by his uncle, Morris Purcell, of this city.

The great blemish on the record of the last session of the Forty-ninth Congress, which has just come to a close, is the treatment of the appropriation bills and the use made of them to obstruct and defeat legislation without reference to the will of the majority.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 4.--A phase of the litigation growing out of the settlement of the estate of the deceased millionaire, Walter H. Newberry, was referred for disposition to a Master in Chancery to-day. Edward H. Newberry was a remote connection of Walter H. Newberry, ...

OTTAWA, March 4.--The prevailing impression is that Mr. Blaine is at the bottom of the retaliatory measure, although his hand is scarcely visible. It is thought that the Retaliatory bill is nothing more or less than a Republican dodge which has been proposed to Congress ...

Robert L. Cutting's will, dated July 4, 1885, with a codicil dated Aug. 24, 1886, was filed for probate yesterday. The Executors are the widow, his brother, Walter L. Cutting, and his two sons, Robert L. Cutting, Jr., and Walter Cutting.

Roger Williams University is still in a condition of revolt. According to the Rev. Dr. H.L. Morehouse, Secretary of the American Baptist home Mission Society, which has control over the university, a final settlement of the breach now existing between the President, Dr. Stifler, and the Treasurer.

A cable dispatch received here yesterday announces officially that Mrs. James Brown Potter has signed a contract for an English and American tour. Her manager will be Mr. C.A. Chizzola, who managed Signor Salvini's tour in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 4.--The Forty-ninth Congress is dead, a thing of the past, and to most of its members the uppermost recollection of it is about a session 24 hours long, marked by a few public struggles, some disorder, a great deal of harmless chatting and noise, a suggestion ...
BERLIN, March 4.--Herr Wedell Piesdrof was to-day elected President of the Reichstag. He received 184 votes. Two ballots were cast for Dr. Windthorst and 99 were cast blank.
PORTLAND, Me., March 4.--Pneumonia is alarmingly prevalent in some parts of the State, and in the two villages in Sanford more than 40 cases are reported.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 4.--The State Supreme Court to-day rendered a decision to the effect that prisoners confined in the penitentiary at Jefferson City cannot be taken therefrom to testify in criminal courts. The point was raised by the attorneys for Messenger Fotheringham, who wanted Jim Cummings brought here to testify in the case of the Adams Express Company against their client.

The presentment of the February Grand Jury directs attention to a problem of great importance whose solution the city cannot long postpone. The buildings in the City Hall Park are not only inadequate for the accommodation of the courts and municipal departments, but at least one of them is unsafe ...

What appears to have been a conspiracy to destroy the Pennsylvania Railroad's property in Jersey City and one of their passenger ferryboats, the Chicago, was prevented yesterday by the timely discovery of the chemical agency employed and the arrest of the supposed culprit, undoubtedly a cat's-paw of the plotters, who were themselves too cowardly to "plant" the combustible compound.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 4.--The employes of the boot and shoe firm of N. Hess Brother to the member of 60 have gone on a strike because of the employment of a Mr. Hart as foreman, who has declared himself in favor of non-union labor.

PARIS, Ky., March 4.--Paul King, Cashier of the Farmers' National Bank of Cynthiania, committed suicide this afternoon by shooting with a pistol. The bullet penetrated the right temple. Bad health caused the act. He leaves a family in comfortable circumstances.

GREENFIELD, Mass., March 4.--Considerable excitement was caused here to-day by the announcement that Frank W. Foster, Town Clerk and Treasurer, is a defaulter to the extent of over $14,000. The Selectmen have been overhauling the Treasurer's books during the past ...

The absence of Col. John R. Fellows from the trial of Cleary has given rise to all kinds of stories around the Court House, clubs, and hotels. One is to the effect that while he was at Montreal during the carnival he was "squared" by Keenan and Moloney.

CHICAGO, March 4.--State Attorney Grinnell took to-day the first decisive step in his campaign against the county officials and contractors who have been furnishing the county with supplies at exorbitant rates by ...

A man, whose attire was that of a sailor or longshoreman, was drowned last night from the canal boat Swain, at Twenty-eighth-street and the East River. His body was picked up. In the pocket of his coat was an envelope addressed to "B.A. Shaw, care of Capt. C. Miller, 74 Pearl-street."

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 4.--A burglar, who evidently knew the combination, broke into the Adams Express office at Orville, Ohio, between 8 and 8:30 last evening, while the clerk was absent, opened the safe, stole $1,000 in money and two valuable packages and escaped.
OTTAWA, March 4.--Parliament has been summoned for the dispatch of business on April 13. The session will prove a short one unless the Opposition pursue an obstructive policy.
CHARLESTON, S.C., March 4.--The slight earthquake tremor felt here at 2:30 o'clock this morning was also felt at Summerville, Oakley, Midway, and at other points in Lower Carolina.

"Z.P."--The Post Office address of the jockey is Megowan-street, Lexington, Ky. The Class of '80 of the Normal College will have a reunion and dinner at Clark's, in Twenty-third-street, this afternoon, at 3:30.

The iron bark Argo lies on the rocks under Fort Picolet,at the entrance to the harbor of Cape Haytien. Other vessels have gone to pieces on the same rocky bar, but a special interest surrounds the Argo, for her loss was unnecessary.

A fire broke out shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday morning at "Linden Court." 690 and 692 Eighth-avenue. The "court" consisted of two four-story frame buildings, with a common entrance in the centre, and a four-story brick building in the rear.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., March 4.--The butter tub manufacturers of Vermont and Northern New-York held a meeting here yesterday afternoon and evening and organized for mutual protection.
CHARLESTON, West Va., March 4.--The Governor has drafted his proclamation calling an extrasession of the Legislature, and the copy is now in the possession of the Public Printer.

NEWPORT, R.I. March 4.--Daniel Watson, of this city, has developed an important project to shorten by one hour the time between New-York and Newport. His plan is to cut a channel through Conanicut Island at the Narrows, just above the point opposite Newport. A steamer then would make the trip direct from ...

ERIE, Penn., March 4.--The investigation of the charges of cruelty and mismanagement at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home was concluded to-night. Every charge, including the cruelty to inmates, had provisions, and jobbing on the part of the management, fell flat under the evidence of the men who were presented as witnesses to sustain the allegations against the management of the institution.

ALBANY, March 4.--It seems to be settled that ex-Senator James Arkell, notwithstanding the fact that he carried the flag of the Platt-Morton Republicans, in the Senatorial fight and employed the Albany Evening Journal in firing broadsides at the Miller column, will be given the cold shoulder by the Platt Senators.

The Emmet Club, of Brooklyn, celebrated the one hundred and ninth anniversary of Robert Emmet's birth last evening by listening to a discourse on "Illustrious Irishmen of a Century," by John Boyle O'Reilly, the distinguished poet and journalist.

PEORIA, Ill., March 4.--It is claimed that when his case comes up in the court the lawyers of J. Finley Hoke, the extradited bank forger, will plead that the United States Revised Statutes define the alteration of checks or drafts of a national bank to be a misdemeanor, and therefore the defendant must be released, because he was extradited for forgery, which is a crime and not a misdemeanor.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 4.--An east-bound Northern Pacific overland train ran against a broken rail near New-York Mills, between Perham and Wadena, Minn., this morning. Two emigrant and one second-class coach left the track. Three persons were injured. One sustained a broken shoulder and some of the others received scratches. The track has been cleared and the train was only five hours late.

The post-mortem examination of the body of Miss Fannie Briggs, who died at 45 Hoytstreet, Brooklyn, at 4 o'clock Monday morning, showed that the cause of death was meningitis, as the certificate of Dr. B.M. Briggs stated.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4.--The mass meeting of Harvard students called to-night to form a new league for baseball was the most lively and numerously attended mass meeting seen at Harvard for many years. The meeting was from the very outset thoroughly determined that Yale should not dictate terms as to the ...

Meetings for three days in succession proved too much for some of the out-of-town railroad managers who have been in New-York to got light on the probable effects of the Interstate Commerce bill, and the attendance at Commissioner Fink's office was smaller yesterday than on the two previous days.

Capt. Larkin, of the Princeton Baseball Club, and Mr. Holden, of Harvard, visited Mr. S.C. Herriman, President of the Columbia College Association, Thursday evening, and made a proposition to form a league of Columbia, Harvard, and Princeton, and to invite Yale to join.
Congressman-elect Wilber is seriously ill at his home in Milford. His illness is the result of overwork in the recent campaign, and his friends have considerable anxiety over his condition.

The New-York State Academy of Veterinary Science and Comparative Pathology held a meeting last evening at the United States Hotel. The Secretary read a draft of a set of resolutions which has been prepared for presentation to the Legislature.

LONDON, March 4--The steamship City of Berlin, (Br.,) Loud, from New-York Feb. 23, for Liverpool, arr. at Queenstown at 12 o'clock to-night. The National Line steamship Helvetia, Capt. Cochrane, from New-York Feb. 17, for London, was reported off the Lizard March 2, at 11 P.M.
Ex-President Davis and his daughter, Miss Minnie, will acoompany the Vicksburg Southrons to the Washington drill.

The Bacon Assembly committee, which is going to investigate matters municipal in Brooklyn, held its first session yesterday. This was held in the Common Council Chamber, in the Brooklyn City Hall, and was to have begun promptly at 10 o'clock.

CHICAGO, March 4.--The Rev. P.M. Donohue, a young Catholic priest of Arcola, Ill., who has charge of the churches of that denomination both at Arcola and Tuscola, has just been created by Gen. Boulanger, the French Minister of War, a Lieutenant in the French Army for services rendered.

TROY, N.Y., March 4.--Reports have been printed to the effect that the body of Mrs. Druse had been taken to the Albany Medical College. A resident of Troy, who is a student at a college, says that about a month ago the body of a woman was brought from New-York to be dissected for ...
The shooting match between the South Side Gun Club, of Newark, and the Elizabeth Gun Club took place yesterday at the South Side Club's ground, in Newark.

MONTREAL, March 4.--The Canadian Pacific Railway Company have chartered three steamers for the service between Vancouver, Japan, and Hong-Kong. The service at first will be monthly, but will be fortnightly if business warrants. The Parthia will leave Hong-Kong early in May, the Abyssinia in June, and the Batavia in July.

A memorial service in honor of Gen. John A. Logan will take place in the Brooklyn Academy of Music Tuesday evening. MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 4.--Information obtained from steamboat men shows a bad state of affairs down the river between this city and Arkansas city. In this district hundreds of men, mostly white laborers, are engaged on levee work for the Government and the State of Missippi.
Miss Anderson will revive Dean Milman's "Fazio" during her Spring tour in England. "Aida" will be sung at this afternoon's matinee performance at the Metropolitan Opera House.
PORTLAND, Me., March 4.--Thus far the special committee of the Legislature to ascertain the cause of the outbreak of tuberculosis at the college farm has held two meetings.
A public meeting under the auspices of the Caledonian Club was held at Caledonian Hall, on Horatio-street, last evening, to express sympathy with and take steps to aid the Scottish Crofters.

CHICAGO, March 4.--The General Managers of the various Western, Southwestern, and Northwestern roads have been in session at Commissioner Abbott's office, in this city, for the last three days considering the General Passenger Agents' report regarding the application of the inter-State commerce law upon the passenger affairs of those roads.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 4.--It was announced in chapel this morning at Iowa Colloge, Grinnell, that the Rev. George A. Gates, of Upper Montclair, N.J., had by a letter just received accepted the Presdency of that institution, recently tendered him.

SOFIA, March 4.--The Government authorities have placed under arrest 30 persons, including M. Karaveloff and M. Tsapoff, who were found to be in communication with the insurgents at Silistria and Rustchuk.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 4.--The members of the Joint Schedule Committee of the National League and American Baseball Associations met at the Neil House this morning, and were in session all day. The object of the meeting is the arranging of a schedule so as to avoid conflicting dates as far as possible.
George M. Pullman, of Chicago, is at the Victoria Hotel. Gen. E.P. Alexander, of Georgia, is at the New-York Hotel.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 4.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following cases were argued: No. 90--William J. Syms, etal., Executors, appellants, vs. Mayor, , of New-York City.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 4.--The fifty-second annual parade of the New-Orleans Fire Department took place to-day. The absence of floral and millinery decorations was conspicuous, the parade being made up of steam engines, horses, and men. There were 25 companies in line, each averaging 40 men and 5 horses.
ST. LOUIS, March 4.--The George K. Oyler Manufacturing Company made an assignment this afternoon to N.O. Nelson. The assets of the company are estimated at $80,000 and the liabilities at $70,000.

Preparations advanced rapidly on the Coronet yesterday, the crew being steadily at work all day. The squaresail yard came down in the afternoon, and a large part of the stores were taken on board, and the expectation was, last night, that the yacht world leave the docks this afternoon at high tide and be towed down to Owl's Head.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 4.--News of the passage of the Grand Tower Bridge bill by Congress reached the offices of the St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas Railroad to-day, and there was much rejoicing over the result.

Two "sawdust" swindlers, "Sam" Hess, who goes by the name of Hays, and Adolph Saunders, were before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday for examination. They were arrested late the night before in handsomely furnished rooms at 221 West Fortieth-street.

Mr. Henry E. Abbey returned from Washington last evening and perfected arrangements for Mme. Patti's appearance in opera at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The expiration of the stove contract at Sing Sing Prison on Monday last deprived more than seven hundred convicts of employment. Since that time nearly all of these men have been locked in their cells the greater part of each day.

Andrew Fogarty and Stephen Coleman two leaders in the riots started at South Amboy by the striking coal handlers, were arrested yesterday and sent to the county jail to await the action of the Grand Jury.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 4.--In the State Circuit Court to-day the case of Edward Harland, Receiver of the American Rapid Telegraph Company, against Edward S. Stokes and the Receivers of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company, was remanded to the Common Pleas, the Circuit Court refusing to confirm the sales of tho Rapid lines to Stokes under foreclosure.

CHICAGO, March 4.--Another twist was given the screws in the great pork deal to-day, and the price was lifted from $19 at the opening to $21. Trading was very light and the bidding up of prices was done wholly by the shorts in the efforts at settlement.

Three times yesterday the jury box in the Cleary trial was filled, and three times the defense used the peremptory challenge, and when the court adjourned, after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, there was still one empty chair, and the panel and the spectators were exhausted.
The Baltimore Sun of yesterday contained an apparently inspired cablegram from Rome to the effect that trustworthy information had been received at the Vatican that Dr. McGlynn would come to Rome.

The United Clan-na-Gael of New-York and Brooklyn celebrated in the Academy of Music last evening the one hundred and ninth anniversary of the birth of Robert Emmet. The Academy was tastefully decorated with flags and bunting of many hues, and the entire house, including the stage, was crowded with Irishmen and their families.

The Directors of the Ladies' Health Protective Society met yesterday afternoon at the residence of Mrs. M.J. Herbert, 215 East Fortyeighth-street, to discuss Senator Cullen's bill regulating the removal of refuse from city stables. Thirteen ladies were present, and Drs. Alexander Hadden and J.C. Peters appeared as representatives of the County Medical Society.

Some time ago Edgar Weeks, of Yorktown, Westchester County, had his wife, who was suffering from consumption, placed in the County Almshouse. Three days ago he was notified that she was dying.
VIENNA, March 4.--Dr. Schmit von Tavera, the new Austrian Minister to the United States, has postponed his departure until the 19th inst.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 4.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 25 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

The flour trade is somewhat exercised over a London project to establish in Rio Janeiro a flour milling company, with a capital of 500,000. No flour is at present milled in Brazil, for the excellent reason that there are no mills there. American vessels from the ports of NewYork, Baltimore, and Richmond carry out cargoes of flour to Brazil.

On warrants issued on indictments for false pretenses, by Recorder Smyth, the police yesterday pricked the bubble known as the British-American Claim Agency, which was snugly established in a well appointed office on the fourth floor of the Stewart Building, at Chambers-street and Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4.--The Reading management to-day gave notice to all concerned that, on the day the Inter-state Commerce law goes into effect, all special contracts and rates inconsistent with its provisions will stand revoked on its entire system.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 4.--The Examiner announced to-day that Senator George Hearst has transferred the proprietorship of that journal to his son, William R. Hearst.

LYONS, N.Y., March 4.--A verdict in the action of Miss Louise Correll against Frank A. Riley, of Huron, for $10,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, was rendered this morning. It gives the plaintiff $350.

The Ladies' Meridian Club met yesterday morning at the Hotel Brunswick. This club has a limited membership of 30, and the ladies meet regularly for the purpose of discussing a luncheon and, incidentally, subjects of permanent and current interest.

Mayor Hewitt braved the dangers of yesterday's doubtful weather by venturing out, and, for the second time since his election, visited his office in the City Hall. He was bundled up in a plaid shawl of Scotch wool, and was driven from his house to the City Hall Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4.--The strike of the employes of the Sutter Geary-Street Cable Car Roads, which began four months ago and has led to several dynamite explosions and other criminal attempts to terrorize passengers on boycotted lines, has come to an inglorious end.

BERLIN, March 5.--The Reichstag will begin the debate on the Army bill on Monday. There are 221 Septennists against 176 opponents of the bill. This estimate supposes that 97 Centrists will adhere to the triennate, but when a division is taken it is probable that through Centrist-Septennist votes and abstentions the Government will obtain a majority of nearly 100.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., March 5.--A meeting was held here last night for the purpose of organizing a league of baseball clubs in Vermont and possibly in a portion of New-York State. Representatives from Rutland, Burlington, and St. Albans were present. After the complete organization of the Burlington association another meeting will be held for the full formation of the league.

READING, Penn., March 5.--The Farmers' National Bank of this city forwarded to the Assistant United States Treasurer at Philadelphia 23,000 trade dollars. That functary, when the dollars arrived, refused to receive them, and so telegraphed the bank. The trade dollars were then ordered to be deposited in the vaults of the Bank of the Republic. The five other banks of this city have 80,000 more ready for shipment.

FARMINGTON, Me., March 5.--The Grand Jury this morning reported indictments against the Maine Central Railroad for causing the death of Lawrence Garcelon, who was run over by an excursion train last Summer near North Jay.

LONDON, March 5.--The Red Star Line steamship Waesland, which went ashore on the Goodwin Sands, near Deal, while on her way to Antwerp from New-York, floated after throwing overboard 200 tons of her cargo. She has been towed to Antwerp.
NEWBURG, N.Y., March 5.--Fifty-eight employes at Hodges Co.'s brick yard, at Cornwall, have struck. They were getting $1 12 per day for nine hours' work, and demand $1 50 per day for ten hours' work.

Mr. Henry Cabot Lodge has finished with the ninth volume his edition of the works of Hamilton. A general index for the eight preceding volumes is in Vol. VIII., while to the present volume is given "The Federalist" with an introduction and index of its own.
ROME, March 5.--Prime Minister Depretis and his colleagues held a conference which lasted two hours to-day. It was decided to obey King Humbert's commands to resume their portfolios.

A strong effort will be made for a pardon, and all the letters say that it should be granted.

TORONTO, March 5.--Edward Hanlan, the oarsman, returned home from Boston yesterday. He will begin active training on Monday, proposing to walk 15 or 20 miles daily for about six weeks. He will draft articles for a race with Beach on Monday or Tuesday, and will forward them to the London Sportsman for approval. He does not know whether he will row more than one single scull race before leaving for Australia.

At the close of the first half of Mr. CLEVELAND'S term the country has a very distinct impression of him, and it is on the whole favorable. No President since Mr. LINCOLN has shown more evidence of independence of judgment and firmness of character.

PARIS, March 6.--It is semi-officially denied that Gen. Boulanger intends to visit the northeast frontier.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., March 6.--This was a dreary day in the Anderson cottage, near this village. Mary passed a fairly comfortable night, but was far more irritable than she has been before. She now enters her fifth week with the mysterious bullet in her brain.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6.--Two notorious burglars were caged by Chief of Detectives Kelly's men to-day. They are John Jenkins and Samuel Torrence, and their exploits are recorded in the criminal annals of nearly every large city east of the Rockies.

WAKEFIELD, Mass., March 7.--As the Portland express on the Boston and Maine Railroad was passing here this afternoon it struck two men named John Muse and John Shaw, killing them instantly. They were walking on the track. They lived in Reading, Mass., and leave large families.
TRENTON, N.J., March 7.--Both branches of the Legislature met at 8 o'clock this evening. The scenes were in strong contrast with those of last Monday evening.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 7.--The river here today stands 36 2-10 feet on the gauge, a rise of twotenths in the last 24 hours. This is the highest water ever known here, being two-tenths over the high water of 1882.

When Mrs. Sarah McComber died in Brooklyn, in 1869, she left a large estate, heavily mortgaged, to be divided among her daughter, Mrs. George A. Powers, and her two sons, George and Edward.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7.--Saturday's advance in wheat has been maintained. The rise of 5 cents per cental is believed to be permanent, and is due chiefly to the small quantity of wheat on hand and in the State, which at the present time does not exceed for export 3,000,000 bushels. There is a disengaged tonnage list in port for nearly twice that quantity.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 7.--This morning a negro named Alexander Crawford was lynched at Winona, Miss., for the murder of Victor Loggins, a young merchant of that town.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 7.--The City Council to-night voted to allow the Standard Oil Company to bring natural gas here, and to charge not more than 75 cents a thousand feet. Illuminating gas has been furnished by the old companies since Jan. 1 to the city at $1 a thousand, and to private consumers at $1 25.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., March 7.--This city is having another financial sensation, and, so closely following the embezzlement of Bookkeeper Grossman, it is the talk of the town.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 7.--The State Senate adjourned sine die to-night at 10:30 o'clock. The day had been a stormy one for the Democrats, and several times the session was interrupted to go into caucus.

Something about the Jersey atmosphere, foggy as it was, proved inspiriting for amateur boxers last night, and the thousand spectators who found seats in the Oakland Rink in Jersey City were almost ready to vote a gold medal to the Manhattan Athletic Club when the final bouts in the American amateur boxing championships were finished.

Six hundred pounds of nitro-glycerine, in process of manufacture into dynamite, at the nitre house of the Ditmar Dynamite Works in Bay Chester, exploded shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon. People living within a radius of the place thought an earthquake had occurred, so terrible was the shock.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 7.--Sight drafts on New-York, 25 cents; telegraphic, 30 cents.

LONDON, March 7.--A Conservative whip has been issued summoning members of the House of Commons to be in readiness to support the Government at the finish of the debate on the cloture to-morrow. The Parnellites and Radicals are concerting arrangements to have reliefs ready for a continuous sitting.

We are authorized to state that the Rev. Dr. James Freeman Clark's physician is still of the opinion that his state of exhaustion is caused by overwork, and that a season of entire rest will enable him, after a time, to resume a portion of his labors. Dr. Clark's health has improved somewhat during the last week.

One day more of ceaseless inquiry into the opinions of proposed jurors to try ex-Alderman Cleary, who labors under an indictment for bribe-taking in connection with the Broadway franchise, left the jury box still unfilled.

Mr. Beecher yet breathes, but that is all. There was no perceptible change in his condition yesterday from hour to hour, but between morning and noon and noon and night it could be seen that he waw sinking, growing slowly weaker, with a steady drain upon his vitality. How long he may last is beyond foresight.

The Inspector of Milk sets down onefourth of the milk dealers of Boston as professionally dishonest. The Inspector either draws a long bow or else he has got his hands full to take care of the rogues.

MADISON, Ind., March 7.--Dennis Noon, at 8 o'clock to-night, fatally shot his brother, Patrick, in the former's saloon on First-street, in the west end of the city. The weapon used was a 44-calibre pistol. The shooting was the result of a drunken quarrel.

MONTREAL, March 7.--Axel Paulsen, the Norwegian skater, has challenged Frank Dowd, the Canadian champion, to skate him in Christiania, Norway, next year from two to fifty miles for the championship of the world. Dowd is to be allowed $250 for expenses. He is by far the fastest rink skater in the world, but in a long track the chances will be very much in favor of Paulsen.
TORONTO, Ontario, March 7.--Hanlan has signed articles for a race with Beach on the Nepon River, in Australia, on Saturday, Nov. 26, 1887.

The redemption of trade dollars began yesterday at the Sub-Treasury, and all day long the silver came rolling in faster than the professional counters and examiners could take it. There is a vast deal of work attending the plan of redemption.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 7.--The situation between the officers and striking brakemen on the New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio Railroad is practically unchanged.

CHICAGO, March 7.--The report of the visible supply of grain on March 5, as compiled by the Secretary of the Board of Trade, shows a decrease of 1,840,000 bushels wheat, 400,000 bushels corn, 152,000 bushels oats, 15,000 bushels rye, and 189,000 bushels barley.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 7.--Gen Miles last night received a telegram from Capt. Lawton, stating that troops were encamped near Nogales, but that he anticipated no trouble. The Mexican authorities regretted the outrage committed by Lieut. Guitterez and the four Mexican soldiers, and have arrested all the offenders but one, and turned them over to the American civil authorities.
DUBLIN, March 7.--Mr. Balfour, the new Chief Secretary for Ireland, has arrived here.

MONTREAL, March 7.--The Hemmingford train on the Grand Trunk Railway due here at 8:30 o'clock this morning is not expected to arrive this evening, being blocked with snow. On the Canadian Pacific Railway the western train due here yesterday is expected to arrive to-morrow morning. The trains which arrived to-day were from 30 to 60 minutes late.
TRENTON, March 7.--The certificate of organization of the Southern cottonseed Oil Company has just been filed in the office of the Secretary of State.
GIBRALTAR, March 7.--Mr. Lewis, United States Consul to Morocco, has arrived here. He is awaiting an American war ship to convey him to Tangier.

Men, women, and children flocked to the prayer meeting in the lecture room of Plymouth Church last evening until every seat was occupied, and it was necessary to open the extension, which of late has not been much used. BOSTON, March 6.--The Board of Aldermen of this city has passed resolutions to examine the system of heating as operated by the New-York Steam Company, with a view to its introduction here. HUNTINGDON, Penn., March 7.--A general strike of miners in the Broad Top coal region was begun this morning. The difficulty this time is with the wages of the drivers, who demand the same amount of pay for nine hours' work as is paid in the Clearfield region for ten hours' work.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 7.--Something of a sensation was produced to-day by the announcement that P. FRANKLIN, Ky., March 7.--Dick Robertson, formerly a lawyer of this city, went to Tennessee in pursuit of his eloping daughter and her lover, Mr. Kline. He met them returning home after the marriage and began to abuse the young man for his conduct. Mr. Perdue, the groom's best man, took up the quarrel, whereupon Robertson knocked him off his horse with the butt of his gun, killing him instantly.
CHICAGO, March 7.--The recent bulge in pork which has caught the bucket shops so disastrously swamped two small Board of Trade firms to-day.
LANCASTER, Penn., March 7.--Executions aggregating $21,000 were issued this afternoon against Edward J. Zahm, a prominent jeweler of this city. His liabilities are heavy.
PITTSBURG, Penn., March 7.--Thomas Acton, of this city, enlisted in the regular army in 1884, and was assigned to duty at Fort Verdi, in Arizona.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 7.--The body of an unknown well dressed man was found in a hog pen on George White's farm in Rotterdam, about four miles from this place, last night. It is supposed that the man was frozen to death. When the pigs were fed yesterday morning the man was not in the pen. The remains were brought to this city today. They are not mutilated. Their is no clue to their identity.

CHICAGO, March 7.--The Underwriters' Association of Chicago, through its President, sent a telegram to the Metropolitan Underwriters' Association, of New-York, to-day, requesting the canceling of blanket policies on Chicago property.
Andrew Roos, of 417 East Seventeenthstreet is an agent of the French society which looks after the interest of French immigrants.
PORTLAND, Me., March 7.--The Hon. Charles J. Chapman was re-elected Mayor to-day. Elections in cities and towns of the State to-day generally show Republican gains.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--Gov. Hill may not be troubled with the "bee," nor making any effort to secure the Democratic nomination for President in 1888, instead of allowing it to go to Mr. Cleveland, but there are indications that he has at least some shrewdly directed friends at work in familiar ways.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 7.--Negotiations are in progress for the formation of a baseball league to include the clubs of Western Vermont and Northeastern New-York, and to be called the Northeastern Baseball League.

There is an urgent demand for the completion of public parks in the upper part of the metropolis. The Commissioners estimate the cost of completing Central, Riverside, Morningside, Mount Morris, and East River Parks at $1,000,000.

An item is going round the papers asserting that there will be no shad fishing in the Hudson above the Poughkeepsie bridge when it is completed, "as for some unexplained reason these fish will not pass under a bridge." Stuff! We have seen 200 fat and juicy shad drawn at one haul of the seine a dozen miles above the Connecticut River bridge, under which they had passed, probably that same morning.

A yacht race in March across the North Atlantic is a kind of contest that naturally excites popular attention. It is fair to say that the interest it creates is much stronger among those who know nothing about yachting than among those who know something about it.

Gen. Shaler, the deposed President of the Health Department, still held the fort at the department yesterday, apparently awaiting the arrival of his successor. He said that he had received the official notification of his removal at about noon yesterday, just as he was stepping out for lunch, and from that time he ceased to exercise any of the functions of the President of the Health Department.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 7.--The Supreme Court to-day rendered an important decision relating to the State debt settlement in the case of J.H. Wright against W.B. Bate.

WASHINGTON, March 7.--A general court-martial has been ordered to convene at Fort McDowell, Arizona, March 15, for the trial of Lieut. Alexander T. Dean, Fourth Cavalry. Col John S. Mason, Ninth Cavalry, is to be President, and Capt. John S. Bishop, Thirteenth Infantry, Recorder of the court.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--There is a controversy between the new Surgeon-General of the Army, Dr. Moore, and the Secretary of War, and the matter has been brought to the attention of the President on an appeal from Dr. Moore.
Throngs of ladies and gentlemen in evening dress attended the reception of the Nineteenth Century Club at the American Art Galleries in Twenty-third-street last evening.

Joseph H. Bradley, the Nestor of the Washington Bar, is seriously ill at his home in Georgetown, 1,517 Twenty-ninth-street. On returning from his office one evening last week he was taken suddenly ill, and botook himself to his bed, from which he has not risen since.

Paul Henri Feval, one of the most, prolific of modern French romance writers, died yesterday. He was born at Rennes, France, in 1817.
The memorial service held in the Brooklyn Academy of Muisc last evening in honor of Gen. John A. Logan brought together such an audience as that building has seldom seen.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., March 8--The schooner Anna E. Kranz sailed this morning in tow of the steam tug Seguin for Boston. When off East Chop the mate of the Kranz had his skull fractured and his nose broken while engaged in getting the anchor to the schooner's bow, and in consequence the schooner returned to the harbor. The mate was taken to the Marine Hospital here.

KINGSTON, Ontario, March 8.--The trotter Shooting Star and his driver left Gananoque on Saturday afternoon to go across the river on the ice to Clayton. They have not since been heard from, and the impression is that they have been drowned.

The accident on the elevated railroad at Fourteenth-street yesterday was not foreseen. If it had been it would very possibly have been provided against. To say this, however, is not to relieve the road of responsibility.

Little Miss Helen Dauvray, of the Lyceum Theatre, has excited in the breast of a slender Chicagoan a passion which she can never reciprocate. In fact, so certain was she that her feelings for the lover were anything but tender that she was forced yesterday morning to visit the Yorkville Police Court, and beg Judge White to protect her from love's importunities.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 8.--John H. Martin edits the New Mississippian at Jackson, Miss. He has lately returned from a visit to Washington, during which he made it his business to ascertain why there were not more Mississippians in the public service.
