MONTREAL, March 8.--A delegation of the leading members of the Board of Trade and Corn Exchange went to Ottawa this morning to urge the Government to reduce the canal tolls permanently, as otherwise Montreal would be out of the race for the carrying trade.

A miner in Leadville, Col., who can neither read nor write, is worth to-day at least $3,000,000. Four years ago he hadn't a penny except what he earned from day to day as a miner. His name is John L. Morrissey.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 8.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 20 cents; telegraphic, 27 cents.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 8.--The first commission appointed by the Supreme Court to appraise damages for land taken for the Poughkeepsie Bridge sat to-day, and considered what is known as the Elting homestead property, on this side of the river.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 8.--Mrs. Catharine Allen, aged 78, of Greencastle, has been for a long time confined to her bed with rheumatism. She weighs nearly 200 pounds. Yesterday, while being turned over in her bed, she fell to the floor. Both of her thighs were broken and she will die.

ALBANY, March 8.--The argument on the appeal in the New-York Broadway Railroad case was set down for to-day by the General Term of the Supreme Court, but Attorney-General O'Brien notified the court that he was not ready to proceed, and the case went over until the May term.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 8.--In the Senate to-day the House bill to prevent pooling by railway companies, providing for the punishment of railway officials violating the act by a fine of from $5,000 to $20,000 and imprisonment for from six months to twe years, was passed without debate. The bill requiring railway companies operation lines in Texas to give 30 days' notice of a reduction of wages was also passed.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 8.--Thomas Fogarty shot E.J. Kieffer four times on a crowded thoroughfare in this city yesterday morning, inflicting wounds which may prove fatal. Kieffer had caused Fogarty's arrest for using obscene language in the presence of his wife. After being released Fogarty purchased a pistol and fired on Kieffer when he met him near a drug store. Fogarty escaped.

ALPENA, Mich., March 8.--This morning at Carr Brothers' shingle mill, 12 miles north of here, the boiler blew up. Emory Carr was killed instantly and Waldo Carr fatally scalded. Eugene Carr was also badly scalded. The cause of the explosion is unknown. The mill was blown to pieces.

CHICAGO, March 8.--The General Managers of the various roads in the Central Traffic Association met to-day at Commissioner Blanchard's office to take up and consider the action taken by the joint committee in New-York regarding the establishment of through rates between Western association points and seaboard points; also to...

The deadlock in the Board of Police over the promotions to the vacant Inspectorship and Captaincies is broken at last. On Saturday Commissioner McClave sent for Mr. E.P. Wheeler, Chairman of the Civil Service Supervisory Board, and showed him Mr. Voorhis's...

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 8.--The local newspapers throughout the milk-producing districts of New-York and New-Jersey announce that the traffic in bob veal is carried on more extensively this Spring than ever before.

The report on the indigo season just closed describes it as one of special interest. The opening of the season was rather dull. Prices fell till about the middle of January, when they began to recover.

Surrounded by those who loved him best, and with no sign of pain, Mr. Beecher passed, quietly away at 9:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The end was painless to him, and those who attended him were spared the agonies that had attended their patient watch.

SCRANTON, Penn., March 9.--A rickety building at Olyphant, six miles north of this city, occupied by Hungarians and Poles, has long been regarded as a robber's roost, and was raided last night by the local authorities, who discovered a large quantity of stolen goods secreted there.

Coroner Rooney, of Brooklyn, was notified yesterday that it might be advisable to take the ante-mortem statement of Mrs. Pauline Hall, who is lying dangerously ill from malpractice at a boarding house, 53 Johnson-street.

LONDON, March 9.--Lord Hartington has offered the Government the solid vote of the 70 Unionists for the Irish Crimes bill. The opinions of his followers, privately ascertained, favored stronger coercion than the bill proposes.

A new kind of theatre party is coming into fashion, having first appeared since the production of "The Taming of the Shrew" at Daly's. It consists of young misses from 12 to 15 years old, who visit the theatre in charge of their teacher, the entertainment being offered them as a reward of merit.
DETROIT, Mich., March 9.--Chauncey Hurlbut, an old citizen and pioneer merchant of this city, died on Sept. 9, 1855, leaving property estimated at $250,000.

The Amateur Baseball League held a meeting yesterday afternoon at 51 Fulton-street to agree upon a schedule of games to be played during the ensuing season. This meeting was looked forward to with considerable interest by...
ALBANY, March 9.--The Pitts bill giving the right to women to vote in municipal elections was defeated by the Assembly to-day by a vote of 48 to 68.

The freight steamship Egypt, of Newcastle, England, which left this port for Lisbon with a cargo of grain, was abandoned at sea in a sinking condition on March 3. Her crew, consisting of 30 men all told, arrived in this port last evening on the bark Hannah Blanchard, Capt. Atkins, from Amsterdam. Capt.

The old and well known house of L. Levenson Co., wholesale dealers in clothing at 515 Broadway, failed yesterday. The partners, Louis, Michael, and Max L. Levenson, made a general assignment for the benefit of their creditors to David Davies, giving preferences for $56,470, as follows: Amelia Vogel, $20,470; Mechanics' National Bank, five notes, $25,000; L. Boscowitz, $11,000.

The limited train, known as the "NewYork and Chicago Limited," now running over the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad in connection with the Lake Shore Railroad, is made up exclusively of elegant drawing room cars and magnificently appointed sleeping cars, with a smoking car furnished with...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 9.--The stock, lease, and fixtures of the late dry goods house of Roll, Thayer, Williams Co., of this city, was sold to-day by the Sheriff to G. Bernheimer Brothers, Quincy, Ill., for $102,000. The business will be carried on by the new firm.

The mysterious middle-aged man who entered the police station in West One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street Monday night, and by request was sent to the Manhattan Hospital, where he was with difficulty saved from an overdose of morphine, caused great excitement in theatrical circles by falsely giving the name of John Templeton, the well known manager and...

PARKERSBURG, West Va., March 9.--The evidence in the case of the women Lucy Berry, May McAtee, and Louisa Russell, charged with the murder of Richard Miller, the Wood County merchant who disappeared so mysteriously a week ago, turned out to be very sensational, and implicates two men, James Rosier and John Barnes, in the crime.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 9.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the Hon. William C. Ruger, ChiefJustice, and associates present, the following causes were argued: No.255--The People, respondent, vs. Horn Silver Mining Company, appellant.--Argued by Julien T. Davies and Edward Lyman Short for appellant, D. O'Brien for respondent.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 9.--The mystery attending the unaccountable disappearance of Smith Calkins, a well known farmer of the town of Smyrna, is at length solved.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 9.--The funeral services over the remains of Mrs. Ruth Rogers Harmon, the widow of the late Elisha Harmon, of Wheatland, and grandmother of Mrs. Grover Cleveland, were held at the residence of George E. Harmon, a nephew of the deceased, in Churchville, seven miles west from Rochester, at 11 o'clock this morning.
Nathan Appleton, of Boston, is at the Albemarle Hotel. Congressman Robert R. Hitt, of Illinois, is at the Astor House.

While the Bacon investigating committee is looking sharply into special evils in the administration of the larger offices in Brooklyn, it is worth while to call attention to certain facts in the general service of the city which show the tendency that has prevailed there.

Julien T. Davies, Receiver for Grant Ward, has sent out circulars to the creditors of that deceased firm, asking them to send in their claims, in order that he may ascertain the exact amount outstanding against the firm, take account of the assets, arrange for a final distribution, and apply to the courts to be relieved from...
The Crosby High License bill is in a position on the calendar of the Assembly where it is liable to come up for consideration at any time.

The Atlanta and Charlotte Railway Company elected as Directors yesterday Eugene Kelly, P.P. Dickinson, James H. Young, Richard Irvin, Jr., R.A. Lancaster, H.W. Sibley, James E. Grannis, B.R. McAlpin, S. Wilmer, J.H. Williams, J.W. Brown, and W.N. Wilmer. H.W. Sibley was elected President, W.M. Wilmer Secretary, and George Sherman Treasurer.

The meeting of the Amherst Alumni, to take action on the death of Mr. Beecher, who was graduated in 1834, was held at the office of Elliot Sandford, President of the Alumni Association, 95 Nassau-street, and was well attended, considering the short and informal notice of the meeting. Mr. Sandford called the meeting to order.

The efforts of the Education Committee of the American Baptist Home Mission Society to bring about a reconciliation between the students of Roger Williams University, Nashville, Tenn., and their Treasurer, Theodore E. Balch, seem to have been successful.

BERLIN, March 9.--The Septennate bill was called up for second reading in the Reichstag to-day. Herr Stauffenberg's amendment proposing that the term of the bill be three instead of seven years was rejected by a vote of 222 to 23. Eighty-eight members abstained from voting. The Polish and Alsatian members were absent. The Socialists voted with the minority.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe sent an opinion to Gen. Newton, Commissioner of Public Works, yesterday, in reference to sidewalk obstructions, in which he says that the fact that the Common Council has authorized an obstruction in the streets does not in any way affect the duty of the Commissioner to remove the same if the Council had no power to grant permission therefor.

BAYPORT, Mich., March 9.--"Elder" Cornish, a Mormon, of Salt Lake, has been lecturing in this vicinity for several weeks. The Rev. John B. Davis, of the Methodist church, challenged Cornish to a debate.
The three hundredth performance of "Erminie" will take place at the Casino April 12. Mr. Anton Schott will give his second and last song recital at Steinway Hall this afternoon.

The taking of testimony in the contested will case of John H. Masterson, the wealthy contractor, who died leaving his estate to his wife. Augusta L. Masterson, while another wife, Mary Masterson, was living, was continued before Surrogate Lott, of Brooklyn, yesterday. The contest is made by nieces living in Albany.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 9.--Mr. Jay Gould has just put the merchants' bridge project asleep. If it wakes within the next month it will do more than its best friends expect. If it does not wake within a month it will not be heard from for another year. Mr. Gould has made no direct attack upon the project.

Coroner Eidman will begin an inquest next week in the case of the victims of the Third-avenue elevated road accident. The delay iscaused by the condition of some of the injured, who will be wanted as witnesses.

Last night's performance of "Aida" was a repetition of Saturday's representation, with the difference that the tempos that were most dragged at the matinee were taken at a somewhat quicker pace. The cast was the same as before, Mr. Candidus personating Radames, Mr. Ludwig Amonasro, Mr. Whitney...

DETROIT, Mich., March 9.--It was not until a late hour last night that the little squad of Greenback bosses in Grand Rapids broke up their meeting, and a mighty disgruntled and crestfallen set of chaps they were, too.

PORTLAND, Me., March 9.--By a vote of 9 to 1 the Railroad Committee has decided to report the bill allowing the International (the Megantic) to change its location at the foot of Moosehead Lake, but they have put on to the bill the condition that the International shall make and maintain connection with the Bangor and Piscataquis Railroad at Greenville (if the...

CHICAGO, March 9.--Mrs. Sarah E. Bromwell, widow of H.H. Bromwell, was declared to be insane eight years ago, but an order was entered in the County Court to-day declaring her to be sane and restoring her to her legal rights.
The seventh anniversary of the Home for Convalescents was commemorated yesterday afternoon by a meeting at the Fourth-Avenue Presbyterian Church, corner of Twenty-secondstreet.
ROME, March 9.--In an interview to-day Cardinal Gibbons said: "I am, and ever shall be, an enemy of a plutocracy of soul less corporations and men.

During the past week Col. Hafford added some 10 birds to his collection of the feathered tribes of Arizona, among which is a very rare specimen of the hawk family called "devil hawk" by the Mexicans. It is a bird of the handsomest plumage, at the same time it has a most ugly head and vicious talons, besides its beak is almost as sharp as a needle and nearly as strong as the largest hawk.

LANCASTER, Penn., March 9.--The trouble among the prisoners in the county jail came to an end this morning. Close watch was kept over the cell in which Green and Watson held the fort with their clubs ann revolvers until this morning, when they concluded to surrender, the starvation policy of the keepers proving too much for them.

CHICAGO, March 9.--Anarchist Oscar Neebe went out into the busy world this afternoon for the first time since his conviction nearly seven months ago. His wife died a day or two ago, and Sheriff Watson to-day permitted him to go and look upon her face once more and also meet his children.
OTTAWA, March 9.--Capt. Scott, Royal Navy, commander of the cruiser Acadia and Admiral of the fisheries protection fleet in the maritime provinces, has arrived here.

The Oxford Club of Brooklyn has just had its annual election, which, while harmonious, has caused considerable excitement among its members. Two tickets were in the field, one made up of the older members of the club, who are opposed to opening the bar on Sunday, and the opposition ticket of younger members, who want their drinks upon that day.

In the trial of the suit of ex-Assemblyman John Carey against the Manhattan Railway Company, in the City Court yesterday, before Judge McAdam and a jury, a verdict was rendered for the defendant. On Christmas Day, 1885, Mr. Carey got into a train at One Hundred...
LEXINGTON, Ky., March 9.--The interment of Mrs. Beck, wife of Senator Beck, took place at the cemetery this afternoon. The remains arrived from...

CHICAGO, March 9.--The General Managers and General Passenger Agents of the various roads in the Western, Southwestern, and Northwestern Passenger Associations have agreed to merge the three associations into one, to be known as the Western States Passenger Association.
Will "An Interested Party" please send name and address to THE TIMES office. The Armory Board yesterday decided to continue the lease of the Twenty-second Regiment Armory for one year.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 9.--In the Federal Court to-day Gen. George W. Russ and others obtained judgment against Count Joseph Telfener, of Paris, for $384,900 for non-fulfillment of a land purchase. Russ Co. in 1882 under the "Fifty per cent act," filed on a large tract of land in El Paso County, which they subsequently sold to Count Telfener at 75 cents per acre.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9.--The Court of Pardons will not decide the application of Janitor Titus for commutation of the death sentence till March 19. The friends of the condemned man have till the 15th to lay their case before the court, and then on the 19th the court will give its decision.

The trial of the case of Ellen McKewen against Nathaniel McKewen, in which the plaintiff asks for a separation on the ground of her husband's abandonment of her and their six children, was begun in the Superior Court, Special Term, before Judge O'Gorman yesterday.

The mind of Capt. Colt, of the Dauntless, was greatly relieved when he received on Tuesday evening the formal sailing notification from Capt. Crosby, of the Coronet. He immediately abandoned the trip to Bermuda, which his friends had proposed while the other yacht was getting ready, not that he loved Bermuda less, but that he wanted Queenstown more.

Matthew Richardson, a bricklayer, was working on a building in Franklin-street yesterday when Bartholomew Quinn, who said that he was the walking delegate of a bricklayers' union, asked to see his card. He replied that be had lost it.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 9.--It was anticipated this morning that Judges Brewer and Thayer would render a decision on the intervening petition in the Wabash case, so forcibly argued by Henry Crawford, and which at present shuts the Purchasing Committee out of possession of the road.

CHICAGO, March 9.--The Central Traffic Association met again at Commissioner Blanchard's office to-day to complete the work of harmonizing the affairs of the roads in the association after the inter-State commerce law has put an end to the present pool.
MADRID, March 9.--Advices from Ceuta, in Morocco, state that it is reported that the Sultan of Morocco has ordered the cutting of the cable between Tangier and Gibraltar.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9.--Catcher Deasley, of the New-York Baseball Club, who was reported as having been on a drunk last week, and while under the influence of fright occasioned by seeing water gushing from a hydrant hurling three cuspidors through the back window...
TRENTON, N.J., March 9.--The House by a unanimous vote to-day passed the bill to repeal the charter of the Morris and Essex Railroad.

The Panama Railroad Company has sued Elie Stacy Charlier, its bookkeeper at Aspinwall in 1885, and Clement Dupuy, then and there its cashier and auditor, to recover about $50,000 which, the company charges, they stole from it at one or more times during the Spring or Summer of 1885.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March 5.--A lady residing in Sevastopol, a suburb of this city, went to the well last evening after dark to draw a bucket of water, which she did, and, being thirsty, drank a dipperful at the well.

The sale of single tickets for the Bernhardt season began at the Star Theatre yesterday morning and lasted until a late hour last evening, thousands of seats being disposed of until with the sale of season tickets the advance sale now aggregates nearly $40,000, something almost unprecedented in the theatrical history of the city.

KINGSTON, N.Y., March 9.--At the coming sessions of the New-York Methodist Episcopal Church Conference in this city the district stewards of the Ellenville District will present a plan for the consolidation of all the districts on the west shore of the Hudson River.

Andrew D. White, ex-Minister to Germany, addressed the Republican Club of NewYork City last evening at 32 West Twentyeighth-street on the subject of "Municipal Reform." He said that municipal governments were the spots from which all corruption springs. The whole system here was wrong.

CHARLESTON, March 9.--Senator Sherman and his party reached Charleston at 3 o'clock this morning and remained here until 3 o'clock this afternoon, when they left for Savannah, whence they will go to Florida and Cuba.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 9.--The weather to-day was clear and warm. The track was heavy. Following were the events:

BENNINGTON, Vt., March 9.--The first liquor prosecution by the Bennington Law and Order League was concluded this evening, after a two days' trial. James T. Fitzgerald, the respondent, was found guilty by the Municipal Court of 135 offenses against the prohibitory law and was fined $1,350, with costs, and an alternative if not paid of three days' hard labor in the House of Correction, at Rutland, for each dollar.

S. Marks Co., of 107 East Sixtyfirst-street, own the tenement house 145 Thompson-street, which is inhabited by 20 Italian families. A woman named Chapini was installed as housekeeper, and the owners gave her a large number of receipts for rent signed in blank, as she was authorized to collect the...

FRANKFORT, Ky., March 9.--A short time since Capt. H.C. Milam, of this city, made a very elegant reel, which he sent to Senator Blackburn and Representative Breckinridge, with the request that they would present it to the President with the compliments of a Kentucky Republican, who loved him for the fish that he had caught. To-day Capt. Milam received the following letter:

ALBANY, N.Y., March 9.--The operatives at the Feary Shoe Factory here, numbering 325 men, struck work at noon to-day because the manufacturing company declined to accede to their demands for an advance of 10 per cent, on their old wages. President Feary's proposal to arbitrate the matter was not accepted by the Knights of Labor.

The Cleary trial lay at anchor yesterday in a wearisome calm. When Judge Barrett took the helm it was found that Howard Lockwood had been excused to celebrate his birthday in his domestic circle, and even if a jury had been secured the roll call would have had to be post poned until to-day.

The collection of paintings in oil numbering 75 and all the result of the artistic labors of Worthington Whittredge, N.A., during the past 20 years, was sold at auction last night at Ortgies's Art Galleries, 845 and 847 Broadway.

RAHWAY, N.J., March 9.--The result of the recent assessment levied by the Board of Directors of the Rahway National Bank culminated to-day at a meeting of the stockholders, when they voted unanimously to go into liquidation. A new bank will be at once organized under the State laws composed of Rahway capitalists.

The demand for sedan chairs, which has lately caused sevesral pecimens of these quaint old vehicles to be sold for several hundred dollars here in Boston, is a result of those aesthetic re-- vivals which, in certain circles, are more effective than revivals of religion.

Mrs. Louisa A. Greene, of Bay City, formerly the wife of Frank C. Begole, who died in1877, has brought suit against her erstwhile father-in-law, ex-Gov. Begole, to recover certain lands in Michigan and Wisconsin which were deeded to the father by the son when the latter was on his deathbed and on being urged that such step was necessary to protect his wife and children.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 9.--News has been received from a lonely farming community on Cats' Fork, in Lawrence County, of terrible tragedy. Samuel Smith, aged 16, who had some difficulty with a neighbor, Stephen Hammond, yesterday, armed himself with a revolver and went over to Hammond's, following him into the house.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 9.--The SubCommittee on Congressional Apportionment, appointed last evening by a caucus of the Republican members of the House from Philadelphia, met this afternoon and agreed upon a basis of apportionment of that city into Congressional districts.

Two alarms were sent out last night for a fire which broke out on the top floor of the fourstory building 47 Mercer-street, occupied by S. Fleisher Co., manufacturers of fur trimmings, and before the flames were extinguished the third and fourth floors were burned out and the lower floors deluged with water.

MONTREAL, March 9.--The French Canadian Board of Trade, at a meeting held this afternoon, resolved to hold an international congress in Montreal during the first week in June. Invitations are to be sent to all the American and Canadian Boards of Trade to send delegates...

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 9.--The election of the Faculty of the new Law School of Cornell University took place at Ithaca to-day. Following is the corps of instructors: Charles K. Adams, President; Judge Douglas Boardman, of the Supreme Court of New-York, State Dean; Harry B. Hutchins,

READING, Penn., March 9.--Frank Bridegam, 16 years of age, who, with a friend, was returning home this evening from the country, was run down and killed by an engine on the tracks of the Reading Railroad a short distance below this city. His companion escaped injury.

ST. JOHN, N.B., March 9.--The failure of the Maritime Bank was largely precipitated by the failure of Mr. Schofield, a ship owner. This is the bank's second failure in a few years. The bank originally was established by James Dornville, an ex-member of Parliament, and his friends.

James E. Quinn, Master Workman of District Assembly No. 49, of the Knights of Labor, in addressing a mass meeting of the United Labor Party that met last evening in Bartholdi Hall, in Greenpoint, to champion the rights of the Rev. Dr. McGlynn and to denounce Archbishop Corrigan and the Roman Cardinals who had undertaken to sit down upon that reverend gentleman,

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 9.--Mr. E.J. Baldwin returned to this city to-day and was shown the dispatch from Memphis, Tenn., containing the conditions proposed by J.D. Morrissey in his reply to Mr. Baldwin's challenge made to James Murphy, Mr. Morrissey's trainer, for a race between the latter's Montana Regent and Mr. Baldwin's Volante.

Only one thing was talked about in Wallstreet yesterday; only one thing was thought of. But there was neither measure nor limit to the thought and the talk on that one subject. For Wall-street was made a very hurly burly by the news that THE TIMES gave of the practical sale of the control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
Judge Allen, in the Special Term of the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday, granted a new trial in the suit of Mrs. Anne Forestal against Mrs. Juliet Drury, Bartley Green, and Thomas Reilly.

MANCHESTER, March 9.--The Guardian in its commercial article says: "The market is firm and strong, checking progress in several departments where quantity is concerned. The demand for India is exceedingly poor and will not be materially improved by a moderate concession by producers.

A year ago Harvey C. Malcolm was a barkeeper of the St. Denis Hotel and his most intimate friend was Franklin Coxe, then boarding at the Chelsea, in West Twenty-third-street, but who owns a handsome place at Bayside, Long Island. Now the friendship is at an end and Malcolm has sued Coxe to recover $420, which he says is due him for services rendered to Coxe.
WASHINGTON, March 9.--Senator Ingalls appears to have a very good opinion of Mr. Matthews, the colored man whom he helped to keep out of the office of Recorder of Deeds of the District.

CHICAGO, March 9.--The National League of Musicians had a session here to-day. There were 27 delegates present, representing musical organizations in New-York, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, Chicago, St. Louis, Newark, N.J.;

At a meeting held by the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday the Legislature was requested by resolution to prevent the building of any bridges across the Hudson which would interfere with navigation.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--It is understood that the Secretary of War has severely reprimanded Col. Gibson, of the Third Artillery, for the want of promptness and bad appearance of the troops on the occasion of the funeral of the late Col. Scott, and the unsoldierlike conduct of the officers.

The baseball men finished their work in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel last evening. Everything has been arranged amicably, and if Denny and Boyle can be persuaded to sign contracts for the amounts offered by the Indianapolis Club further trouble will be averted.

RUSTCHUK, March 9.--Sentences were pronounced to-day against several more insurgents. Four officers were condemned to prison for life, four were sentenced to confinement for 15 years, and three for 8 years.

A very nice little surprise party awaits Josef Rohrmeier, a large mill owner of Nurem berg, Bavaria, who is now on his way to this city in the steamer Nederland, from Antwerp, which is due here to-morrow.

Before Judge Patterson, in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, Charles P. Miller, the counsel for Andrew Jackson, who has been an expressman so long that he is known as "Express" Jackson, argued in behalf of a motion to vacate an injunction which the New-York.

Joseph Mauz, an Italian laborer, 23 years old, was stabbed in the abdomen last night at 10 o'clock, at 13 St. John's-lane, by a woman whose name and present whereabouts were, up to 1 o'clock this morning, unknown to the police.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9.--Mrs. Lucy Parsons, through her agent, one Hartung, a German shoemaker, came very near getting an audience to listen to her ravings to-night.

RAHWAY, N,.J., March 9.--Daniel G. Hetfield, the well known carriage manufacturer of this city, was attacked last night without any warning by a young man named Hoole while riding home to Rahway in a Pennsylvania train. He was seated about the middle of the smoker. After the train left Elizabeth a party of young fellows more or less intoxicated...

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., March 9.--Fifty men employed on the soft coal docks here in the place of strikers left their work to-day. The men on the hard coal docks, being ordered to take the place of the new strikers, refused to do so, but when threatened with dismissal complied.
Henry E. Abbey reached Chicago yesterday, and to-day will arrange with Mme. Patti the details of her five weeks' operatic season, which will begin at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, April 11.

RONDOUT, N.Y., March 9.--Fruit growers along the Hudson Valley are organizing to thwart what they claim is a combination formed by NewYork City commission men to make producers ship small fruits, especially grapes, in non-returnable packages. In the great grape country between Cornwall and Catskill there are scores of vineyard owners who will ship from 10 to 70 tons each of Concord grapes the coming season.

The birthdays of Simon Cameron, celebrated yesterday, when he was 88 years old, is made more than ordinarilly noteworthy by the fact that among all his contemporaries no other man had so excellent a faculty of keeping all the friends he made.

Mr. "Joe" Cotton and Mr. "Al" Smith, two of the shining lights of the bookmaking fraternity, met one another yesterday in the chalkstained arena of billiards, and Mr. Cotton proceeded to scrape the cobwebs off the moon with the unfortunate descendant of the original Adam Smith.

Detective Sergeant Heidelberg returned to the city yesterday from a trip to Canada, and brought with him as a prisoner a man named Budd, who is said to have been a broker here, and who is accused of forgeries to a large amount, Budd was locked up at Police Headquarters. Inspector Byrnes, when asked about the case, appeared surprised that the news of the arrest should have gained publicity.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 9.--The funeral of the Hon. James Mackin took place at Fishkil Landing this afternoon. The service was held at the Reformed church. The Rev. Dr. Suydam, of Jersey City, officiated in the absence of the Pastor.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, March 9.--The Mormon jurors in Judge Zane's court, after having taken on Monday oaths on the new Edmunds-Tucker bill, on examination yesterday went back to the old principle and declared the law or God higher than that of man. They believed it right for man to live in polygamy and were rejected as jurors in the case to be tried.

The body of Mr. Beecher was put in its coffin at dusk yesterday. It lies in the parlor, a little forward of the folding doors. When the attendants had finished their work the family visited the parlor. The perfume of flowers filling the room add the glow of a soft light upon the face of the dead had a soothing influence.

According to the statement of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the quarter which ended Dec. 31, 1886, the net revenues were $991,018, and for the quarter ending March 31, based upon nearly completed returns for January, partial returns for February and estimated for March, $750,000.

BOSTON, March, 9.--At 214 State-street was the joint office of William C. Hickman, and the American Crystal Light Company. The signs on the outer wall still remain, but Hickman has joined the American colony in Canada and with him has gone to smash the National Sugarine Refining Company, incorporated on Jan. 22 last, for the manufacture, production, and sale of an article or substance called sugarine, being a substitute for common sugar.

The body of Mr. Beecher was put in its coffin at dusk yesterday. It lies in the parlor, a little forward of the folding doors. When the attendants had finished their work the family visited the parlor. The perfume of flowers filling the room add the glow of a soft light upon the face of the dead had a soothing influence.

The celebration of the festival of the Purim was begun last evening by the Hebrews throughout the world, and will be continued today. The festival was ordained to commemorate the deliverance of the Israelites in the Kingdom of Persia from extermination by the decree of Ahasuerus, the King of the Medes and Persians, who had been instigated thereto by the machinations of Haman, the Prime Minister.
His veto of the Dependency Pension bill, in my opinion, was a grave error of judgment. I believe that the people of the United States stand ready to support the indigent soldiers of the war.

ST. Louis, March 9.--To-morrow the State of Missouri will have no militia organization. The bill for the relief of the troops, defeated a few weeks ago and reconsidered by hard work on the part of Gov. Marmaduke, came up for final passage this afternoon and was killed by a vote of 68 to 65.

Mayor Hewitt, Morris K. Jesup, Jesse Seligman, Edward Cooper, and Cornelius Vanderbilt, of the Distributing Committee of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, met in the Mayor's office yesterday afternoon.

OTTAWA, Ill., March 9.--Startling reports are given to the public to-night be the local papers charging ex-County Treasurer Raymond with being from $16,000 to $20,000 short in his accounts. He had been Treasurer for a number of terms, and was succeeded by A.M. Hoffman, his son-in-law, who was also his deputy.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 9.--The excitement over the peculiar conduct of the Denmead hermits which has been agitating the people of the town for six weeks reached its culminating point this afternoon, when Mrs. Brundage, of Piscataway, a sister of old Mrs. Denmead, announced her intention of obtaining a search warrant to-morrow to see what had become of her relative.

PORTLAND, Me., March 9.--There have been no regular trains over Franklin and Megantic Railroad the past three weeks. One of their engines is disabled and will have to be repaired. The snow is five feet deep in the woods. Lumbering is at a standstill until the snow settles. In the town of Kingfield the snow is from 6 to 15 feet deep. This Winter there was the heaviest fall of snow in Maine for years.

DETROIT, Mich., March 9.--Salt is now selling in Michigan at 51 cents a barrel, the lowest price since its manufacture was commenced. At the beginning of the present year the Salt Association, which controls nine-tenths of the product of the State, had on hand 1,600,000 barrels of last year's salt, and the first three months of this year shows an increase in the product of 100,000 barrels, as compared with the same period last year.

NORFOLK, Va., March 9.--The steamer Goldsborough, which arrived here this evening from Philadelphia, reports passing at 9:30 o'clock this morning the North German Lloyd steamship Rhein, from Bremen for Baltimore, ashore off Hog Island.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 9.--The Nickel Plate decree entered in the Circuit Court was accessible to-day and differs in important particulars from statements made yesterday by attorneys.
The news of the change in the relations of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad given in THE TIMES yesterday morning caused a good deal of excitement in speculative circles.

The revival of the medical education of women began in this country about thirty years ago. The movement has steadily grown despite great opposition, until now there are five or six schools in the United States in which women can get a passably good training, and two or three in which the training is decidedly above that given by the average medical college for men.

The employes of Calvary Cemetery have caught the strike epidemic, and threaten to go out if their demands are not complied with. They say that their present wages range between $1 50 and $1 75 a day. They demand an increase of 25 cents.

BOSTON, March 9.--The Executive Committee of District Assembly 8,149, Cambridge, to-night declared the Cambridge Railroad strike off, and the men are at liberty to return to work if they can obtain places. Nearly all the vacancies have been filled with new men, and only very low of the strikers will be taken back by the company.

WASHINGTON, March 9.--When the attention of Secretary Whitney was called to-day to the suspension of a foreman and dismissal of a draughtsman by the English naval authorities for giving information to the United States concerning British naval designs, the Secretary remarked that the details of the story pointed to the obtaining of the secret designs as a piece of private enterprise.

TORONTO, March 10.--The police have arrested Daniel A. Stewart on a charge of procuring innocent young girls for immoral purposes. He nominally kept a registry office for servants. BALTIMORE, March 11.--No one in Baltimore believes that the Baltimore and Ohio deal is off. The people accepted the rumors of the affair very incredulously at first, but they seem to have an abiding conviction now that it is to take place.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 11.--The Rectorship of St. Paul's Church, Troy, N.Y., which has been vacant since the death of the Rev. Francis Harrison, S.T.D., has been filled by the election of the Rev. Edgar A. Enos, M.A., Rector of St. John's, Bridgeport. Mr. Enos was graduated at Hamilton College in the Class of '74, and is an advanced churchman of the conservative type.

BOSTON, March 11.--A fire broke out on the steamer Principia (British) at 8 o'clock this morning while she was lying at the Hoosac Tunnel dock. The fire had its origin in some bales of flax, several of which were consumed. Some other portions of the cargo were damaged by water. The loss will be $10,000. The vessel is insured.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 11.--Gen. Fairchild, Grand Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, was banqueted here to-night by the citizens. Mayor Kumpf delivered the address of welcome.

PORTLAND, Me., March 11.--A letter received in this city from Winnipeg says that Blackstone, the defaulting clerk of the Canal National Bank, has been very handsomely treated by the Chief-Justice of Manitoba, by whose decision Blackstone escaped extradition. He has been restored to his old position in that city by the firm that formerly employed him, and he has retaken his old class in the Sunday school.

Blaine, may not be of much value to its stockholders, for the Rodicks are pushing the completion of their works, which will be finished before the opening of the Bar Harbor season.

MONTREAL, March 11.--The City Health Officer to-day disinfected a large quantity of Dominion notes that had been in use during the smallpox epidemic, and which had been called in by the City and District Bank. The notes were stored in the vaults of the bank, but the Government refused to accept them until they were disinfected. There was over $200,000 in one and two dollar bills. When thoroughly disinfected they will be forwarded to Ottawa.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 11.--President Dwight authorizes the statement that the reports respecting the teachings of Prof. Russell, of the Yale Theological Seminary, as denying the divinity of Christ, , are without any foundation in fact.
French possessions in India cover 194 square miles and contain 285,022 inhabitants, of whom only 1,660 are Europeans. In all but Pondicherry the non-official element may be counted on the fingers.

The whistle has sounded and the two white-winged competitors in the great ocean race of 1887 are now flying across the Atlantic. The start was a beautiful picture and took place amid every evidence of impartial enthusiam and general good-will.
Mrs. Leonora Allen has brought an action in the Supreme Court against Mrs. Mary Louisa Baldwin for the partition of property left by exJudge William H. Nichols, of Bellmore, Suffolk County.

A writer in the Cleveland (Ohio) Leader says: "No man of ordinary observation but knows that the custom of treating in saloons--unknown in any country but this--is the cause of more drunkenness than any other thing. Thousands of men are constantly drawn into drunken sprees by it who would otherwise have remained sober men. It is very rare that a man will enter a saloon and deliberately sit down to get drunk in unsocial loneliness.
A bill now before the Senate transfers to the Park Department from the Department of Public Works certain streets which are intended to be reserved as pleasure drives.

To-day is the third Sunday in Lent and the gospel of the mass refers to the casting out of devils by Jesus.

The second illustrated lecture in course A of John L. Stoddard's Lenten series will be delivered in Daly's Theatre to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock, the subject being "Queen Elizabeth," and the same lecture will be repeated, as the second in course B on Tuesday morning.

DOVER, N.H., March 12.--Recent developments seem to indicate that Mrs. Annie Marshall, who was last Wednesday held in $1,500 upon a charge of attempting to kill her husband by putting strychnine in some pies, is innocent, and that Marshall himself placed the poison there. His object, it is claimed, was to criminate his wife and get her imprisoned, so that he might obtain a divorce and remarry.
In appearance Eve was exceedingly gracious and beautiful, full of reticence and dignity; people always spoke of her as a lady, and whispered to one another that she had come of good stock.

The expectation that Col. Bacon's investigating committee would deal harshly with the four witnesses who at former sessions had refused to answer Mr. Parsons's questions drew to yesterday's meeting of the committee in the Brooklyn City Hall such an expectant crowd as the Aldermanic Chamber had rarely held.

There is one feature of the municipal civil service system to which Mayor HEWITT could with advantage direct his attention. It is the number of names from the list of eligibles which it is now the practice to send to the appointing power in case of vacancies.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 12.--Two injunctions have been granted against the NewYork, Pennsylvania and Ohio strikers, one by the United States Circuit Court and one by the Common Pleas. Judge Stone, of the Common Pleas Court, to-day refused to dissolve his injunction and indefinitely postponed decision in the case of contempt against one of the leaders, ...

A platform, six feet wide, is erecting over the south roadway of the East River Bridge and adjoining the wall of the station in this city. It begins at a point just west of the head of the stairway inside the station and ends at a point opposite the middle of a train of cars waiting to carry passengers over to Brooklyn.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, March 4.--The local papers express much anxiety about the outbreak of small pox in Havana and Matanzas and the appearance of the disease in this city, two cases being reported here.

LEE, Mass., March 12.--Thomas Kinsella, Jr., who accidentally, but carelessly, pointed a gun at his mother-in-law on the night of March 4 and shot her dead, was tried before Justice Dunham at Stockbridge to-day, and, after half the witnesses had been examined, was bound over for the Grand Jury at Pittsfield, July 11, in $10,000. Failing to obtain bail, he was committed.

Mayor Hewitt pondered all day yesterday over the appointment of a successor to Gen. Shaler, and at the end of the official day he was in such bad humor that it was dangerous to approach him on the subject.
BOSTON, Mass., March 12.--An attempt was made early this morning to rob the premises of D.J. Cutter, at Dorchester.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 12.--Mr. George Jones, proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, arrived here yesterday, accompanied by his daughter, Mrs. Ireland, who comes for the benefit of her health. Speaking of Southern California, Mr. Jones said he thought the climate far superior to that of Nice, or other Continental resorts, and ahead of Florida.
George H. Watrous yesterday resigned the Presidency of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, and, at his suggestion, the Directors of the road elected Charles P. Clark his successor.

LONDON, March 12.--Not even the most lachrymose of created beings can weep always, and it is only human nature's law that there must be a smiling moment somewhere. This is the period of Europe's relaxation from the wearing strain of war alarms which have hung over her like a nightmare since September.

PITTSBURG, Penn., March 12.--James G. Blaine, Jr., has permanently severed his connection with the Pittsburg Times. Mr. Blaine left this evening to accept a position with a prominent Wallstreet broker.
The stated meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society was held yesterday afternoon, and the President, Dr. George E. Ellis, occupied the chair. His opening remarks were as follows:

PARIS, March 12.--Whatever may be the opinion outside of France, there can be no doubt of the decided conviction here that the immediate danger of war has entirely passed. The consequent relief is intense.

READING, Penn., March 12.--Considerable of a stir in industrial circles was produced today by the issuing of an open letter from George Brooke, President of the E. Brooke Iron Company, of Birdsborough, to his employes, in which he wishes the men to leave the Knights of Labor.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 12.--A passenger on the fast express train from Boston, due in New-York at 5:45 P.M., died suddenly in his chair in a drawing room car a few minutes before reaching this city.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The General Passenger Agents of the various roads in the new Western States Passenger Association finished today their work of formulating rules and regulations for conducting passenger traffic in conformity with the new inter-State commerce law.

At Mayor Hewitt's suggestion, the Board of Excise has prepared a bill to straighten out the tangle caused by the granting of licenses by the unauthorized Commissioners, Messrs. Haughton and Morris, last year.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 12.--In the United States Court this morning a verdict was rendered for for $250 against the city of Charlotte, in favor of James Cathcart, Salvation Army Captain, who was arrested a year ago for parading the streets against the orders of the council. He sued for $10,000.
Probably the book that gave its author the greatest pleasure was "The Doctor," that medley of grotesque fancies and out-of-the-way learning, of boyish humor, and of the serene wisdom of age.
The unveiling of the statue of Louis Blanc in the Place Monge took place to-day. The ceremony was attended by representatives of the Ministry and both houses of the Legislature.

Two Wall-street men representing Jay Gould and Russell Sage left this city for Baltimore last sunday just as soon as those distinguished financiers had learned in confidence of the contract given to Alfred Sully by Robert Garrett providing for the transfer of the control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 12.--Hannah Atkins, colored, died here last night, aged 103 years. She was born in Virginia and was formerly a slave.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 12.--Parliament at its approaching session will be asked to vote a sufficient sum to organize and equip a troop of cavalry, bringing the permanent force up to 1,000 men.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The more the railroad officials try to bring about uniformity of action in making rates under the new inter-State commerce law the more do they seem to be getting apart, and the indications are that each road will have to act independently and make such rates as it may deem best.

In addition to the names of Dr. Joseph Parker, of London, and the Revs. A.J.F. Behrends and Hugh Smith Carpenter, that of Dr. Joseph T. Duryea, Pastor of the Central Congregational Church, of Boston, has been mentioned as a possible successor to Mr. Beecher.
SANTIAGO DE CUBA, March 4.--W.K. Vanderbilt's steam yacht Alva, which arrived here on 1st inst., made the run from Port Royal, Cuba, in 15 hours.

Each volume of this great enterprise that issues from the press is a subject for congratulation. Here is history written with a fullness, an accuracy, and an unflinching devotion to the plain facts seldom met with.

Hundreds of presents and birthday cards reached Cardinal Newman at the Oratory on the Monday in last week, the occasion being the eighty-sixth birthday of his Eminence. He looked remarkably well, and took part in the special high mass, which was celebrated at 8 in the morning.

CHICAGO, March 12.--The wife of Anarchist Oscar Neebe will be buried tomorrow, but the husband will not be there. Sheriff Matson told him when Mrs. Neebe died that he might attend the funeral and Neebe had intended to avail himself of the privilege.

BOSTON, March 12.--Edward Burgess, the designer of America's champion sloops, says that the Mayflower will not reach England in time to sail in the Queen's jubilee race on June 14, as she will not start until the 1st of June. Even if she were there, she would not go into the races.
SOFIA, March 12.--A Russian named Beloof recently brought bands of Montenegrin desperadoes numbering 50 men each into Sofia with a view to creating an insurrection.

FARGO, Dakota, March 12.--Passenger train No. 1 on the Northern Pacific Railway this morning came into collision with freight No. 16, four miles west of Wheatland. Fireman Snyder, of the freight train, was killed outright and Engineer Ryan, of the passenger train, had a leg taken off just below the thigh. A brakeman and the baggagemaster were also seriously injured. It is understood that no passengers were injured.
Railroad earnings for the first week of March were reported by several companies in Wall-street yesterday. The following increases were shown as compared with the corresponding week of 1886:

Charles Foley, a 7-year-old boy, was attending a herd of goats at Weehawken yesterday, when one of his goats wandered to the Erie Railway track. While the boy was attempting to drive the goat off the track he was struck by a train and probably fatally injured.
ERIE, Penn., March 12.--At a meeting held this afternoon the Ohio River and Lake Erie Railroad was reorganized as a part of the Lake Erie, Butler and Pittsburg Railway syndicate.
All Holland celebrated to-day with the greatest enthusiasm the seventieth anniversary of the birth of King William III.
OCEAN GROVE, N.J., March 12.--The destruction of the Baptist Church at Key East on Thursday morning is now known to have been the work of incendiaries. It was the only church in the place.

Some have supposed this well known English word to be a corruption of the Persian Hindustan sirband (head-wrap.) This is, however, quite inconsistent with the history of the word.

LANSING, Mich., March 5.--While presiding in the Senate yesterday, Lieut.-Gov. McDonald was handed a telegram from a friend announcing to him that a sister from whom he had not heard and whom he had not seen for 39 years was alive, giving her address.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 12.--There is great excitement at Powhatan over the death of Mrs. William McLaughlin, whose dead body was found in a creek near her house. At first it was supposed to be a case of suicide, but later developments show that it was a murder. The body was found in three feet of water and it was apparent that Mrs. Mc Laughlin was killed while drawing water from the creek.

CAMBRIDGE, March 12.--It is curious to note that the first public mention of the modern Harvard cheer of "Rah, rah, rah!" appears in August, 1869, when the London Times, in its account of the Harvard-Oxford race of that year, speaks of the curious "Ah! Ah! Ah!" of the American college men, which of course could have been no other than the present "Rah, rah, ...
Stephen Moffatt's poker room, at 210 West Forty-second-street, was raided last evening. Twelve persons were arrested and the gambling implements seized.

James Learned, a middle-aged patient at the Bloomingdale Asylum, and one of the least insane of its inmates, went to the Bijou Opera House last night with Dr. George West, one of the physicians of the institution.

Col. Forney in a Press article used the expression: "Strained at a gnat and swallowed a camel." The editorial proof came down: "Strained at a knot and swallowed a camel." The proof was corrected three times and returned with the object of the distinguished editor's wrath still straining at that irrepressible knot.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., March 12.--A dastardly attempt was made last evening to wreck a Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul passenger train near here. Some miscreant broke the lock and moved a switch at Breen's Crossing, sending the entire train from the track. Fortunately the flanges of the wheels caught firmly on one side of the track and averted a terrible disaster. The engineer was slightly injured and the train was delayed several hours.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 12.--The contractors have commenced to lay the stone on all of the locks on the Oswego and Eire Canal, which are being lengthened, and, although the contracts call for the ...
The big Barnum-Forepaugh Circus is at the Madison-Square Garden.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 12.--Miles T. Cassaday has been arrested, charged with violating the internal revenue laws. Mr. Cassaday has served several terms in the Board of Supervisors in this county and for the past two years has been Chairman of the board.

The coopers' conference committee had another interview yesterday with the boss coopers' committee, and a partial termination of the strike was agreed upon. To-morrow work will be resumed in 34 shops, but the employes of Mr. Connor, the Messrs. Connolly, and Briggs Co. will remain on strike. The men who resume work will each contribute a day's pay every week for the support of the strikers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 12.--Enoch Carter, colored, was hanged at Orlando, Orange County, Fla., to-day for the murder of Policeman Beasley on Christmas Eve, 1885. Carter bore himself firmly. His dying statement, acknowledging the killing, was read by a priest on the scaffold. Death resulted from strangulation in 14 minutes.

At the offices of the Grand Trunk line in this city, the report that the road has declared that it will pursue a different policy about excursions than that adopted by the Central Traffic Association is disbelieved. No official information has been received here on the subject, but the representatives of the Grand Trunk say that line will stick to the association's agreement.

A very genial young gentleman in an abbreviated "topcoat," an elongated undercoat, a yellow pair of gloves, and a gorgeous high hat, and carrying an elkhorn cane and a general appearance of luxury, started to walk up Broadway last night.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 12.--The Phi Kappa Psi College Praternity will have a convention in this city on the 6th and 7th of April. A committee on arrangements was in session to-day outlining a programme and making other preparations for the reunion. The convention will embrace the chapters in the first district, comprising colleges in Pennsylvania and New-York. There will be a banquet at the close of the convention.

Baseball matters are very quiet after the great meeting, and are expected to remain so until the season fairly opens. It is generally supposed that the Indianapolis team is at present doing the hardest work in preparation for the Summer campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 12.--First Lieut. Robert Craig, Fourth Artillery, now on duty in this city, has been ordered to report to the Chief Signal Officer for temporary duty as Acting Signal Officer.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 12.--George W. Burnham, who is to be the manager of the new ball club, has returned from New-York. Mr. Burnham says that it is all nonsense that Glasscock and Denny have refused to come here without a guarantee of salary, and he adds that the story was started by Rowe, of Kansas City, when he found he had been floored by the Indianapolis delegates to the League.

Officer Charles D. Sands, of the EldridgeStreet Precinct, was walking along the Bowery in citizen's clothes late Friday night when he noticed several men following Emil Serem, and acting in a very suspicious manner. He kept his eyes upon the men and presently saw one of them push against Serem. A moment later he noticed that the latter's watch chain was dangling.

GENEVA, N.Y., March 12.--Joseph Gragor, a half-bred Indian, whose home is in Pittsford, came to Geneva this evening and went to the home of George W. Hamilton, colored, in Power's Alley, where his (Gragor's) wife has been stopping for some time. A quarrel ensued at once, and Gragor, drawing a revolver, pointed it at his wife.

In 1852, after the coup d'eta's, he was asked to compose a cantata in honor of the empire, and he was given to understand that he would receive by way of reward, besides his profits as an author, the cross of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. Dumas fils refused.

The two Conferences of the Methodist Episcopal Church of this city and vicinity will convene on April 7. These are the New-York Conference, which will hold its sessions at Kingston, N.Y., and over the deliberations of which Bishop Fowler will preside, and the New-York East Conference, which will sit at ...

A paper of great interest and historical value has been discovered by E.P. Allinson, who, with Senator Boies Penrose, is preparing a history of the Municipal Government of Philadelphia from 1681 to 1887.
HAVANA, March 12.--The American bark Matanzas, Capt. Simmons, which sailed from Philadelphia Feb. 24, has been burned at Matanzas. Both vessel and cargo are a total loss.
In the Supreme Court yesterday Judge Donohue granted an absolute divorce, with leave to marry again, to Lydia N. Jackson from Harry Jackson, who is prohibited from marrying.

There is a strike among the operatives in the brass and iron works of Wilbur F. Washburn, at Yonkers. Three weeks ago an apprentice was put in the foundry room and soon developed a faculty for doing more work than his instructor.

About three years ago Mrs. Lizzie Mack, of 156 Forsyth-street, bought $700 worth of furniture on the installment plan from John F. Manges, of 114 Rivington-street. She agreed to pay $2 a week, and gave a mortgage on the furniture as security. She made her payments promptly, and a short time ago increased her payments to $3 a week. Feb. 25 she paid the collector $6, which made her total payments something over $500.

With Granville P. Hawes as Referee, Miss Sophie L. Mattern and F.H. Vanvechten, her legal second, met H.S. Bennett, the defendant of Russell Sage, in a small room at 2 Nassau-street yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Mass., March 12.--Kate Donohue, aged 22, a domestic employed in West Roxbury, was arrested this morning, charged with causing the death by smothering of her illegitimate infant. She is held for murder.
COLEMAN, Texas, March 12.--The railway office was robbed here by three masked men about 4 o'clock this morning. The amount of money taken was over $3,000.

CONCORD, N.H., March 12.--The high wind yesterday caused heavy snow drifts on the Northern Division of the Boston and Lowell Road, those in the cut one and one-quarter miles southeast of Andover being the largest known on the line for years.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 12.--A private telegram received here says that Capt. Morris, of Battery G, United States Army, stationed at Fort Adams, is dying on pneumonia in New-York. Capt. Morris left here a few days ago on leave of absence.
Leopold C. Eisler, of 366 Sixth-avenue, was in the Yorkville Court yesterday charged by Julius Steger, of 432 Sixth-avenue, with perjury. Justice White held him for examination on March 16.

One of those revelations of the gentler side of human nature which I prize when they come in my way--not for their rarity, for they are plenty enough if one but keeps himself in a mood to notice them, but because they make a hard world so much pleasanter--came to me the other day.

WEST CHESTER, March 7.--On Saturday the Hon. R.E. Monaghan, of this borough, presented to the West Chester State Normal School a valuable collection of historical letters which were at one time the property of the late Gen. Persifor Frazer Smith, United States Army.

BERLIN, March 12.--The Official Gazette publishes the Army bill as passed. The arrangements to put it into action on April 1 are completed. New battalions will be formed as fourth battalions in existing regiments. Four now railway companies will also be formed-- two Prussian, one Saxon, and one Wurtemberg.

CHICAGO, March 12.--Maurice Pincoffs, the Secretary of the Gabain Commission Company, 140 Lasalle-street, whose failure was rumored around the Board of Trade yesterday, went to the wall and caught the boys for about $23,000.
The second and last entertainment by Mr. George Riddle in behalf of the Free Home for the Incurables will be given in Chickering Hall next Wednesday evening.

There is reason to behave that the investigation which the Commissioners of Accounts are now making into the affairs of the Department of Public Parks will establish facts which will make it the duty of Mayor Hewitt to accept the resignation of Commissioner Crimmins and to decline to reappoint him when his term expires in May.
Harry Hill and Ella Roberts, one of his waitresses, were arrested last evening for violating the excise law. They were locked up, but soon gave bail and were released.

A lady, the wife of Mr. Woodward, the insurance adjuster, while sitting in the parlor of their residence Friday afternoon, was the startled and unfortunate victim of a most singular occurrence, involving the loss of sight in her right eye.

Patrick Peter McLarney, a decorative artist of 242 West Sixteenth-street, was sentenced to six months on the Island yesterday by Justice Ford, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, for brutality toward his wife, Elizabeth.

PARIS, March 12.--A sharp shock of earthquake was felt throughout Marseilles yesterday. For a time there was a general panic, and the hotels and the Bourse were emptied of their occupants in a very few seconds. The people were, however, soon reassured. It is found that many walls of buildings in various parts of the city were cracked by the quake.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 12.--A large black wolf, the first of the species seen in Sullivan County for 20 years or more, has just been killed, after a hot chase of three days, in the wilderness section of the town of Rockland.

LONDON, March 12.--The Right Hon, Joseph Chamberlain, speaking at a meeting of the National Radical Union at Birmingham this evening, deplored the delay in the reunion of the Liberals, and said that the longer the rupture continued the more serious the situation became, and that if they did not agree quickly they would drift further apart.
Capt. Arthur Morris, of the Fourth Artillery, United States Army, who has been seriously ill at the Everett House for several days, was almost out of danger last night.

What the Lick telescope will do will depend on the men who have the handling of it. It will not make discoveries of itself. All that can be said of it is that it will place in the hands of painstaking competent observers the best means now in existence of scanning the heavens.

Of the prehistoric races that once lived upon the great Territory of the North west no record remains. That the soil was once occupied by a people of intelligence and partial civilization there is no question.

Barnum's parade did not diminish the enthusiasm or the attendance at Wood's big gymnasium, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Fifthavenue, last night, when the third amateur gymnastic competitions for the amateur championships of America were held under the auspices of the American Athletic Club.
DANVILLE, Ky., March 12.--News has just reached here of the assassination of Adam Carpenter, at Hustonville, last night at 11:30 o'clock.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 12.--At 12:40 o'clock this morning Freeman Rowe, a farmer residing two miles southeast of Newark, Wayne County, and his ...

No man, we think, ever equaled Sydney Smith in the wit of extravaganza. He understood better than any other the artistic use of exaggeration. Mere exaggeration is not wit; nor can we lay down any law for making it become so.

Mr. Abbey arrived yesterday from Chicago, where he consulted Mme. Patti in regard to the forthcoming season of Italian opera. His partner, Mr. Schoeffel, signed the contract during his absence with Mr. Stanton, of the Metropolitan Opera House, for the use of that house for the fortnight in which the famous singer will be heard here.

SHELBY, N.Y., March 12.--Miss Elizabeth Kolar, of this place, committed suicide this morning by taking a large quantity of Paris green. She was laboring under aberration of mind caused by intense religious excitement, but it was not thought she would kill herself. She was 47 years old.

A man named Kearney, employed in the Lackawanna Iron and Coal Company's steel mill, while on his way to work early yesterday morning met a lady at the corner of Lackawanna-avenue clad in the garments of the night. He observed that the woman's feet were bare and her head was uncovered, and upon closer scrutiny he found that she was fast asleep.

CHICAGO, Ill., March 12.--Warden Frey, of the County Infirmary, has confessed. He has, it is stated, seen the State Attorney, and, under promises of immunity, has signified his willingness to tell all that he knows.

Rhode Island is amazingly slow about some things, and just as much too fast about others. It is the last State to continue odious classifications and restrictions upon its male voters, but it is the first State in the Union to submit a woman suffrage amendment to its Constitution to popular vote.

Mayor Hewitt held another secret conference yesterday with the heads of the various city departments. The seal of approval was attached to the bill placing the construction and maintenance of the subways in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment and Gen. Newton, and to various minor measures now before the Legislature.

The Lenten dullness continues, and there has not been enough of incident during the week past to even supply topics of conversation. All who can have fled the city and are not encouraged to return by the bulletins from home. Not in years has so absolutely an uneventful period as the present Lenten season has thus far been come to New-York society.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 12.--Fifty firemen of the Consolidated Road arrived in this city this evening at 9 o'clock and proceeded to the residence of President William H. Stevenson, of the New-York, Rutland and Montreal Railroad, formerly Superintendent of the New-York Division of the Consolidated Road. The firemen presented him with a handsome gold Elk's badge, set with diamonds.
The most careful pre cautions will not always avail against confederated thieves directed by superior intelligence.
"Mrs. H.C.G.," Leatherwood, Va.--The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage is a Presbyterian.

It is painful to observe that a tavern keeper of Red Hook, N.Y., and a farmer presumably of the vicinage have been arrested and held to bail for having conceived and fomented a contest at hog guessing.
Congress on the 20th day of May, 1785, ordered a survey of the territory of the Ohio, and Gen. Benjamin Tupper, of Massachusetts, the intimate friend of Gen. Putnam, was sent out to survey the field.

VIRDEN, Ill., March 12.--The south-bound passenger train on the Jacksonville and Southeastern Railroad, consisting of engine, baggage car, and two coaches, was thrown down an embankment near Girard last night, injuring State Senator E. Southworth so severely that he will probably die, and seriously wounding 12 or 15 other persons.

The dealers in fruits interested in the sale of peaches in New-York, Boston, Philadelphia, and Baltimore have been agitating the question of the sale of the baskets with the peaches to be sold in the future in those cities.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 12.--The correspondent of the Times-Democrat at Truxillo, Spanish Honduras, sends an account of the formal opening of the Aguan Navigation and Improvement Company's bank at that place.

WORCESTER, Mass., March 12.--The great strike of the boot and shoe makers in Worcester, Spencer, Brookfield, and North Brookfield, which began with the posting of the "free shop" notices by the manufacturers, still continues.
The plays chosen for Mme. Bernhardt's first week at the Star Theatre are Sardou's "Fedora." Dumas's "La Dame aux Camelias," ("Camille,") and Meilhac and Halevy's "FrouFrou."

When, some time ago, proposal was made in the House of Commons to vote the money for the purchase of a costly picture from the Blenheim House collection, Mr. Biggar made a suggestion which commended itself to the common sense of the House.

William Early, or "Billy the Tailor," was found lying on the floor of the cutting room of the tailoring department of the penitentiary Friday afternoon with a bullet wound in his head and a pistol by his side. He died last night.
The most sensational development in the Denmead case at New-Brunswick, N.J., yesterday was that which arose out of the professional consultation between County Physician Rice and Dr. H.R. Baldwin.

WASHINGTON, March 12.--The President has commuted to five years the sentence of imprisonment of Douglass W. Vanderhoof, of Minnesota, who pleaded guilty of embezzling the funds of a bank in which he was a clerk. His original sentence was 10 years' imprisonment.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 12.--The approaching season is attracting the usual attention, and active preparations are being made. It is believed that the usual number of houses will be occupied and that the season of 1887 will be voted a success.

ANNAPOLIS, MD., March 12.--William Stanley, one of the crew of the schooner O.M. Rhoark, of Baltimore, was shot last night and killed by the Captain, Jacob Doleman, while in Chesapeake Bay, seven miles from this city. The Captain says the shooting was accidental, but the crew all say it was deliberately done because they refused to raise the foresail, as they knew the vessel could not carry it in the heavy wind that was blowing.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 12.--A combination sale of blooded horses will begin in this city on Tuesday, the 15th, and continue three days. About 225 animals, some of which are of fine pedigree and very speedy, will be offered for sale.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 12.--Messrs. Frederick Oliver and H.C. Butcher will leave Columbia on Monday for Houston, Texas, to choose the site for one of the first of the oil mills to be established by the Southern Cotton Oil Company.

KEY WEST, Fla., March 12.--A band of 11 Cuban outlaws arrived from Tampa last night by the steamer Whitney. They were immediately waited on by a committee of citizens and requested to leave the town at once and forever.

POTOMAC, Ill., March 12.--A street duel between John Goodwin, a wealthy farmer, and Charles Morehead, a young bank cashier, occurred here today. Goodwin had charged that Morehead betrayed his 15-year-old daughter. The two men met near the centre of the town about noon. They whipped out revolvers simultaneously and commenced shooting emptied, when Morehead fell, mortally wounded. Goodwin escaped without a scratch and made his escape.

HOWELL, Mich., March 13.--A little before midnight last night fire was discovered in E.N. Monroe's hardware store by a couple of young men who mere passing at the time. An explosion occurred at that time, the store being badly torn and the men knocked down.

A letter received by one of the parishioners of All Souls' Church from Mrs. Newton states that the Rev. R. Heber Newton, the Pastor, was prostrated at Philadelphia last week on his way South by a fit of weakness.
Plymouth Church could not have held many more people than crowded into it yesterday morning to hear Dr. Lyman Abbott's estimate of Mr. Beecher's character.
The General Committee of the GermanAmerican Independent Citizens' Association met last evening at Beethoven Hall, in Fifthstreet, and passed resolutions with regard to bills before the Legislature.
W.S.B."--A State institution. Henry H. Sherman, formerly private secretary to Police Commissioner Voorhis, has been appointed stenographer in the Mayor's office.

BALTIMORE, March 14.--"There is nothing new," said President Robert Garrett, this afternoon, for about the two hundredth time since Wednesday. Mr. Garrett seemed particularly happy to-day, and the invariable bunch of violets, in the lapel of his coat, was larger than ever.
There isn't the shadow of doubt that the "greatest show on earth" may now be seen at Madison-Square Garden.

The twenty-sixth annual Commencement of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College took place last evening at Carnegie Laboratory, 338 East Twenty-sixth-street. After the diplomas had been presented by Prof. I.E. Taylor the graduates and Faculty adjourned to Delmonico's, where dinner was served.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--Commissioner of Patents Montgomery, who will leave his office to return to the practice of law as soon as the President selects his successor, has been talking rather freely concerning the trials and tribulations of an office holder who has patronage to dispense.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14.--The officers of the Kentucky Association decided on an extra day's racing at the coming Spring meeting this afternoon. This will cause the meeting to begin on April 30 and continue until May 9.

Yesterday was Spring opening day at E. J. Denning Co.'s spacious store, at Broadway and Ninth-street. How much this meant to the fairer half of humanity was plainly demonstrated by the hosts of ladies who thronged the aisles and crowded the counters where the costly and dainty products of the loom and the milliner's art were exhibited.
There was a fight at Yonkers on Sunday evening in which Albert G. Wolf, son of Louis Wolf, met his death. He, with Chales Zabinski, started out about 8 o'clock to take a walk up Warburton-avenue.

LONDON, March 14.--Mr. Gladstone, replying to the request of a number of his adherents for information as to the concessions offered to the Unionists, declines to enter into details, but says the Liberals may rely upon his firm adherence to the principles and bases of his home rule policy.

If the exhaustive search for jurors in the Cleary trial shall be continued much longer there will be a fine chance for the remaining unconvicted boodle Aldermen to enjoy a respectable funeral.

The Young Men's Democratic Club held a special meeting last night to listen to the report of a special committee appointed "to take into consideration and report upon the expediency of promoting the formation of young men's Democratic clubs to unite with us in promoting reforms in the direction of a pure Democracy, " The report, which was written by E.J. Donnell, was ordered printed without being read, as there were only 13 members present.

Soudan, four years, by Happy Medium, dam Maria Sturgiss, by Almont, for $1,600; to J.S. Givens, Waverly, Kan., the b.c. Acapulco, four years, by Almont Lightning, dam Clarenda, by C.M. Clay, Jr., for $1,000.

TRENTON, March 14.--Both branches of the Legislature met at 8 o'clock this evening. The bill to abolish the Board of Public Works of Jersey City was read through a second time and laid over until to-morrow at the request of Mr. Tumulty, the introducer.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 14.--The Grand Jury here to-day failed to indict Farmer Scism and and Landlord Daly, of the hog-guessing case, who were arrested by order of Anthony Comstock charged with engaging in a lottery.
CITY OF MEXICO, March, 14.--Via Galveston.--The public announcement of the new tariff schedule shows that it is more liberal than the previous.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 14.--A case came before Judge Barnard which is of interest to 150,000 Knights of Honor in America. Magdalena Keppler, Executrix of Adama Macht, sued the order, the central office of which is in Missouri, for $1,000.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 14.--The body of Capt. Eads arrived on the City of Monticello from Nassau at 12 o'clock, accompanied by his widow and his daughter, Mrs. Hazzard, who were with him at Nassau. They were met here by J.F. How, his sonin-law. They left on a private car for St. Louis at 5 P.M. The funeral will take place there on Thursday. The remains were transferred to another casket here.

The beer boycott is ended. It has failed to bring about the object for which it was designed, but has accomplished another entirely unexpected. The Crosby High License bill, which comes up for consideration at Albany today, has been the white-winged messenger of peace.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 14.--The Coroner's inquest in the case of Mary C. Anderson, the young girl shot on the night of Feb. 7 on the Ayrestown road, near this place, was held to-day. The autopsy was made by Prof. Pancoast.

ZANZIBAR, March 14.--News has been received from Emin Bey to the effect that in November last he went to Uganda, and that King Mivanga refused to permit him to go through the country.
Mary E. McCool, a young daughter of Nicholas McCool, a rich contractor, was married to Sergt. John H. McNamara, of the Nineteenth Sub-Precinct, Nov. 10, 1885, and died April 8, last year.

There was a fire yesterday afternoon in Bleecker street, near Greene, and the usual fire line was formed. James Newman, a porter in a paper factory, got permission from Patrolman William F. Connery to deliver an armful of boxes at a building near the one on fire.
BELFAST, Me., March 14.--At the municipal election to-day Albert C. Burgess was chosen Mayor on what was called the tax reducer ticket.

Floating ice made a good deal of trouble for the Hudson River Railroad Sunday and gave one of its trains a narrow escape from a serious accident.

The Westchester County Grand Jury, in compliance with the charge of Justice Dykman made a week ago, paid an official visit to Sing Sing Prison yesterday for the purpose of inspecting the methods of punishment in use there and to take testimony bearing on the subject.
CHICAGO, March 14.--Michael O. Dezutti and Patrello Perona are Italian miners living at Diamond, near Braidwood. Perona boarded with Dezutti and won the affections of the latter's wife.
