BERLIN, March 14.--A decree has been issued directing that the four new infantry regiments and the Fourth Battalion, which have been added to the existing regiments, be garrisoned almost exclusively in Alsace-Lorraine and Baden, along the Rhine.

CLEVELAND, March 14.--The Euclid-Avenue Presbyterian Church to-night unanimously called to Rev. Dr. Samuel P. Sprecher, of San Francisco, formerly of Philadelphia and Utica, to succeed as Pastor the Rev. W.V.H. Davis, resigned to go to Worcester. The consideration offered is $4,500 salary and a parsonage.

Edward E. Bowen, an old resident of Brooklyn, died suddenly at the home of his sonin-law, William H. Williams, 11 Willow-street, yesterday afternoon. Mr. Bowen had been in his customary health, and Saturday was among those who followed Mr. Beecher, his old Pastor, to Greenwood.

CINCINNATI, March 14.--George S. Crawford, lumber dealer, assigned this afternoon. Liabilities, $100,000; assets, $60,000. Later in the day it was learned that S.W. W.G. Boyd, lumber dealers in this city, have made a bill of sale to Kilpatrick Co., of New-York, conveying all their effects here for $60,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 14.--Fannie Rasche, 60 years old, a widow, and for many years a street ragpicker, was found dead in her room, on North Peters street, this morning, lying across a pile of rags. A bank book and other securities were found in the room representing $4,400. The deceased woman has a brother and sister named Hobbs somewhere in the North.
Anton Rubinstein's opera of "Nero" was performed for the first time in this country at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 14.--The Czar, Czarina, and Czarowitz left this city yesterday for the imperial palace at Gatschina.
Letters from Bermuda, which were received yesterday by friends of William R. Travers in this city, state that he has gradually grown weaker of late.

The fact that James C. Bayles, who lives in Orange, N.J., but who voted last Fall in this city, had been selected to succeed Gen. Shaler as President of the Board of Health, had been so freely discussed Saturday that little surprise was caused yesterday when it became known that Mayor Hewitt had formally appointed him to the position.
When Sarah Bernhardt came into view at the Star Theatre last evening attired in a singularly effective gown of lace she conquered the large assemblage of spectators with a look and a gesture.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., March 14.--At Brown's Crossing the family of John Harris, colored, consisting of himself and wife and nine children, were poisoned by a Voodoo doctor whose powers they doubted. One of the children is dead, and the rest are unconscious and not expected to live.
HAVANA, March 14.--United States Senator Sherman and other distinguished American excursionists have arrived here.
GLASGOW, March 14.--The Lanarkshire miners have resumed work, the masters yielding the 6d. advance in wages demanded by the men. The agitation is ended.

The statement which has been made in Methodist Church circles to the effect that the Jane-Street Church, of which the Rev. N.B. Thompson is Pastor, was to be merged into the Franklin-Street Church, was positively denied yesterday. The Jane-Street Church is asserted to stand better financially to-day than it has for years past. Mr. Thompson is said to have done much to improve the condition of the church.

ROME, March 14.--At the Papal Consistory to-day the Pope announced that Monsignor di Rende, Papal Nuncio at Paris; Rampolla del Tindaro, Nuncio at Madrid; Vannutelli, Nuncio at Vienna; Massela, ex-Nuncio at Lisbon, and Bishop Giordani, Bishop of Ferrara, had been created Cardinals.
PHILADELPHIA, March 14.--The resignation of Purchasing Agent W.I. Wilson, of the Reading, has been announced by General Man ager McLeod.
The life and reign of Queen Elizabeth of England was the subject of John L. Stoddard's second lecture in his series of Lenten matinees at Daly's yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, March 14.--The visible supply of grain on March 12, as computed by the Secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, shows a decrease of 1,515,000 bushels wheat, 211,000 bushels corn, 217,000 bushels oats, 14,000 bushels rye, and 128,000 bushels barley.

Dockstader's minstrels added a bit of green to their black cork last night and sang many Irish songs, danced a few Irish jigs, and made merry in a lively skit they called "The Donnybrook Fair." "Ka-ren" and "Sarah Heartburn in 'Camille" were cheerfully received by the audience.

ELMIRA, N.Y., March 14.--Charles Rose, a young man of this city, shot himself in the breast in front of the residence of Charles Roberts, at Sullivanville, a small hamlet in the northern part of the county, last night.

Yesterday morning was a weather breeder. The air was mild and the sun smacked decidedly of the flowers of Spring. The young man put a bunch of violers in the buttonhole of his cutaway coat and sallied forth without his new Spring topcoat.

Mr. WOODMAN, the President of the Excise Board, writes to the Evening Post that he is not in favor of the bill, announced to have been prepared and to be favored by that board, for the sale of wine and beer after 1 o'clock on Sundays.

M. Eugene Grange, a dramatist, who has just died here at the age of 75, deserves a line of obituary notice, if only for the fact that he collaborated in the preparation for the stage of "The Corsican Brothers," a drama which is as popular in England as in France. He had also a hand in "The Memoirs of Mimi Bamboche," one of Hortense Schneider's successes at the Palais Royal.
ALBANY, March 14.--Even some of the Democratic Senators are quietly "kicking" over the course of their straight-backed Democratic Governor.

When Mayor Whitney was called to testify before the Bacon investigating committee, in the Brooklyn City Hall, yesterday morning, Corporation counsel Jenks said that now that it became apparent that the committee was going to turn its attention from county to municipal affairs, he would ask that the officials under investigation be represented by counsel.

Senor Agramonte, Acting Secretary of the Cuban Federation of Cigarmakers, in conversation yesterday about the arrest and expulsion of Secretary Rubeira at Ybor, Fla., said that Mr. Rubeira had been sent there to settle a strike in the factory of V. Martinez Ybor Co.

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, held yesterday afternoon at their office in Brooklyn, the plans prepared by the Executive Committee for the proposed new platform on the north side of the roadway on Centre-street were adopted, and a new locomotive was ordered purchased.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15.--Work at the morocco factory of E.A. Smith Co., 929 North Thirdstreet, was suspended to-day and the building and stock taken possession of by a Sheriff's officer. Nearly 400 hands are thrown out of employment.

Mrs. Beecher went to Peekskill yesterday with her son, Col. Henry Beecher, to take a last look at her old home, which is soon to be sold. To-morrow she expects to go to Florida with her daughter, Mrs. Scoville, and Miss Bullard.
Mr. Speaker CARLISLE went way to Boston last week to address the Bay State Club of that city on national politics, and he was very warmly received, as he ought to have been.
Coroner Mitchell continued his inquest at Yonkers yesterday on the case of Albert G. Wolf, the young man killed on Sunday evening by Cornelius Devitt.

Carter, of Titusville, and the Standard Oil Company, in Parlor F, of the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. The conference opened at 10 o'clock in the morning and lasted, with an intermission, until 7:30 P.M. CHICAGO, March 15.--The indications are that there will yet be a serious conflict between the Eastern and the Missouri River roads west from Chicago regarding the percentage basis on traffic to and from Mississippi River points.

TROY, N.Y., March 15.--The Rensselaer County Supervisors met for organization to-day. The board stands 15 Republicans to 14 Democrats. Louis Behrman's trial on the charge of attempting to blackmail his former employer, Morris Spiegel, was continued yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part II. Many tears of genuine sorrow were shed yesterday at the funeral of Charles O'Connor, Superintendent of the Newsboys' Lodging House. The services were held in the large dining hall of the institution amid a profusion of flowers and mourning drapery.

Major Thomas Howard celebrated the ninety-eighth anniversary of his birth yesterday at his home, 245 Carlton-avenue, Brooklyn. He is still active, and enjoys good health with the exception of an occasional touch of rheumatism. He can still read large type with the aid of eyeglasses.

There is but little hope that the sentence pronounced by Chief-Justice Beasley, consigning Titus to the gallows, will be interfered with.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 16.--The Republican members of the Philadelphia delegation in the House of Representatives met to-night and decided unanimously to rearrange the Congressional apportionment for Philadelphia so as to provide a Democratic district for Mr. Randall.

MADISON, Wis., March 16.--Two freight trains on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul and Chicago and North western Railways came in collision at a crossing on what is called "The Fill." An engine was badly smashed and a number of cars dumped into the lake. The engineer and fireman saved their lives by jumping. The loss is estimated at $10,000.

LONDON, March 16.--Sir G.O. Trevelyan, speaking at Liskeard this evening, said that his position as regards Ireland had not changed. He hoped, however, that a basis of agreement would yet be found by conciliatory methods.

CINCINNATI, March 16.--George F. Belden Co., rubber dealers, 104 Main-street, has assigned to Baker Humphries. They previously filed two chattel mortgages on their stock, one for $10,000, to the Fidelity National Bank of Cincinnati, and the other to Josiah Belden, of New-York City, for $15,575. Assets and liabilities are supposed to be about equal, and to reach $50,000. Belden Co. succeeded the old firm of Bart Hickox.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 16.--At Dixiana Stud Farm, four miles from this city, King Ban, a noted thoroughbred sire, died late this afternoon after an illness of 24 hours of spinal meningitis. King Ban was a chestnut horse, foaled 1875, by King Tom, dam Atlantis, by Thormanby.

BOSTON, March 16.--Secretary Endicott was interviewed by a Post reporter to-day at his home in Salem. In his relations with the President there had not been the slightest misunderstanding or anything that could in the least affect their cordiality.

As buyers and sellers are both at sea as to the cost of transportation nothing can be done.

A Nantwich correspondent writes: "A Cheshire dealer has received instructions from Germany to buy a large number of horses for military purposes, and has accompanied a representative of the German Army to several horse fairs." A Dungannon correspondent telegraphs that at Moy fair, which was held yesterday, over 200 horses, adapted for cavalry purposes, were purchased by German agents. Owing to the unusual demand prices were considerably enhanced.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 16.--The Senate to-day passed finally Senator Cooper's joint resolution, providing for the submission to the people of an amendment to the Constitution abolishing the poll tax as a qualification for voting; also, among others, the bills authorizing County Commissioners to discharge prisoners without insolvency proceedings, and authorizing County Commissioners to provide office room for Superintendents of Public Schools.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., March 16.--Mary C. Anderson, who was shot, as alleged, by her cousin, Bart Peak, and who died Saturday, was buried near here to-day. Her funeral was the largest ever known in this part of the State, hundreds being unable to gain admission to the house.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, March 17.--The blockade on the Canadian Pacific in the Rocky Mountains is complete, and there will be no through trains for a fortnight. The snow has blocked the roads, and "Mud Tunnel" has caved in. Passengers who went West two days ago have returned from the mountains, having been unable to get through, and went south to reach the coast by the American lines.

ALTOONA, Penn., March 17.--A large boiler in the sawmill of Joseph Ramer, five miles from here, exploded to-day while the mill hands were at dinner. Ramor, the only man in the mill, was hurled through the roof and picked up outside with an arm and leg broken, shoulder dislocated, and internally injured. The mill was completely wrecked.

Ford, of Shreveport, who shot and killed a man named Kirkpatrick in this city somo four months ago for the alleged seduction of his wife. Petitions for the pardon signed by thousands of the people of forth Louisiana, male and female, were filed with the board.

Hutohinson left Port Jefferson for the lighthouse on Monday and his boat and cap have since come ashore. The letters "L.H. B." are marked on the cap. It is regarded as almost certain that Hutchinson was drowned.

Friends of Dr. F.A. Roy, of 165 West Fifty-third-street, called at Police Headquarters at an early hour this monring and said that he has mysteriously disappeared. He left home yesterday afternoon with the intention of delivering a lecture before the College of Dentistry. He promised to return at 7 o'clock. He delivered the lecture, but has not been seen since by any of his family.

According to the annual report of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company for 1886, 1,000 miles of new road were completed during the year. The total mileage on Dec. 31, 1886, was 4,687, and the average mileage operated 4,601.

ROME, March 17.--A public consistory was held to-day in the Sala Regia. It began at 10:20 o'clock and concluded at noon. The procession was headed by the consistorial advocates, with attendants arrayed in crimson robes and ermine capes.

No news of the crew has been received.

Whittaker, a son by the first marriage, is trying to break the will.

Manager Poole, of Poole's Theatre, on Eighth-street, has been having a curions experience. His theatre has been suffering from a "silent boycott," whatever that may be.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 18.--Gen. Bragg, who is at his home in fond du Lac, is slightly improved in condition to-day, and a glimmer of light was apparent in the eye, the sight of which has been lost.

PANAMA, March 9.--A Venezuelan paper --the Sol de Abril--says that in six districts there honorable men have been murdered to prevent them from voting with the Liberal Party and making manifestations against the policy of Guzman Blanco and his party.

An adjourned meeting of the Independence Day Association was held last evening at the Ninth Judicial Court Room, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth-street, near Lexington-avenue. The committee appointed at the last meeting to draw up a constitution and by-laws made its report, which was adopted.

BUFFALO, March 18.--The Richmond, Buffalo's newest and best furnished hotel, St. James's Hall, Buffalo's oldest and largest theatre, and several stores and other buildings were destroyed by fire at 3:30 o'clock this morning.

TORONTO, Ontario, March 18.--T.H. McDuffie, the absconding forger from Texas, left here tonight, accompanied by Deputy Sheriff Peffers, of Dallas, Texas., for the scene of his offense. President Cleveland's warrant for his extradition arrived to-day.
David Stewart and George Woodle, colored, were arrested in Jersey City yesterday for having robbed the residence of Joseph Allen, at 293 Varick-street.
CHICAGO, March 18.--A meeting of the Executive Committee of the newly organized Merchants and Manufacturers' Association of Chicago was held this afternoon.

OTTAWA, March 18.--The Goverment has received from the United States authorities a requisition for the extradition of Francesco Trinarco, an Italian, who murdered a fellow-countryman in Chicago about a month ago. Trinarco escaped to Manitoba, but was arrested in Winnipeg a short time ago and is now in jail there.
The flight of Walter E. Lawton is bringing to the surface a singular record. For 41 years Lawton has been in business, the greater part of that time in this city.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 18.--There is every probability that the difficulty between the United States Commissioner of Agriculture and the Illinois Board of Live Stock Commissioners, arising from the pleuro-pneumonia outbreak early in the Winter, will soon be settled.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 18.--The capital stock of the East Tennessee National Bank has been increased from $150,000 to $350,000. With the organization of the Third National Bank that banking capital of Knoxville allows a total increase of $550,000.

LONDON, March 18.--In Mincing-lane markets beet sugar is firm, but quiet; cane is steady; refined is slow of sale. There is less demand for coffee, and the market is dull. Tea is dull and inactive; Ceylon is easier; Indian continues depressed. Rice is rather lower. Black pepper is advancing; white is unaltered.
SOFIA, March 18.--The Regents have assured the foreign envoys that no more persons who participated in the recent insurrection will be executed.

RAHWAY, N.J., March 18.--Benjamin Squire, a former member of the Board of Finance, who was tried and convicted of embezzlement and sentenced, in 1885, to three years in State prison, has been pardoned and released. Squire is connected with some of the most prominent residents of this city, and there were many who felt his conviction was unjust.

George Garrett Sickles, the father of Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, died at his home in NewRochelle at midnight on Thursday, in the eightyseventh year of his age.

LIMA, Peru, March 18, via Galveston.--A letter from Mr. Guillaume, President of the committee of Peruvian and French bondholders to President Caceres is published. In this letter Mr. Guillaume opposes Mr. W.R. Grace's proposal and makes a counter proposal which will give the bondholders the right to work all Peruvian mines and establish a bank with a capital of 10,000,000f. The letter has attracted much attention.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19.--At the Philadelphia Methodist Conference to-day the committee to which was referred the application of the Rev. T.B. Miller for a restoration of his certificate of ordination reported recommending that the application be not granted. The report was adopted.

President C.P. Huntington denied yesterday a story that has been floating around Wallstreet lately. The Central Pacific Railroad, he said, will not issue now stock to take up convertible bonds. It will issue $8,000,000 in stock, however, to cover newly constructed road and recent acquisitions and betterments.

LONDON, March 19.--It is stated that the new alliance between Germany, Austria, and Italy places each of these powers on an equality. All three will undertake the protection of individual interests, the infringement of which might disturb the peace of Europe. It is rumored at Vienna that the Emperor Francis Joseph will follow the example of Germany and confer a decoration on Signer di Robilant, the Italian Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, March 19.--The announcement of the names of the five Inter-State Com merce Commissioners was expected to-day, but the usual hour for issuing nominations passed without bringing the list from the President.

BOSTON, March 19.--In addition to the Summer courses in chemistry and botany which are offered by Harvard, College, there will be given this Summer for the first time in any college of the country a course in "physical training for teachers."

An English company is to provide pure water for Genoa, which now only receives a very insufficient supply through the half-ruined aqueducts of Nicholai and Corzente. The water of the Concasca and Bisagno Rivers is to be stored in large reservoirs and will be brought into the city by iron pipes.

There is no member of the royal family who does so much really practical good work as Princess Christian, and it is a real blessing to the poor of Windsor that she should be settled near the town, as she is constantly engaged in laboring for them, and sets an admirable example to her rich neighbors.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., March 19.--The Hon. James Sharnahan, State Superintendent of Public Works, is reported as a little better to-day. His Condition, however, is very serious. He has been Confined to his bed for a week or more, and has done no business except signing papers brought to him from Albany. Some persons, who are apparently well informed, express a belief that he will not recover.

The common feeling respecting debtors and creditors is often erroneous, and, as is common with fallacies, it affects with double force the young and inexperienced. Debtors are represented in the ordinary language of a large portion of society as a set of amiable, unfortunate, and most interesting persons.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19.--The Republican politicians of Chester County have ceased hostilities for a while, and West Chester has time to discuss the disgrace of Jacob Devaughn, janitor of the railroad station of the prosperous town.

RED BANK, N.J., March 19.--A case of interest to farmers has just been decided by Justice A.J. Child. Peter Drummond, of Asbury Park, died some time ago, and Edward H. Ward was appointed Administrator of the estate.

CHICAGO, March 19.--The various roads in the Western States Passenger Association, comprising all lines west, northwest, and southwest from Chicago, have agreed to abolish the system of issuing land exploring tickets at reduced rates and, after April 4 land explorers will have to purchase tickets at regular tariff rates.
Mr. Besant is in part right and in part wrong in his contention about authors' relations with publishers.

President Bayles, of the Health Department, was in consultation yesterday with Assemblyman Jacob A. Cantor, who introduced the Tenement House bill in the Assembly; Col. Clark, the Secretary of the department, and Col. Prentice, counsel to the Board of Health.

Capt. Murphy, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, went to Police Headquarters yesterday and conferred with Commissioner McClave and Superintendent Murray in relation to the arrest by him of Martin Baker, alias "Moxey," who is suspected of having assaulted Miss Marie Ernestine Schmid.

Samuel Bellefont, a coal handler employed by the Wilkesbarre Coal Company, was taken to the Chambers-Street Hospital yesterday afternoon with his right leg and foot so badly shattered as to require amputation. With him were brought Levi Schwarz and Solomon Lannker, also coal handlers, each of whom had a badly bruised foot. The injuries were received from a fall of coal from a car in the company's yard at Port Jervis.
A small blue Book is published containing a report drawn up by Mr. S. Brown, Government engineer, of what is called the locust campaign in Cyprus in 1885-6.

Edward Lafayette Tilton, an old actor of sound training, died on Thursday morning at Birmingham, Ala., whither he had gone as a member of the company supporting Mr. Louis James. During his long professional career his work was always respectable and often better than that. He was sincere and thorough.

Four thousand pounds of unwholesome fish were seized yesterday at Fulton Market. Prof. Carpenter's illustrations of "Hypnotiam" serve to attract a large attendance to Grand Opera House Hall, Eighth-avenue and Twenty-third-street, every night.

The importance of Long Island as a manufacturing centre has recently been brought to special notice by Messrs. Sohmer Co., the well known pianoforte manufacturers, erecting a large factory at Astoria.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 19.--The steamship Hartville, of West Hartlepool, Capt. Bartram, from Norfolk, Va., cotton laden for Liverpool, arrived here to-day, having been in collision with an iceberg.
BISMARCK, Dakota, March 19.--The flood in the Missouri River is still at its height, and there is much alarm concerning the fate of settlers along the banks.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 19.--Alexander Cummings, a well known manufacturer of Walton, Delaware County, suddenly disappeared last November, and all efforts to trace him were unavailing. Many reports were since started that he had been seen in Kansas and later in Pennsylvania.
When the Cleary trial was resumed yesterday the court room of the Oyer and Terminer was crowded. Many politicians were present and many of the faces were unmistakably Irish.
Modern is the reply of Alexandre Dumas when asked the other day if he saw much of his neighbor at Marly, Victorien Sardou. "No; we are excellent friends, but we see each other as little as possible.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., March 19.--Hathaway, Soule Harrington's statement of savings of edgemakers in their shoe factory has opened the men's mouths, and they say they have averaged only $10 a week through the busy season. They have moderated their demand to an advance of 50 per cent., and the firm offers 35 per cent. The men say they have reason to believe that 50 per cent. will be granted by next Tuesday.

MARLBOROUGH, N.Y., March 19.--Reports received to-day from the principal fruit growing localities along the Hudson River state that all classes of horticulturists are jubilant in the anticipation of securing one of the largest fruit yields on record the coming Summer. Peaches have been a failure for five years.

The gravediggers of Calvary Cemetery have not succeeded in getting all their grievances remedied. The only favor granted them thus far by the Board of Managers of the cemetery was to have a shed built for the men to eat their meals in.

MONTREAL, March 19.--Stewart Co., of London, England, and St. John, New-Brunswick, have through their attorneys, Messrs. Geoffrion Co., taken an action for $500,000 against the Bank of British North America.

ROME, March 18.--A very large number of personal including Archbishop Carr and Bishop Keane, were present to-day at the ceremonies attending Cardinal Taschereau's entering into possession of his titular church of Santa Maria della Vittoria.

A burly street car driver on Broadway last night was plaintively heard to remark that if the Street Commissioners didn't prohibit mind readers and their carriages from taking possession of the car tracks he would tender his resignation. There was reason in the complaint.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 19.--The Third National Bank was formally organized this morning, with R.N. Hood President and John A. McKeldin Cashier. The capital of the bank is $3,000,000.

CHICAGO, March 19.--The action of the North western roads in advancing the through rate on grain and its products from 7 to 18 cents per 100 pounds from Minneapolis to Chicago or Milwaukee, was a general topic of conversation in Western railroad circles yesterday.
The Twenty-third Regiment had a gala time last night at its armory in Brooklyn. Mayor Whitney reviewed it, and then the labor of giving 308 medals was begun.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19.--The negotiations involving the future of the Baltimore and Ohio were transferred from Baltimore to Philadelphia to-day.

The Executive Committee of the AntiMonopoly League met last evening at the Knickerbocker Cottage, on Sixth-avenue, and passed resolutions denouncing the Crosby High License bill as class legislation, and calling upon the Legislature to defeat it. A peculiar phenomenon was observed in the southeastern sky last evening at about 7:30, when three streaks of fire, extending upward from the horizon, each of equal length and apparently the same distance apart, were visible. They resembled tails of comets and were very bright when first seen, gradually fading until 8 o'clock, when they disappeared. The same thing was seen some three months ago and noted in the Herald at the time.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 19.--The Senate to-day passed a bill requiring railway companies to furnish all express companies equal facilities upon the same terms. POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 19.--The Casinos of this city met the New-Havens, the champion of the Eastern States, in a game of polo to-night, in the presence of an immense assemblage. Conners of the New-Havens, won the first goal in 2 minutes, 35 seconds.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 19.--Company B, Twenty-second Regiment, of New-York, and Company K, Second Regiment, of Wallingford, gave a big joint athletic carnival in the Second Regiment Armory here to-night.

CHICAGO, March 19.--The report of Receiver Cooley, of the Wabash Railway, covering receipts and expenditures from Jan. 1 to March 1, was filed in the United States court here today. It shows receipts amounting to $887,781. The disbursements on account of agents were $160,184; for operating expenses, $253,797; for supplies and material, $5,772; for interest, $16,034, making a total of $435,788 and leaving a balance of $451,993.

Two young shoemakers, John Guinan and Charles Bohen, who room-together at 228 Parkrow, went into the shooting gallery of John Lee, at 117 Bowery, last evening, to try their skill at the targets. Guinan picked up a Ballard rifle, and, standing at the shooting bar, prepared to fire.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19.--Edward Leening, aged 52 years, who, two weeks ago, attempted suicide by cutting his throat after a quarrel with his wife, succeeded in ending his life to-day by drowning in a bathtub at the Episcopal Hospital, where he had been under treatment since his former attempt on his life. Leening and his wife came here rom Germany about five months ago.

CINCINNATI, March 19.--Guy Weber, Treasurer and Manager of the St. Andrews Bay Land Company, of Florida, was arrested this afternoon on a charge of misusing the United States mails by sending out circulars and matter designed to defraud. The company has been offering to sell lots in Florida at $1 apiece.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 19.--Gov. Marmaduke to-day signed the bill repealing the State oleomargarine law, which provided that any one selling or manufacturing oleomargarine within the State should pay a fine of $600 and suffer imprisonment for three years. Dealers in and manufacturers of this article now can carry on their trade in this State by complying with the United States law.

ALBANY, March 19.--Michael J. Rickard, the Governor's nominee for Railroad Commissioner, sat around the Senate for an hour yesterday and for an hour watched the proceedings of that honorable body. It was the first time in his life that he had had any desire or opportunity to see the Senate in session.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 19.--A Post Office Inspector yesterday discovered that the accounts of H.C. Douglass, Postmaster at Plainfield, were short $500 or $600. While the Inspector was at dinner Douglass took $150 from the money order account and a lot of stamps, drew from the bank his private deposit of $100, and left the town. He was appointed some months ago. His shortage is attributed to losses at poker.

The friends of Dr. Frank Austin Roy, the dentist who has been missing since Thursday afternoon, are becoming alarmed at his mysterious absence. Neither they nor the police have been able to obtain the slightest clue to his whereabouts. Since the moment the doctor closed the door of his residence, 165 West Fiftythird-street, when he started for the College of Dentistry to deliver a lecture, no one seems to have seen him.

BOSTON, March 19.--When the Railroad Commissioners reopened this morning the investigation of the Forest Hills disaster Chairman Crocker deemed it best to make a statement that would satisfy the public that everything possible would be done to get at the cause of the accident and place the responsibility where it belongs.
RICHMOND, Va., March 19.--In the House of Delegates to-day a lengthy preamble and resolution were introduced by Mr. Hoge, of Pulaski, in relation to the State debt.

The Poughkeepsie Eagle of yesterday says that the story that Secretary Endicott has stated that no authority existed from the United Statets for the construction of the Poughkeepsie Bridge is an old one.

BOSTON, March 19.--Detective Ducey, of Cambridge, has been in New-Jersey the past few days hunting for Dr. Andrew Jackson Grant on a charge of swindling, and a dispatch from Woodbury last evening stated that he found the doctor at that place and will bring him to Cambridge forthwith, the doctor agreeing to come without a requisition.

The Rev. J.C. Mackay, of the United Presbyterian denomination, who was formerly stationed in this city, the Presbytery decided last week, ought to be deposed from the ministry and the Synod is asked to take the necessary action.

Mr. GEORGE R. CONNER is Commissioner of Public Works for the city of Brooklyn. He was asked on Friday, before the investigation committee, for his opinion as to the utility of the civil service law to the service of the city. He replied: " It's no good.

ST. LOUIS, March 19.--A memorial meeting in honor of the late James B. Eads was held at the Merchants' Exchange this afternoon. Business was suspended during the meeting, which was largely attended. The floor and galleries were crowded. Resolutions eulogizing the deceased and expressing sympathy for the bereaved family were presented, and after remarks upon his life and character by many prominent citizens, were adopted.

CHICAGO, March 19.--The Republicans to-day nominated Mr. John A. Roche for Mayor. The Domocrats nominate a candidate next Wednesday. May or Harrison is out in a card declaring that he will not accept a renomination.

BALTIMORE, March 19.--An accident of unusual horror occurred on the property of the Baltimore United Oil Company to-day. A still of 600 barrels capacity was being repaired. It was said to contain no oil.
BALTIMORE, March 19.--There is no enterprise in this country about which there is so much of interesting reminiscence and history as the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

English, or Inglis, the young man arrested on Thursday for shooting at members of the New-York police force, is suspected, on purely circumstantial evidence, to be the murderer of Lyman Smith Weeks, who was shot in cold blood at his residence on De Kalb-avenue, Brooklyn, early Wednesday morning.

Peter B. Sweeny, the Bismarck and brains of the old Tammany ring, sailed yesterday for Havre on the French steamship La Champagne. His family are in Paris, where he has lived about all the time since 1875. After a prolonged absence he returned to NewYork Dec. 30, 1885.

BERLIN, March 20.--The Crown Prince and Princess met the Prince of Wales on his arrival here and drove with him to their palace. Other arrivals are the Crown Prince and Princess of Sweden, the Grand Duke Vladimir, Grand Duke Michael, of Oldenburg, and the Duke of Saxe-Meiningen.
Ralph Ogle, now an aged man, was at one time well known in sporting circles. He was an upright citizen and had considerable money.

LIMERICK, March 20.--The striking tailors of the army clothing factory here have been locked out. The men struck because the manager of the factory took local shop work.

The body of the man who committed suicide at the Pennsylvania Railway station in Newark on Friday was identified yesterday as that of Albert Koster, a cigar manufacturer of Stroudsburg, Penn., by his brother. He said business reverses were the cause of the act.
Inquiry was made of the Brooklyn police yesterday about Nellie Arnold, the little girl found astray Saturday night at Third-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, and who was taken to Matron Webb.

MADRID, March 20.--The trade convention between Cuba and Porto Rico on the one hand and the United States on the other, which was to have terminated in April, has been prolonged to November in order to give time for the negotiation of a treaty.
The Independent Clothing Cutters' Union organized an open trades union yesterday at 10 Santon-street, and applied for admission to membership in the American Federation of Labor.

Inglis, or Engilsh, is the burglar who successfully operated in the Fourteenth Brooklyn Precinct, who exchanged shots with Patrolman Lowe on the night Charles Rumpt's residence in Jefferson-street was robbed, and who may have killed Lyman S. Weeks.

Robert L. Thiele, a decorator and fresco painter, who lives at 62 Stanton-street, has been working at the Metropolitan Hotel, Brooklyn. One night last week he slept there, and next day a silver watch was missing.

CHICAGO, March 20.--The week has been a prosperous one at all the Chicago playhouses, devoted mainly to music and mirth, however, and "Adonis" continues its successful season at the Chicago Opera House, entering this evening upon its fourth and last week.

Prof. Baird's "History of the Rise of the Huguenots of France," published some three years ago, was so well received on all hands that to the writer was assigned a place by the side of the best American historians.

TROY, N.Y., March 21.--2:15 A.M.--The Grand Central Theatre and two adjoining buildings are in a blaze. Three alarms have been sounded, and the whole Fire Department is out. The fire promises to be a serious conflagration.

DES MOINES, Iowa, March, 20.--Daniel Miller, of Van Buren, aged 102 years and 8 months, is dead. He was a native of Pennsylvania, migrating in succesion to Kentucky Indiana, and Iowa. His numerous descendants include three great-great-grandchildren.

CHICAGO, March 20.--Max Ernest Virgo, a young Englishman of respectable family, attempted to commit suicide to-day by taking muriatic acid in the once of the General Secretary of the Young Men's Christian Association, A.T. Hemingway, and Mr. Hemingway nearly lost Lis life in trying to save that of Virgo.

William Ferzel and his wife, Marie Pres-- cott, the actress, had a disagreement some time ago, and Feb. 14 Mr. Perzel published a card, saying that he had forever renounced her love and would not be responsible any longer for her actions as his wife nor, of course, pay any debts she might contract in his name.

George Garrett Sickles, father of Gen. Daniel E. Sickles, was buried yesterday at Beechwood Cemetery, New-Rochelle. A special train took from this city about 50 members of Kane Lodge, No. 454, F. and A.M., of which Mr. Sickles was a charter member.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 20.--David Clark, of this city a retired merchant, has given to the Hartford Hospital and Old People's Home jointly, his fine farm of 108 acres to the southern part of Hartford; also 20 head of Jersey cattle and the whole outfit of the farm as it stands.
Miss Matilda Travers, a daughter of William R. Travers, arrived yesterday from Bermuda on the steamship Trinidad.
On March 4 a young man, accompanied by a dashing blonde, hired a horse and wagon, valued at $600, from John McGuire's stable at 220 West Forty-eighth-street, but he never returned it.
Some remarkable instances of the extraordinary depreciation in the value of property in Lincolnshire were furnished at a large estate sale held at Long Sutton yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Penn., March 20.--William Ritchie, son of G.W. Ritchie of West Alexander, while in an intoxicated condition, fell under a train of cars at Wheeling yesterday. The wheels passed over him and amputated both feet, and he died soon after.
Inquiries are often made about Sir Charles Dilke. With a prudence and good feeling which will be generally acknowledged with pleasure he is remaining comparatively in private life.
Halifax people, from his Worship the Mayor down, are doing their best to make their big yacht race, which is to mark the Queen's jubilee, as much of a suceees as crack boats can make it.
GENEVA, March 20.--Joseph Ignace Kraszewski, the Polish poet and essayist, is dead, and the Polish residents here have informed Prince Bismarck of the fact.
Another Catholic church besides St. Stephen's has been entered by burglars recently. One Sunday night a few weeks ago St. Cecilia's Church, in East One Hundred and Sixth-street, was visited.
The Central Labor Union held its usual meeting at Clarendon Hall yesterday, and elected Committees on Credentials, Organization, Arbitration, Grievances, Outside Communication, Boycott, and Auditing.

No further news of the yachts Coronet and Dauntless was brought to this port yesterday, although a number of vessels arrived during the day. The masters of several of these reported having seen any number of icebergs, but no yachts. Storms from the west were also reported, but these, instead of proving a drawback to the racers, must have wafted them rapidly on their journey.
ELMIRA, N.Y., March 20.--William Church, although only 24 years old, is one of the worst forgers in the hands of the law. On Saturday he was sentenced to 10 years in the Auburn State Prison...

WALTON, N.Y., March 20.--The body of Alexander Cummings, who has been a cooper here for the past eight or ten years, and who mysteriously disappeared from Walton on Nov. 18 last, was found Wednesday afternoon about five miles below this village.
Martin Baker, the man arrested on suspicion of being Miss M.E. Schmid's assailant, was discharged by Justice Welde in the Harlem Court yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20.--The remains of Pierre Solider Milon, a soldier under the First Napoleon, were laid at rest in the new Cathedral Cemetery this afternoon.

The Pennyverein Benefit Association, a society of young women, had a ball Saturday night in the hall in the rear of John Ross's saloon, 335 West Thirty-ninth-street. Michael J. Rickard, Gov. Hill's latest nominee for Railroad Commissioner, has not made his effort yet to get the backing of the labor organizations of this city, as he stated at Albany he intended to do.

ROME, March 20.--Bishop Keane, of Richmond, preached a maginificent sermon this morning in the Irish Franciscan Church of St. Isidore on the subject of St. Patrick and the Irish Nation, comparing the early glories of Christian Ireland to the transfiguration of Christ on the Mount, and her after persecution and suffering to the journey to Calvary.

There will be a change in the programme of performances offered by Barnum and Forepaugh, at Madison-Square Garden to-night, and many new acts will be substituted. The combined shows have so many acts that they must add new ones every week.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 20.--Moses W. Fische, of the Corinne Opera Company, which has been playing here for the past week, was found dead in bed at the Palmer House this morning. Death was caused by heart disease. He had been an actor for over 40 years. His home was in Providence, R.I.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The eleventh section of the Inter-State Commerce Commission bill provides that "no person in the employ of or holding any official relation to any common carrier subject to the provisions of the act, or owning stock or bonds thereof, or who is in any manner pecuniarily interested therein, shall enter upon the duties of or hold" the office of Commissioner.

Two masons at work on a scaffolding at the height of the third floor of a house on the Boulevard Excelmans, at Auteuil, yesterday, quarreled about a sum of a few pence and came to blows.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--During the past Winter, which was an unusually severe one at sea, the Fish Commission succeeded in hatching 35,000,000 cod eggs, bringing the young up by hand, so to speak, to the age of self-feeding adolescence, and turning them loose into the ocean. This "crop" will be ripe four and five years hence.
New-Brunswick was wildly excited yesterday by a story that a coffin full of bones and a lot of bloody clothing had been found under the Denmead hut. The report had but a slight foundation.

George E. Horton and Miss Hattie Norton, of Port Jefferson, were to have been married on Saturday, but Horton did not put in an appearance and the wedding did not take place. Horton, who is a young machinist, has had the wedding postponed twice before.

William H. Crossman, of Crossman Brothers, commission merchants at 77 and 79 Broad-street, went to the Detective Bureau on Friday and applied for the arrest of his shipping clerk, Daniel Jenkins, of 997 Broadway, Brooklyn.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 20.--Late yesterday afternoon the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr. Pendleton, and the Assistant Sergeant-at-Arms were arrested on a charge of assault preferred before Justice Tegener by Mr. H.S. Canfield, of the San Antonio Express, who was ejected from the House in the latter part of February, on account of certain articles written by him reflecting upon some of the members.
No tidings were received yesterday by the friends of Lean Theresa Rhoades, who has been absent from her home, 97 South Fourth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, since Wednesday.

The Jane-Street Methodist Episcopal Church celebrated its forty-second anniversary yesterday. In the morning there was a reunion, or love feast, of all the former Sunday school Superintendents and in the afternoon a platform meeting.

PORTLAND, Oregon, March 20.--Bamberger Frank, general merchandise dealers, of Lake City, Oregon, and Weisre City, Idaho, have failed, with habilities of about $100,000, of which $62,000 is owing in San Francisco, $8,000 in Portland, and the balance in the East and to local creditors. The firm was regarded as the strongest in Eastern Oregon. It is understood that they offer a compromise of 65 cents on the dollar.

Saltado Minello, an Italian lad 13 years old, died suddenly at 5 York-street yesterday without medical attendance. He had been out on the street examining ash barrels and, it is believed, found something which he ate that poisoned him. The boy was very poor.

BISMARCK, Dakota, March 20.--The Missouri River is still on the rampage. The Buford rise reached this point to-day, and the water is flowing over the prairie at a greater depth and more terrific speed than ever.
An Irishman telephoned to Brooklyn Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon that a man had handed himself at 87 First-street.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 20.--About 2 o'clock Saturday afternoon, just as the numerous guests of the Hotel San Marco in this city were returning from luncheon, they were startled by the sharp ring of a pistol resounding through the long corridors.

Representatives of many of the leading dry goods houses of New-York, with members of several Western firms, met in the rooms of the Merchants' Club, in Leonard-street, yesterday afternoon, to express their opinion of the new trunk line freight classification.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21.--Mr. William L. Royall, counsel for the English Council of Foreign Bondholders and representing their affairs in connection with Virginia's debt, was to-day convicted in the Hustings Court of intimidating the Grand Jury of that court and was fined $150.

BERLIN, March 21.--Emperor William's Birthday festivities virtually began yesterday, many societies and clubs throughout Germany holding reunions in honor of the occasion. The influx of strangers into Berlin continued to-day.

BOSTON, March 21.--The long-expected application of the West End Railway for permission to tunnel under Boston Common came to-day in the shape of a petition to the Legislature. The idea of tunneling under the common has been ridiculed a great deal, but this company evidently means to do it, if it can get permission.

FALL RIVER, Mass., March 21.--With a very fair demand for 64-squares and various styles of odd goods the Printing Cloth market is steady at 3 3/8c. less per cent. for the above, but dull for 60x56 Cloths.

BOSTON, March 21.--At the investigation of the Forest Hills disaster to-day Civil Engineer Henry A.G. Pomeroy testified as an engineering expert of 38 years' experience.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21.--The ice in the Hudson at this place and for three miles north is on the move. The Great Scott and Arrow, of the Hudson River Ice Yacht Club, sailed the last races for the season on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 21.--Capt. S.M. Mills, Fifth Artillery, has been relieved from duty in this city and ordered to join his proper station. Fifty recruits have been ordered to the Division of the Missouri for the Third Cavalry, and 27 colored recruits to Fort Shelling on the 25th inst. The resignation of Cadet William W. Farish, of North Carolina, has been accepted by the Secretary of War.

PALESTINE, Texas, March 21.--In the Democratic Congressional Convention to-night, on the two hundred and seventy-second ballot, William M. Johnson's name was withdrawn, and amid one of the wildest scenes ever witnessed in a Texas convention. William H. Martin was unanimously nominated to fill the seat in the House of Representatives occupied for many years by Judge John H. Reagan.

NEW-HAVEN. Conn., March 21.--The Criminal Club of Yale College gave its first annual banquet to-night. The club is unique in its way, and great care was taken to admit none but members to the banquet.

BOSTON, March 21.--A meeting of the creditors of Randall, Giles Shallies, boot and shoe manufacturers, was held to-day. The nominal assets were shown to be $79,037. Of the accounts $13,700 are considered good $18,500 doubtful, and $24,000 bad. The liabilities are given at $101,200. A committee was appointed to investigate the affairs of the firm and report at a future meeting.

Goldsmith was second and Mr. Craven's 3-year-old chestnut filly, by Albert Victor, out of Pompano, third. A meeting of the Trustees and members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was held at Mayor Hewitt's residence, on Lexington-avenue, last evening, to confer with him upon the question of Sunday openings. HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 21.--The schooner Parthenia, from Trinidad, reports that on the 13th inst. the first mate, John Townsend, was knocked overboard and drowned. The second mate was also knocked overboard with him, but was saved.
After three months of gymnasium work the 'Varsity and Freshman crews of Columbia College began their work on the Harlem River yesterday.

MONTREAL, March 21.--The writ of capias taken against Mr. Loughran, of New-York, by one of the servants of the Windsor Hotel here, whom he had charged with stealing a diamond ring from his room, and who sued him for damaged for false arrest was quashed to-day, on the ground that there was nothing to show any evil intent.

The local assemblies of the car drivers of this State, New-Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, and Pennsylvania, are each going to send a representative to a conference to be held in Philadelphia for the purpose of discussing the advisability of forming a national district assembly of the Knights of Labor. If they agree they will apply for a charter from the General Executive Board.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 21.--The New-YOrk Comedy Company, with Mr. John Jennings as star, disbanded at Port Jervis yesterday.

MACON, Ga., March 21.--A shooting affray occurred to-day on the place of Mr. Sim Spivey, in Putnam County, which resulted in the killing or one negro, the serious wounding of another, and injury to a white man.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 21.--The first of a series of exhibition games between the Memphis Southern League nine and the Syracuse Club, of Syracuse, N.Y., was played to-day. The score stood: Memphis, 11; Syracuse, 4.

RICHMOND, Va., March 21.--A caucus of the Democratic members of the Legislature was held tonight and spent three hours in a discussion of the various measures presented at this session looking to a settlement of the State debt. The caucus agreed not to take a vote on any question until all who wished had had an opportunity to express their views on the subject.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 21.--Another bank was organized here to-day, making the fourth within a short time. It will be capitalized at $100,000. Rush Strong will be President.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 21.--The Carll Opera House in this city was to-day leased by Dr. A. E. Winchell, for a long term of years, to George B. Bunnell, whose museum in Buffalo was destroyed by the Richmond Hotel fire. The theatre is the biggest in the State. Mr. Bunnell has been conducting a museum here with great success for the past few years.

The Baron de Lorme, a Frenchman with a speculative turn of mind, who will be recalled as having some connection with a scheme for building a railroad in China, has recently turned his attention to ship building and is now posing as a bidder for the Roach ship yard at Chester, Penn.

Dr. E.J. Jones, a specialist, who has an office at 321 Market-street, Newark, has not been seen at his place of business since the middle of last week. Nothing as to his whereabouts can be learned. He has been in business for some years. It was learned late last night that several of his patients who had paid him money in advance are very anxious to find him.

Sellers, District Attorney for Indiana; Thomas Haydon, District Attorney for Nevada; James F. Tucker Marshal for Florida; Samuel L. Blaisdell, Marshal for Rhode Island.

CINCINNATI, March 21.--"Ruddigore" was produced at Henck's to-night by the McCaull Opera Company to the largest audience of the season. The opera, as produced by the McCaull Company, is an undoubted success here. The audience encored the principal arias and choruses, and in some cases two and three repetitions had to be given. Manager McCaull has spared no expense in the production of "Ruddigore."

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 21.--No more bodies have been found in the ruins of the Richmond Hotel up to noon to-day, when the searching party was withdrawn owing to the shaky condition of the walls, which are to be pulled down at once.

PORTLAND, Me., March 23.--Much suffering is reported among the horses in lumber camps owing to the deep snow. Supplies cannot be hauled in, and one lumberman said to-day that horses a long distance in the woods would have to be killed.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 23.--A bill has been prepared to bring before Congress one of the most important movements ever inaugurated in the history of the American people, so far as it relates to the commemoration of events. It is to provide for the purchase by Congress of...

Theodore Upton, accused of running a bucket shop at 60 Broad-street, waived examnation in the Yorkville Court yesterday, and was held for trial. Detective O'Mallery worked up the case, and Justice Duffy visited the shop and said yesterday that he thought the business illegal, and that it would probably say a time to take the case to a higher court at once.

The season of Italian opera at the Metropolitan Opera House, with Mme. Patti, will include five evening performances and a matinee. It will be a notable season, for it will be the great artist's last appearance in this country, and also her first appearance in America in "Carmen," a role in which she is especially anxious to appear before New-Yorkers. As has been previously announced.

LONDON, March 23.--An explosion by which 70 miners were killed occurred to-day in Bulli Colliery, at Sydney, New South Wales.

MONTREAL, March 23.--The motion presented before Judge Desnoyer to-day to quash the information for conspiracy against the Directors of the Montreal, Portland and Boston Railway, was rejected by his Honor, who ordered the case to be proceeded with next week.
J.H. Millard, of Omaha, is at the FifthAvenue Hotel. Col. John M. Wilson, United States Army, is at the Westminster Hotel.

RUSSELLVILLE, Ky., March 23.--A murder was committed a short distance from this place last night. Tom Lett and John B. Simmons have been running a country store about a mile from town on the Nashville pike. This morning Simmons was found dead at the store door.

ROME, March 23.--The Artist Gagliardi has been engaged to paint a portrait of Cardinal Gibbons. The picture will hang beside that of the Pope in the Cardinal's titular church. The coat of arms assumed by Cardinal Gibbons has in the centre a picture of the immaculate conception on a green background. The shield is surmounted by a Cardinal's hat with five rows of tassels depending from the sides.
TRENTON, N.J., March 23.--Gov. Green to-day nominated Alfred Hugg as Law Judge of Camden County, to fill the vacancy caused by the rejection of the nomination of Judge Wescott.

A down-town Captain of Police yesterday incidentally remarked in the corridor of the Astor House that Inspector Byrnes's book was performing a mighty work toward the detection and suppression of crime, now too rampant.

An adjourned meeting of the Board of Education was held yesterday at the building in Grand-street. Nineteen Commissioners were present. Commissioner Gallaway in the chair. The board proceeded to the consideration of a resolution offered by Commissioner Vermilye at the meeting of March 16, which was then laid over until yesterday's session.

A fire broke out at 9 o'clock last evening in the five-story brick block on the southeast corner of West and Murray street. The Fire Department was soon at work, and within half an hour the fire was under control.

BUFFALO, March 23.--Mary Nolan, the twelfth victim of the Richmond Hotel fire, died this afternoon at the Sisters' Hospital, where she was taken last Friday. From the first it was seen that her case was hopeless, and the marvel was that she lived so long.

The managers of the French Cable Company, who were reported a few days ago in THE TIMES's special dispatches as at war with pool cable companies, issued a statement yesterday which confirms those dispatches.

NYACK, March 23.--Mrs. Eliza Flynn, the woman who was struck by a falling shed in front of a grocery store in this place yesterday, is still in a very bad condition and unable to move in her bed. It is said that the shed which caused the injury has been in a dangerous condition for a long time, and a lawsuit for damages is threatened against the owner of the building.

TOLEDO, March 23.--Quite a sensation in financial circles will take place when it is known that late this afternoon, in the United States Circuit Court, the firm of Scribner, Hurd Scribner filed the papers in a case involving $800,000 in bonds and $135,000 in claims.

The session of the Rahway (N. J.) Common Council Tuesday night was enlivened by two communications from Mayor Daly and a proposition offered by Councilman Denike to rescind the contract with the Tesla Electric Light Company for lighting the streets.

MANCHESTER, March 23.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "Buyers and sellers are alike dissatisfied with their experience. Buyers with important orders find that the strength of prices prevents progress. Sellers are striving vainly to improve their position in view of the enhanced cost of the raw material.
LONDON, March 23.--The steamship Elysia, (Br.,) Capt. Baxier, from New-York March 2, for Leghorn, passed Gilbraltar yesterday.

The Inman and International Steamship Company, Limited, has contracted with Laird Brothers,of Birkenhead,for a transatlantic steamship. She will be built of steel, with triple expansion engines and twin screws, and is to be superior in speed to anything now afloat. Her dimensions ...
A good many newspapers, mostly Democratic, are discussing with a semblance of earnestness the probability of an extra session.

Everybody who saw "Erminie" last year remembers Agnes Folsom. Everybody remembers when the curtain rose on the delicate, ethereal, and glittering beauty of the pink ballroom how Javotte came forth in her snow-white wig, her pretty dress of pale blue and cream color, and sang her mezzo song of girlish coquetry to Simon.

DETROIT, Mich., March 23.--Dr. E.C. Rogers recently died at Quincy, in this State, leaving a somewhat remarkable will. He was a bachelor brother of the sculptor, Randolph Rogers, and left property valued at $80,000. The sum of $10,000 was left to children of his...
CHICAGO, March 23.--The new rates recently established by the roads interested in the Pacific coast traffic, to go into effect April 5, have just been published.

Very little has been heard about the code since it passed the Assembly. It has been said that the bell has been rung for the only living author of it to step up to the Captain's office and pay for its passage.

WILKESBARRE, March 23.--John Knepper, a resident of Ransom, and for many years a conspicuous character in Luzerne County, died last night, aged 108 years 1 month and 17 days. He was a native of Austria and fought in the army of that country against Napoleon I, in the wars of 1797 and 1805. He came to this country when 40 years old, and resided here up to the time of his death.

The officers of the steamship City of Puebla, which arrived yesterday from Havana, roport that during the night of March 20, when off Cape Canaveral, a disabled steamer was sighted lying to. The City of Puebla sailed around the disabled vessel and made offers of assistance,but it was said that no help was needed.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 23.--St. Mary's Catholic, St. Paul's Episcopal, and the First Presbyterian Churches were entered by thieves last night and the poor boxes in each were robbed. From St. Paul's a number of Treasurer's receipts were also taken. The amounts obtained were small in each instance. No other damage was done. There is no clue to the robbers.

James Jackson, the famous State detective, resides in Sing Sing, and is generally in attendance at the prison. His duties are to examine carefully the face of every convict as he enters and to scrutinize every visitor in order to prevent any discharged convict seeing his pals.
PORTLAND, Me., March 23.--A lumberman who has been operating on the borders of Canada and New-Hampshire has embroiled himself with Uncle Sam by smuggling supplies across the line.

Away back in 1873 Mary Nagel, a pretty German lass of this city, became engaged to be married, and wrote to her widowed aunt, Mrs. Ida Peyser, then temporarily residing in Paris, informing her of the interesting occurrence. Mrs. Peyser wrote back a long letter.

BOSTON, March 23.--"If a newspaper now wants to disparage a man it can safely attack his dinners," said a Boston lawyer to-day after the decision of the full bench of the Supreme Court on the interesting question whether a newspaper's comments on what it considered a poor dinner renders it liable to an action for libel.

CHICAGO, March 23.--Saying he would ne'er consent, Carter Harrison to-day consented, to accept a nomination for the fifth time for Mayor, on the Democratic ticket, having been nominated by acclamation.

Three policemen were on duty yesterday on the stairway leading to Hanan Son's shoe factory to prevent the strikers from creating a disturbance. On the outside a number of strikers had picketed the building to prevent any workmen from applying for work.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 23.--A most affecting scene was witnessed this morning when Janitor James J. Titus's counsel, J.T. Shipman, brought him the news that the Court of Pardons had commuted his sentence to one of imprisonment for life.

A meeting was held at 375 Fulton-street, Brooklyn, last night, for the purpose of organizing a Grand Army post to be named after Gen. John A. Logan, Col. Hempstead presided. A Committee on Organization was appointed. Only men who have served three years in the war will be eligible.

The 12 jurors who were selected to decide the question of Thomas Cleary's guilt or innocence of the charge of having agreed to accept a bribe of $20,000 for his vote as Alderman for the Broadway Surface Railroad franchise considered the question for 17 hours and then determined that they could not agree.
ROCHESTER, March 23.--D.G. Gray, clothing dealer of Penn Yan, made an assignment this morning. His liabilities are $23,000, and his nominal assets, $16,000.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 23.--The New-York, Pennsylvania and Ohio brakemen's strike is dead, but the strikers do not know it. Those of the men who proclaim that they are still holding out have stoned trains, and have been otherwise mischievous. The railway company has obtained from the United States Court a renewal of the previous restraining order, and had it served on 41 of the most turbulent men here and in Youngstown.

BESSEMER, Mich., March 23.--Ten charred and unrecognizable bodies lay this morning on the snow-covered ground near the centre of this village, all victims of a boarding house fire before daylight this morning.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 23.--The criminal libel case in which Father Hamel appears as complainant and Father Dent as defendant is set down for trial at Little Valley, Cattauragus County, next Tuesday.

Ernest Toepfer, a German baker, 63 years old, who, with his wife, three children, and two nieces, lived in a neat suite of apartments on the top door of 189 First-avenue, made an assault upon his wife with a hatchet early yesterday, and then, to avoid arrest, cut his throat with a razor. Five years ago Toepfer ...

WASHINGTON, March 23.--The President made up the list of Inter-State Commerce Commissioners to comply with the requirement of the law that "not more than three of the Commissioners shall be appointed from the same political party."

PHILADELPHIA, March 23.--A rumor was circulated on the street to-day that Hamilton Disston had been killed by a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad at Germantown Junction. Mr. Disston denied that he had been killed, and said there was no foundation for the rumor, and that he was ignorant of its origin.

"Nero" will be sung at the Metropolitan Opera House to-night, and to-morrow afternoon Flotow's ever welcome "Martha" will be sung by the National Opera Company for the first time in New-York. The cast will include Pamine L'Allemand as Lady Henrietta, Jessie BartlettDavis as Nancy. Charles Baesett as Lionel, and Alonzo Stoddard as Plunkett.

In Judge Donohue's part of the Supreme Court yesterday the city was beaten in a suit to recover $16,129.91 of Matthew H. Moore, a contractor, and Timothy Donovan and Thomas McManus, his suretics. Moore contracted with the city in August, 1880, to build sewers in One Hundred and Fifty-eighth-street and the adjacent--streets and avenues.

An elaborate circular letter has been prepared by Russell P. Hoyt, General Manager of the Traders and Travelers' Union, answering inquiries regarding impositions which merchants and manufacturers suffer in some States from "license" laws.
WASHINGTON, March 24.--The President this afternoon appointed Mr. Oscar S. Straus, of New-York, to be Minietor to Turkey in place of the Hon. S.S. Cox, resigned.
SYRACUSE, March 24.--It is announced that the Grand Jury has found indictments for conspiracy to rob the State against P.J. Brumelkamp, Superintendent of the Onondaga salt Springs.
PORTLAND, Me., March 24.--Mr. Blaine left to-day for an extended tour through the West. In June he will go to Europe.

FULTONVILLE, N.Y., March 24.--A charity ball was given here last night under the patronage of Mrs. Frothingham Fish, Mrs. John H. Starin, and several other ladies prominent in local charities. The music was furnished by the Tenth Regiment...

INDIANAPOLIS, March 24.--A Short time ago the State Board of Finance, consisting of the Governor, Auditor, and Treasurer of State made an arrangement with Coffin Stanton, brokers of New-York, for $330,000 with which to pay the interest on the State debt.

He amuses himself chiefly by watching the players, constituting himself a referee and commenting on the play. Mr. Buchanan has frequently asked Mr. Fowler to stop it.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 24.--In the House of Representatives to-day the struggle over the Brooks High License bill was renewed. The advocates of high license are in the majority, but the liquor men fight desperately, taking advantage of every opportunity to delay the progress of the measure.

Courad Breitenstein, a shoe cutter, who lives at 108 Delancey-street, is suffering an enforced suspension from labor because, in the exact language of those who have convicted and sentenced him, he was "doing to mutch work."
LONDON, March, 24.--In the House of Commons this evening the debate on the motion for urgency for the Coercion bill was resumed by Mr. Gladstone.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Civil Service Commissioner Oberly is now preparing an opinion concerning the Philadelphia Post Office matter, based upon the testimony taken during the recent investigation of the charges preferred against Postmaster Harrity by the Philadelphia Civil Service Reform League.
John B. Alley, of Boston, is at the Hotel Brunswick.

"The Taming of the Shrew," as performed at Daly's, is not to be forgotten when its run upon the stage is ended. The photographer's art has been called into play to perpetuate the characters and the artists who portray them, ...

CHICAGO, March 24.--The General Managers and other general officers of the roads in the Central Traffic Association yesterday considered a plan for the reorganization of the present association, which sets forth its objects to be the preventing of undue and unreasonable preferences or disadvantages between localities and persons for like and contemporaneous service, ...

Luis Mazzantini and his six assistants were the centre of a large crowd of curiosity seekers on Broadway yesterday afternoon. Mazzantini is a matador de toro, and his six assistants are plain bull fighters. In picturesque costume, with flaming neckwear, tremendous lacetrimmed white sombreros, heavily bejeweled hands and gorgeous waistcoats, jet-black long hair and deep-brown complexions, they were an unfailing attraction.

LYDNEY, Wales, March 24.--Eighty-five men were entombed by the explosion in the Bulli Colliery yesterday. The accident occurred in a tunnel a mile and a half from the mouth of the pit. Seven bodies have been recovered. The tunnel is blocked by the debris caused by the explosion.

Every additional appearance of Sarah Bernhardt drives home with fresh force the overwhelming conviction of her greatness. Theorize and criticise as we may, in an hour she sweeps away the strongest structure of logic and brings the critic to her feet. Other women may act, but this woman is.

HAVANA, March 24.--The owner of the Esperanza estate, who was recently kidnapped, has been ransomed.

RICHMOND, Va., March 24.--This morning a freight train went through the bridge nine milers from Liberty, on the Norfolk and Western Railroad. The bridge was in process of repair and three workman were killed and several others wounded. None of them were train hands as far as known. The engine and several cars crossed the bridge safely before the structure gave way.

NEW-HAVEN, March 24.--Capt. Holden, of the Harvard football team, was here to-day endeavoring to excite interest among the Yale students in the proposed football league, consisting of the three leading colleges.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24.--The State Liquor Dealers' Association held a meeting in Turner Hall to-day to complete the permanent organization begun at Elizabeth a month ago. There were 200 delegates present, representing Newark, Orange, Paterson...
Boutonnieres of black and orange nestled on the lapels of 245 men last night in the Hote1 Brunswick, gathered for the eleventh time in as many years, to honor Princeton by a dinner.

The last of Mr. Stoddard's Lenten series of illustrated lectures, course B, will be delivered at Daly's Theatre this morning at 11 o' clock, being a repetition of the story of "Egypt and the Nile," as told in the entertainment yesterday morning.

No list of a dozen Wall-street notables would be complete or worthy of attention without the name of Major Selover in it. Once he was a millionarie, then as the Stock Exchange vernacular has it he "went busted."
Eliza Weathersby, wife of Mr. N.C. Goodwin, died at her home in the Rutland, Fifty-seventh-street and Broadway, at 9:45 o'clock last night.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 24.--The Detroits struck a bright warm day and a big crowd. It put the nine in playing humor, and it played a great game. Ganzel and Getzein were the Detroit battery. Getzein did not suffer from the new rules, pitching drops and curves and changing speed without extra effort. ...

Mr. Thomas S. Preston received a cable-- gram yesterday from Rome announcing that, as a special mark of the Pope's esteem. Archbishop Corrrigan had been named a Prelate Assistant to the pontifical throne. The message was sent to Mgr. Preston because it was not yet known at Rome that the Archbishop had reached home.

READING, Penn., March 24.--The trial of Frank Zabel, indicted for killing his brother Charles last June in a scuffle, was begun here to-day. There were five shots fired, three of them having taken effect on Charles, and the other two the murderer directed at his own throat.

LONDON, March 24.--This was the first day of the Liverpool Spring race meeing. The principal events wero the races for the Prince of Wales's Cup and the Molyneux Stakes. The Prince of Wales's Cup was won by three lengths by W.A. Powell's...
People who keep all their money in the savings bank had less business at Chickering Hall last night than at the first night's sale of the Stewart collection of pictures.

TRENTON, N.J., March 24.--A decree has been filed in the Chancery proceedings of the Rev. H.H. Barbour, formerly of Newark and now of Camden, granting him a divorce from his wife. The latter made no opposition to the decree.

OTTAWA, March 24.--A cable dispatch was received in the city to-day stating that the London Standard and News published this morning statements to the effect that Canada would shortly seek to float a loan for $50,000,000. The report is officially denied, and the Government authorities state that no loan is contemplated.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 24.--Before daylight this morning the members of the Nanticoke School Board, with the aid of a large force of workmen, broke open the Bethel Congregational Church, threw out all the furniture, and tore down the building.

Treasurer Jordan, of Bunnell's Museum, opened his safe yesterday afternoon. It was in the box office. All the contents were found to be intact. None of the books or papers were damaged, and all the money was uninjured. The safe was a small one of Herring's make.--The Buffalo Times, March 20.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 24.--Twentyfive hundred people assembled in the hall of the House of Representatives to-night to listen to the address of senator Sherman.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 24.--A Pittsburg drummer named M.J. Bishop went out "mashing" on Superior-street last evening, and this morning the Police Judge fined him $50 and sentenced him to the workhouse for 30 days for insulting ladies.

CINCINNATI, March 24.--An effort was made in the Democratic City Convention to-day to place Isaac J. Miller in nomination for Mayor. A storm of hisses followed, and Mr. Miller received but 25 votes out of 360.

NORTH EAST, Md., March 24.--A passenger train on the Baltimore and Philadelphia Railroad came into collision with a through freight train at Leslie at about 2 o'clock this morning. Both trains were badly wrecked and the locomotives entirely telescoped.

William E. Nungezer, a German, of 610 Second-avenue, hanged himself yesterday in the cellar of that house. He was a sufferer from paralysis, which had unfitted him for work for some years.

UTICA, N.Y., March 24.--At a Methodist Episcopal donation party held in a schoolhouse at Still ville, near Utica, the floor gave way and 10 or 15 persons were severely injured, being bruised, burned, and scalded and receiving fractures of the limbs.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., March 24.--The bills of Assistant Prosecutor Swartz and Detective Irving, incurrod in the investigation over tho death of "Mingo Jack." who was lynched at Eatontown a year ago were paid by County Collector Haight today. It cost the county at least $500 to contest them.

The Jersey City Board of Finance declared last night its disapproval of the new county road scheme, because the city would contribute two-thirds of the cost of the building of the road. The board prefers cleaner streets and more school houses to a boulevard.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 24.--Sight drafts on New-York, 20 cents; telegraphic, 27 cents.

VIENNA, March 24.--The evidence given in the case of the 15 Anarchists on trial here, charged with being implicated in a conspiracy to burn the city is causing a great sensation. It is becoming evident that only the failure of the plot saved tho city from almost total destruction.

The steamship Scotia, of the Fabre Line, due here from Mediterranean ports over a week ago, has not been heard from since she left Gibraltar on Feb. 27. She had on board from 800 to 1,000 passengers, of whom a large number originally sailed on the steamship Burgundia, which was beached near Naples after having been run into by the Italian manof-War Italia some weeks ago.
The Railroad Commissioners' second report concerning the heating of railway cars is far more satisfactory than the first, which was submitted four weeks ago.

QUEENSTOWN, March 24.--The Guion Line steamship Arizona, which sailed from NewYork on Tuesday, March 15, arrived here this morning.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe has decided in the case of a policeman who wants to be retired on a pension and who was appointed in August, 1865, resigned three months after, was reappointed in March, 1866, dismissed in 1871, and reappointed in 1871, that he must have served 20 years continuously before he is entitled to a pension, which will be in 1891.

TRENTON, March 24.--Mr. Corbin's High License bill was considered in the Assembly this mornings The bill, as amended by the committee, fixes the minimum license fee at $50 and limits the maximum fee at $200. The opponents of the bill endeavored to have it recommitted for the purpose of further amending it.
PARIS, March 24.--It is semi-officially denied that Russia has made overtures for an alliance with France.

To-day will see the Bacon investigating committee again in Brooklyn. There remain only three days for the committee in which to finish its work and report to the Legislature on April 1, but it was stated yesterday that upon the advice of Lawyer Parsons Chairman Bacon would ask for an extension of time.

Down among the shanties of Red Hook, in South Brooklyn, stands a barn-like building, where Hugh Brady, Gerald Nally and "Tom" Collins made rum from molasses without any Government license. Some weeks ago the internal revenue agents swooped upon them, destroyed the apparatus and put the illicit distillers behind jail bars. Nally got out on bail and Brady escaped.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 24.--A cablegram was received here to-day dated Auckland, NewZealand, from Mr. F.C. Johnson, who was a passenger on the German steamer Raiatea, before reported burned while on the voyage from this port to Tahiti. The dispatch says the vessel and cargo were lost, but no particulars are given. From this it is inferred that all the others, 21 in number, who were on board the steamer are safe with Mr. Johnson.

LONDON, March 25.--In the House of Commons this evening a division was taken on Mr. Morley's amendment to the Government's motion to grant urgency for the Coercion bill, and the amendment was rejected by a vote of 349 to 260. The announcement of the vote was received with loud Opposition cheers.

President Datz has secured the adoption by the Jersey City Board of Finance of a resolution opposing the county boulevard scheme. The boulevard will cost $3,000,000, and Jersey City will have to pay the largest part of it.

YORKVILLE, Ill., March 25.--The Kendall County Court House, at this place, was burned this morning. The fire started in the roof from a defective flue. All the records were saved, the priseners removed from the jail in safety, and no person was injured in the operation. Only the bare stone valls of the fine structure remain.
