Victor Murro, a young Italian, 25 years old, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself at Jamaica. Murro was known in Jamaica as the "Italian Count," and is said to have belonged to a wealthy Italian family. He was, however, of dissolute habits, and had no standing in society. A few years ago he was involved in a scandal at Jamaica. He had previously attempted to commit suicide.

PANAMA, via Galveston, March 26.--The sailing of steamers to and from places south of Panama is very irregular, owing to the strict quarantine The last arrival from Callao was on March 18, too late to connect with the steamer Colon for Newyork. A mail steamer left Callao for Panama on March 23, and the last steamer from Panama for Callao left Panama on March 20.

CHARLESTON, West Va., March 26.--There was a novel contest at Nuttall, Fayette County, yesterday witnessed by a very large crowd. It was a bloody fight between a vicious mountain wildcat and an English bulldog. After a hot fight of several hours the dog won by killing the cat. This is the third fight of its kind in the United States, all three having taken place in this section of the State.

SANDWICH, Mass., March 26.--The crew of the schooner Stonybrook, ashore in Hog Island Narrows, Buzzard's Bay, are engaged in lightering the cargo, and expect to be able to get off the ledge with the next tide without the assistance of a tug. The schooner is leaking.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 26.--Gov. Higgs this morning appointed Attorney-General John H. Painter to the Associate Judgeship of the State courts, to fill the vacancy caused by Judge Wooten's death. The appointee is a son-in-law of ex-Gov. Stockley.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 26.--To-day, while Ike Bayliss was plowing on Mrs. R. Dunlap's place, about three miles from town, he plowed up a store of five-dollar gold pieces. CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 27.--The Rev. Rollo Ogden lately resigned the Pastorate of the Case-Avenue Presbyterian Church because he could not longer subscribe to that denomination's dogmas. He preached his farewell sermon to-day. He said that he could not remain in that pulpit without being a hypocrite, but added: "There are absolutely no doctrinal tests to which a Presbyterian layman can be asked to submit."

Something like a panic held sway for a few minutes yesterday afternoon on the southern roadway of the Brooklyn Bridge. Shortly after 3 o'clock the head of a long funeral procession went on the bridge from the New-York end. There were a hundred carriages in line.

Jones, of Newark, N.J., who left his wife and children a short time ago, and who has been living at the Brook House here for two weeks with Jennie Gade, was arrested yesterday charged with adultery, and was locked up in the county jail. He will probably have an immediate trial.

CHICAGO, March 27.--The Farmers' Review prints for its crop review this week the following summary: "Dry weather continues to prevail in Kansas and in portions of Missouri, which has caused some injury to Winter wheat, though very few serious reports of damage are made except in the former State. In Sedgwick and some of the other southern counties of Kansas there has been...

The Bell Telephone Company is still engaged in compelling local exchanges to water their stock and raise their rates, but it prefers that complaining subscribers shall not know the real cause of the changes that are made.

Charles Spath, a young German machinist living on the top floor of the tenement house at 332 East Twenty-ninth-street, had made a toy steam engine, and yesterday connected it by means of a gaspipe with a teakettle, from which he expected to supply steam to the engine. The lid of the kettle blew off, and the hot water was thrown over Spath, scalding him severely about the face and arms.

When a TIMES reporter range the bell of the residence of the Coronet's owner, R.T. Bush, at 202 Columbia, Heights, Brooklyn, yesterday, at 2:30 P.M., a buxom, rosy-cheeked maid said that Mr. Bush had gone out.

CHICAGO, March 27.--It has been reported that a hull insurance pool, embracing every company that is engaged in writing risks on lake hulls, was formed at Chicago a week ago. The report is untrue. This week, however, an effort in that direction is to be made at Buffalo. Townsend Davis and O.T. Flint, who have practically controlled.

The wrecking barge Haggerty arrived at Castle Garden yesterday afternoon with 530 of the Scotia's immigrants on board, and during the evening 70 more arrived by rail. When the people who came on the Haggerty entered Castle Garden bread, sausages, and beer were given them.

OSWEGO, N.Y., March 27.--The case of The People against James Shoemaker for the murder of Dell Vandermark on June 3, 1886, has been on trial since last Wednesday before Judge H. Boardman Smith, of the Supreme Court. The jury retired at 6 o'clock on Saturday evening and at 2 o'clock this morning brought in a verdict of manslaughter in the second degree...

LONDON, March 27.--The Coronet people believe that the Dauntless will be 24 to 30 hours later in arriving. Capt. Anderson says the weather was the worst be ever experienced in all his 174 Atlanticpassages.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 27.--It has always been customary for employes of railroads and other corporations in this State to assign their wages in advance to storekeepers or others for the purpose of obtaining credit or money, pending the company's pay day. James Wooding, and employe of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company, sold his time for a month to a storekeeper...

A meeting in aid of Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, which has for its object the training of teachers for the negro and Indian races, was held yesterday afternoon at the Broadway Tabornacle.

William Young, a painter, living at 652 Park-avenue, Brooklyn, married a young wife some years ago. One child, a boy now 7 years old, was born, and their home was a happy one until one day Mr. Young returned from work to find his wife missing.
ELMIRA, March 27.--Arthur Sheets, aged 19, brother of the Erie telegraph dispatcher at Avoca, Steuben County, and another young man named Con Chase, son of Station Agent Chase, robbed N.B. Chase...

Mr. Hill writes of Canning in what we deem to be a half-hearted manner, as if he were not in love with his subject. It may be that the life of Canning, compressed within the short space of the volume under notice, would be a difficult one to write, for...

The public has recently been made aware that D. APPLETON Co., a publishing firm of high standing in this city, have undertaken the publication of a "Cyclopaedia of American Biography," edited by JAMES GRANT WILSON and JOHN FISKE.
Mrs. Eliza Weathersby-Goodwin was buried yesterday afternoon in Woodlawn Cemetery, in a plot near that where her sister, Emie, who died about two years ago, lies buried.

BOSTON, March 27.--The Herald professes to have received from its Glasgow correspondent advices which radically change the style and dimensions of the Scotch cutter Thistle from those given by that paper some time ago. It had come to be generally considered that the first figures badly needed revision. It remains to be seen whether those now given are more nearly correct.

The family of Edwin M. Stanton, the War Secretary, have intrusted to the hands of George C. Gorham, formerly the Secretary of the United States Senate, the preparation of a biography of their distin- guished relative. All the private papers have been placed at Mr. Gorham's disposal, ...
The funeral of Mrs. Mary Maynard Hitchcock, wife of Hiram Hitchcock, one of the proprietors of the Fifty-Avenue Hotel, took place yesterday afternoon at the Madison-Square Presbyterian Church.
QUEENSTOWN, March 27.--For the last few days yachtsmen and newspaper correspondents have been gathering slowly in this busy Irish city, where even the children have a nautical air at times.

Yesterday was a red-letter day in the history of United Council, No. 1,035, American Legion of Honor, which is a unique council in its way, being composed to a large extent of members of the theatrical profession and governed almost entirely by actors and actresses.
ALBANY, March 27.--There is a bill pending before the Legislature having for its object the taxation of deposits and surplus of savings banks and trust companies.

The programme of the meeting held at Masonic Temple yesterday by the Manhattan Temperance Association was headed by the question, "Which shall rule our city, God, or the rum oligarchy?" followed by a request to those present to enter their protest againt the desecrators of the Sabbath and to teach them "that the great religious and moral force which placed Mayor Hewitt in office is still 'behind the throne.'"
We wonder who it is that really wishes to tax the deposits in savings banks. Every year some one sends or brings to Albany a bill for that purpose.

The steamship P. Caland, of the Netherlands Line, arrived at Quarantine from Rotterdam last evening. She fell in with the steamship Saleron, of the Wilson Line, in a disabled condition at 2 P.M. on March 23, in latitude 41 4' and longitude 57 58'.

The United States flagship Richmond, of the North Atlantic squadron, is to sail to-day for a cruise among the Windward Islands and to return by way of Key West. The crew is made up mostly of men from the old Tennessee.

The memorable fire which burned out the establishment of Nicoll the tailor, in the Bowery, on March 8, has in no wise affected the business push and energy of that well known house. It already invites all its patrons to attend a...

The woman who, Saturday morning, was found hanging in the basement of Woodruff, Conkling Bayard's sash and blind factory, 369 East Third-street, was yesterday identified as Mrs. Margaret Jacobi, a native of Germany, 46...
GREENADA, Miss., March 27.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon a furious hailstorm from the west struck this town. Early garden plants were destroyed and the sprouting foliage of the trees was out off.
BERMUDA, March 24.--The ship Vanloo, (Br.,) Capt Harris, from London, for New-York, with a general cargo, was towed to Murray's Anchorage March 20, leaking badly.

Brooklyn's Twenty-third Regiment attended service yesterday afternoon at St. Luke's Episcopal Church, on Clinton-avenue near Fultonstreet, and listened to a sermon by the Chaplain of the regiment, the Rev. George H. Vandewater, D.D. An elaborate programme was furnished to each gentleman present.
New light is thrown on the disturbances among our friends the Tongans by the latest news from the islands.

William R. Travers, well known for the last 30 years in Wall-Street, in the leading clubs, and in society in this city, died in Bermuda March 19. He was unconscious during the last hours, when his wife, his son, R.J. Travers, his daughter Susie, and his daughter-in-law, Mrs. Duer, stood around his bed.
Jersey City's charter election is to take place on Tuesday, April 12, and active preparations are already making for it. Three Commissioners each in the Board of Works and Police...
We alluded last week to the circular of the Treasury Department regarding the bill for the regulation of what is usually termed imported contract labor.
ALBANY, March 27.--In his visit to Albany last week Col. George Bliss expressed considerable solicitude about the passage of bills giving the New-York authorities the right to expend so much money.

The funeral of Mrs. Rosa Ringler, wife of Mr. George Ringler, took place yesterday afternoon from the family residence, 213 East Ninety-first-street. The body reposed in a handsome casket on the first floor.

John Fitzgerald, the President of the Irish National League in America, stimulated by the proposed renewal of coercion in Ireland, has just issued from his headquarters at Lincoln, Neb., a stirring appeal to the American press and public for a verdict on the treatment the Irish people are receiving at the hands of England.
Information cabled from London to the effect that Mr. Henry E. Abbey has instructed his agent to make overtures to Mrs. James Brown Potter for an American tour is hardly news to New-Yorkers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., March 27.--The owners of the trotter Harry Wilkes announced last night that, as Oliver K. had been incapacitated for starting in the race on Saturday next Harry Wilkes would trot to beat his own record of 2:14 at the Bay District course, this city, on that day, for $2,000.
Mr. Nat C. Goodwin will reappear this evening at the Bijou Opera House, when he will assume the role of Prince Lorenzo in "The Mascot."

Three leisurely youths with nothing to do and ample time to do it in were attracted yesterday into the Madison-Square Garden, which wore its best Sunday gloom, by the sight of several bald-headed gentlemen who announced that...

COCHRANTON, Penn., March 27.--In 1883 the temperance people of this place made an active fight against the granting of licenses in the village and vicinity, and owing to their efforts a number of drinking places were refused a license. Soon afterward a building belonging to one of the leading temperance workers was burned down.

Lewis Smit, who said that he lived in Philadelphia, entered, on Feb. 5, the jewelry store of Moses Van Moppe, at 2 John-street, and asked to see some diamond rings. A number were shown to him and he selected three, valued together at $900.

Some time after the Broadway Railroad investigation drew the attention of the public to the Sharp patent milk bottle some of the teachers of Grammar School No. 72, in Lexington-avenue, near One Hundred and Fifth-street, came to the conclusion that they stood greatly in need of a milk diet.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27.--A stock train on the Pennsylvania Railroad met with a singular accident at 8 o'clock last night. Nine valuable horses and two mules were killed outright and two horses had to be killed on account of their injuries.
QUEENSTOWN, March 27.--The Cunard Line steamship Aurania, Capt. Hains, from Liverpool, sld. hence to-day for New-York.

When Eugene Rouwell, a tailor, living at 341 West Thirteenth-street, returned home late Saturday night he entered the basement door, and being anxious to avoid arousing his family he laid down on a mattress in the basement. At 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning a policeman saw two men burst open the basement door...
CHICAGO, March 27.--Attractions sufficiently strong to draw good houses have occupied the stage atmost of the Chicago theatres the past week, and the business done was satisfactory.
GREENSBOROUGH, N.C., March 28.--Greensborough voted almost unanimously to-day to issue bonds to the amount of $100,000 for public improvements. The vote stands 362 for issue and 20 against.

The fire at Hunter's Point, which cast so bright a reflection upon the clouds about 7 o'clock last night, was caused by the burning of the furniture factory of G. Autenreith, at Vernon and Second streets, and the oil refinery of Nicholas Melen, which adjoins the furniture factory...

LONDON, Ontario, March 28.--A warrant ordering the surrender of Dr. Weir to the Michigan authorities on the charge of murdering Mabel Clarke at Oscoda has been issued by the Department of Justice and the prisoner will be handed over as soon as demanded. Weir views the approaching trip to his old home with alarm.

JACKSON, Miss., March 28.--Since recent publications were made showing how few changes have occurred among the employes of the Interior Department by Secretary Lamar, the latter has been subjected to a brisk running fire all along the line of the Mississippi country press. The Brooktown Leader, an influential independent paper, may be quoted as an example:

MONTREAL, March 28.--Stockbrokers who have been having money forced upon them at 3 per cent. were surprised to-day at the receipt of a notice from a leading money lender that the rate will be raised to 7 per cent. from to-day. It is estimated that nearly a million dollars have been withdrawn from the Street within the last 10 days for use in the West.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe has written a letter to Commissioner of Public Works Newton advising him to revoke all permits for opening streets issued to the New-York Steam Company and not yet acted upon, and to refuse any further permits until the steam company agrees to pay for the services of Street Inspector Thomas W. Gaynor, who was appointed by the Commissioner of Public Works to supervise the opening and repair of streets by the company.

The crew of Mr. Vanderbilt's palatial steam yacht Alva do not seem to have had a luxurious time on their recent trip to Havana. A rumor was circulated yesterday that a strike was threatened on the yacht, and a TIMES reporter visited the Alva at her berth at the foot of West Sixty-fifth-street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 28.--Articles of incorporation were to-day filed in the office of the Secretary of State of the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railway Company. The principal office is to be at Peoria and the capital stock $4,500,000. It is proposed to construct the railway from a point on the eastern boundary line of Illinois, ...

The admirable stand taken by Mr. R.T. Bush, the owner of the Coronet, since his beautiful yacht won the ocean race can scarcely fail to give a sharp impetus to yacht building and lend a more healthy commercial tone to an industry which has hitherto been classed merely as idle and unremunerative sport, but, as is now evident, can easily be made a profitable commercial field.

The silk dyers of Paterson, who have been on strike since Feb. 8 last, went to work yesterday morning, and all who could be employed were taken back. It is expected that the entire 1,700 men will be at work before the week...

The Baptist Pastors met yesterday in the rooms of the Publication Society and listened to a paper on "Prohibition" by the Rev. B.B. Tyler, of the Christian Church. Mr. Tyler favored the High License bill as a step in the right direction. Each of the members present was then given an opportunity to express his views upon the paper.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 28.--Mrs. Fred Neilson, of New-York, is a free woman, and is no longer wife of the handsome member of the New-York Coaching Club. Her brother is Freddy Gebhard. She brought a suit for divorce some time ago and came here to live, as many other...

John L. Sullivan made his first appearance last night on the stage since he broke his arm at Cronheim's Theatre, Hoboken. The boxing entertainment which was tacked on to a variety performance consisted of bouts between "Bob" Turnbull and "Jimmy" Carroll, Joe Lennon and...

OWEGA, N.Y., March 28.--This morning James Shoemaker was sentenced by Justice Smith to one year at hard labor in Auburn State Prison and a fine of $1,000 for killing Dell Van Demark, of Nichols, in a fight in front of Shoemaker's house, in that town, in June last. Shoemaker ran a knife through Van Denmark's heart.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 28.--The barkentine Susan left here Friday for Demerara with a cargo of dry fish. Saturday forenoon, when south of Cape Race, not far from St. John's, she came into collision with an iceberg and sank, with the Captain and four of the crew. The remainder of the crew were picked up by the barkentine Muriel and landed yesterday morning.

Hanan Son, at whose shoe factory District Assembly No. 91 recently declared a strike, received a letter yesterday from a Knight of Labor who wanted employment. He knew of the strike, he said, but could show a letter from...

The challenge of James W. Bell, owner of the Scotch cutter now being built on the Clyde, the Thistle, for the races for the possession of the great America's Cup and the measurements of the Thistle were officially received yesterday by the New-York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Commodore Joseph H. Tooker, of New-York, and his son and daughter are guests at the Arlington Hotel. Washington air seems to have had a sudden and strange effect upon the genial Commodore, for he has apparently thrown off his familiar character cf man-about-town and wrapped himself up in the mantle of a statesman.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., March 28.--The following is a summary of the racing here to-day: FIRST RACE--The Street Railroad Stakes for 3year-olds; seven furlongs. Tom Hood had the best of the start and held the lead throughout the race, winning by three lengths, Romp was second, three lengths ahead of Alleghany, third, beating Mahoney...

INDIANAPOLIS, March 28.--The Indianapoolis, Bloomington and Western Railway, the line from Indianapolis to Pekin, Ill., a distance of 202 miles, including all rights of way, , and also the line of road, and all appurtenances, extending from Indianapolis eastward to Springfield, Ohio, (commonly known as the Eastern Division,)...

CHICAGO, March 28.--"Ruddigore" had its first presentation in this city at the Chicago Opera House this evening. The reception accorded it was flattering in the extreme--more flattering than that awarded any production which Col. McCaull has given in this city.

TORONTO, March 28.--A heavy snowstorm prevailed in Western Quebec and Eastern Ontario today. Nearly all trains were delayed. In Montreal some trains were two hours behind time, while in the Ottawa district several trains are at a standstill.

Gen. Daniel Butterfield desires all honorably discharged ex-members of the Twelfth Regiment New-York Volunteers who are able to take part in the parade April 11, when the Twelfth will take posession of its new armory, Ninth-avenue and Sixty--second-street, to communicate with him at once, or with Major H.A. Bostwick, at the armory, Broadway and Fortyfifth-street. The reception at the new armory will take place on the evening of April 21.

Mayro Hewitt having inquired of the Corporation Counsel whether, in the event of the repeal of so much of the Park bill of 1884 as provides for the taking of Pelham Bay Park, the city of New-York would be subjected to claims for damages, and if so to what extent, Mr. Lacombe replies that it is doubtful that the owners.

Mrs. Summerdike's mysterious boarder, who was suspected of murdering the unknown girl in a lonely part of Rahway, N.J., last Friday night, refused to reveal his identity until his landlady produced a book and told him to register his name, so that in case the house was burned down with him his relatives and friends could claim the remains.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 28.--The bill authorizing the sale of pools and book betting on races run in other States again failed to receive a constitutional majority in the House to-day. Friends of the measure attempted some sharp practice by voting the names of absent members, but the list of names being called the trick was discovered.

ALBANY, March 28.--Gov. Hill has appointed another good Republican to office. This makes the third selection of members of this favored party for places of public trust within three weeks. The latest appointee will be special counsel to revise all bills received at the Executive Chamber during the remainder of the legislative session.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 28.--Capt. Paul Boyton, the swimmer, arrived in this city at 1 o'clock this afternoon on the steamer William M. Lawrence, of the Norfolk and Baltimore Line. He left New-York last Wednesday upon a schooner bound south.

ROME, March 28.--The text of Cardinal Gibbons's report on the Knights of Labor, as published in the Moniteur de Rome, shows that several additions have been made to the report as originally published. Referring to the objections urged against the organization, the Cardinal says: "It is objected that in this kind of organizations Catholics mix with Protestants, to the peril of their faith.

CHICAGO, March 28.--The Democrats are still searching for a standard bearer. The Conference Committee appointed by the City Central Committee to agree upon candidates for the Mayoralty and Treasurership met at 11 o'clock this morning in Edgar Terhune's office, 73 Clark-street.

PARIS, March 28.--The Cabinet has been discussing Minister Develle's proposals in favor of placing mutual betting under the control of racing societies, a portion of the profits to be devoted to encouraging horse breeding or to a charitable object. No decision has been arrived at. The scheme will fail to please the bookmakers. At Longchamps yesterday numerous arrests were made for betting. There was no disturbance.

Mrs. Agnes Booth-Schoeffel, who has been suffering from a severe cold for the past few days, did not appear in "Jim, the Penman" last evening at the Madison-Square Theatre. Miss Annie Meyer, who has been Mrs. Booth's understudy, played the character of Mrs. Ralston.

LONDON, March 28.--The Mark-Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade during the past week, says: "The grain trade does not improve. There has been a further decline in values of English wheat, although the supplies are meagre. The sales of English wheat during the week were 42,970 quarters at 33s, 2d., against 76,001 quarters at 30s, 9d. during the corresponding period last year.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 28.--Gov. Marmaduke to-night signed the repeal of the law of 1857, which enforces the Downing Sunday law in St. Louis. It was confidently anticipated by the majority of the citizens of St. Louis that the Governor would pocket veto the measure, and now that he has signed it, the greatest consternation will follow.

QUEENTSTOWN, March 28.--The anxiety as to the Dauntless is at an end. She arrived today in a sound condition, with all well on board. She passed Kinsale Head at 3:10 P.M., and crossed the finishing line at 6:45. Her actual time on the passage was 16 days, 1 hour, 43 minutes, and 13 seconds.
WINCHESTER, Va., March 28.--The Prohibitionists carry Frederick County, and their majority may reach 300. At many points the contest was animated.

Three days have passed since the body of an unknown young woman who had been murdered was found by the side of the highway in the suburbs of Rahway, but scarcely any progress bas been made toward clearing away the mystery which surrounds the crime.

When Benjamin Sharrat, the veteran fisherman, visited his fyke net, at South Beach, Staten Island, yesterday morning, he saw something in it that made his eyes glisten, while a slow but widening smile bisected his face.

The enactment of the Legislature incorporating the Samuel J. Tilden Library Trust having been signed by Gov. Hill on Saturday it has become a law. In order that the public, who are the designated beneficiaries under the trust, may be acquainted with the intentions of the Trustees, they were seen at their offices, 15 Gramercy Park, yesterday morning. The three gentlement constituting the board, Messrs. John...

A storm is always brewing in the Brooklyn Park Commission and yesterday one burst over the head of Secretary Andrew A. Smith. He is about 65 years of age, very hard of hearing and slow of action, but he got from under this thunderclap and the subsequent deluge with remarkable rapidity. The Secretary was bending over a desk in the office at the City Hall when President Easton, of the commission, entered.

BERLIN, March 28.--The Emperor being indisposed the Empress yesterday accorded a farewell audience to Mgr. Galimberti, the special envoy of the Pope. In receiving him she said: "It seems to me as if I had known you for a long time, Monsignor.

Mr. J.J. Staples gives another version of the scuffle which took place between himself and James C. Flood, Jr., in the corridor of the Hoff man House last Friday night. He says that the party met at the Morton House late that afternoon, going thence to the Hoffman.

Barnum's hairy family had to divide the attention of the crowd at the Madison-Square Garden last night with two dainty little Chinese ladies, who sat perched on a platform with their diminutive feet in full view.

LONDON, March 29.--Tennyson's jubilee ode is published to-day. It is entitled "Carmen saeculare," and is in alternate three and eightline blank verse stanzas. The first and second stanzas are as follows:

A broad band of crape hung beside the door of 40 West Thirty-fifth-street yesterday, and within the house lay the body of William R. Travers. Only a few of the most intimate friends of the deceased were admitted during the day, but many messages of condolence and sympathy were received by the family.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 28.--The purchase of the Jackson Iron Mine, at Negaunee, Mich., by Messrs. Mitchell and Chisholm, is said to have been effected for $1,300,000.

Judge Patterson smiled yesterday in the Supreme Court, Chambers, when Mr. Hummel, in defending Harry Hill, read an affidavit to the effect that the main object for which Hill kept his place at Crosby and Houston streets open was the education of the people up to the line of...

It is highly probable that the Coronet is a faster yacht than the Dauntless, as indeed she ought to be. Off the wind and in a seaway length, which is always an important factor of speed, is especially valuable, and these were the conditions that prevailed during the greater part of the ocean race.

The funeral of ex-Senator James M. Oakley took place yesterday from the Reformed Church in Jamaica. The church was crowded. Among those present were Congressman Perry Belmont, Austin Corbin, Assemblymen Hines, Fitch, and Reeves, Mayor Gleason, ex-Gov. McCormick, and all the county officials of Queens...

The two fifteen-ball pool experts, Albert M. Frey, the champion, and J. Louis Malone, wrestled with each other last night at Maurice Daly's Brooklyn billiard hall and played 31 games that, toward the close, wrought the spectators into a great state of excitement.

Paul Tulane, the wealthiest citizen of Princeton, N.J., died Sunday night at his resi dence in that town at the age of 86 years. Mr. Tulane's wealth is estimated at from $5,000,000 to $7,000,000. He was a Frenchman by birth and went to school, though not to college, in Princeton. He went South early in life and made his home at New-Orleans. He went into the cotton trade and made a fortune.

NASHVILLE, Ill., March 28.--A shooting affray, which causes great excitement, occurred here about 1 o'clock this afternoon. William Miller, a prominent and respected farmer living near here, was shot and fatally wounded by his son-in-law, John Ford, a shiftless, good-for-nothing fellow. Miller was shot down as he was hitching his team near the public square.
ALBANY, March 28.--The United States authorities have lately made investigation of the Watervliet Arsenal with a view to the ultimate establishment there of one of the big gun foundries.

The Gate City Gas Company, of Atlanta, Ga., of which the fugitive Walter E. Lawton was Treasurer and Secretary, has been placed in the hands of a Receiver. The company started in 1884 with a capital stock of $200,000, working under the Lowe water gas patents. Osgood Welsh was President, and $70,000 in first mortgage bonds were soon issued. Lawton claimed to be the largest stockholder and bondholder.

The Directors of the New-York, NewHaven and Hartford Railroad met at the Grand Central Station yesterday and voted to follow the plan of the Pennsylvania Road and the Boston and Albany in regard to passes. That is, they will do away with all passes from a point in one State to a point in another, except such as are held by officers and employes of the road, or...

James Connolly, the State Factory Inspector, appointed under the factory law of 1886, has been investigating the clothesmaking shops on the east side. Yesterday he made affidavits against the proprietors of four of these places, whom he charged with employing girls under 21 years of age and minors under the age...

CHICAGO, March 28.--Dr. McCosh, of Princeton College, being unable to attend the Anti-Secret Society Congress in this city on Wednesday and Thursday next, writes to the Rev. Dr. Blanchard: "Some years ago we effectually put down the Greek...
The Agnes Folsom case was once more before Judge Patterson in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, upon a disagreement between the counsel as to the scope of the order of reference to Samuel Jones.

WHEELING, West Va., March 28.--This morning Sheriff Hauck, with a gang of 125 laborers, went out to the line of the newly laid Piedmont and Cumberland Railroad and tore up about two miles of track which had been put...

OTTAWA, March 28.--Two freight trains on the Canadian Pacific Road, one bound east and the other bound west, came into collision near Franktown yesterday morning. Both trains were wrecked, but no one was killed. The loss is $100,000.

LONDON, March 28.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir Henry Holland, Colonial Secretary, replying to a question, stated that the Canadian Parliament possessed authority to purchase and direct the operations of armed cruisers in Canadian waters without the consent of the Imperial Government. The act of 1867 gave Canada the power to legislate in all matters relative to the militia and military and naval defense.

William Dunphy, of 7 Harrison-street, was employed at Hanan's shoe factory, on Centrestreet, when the men went out on strike, and he went out with them. Two days later, however, he returned to work. The members of the union had for some time suspected that he was disclosing union secrets to their employers. He had fallen behind in his dues, and refused to pay them.

Prof. H.H. Boyesen lectured yesterday at the Lyceum Theatre on "Tennyson." He said the poet was a typical Englishman, marked by moderation, and as clinging to precedent. He criticised Tennyson's lack of discrimination, and instanced the numerous anachronisms in the idyls. "In Memoriam" he considered the noblest product of Tennyson's genius.
The most interesting witness before the Bacon investigating committee in Brooklyn yesterday was Dr. Henry F. Menninger, who was one of the Kings County Coroners last year.

One hundred small boys, homeless, and for the most part without parents, listened with interest last evening to the good advice given them by various speakers at the opening of the new boys' lodging house of the Children's Aid Society...

Commissioner James S. Coleman, of the Street-Cleaning Bureau, has issued orders for the collection of ashes and garbage in the Nineteenth Precinct between midnight and 7 o'clock in the morning on and after April 1.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 28.--Deputy United States Marshall Lovejoy arrested George H. Bacon in this city to-day on charges of forging the signature of the Du Leiru Manufacturing and Milling Company, of Basier, Du Leiru, Canada, to two notes, one for $80 and the other...

Alexander Thain, of 1 Pine-street, counsel for Charles E. Fleming, of 71 West Forty-ninthstreet, procured an attachment yesterday against the property of James Kearney on a claim of $3,327 62, money borrowed between Feb. 13 and March 15.
Ehrich Brothers, of Eighth-avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth streets, held their Spring opening yesterday. It was very successful, both from the standpoint of the firm and of the public.

PARIS, March 28.--A sensation has been caused, by the publication of a reported conversation between M. Flourens, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, and the correspondent of the Novoe Vremya, of St. Petersburg. The story is officially declared to be incorrect, but little value is attached to the denial.

The Forum for April has an attractive table of contents, the subjects ranging all the way from woman suffrage to hydrophobia and from marriage to balloons and the sea serpent. The paper on the latter theme is by Richard A. Proctor, who points out the evil that has been done by satire and levity in discouraging the collection and publication of evidence.

The feature of to-day's events at the Real Estate Exchange will be the sale of Christ Church to the highest bidder. It is to be an unreserved sale, except in particulars that cannot concern any purchaser except another church.

The whisper that went the rounds among the politicians yesterday that the Hon. James O'Brien, with the effective organization in the various Assembly districts which he has periodically evoked to do battle against the "halls and bosses," was to join the Labor Party stirred the political depths pretty thoroughly.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., March 28.--Dr. William B. Eager made an assignment on Saturday to Charles C. Luckay, both residents of this village. The liabilities are stated at $30,000, with preferences of $10,000. The failure was caused by heavy obligations to the Middletown National Bank incurred for Benjamin Brown, the grain speculator who wrecked the bank two years ago. Dr. Eager became involved with Brown in butter and cheese operations in Nebraska.
Grand Marshal Horatio C. King, of the Brooklyn Grand Army of the Republic, has appointed Gen. Robert Avery Chief of Staff, Capt. H.A. Phillips Adjutant-General, Francis M. Edgerton Inspector-General.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 28.--The effects of the Star Baseball Club were advertised to be sold in this city this morning by the Directors of the club in order to obtain money with which to pay a threethousand-dollar judgment recently obtained by John A. Cole as compensation for injuries received at Star Park two Summers ago by falling from the grand stand while witnessing a game of ball and breaking his leg.
PANAMA, March 28, via Galveston.--A riot oc curred in this city last night, owing to a military officer resisting arrest. Three men were killed and several wounded.

The creditors of Edmiston Waddell; the dealers in agricultural implements at 95 Broadway, in the Eastern District of Brooklyn, met there yesterday to fix upon some plan for the payment of their claims.

READING, Penn., March 28.--Frank Zabel, under trial since last Thursday for the murder of his brother, Charles, was this afternoon acquitted on the ground of insanity. The jury were out but a half hour.

The Legion of Justice is the taking title of a company which started the mutual insurance business nearly four years ago under fair skies. Twenty-six branch companies were organized, with 1,200 members.

"Theodora," Sardou's picture of mediaeval Byzantium from a modern Parisian point of view, is now to be seen at the Star Theatre, and to sea it now, with Bernhardt as the Empress, is to understand why Sardou wrote the play.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--The Department of State has received information from the Consul at Milan, Italy, that there will be held in that city in the months of May and June next an international exhibition of flouring milling machinery and apparatus connected with bread making. Italian paste making, race dressing, and similar industries.

The tug Hercules was passing down the North River at 4:30 o'clock yesterday morning with two barges belonging to the Cornell Steamboat Company in tow. The barges swung apart as they came up to the wreck of the Wells City, which lies in midstream off the foot of West...

BOSTON, March 28.--In a gambling house affray this afternoon Adolph A. Albrecht shot and instantly killed David Lannahan and mortally wounded Edward Flanigan, joint proprietors of the faro bank at 10 Avery-street. The murderer, Albrecht, is an apothecary on Harrison-avenue.

The committee of citizens who have undertaken to collect money for the erection of a monument to the memory of Henry Ward Beecher held a meeting last night in the Art Association Rooms, in Montague-street, Brooklyn. WASHINGTON, March 28.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court to-day in the habeas corpus case No. 7, original, ex parte in the matter of George M. Bain, Jr., petitioner. Bain was Cashier of the Exchange National Bank, of Norfolk, Va., and was indicted under section 5,209 of the Revised Statutes for making a false report or statement as to the condition of that bank.

The sale of ceramics of the A.T. Stewart collection attracted a large number of persons to the American Art Galleries, in East Twentythird-street, yesterday, among whom were many ladies. The bidding was general, and some of the rarer pieces called forth a spirited contest for their possession.

Gen.Thomas J. Brady was in town yesterday, receiving the congratulations of his friends upon his recent marriage to Mrs. Harriet H. Yates, of Charleston, S.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Holt, of St. James's rectory, at Fordham, on March 15. Gen. Brady is engaged in settling up some old business affairs preparatory to settling down on his Classic Shore farm, which adjoins Colonial Beach, a noted resort on the Potomac.

Eight members of the Executive Committee of the Irish Parliamentary fund met yesterday afternoon at the office of M.J. O'Brien, 24 Nassaustreet. Judge Brown presided, and R.M. Walters, Secretary; Eugene Kelly, James Coleman, J.P. Farrell, L.J. Callana, Major Byrne, and C.C. Shayne were present. The report of the Hoffman House fund committee showed that there is about $55,000 on hand. There was much discussion about how to render aid to Ireland.

"The Women's Conference of the City of New-York" held its regular monthly meeting yesterday morning at the hall of the Industrial Education Association, 9 University-place. About 50 ladies were present, and Mrs. Josephine Shaw Lowell presided. The subject of discussion was "Temperance."
KEOKUK, Iowa, March 28.--The Government canal at Keokuk was opened to-day for general navigation.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 28.--Joseph Young, a prominent citizen of Harmony, committed suicide by hanging this morning. He was indorser on a note for $1,200 with William L. Carpenter as principal. Carpenter absconded some time since, and although Young claimed that the signature was a forgery he was sued for the whole amount. While in a fit of despondency over this he took his life. He was a widower, and leaves a large family of children.

At the Stewart sale Cornelius Vanderbilt bought Rosa Bonheur's great painting. "The Horse Fair," for $53,000, and gave it to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It wil be far the finest thing in that collection, and a committee ought to be appointed to keep Cesnola from putting some nice old antique heads and legs on some of the horses.

Rollin M. Squire may be torn from his farm on the banks of the Hudson next week and put face to face with an unpoetic and unsympathetic jury. His counsel, however, does not consider it probable. Maurice B. Flynn's case is so closely connected with Squire's that its disposal will depend upon Squire's fate at the hands of the District Attorney.

It would be interesting to know on what issue the Republicans expect to enter the next national campaign. None at the present moment seems to be very clear in the minds of the leaders who are speaking from time to time, or in those of the party newspaper editors who do not enjoy the precious privilege of saying nothing when there is nothing to say.

Some of the stock brokers who are interested in the Phenix Mining Company could not curb their enthusiastic souls yesterday, and before the regular hour for dealings came on the Stock Exchange they were wrangling over Phenix quotations. They howled as if they had a consuming ambition to buy up the whole capital...

DENVER, Col., March 28.--The Democratic City Convention this afternoon nominated Charles D. Cobb for Mayor, W.W. Dale for City Attorney. Charles E. Talmadge for Auditor, E.H. Worrall for Clerk, and Ralph Voorhees for Treasurer.

Commissioner Fink, Chairman of the joint committee of the trunk lines, yesterday sent a communication to W.L. Strong, Chairman of the Dry Goods Merchants' Committee, replying to the letter from the trade. Mr. Fink's letter is interpreted by the dry goods dealers to mean that any concessions they may desire from that trunk lines will have to be fought for.

ERIE, Penn., March 28.--Dr. A.G. Ely, of Girard, committed suicide by taking an overdose of morphine last night. The doctor was one of the leading physicians and surgeons of Northwestern Pennsylvania and had amassed a fortune of $150,000. The delusion that his property was getting away from him drove him to self-destruction.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 28.--Senator Beck, who was invited by leading Democrats to deliver an address in reply to that of Senator Sherman, telegraphed to-day to the Speaker of the Senate that he could not accept. He stated, however, that he would send a letter, the receipt of which is awaited with interest.

WASHINGTON, March 28.--Capt. John G. Butler, Ordnance Department, has been ordered from the Springfield Armory to Colt's Manufacturing Works, Connecticut, to inspect Gatling guns now being manufactured.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 28.--Col. Clarke E. Carr to-day received a letter from Deacon S. V. White, the Wall-street financier and Congressman, in which Mr. White accepts an invitation to make an address at the Commencement of Knox College, Galesburg, in June. The act to incorporate the Tilden Trust has been signed by the Governor, and there is little doubt that the Trustees under Mr. TILDEN'S will will organize in accordance with its provisions and proceed as soon as practicable to execute the purposes of the trust.

Niciolo Gioia, a young Italian who was on the wrecked steamer Scotia, died yesterday at the Castle Garden Hospital. The small amount of food he had received during the latter part of the voyage and the exposure following the wreck are the causes assigned for his death.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, March 28.--The first steamer of the sealing feet, the Aurora, arrived from the icefields Saturday with only 3,400 seals. She reports the steamer Terranova with 20,000. All other vessels poorly fished. It is certain that the catch will be much below last year's. The ice blockade is now broken all along the coast.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 29.--The dwelling house occupied by Matthew Massick, at Ludlowville, 10 miles from this place, was burned between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning. Massick and three children perished in the flames. The Coroner is investigating the case. Massick was an employe of the Lehigh Valley Railroad.

Mount Vernon had a wild time yesterday. It was a wilder time than it had ever dreamed of, and the wildest ever known to an interior town of New-York State. Mount Vernon is a hamlet about 25 miles up on the line of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 29.--Matheson Harley Co., dry goods, have suspended. Their liabilities are about $34,000; half preferred.

To-day the sale of season tickets for the Patti season of opera at the Metropolitan Opera House begins at the box office. The boxes not reserved by the stockholders will also be sold. The season will open on April 11, and the demand for seats by mail has been something unprecedented.

William H. Howe, 22 years old, a nephew of Robert B. Nooney, ex-President of the Board of Aldermen, committed suicide last night by shooting himself in the left breast with a pistol at his lodgings, 379 Fourth-avenue. Deputy Coroner Jenkins gave an order permitting the removal of the body to Mr. Nooney's house. Young Howe had been suffering with nervous depression for some time.

A sale is now in progress at the stores of the Keep Manufacturing Company, 640 Broadway and 32 East Fourteenth-street, at which bargain lovers will do well to pause. All the goods sold are manufactured by the company, so that their quality is guaranteed.

ALBANY, March 29.--The disclosures of Chamberlain Ivins of the political assessments levied on candidates in New-York City have greatly disturbed the politicians of Tammany Hall, and they have been still more disconcerted by the fear that these disclosures will give a powerful impetus to a citizens' movement at the coming city election.

ALBANY, March 29.--The authorities of NewYork City have been negotiating for some days with the Electrical Subway Commissioners to effect a compromise on the several bills relating to subway commissions before the Senate Cities Committee.
UTICA, N.Y., March 29.--William S. Bartlett, one of the best known residents of Clinton, N.Y., committed suicide by hanging in his barn this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., March 29.--Henry E. Dixey, the comedian, who is filling a two weeks' engagement at the Grand Opera House, gave a lifelike imitation this evening of a man walking off in charge of a constable.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 29.--Alfred Smith, who killed his wife and Mrs. Louisa Wilson a year ago last January, and was recently convicted of murder in the second degree, received to-day his sentence, life imprisonment.
WASHINGTON, March 29.--Second Lieut. Henry D. Humphreys, Twentieth Infantry. (recently appointed,) has been ordered to join Company I, Camp Poplar River, Montana.

The consequence of the eight years' rule of CARTER HARRISON as Mayor of Chicago is not only his forced retirement from political life, but such a demoralized condition of the Democratic organization in that city that nobody else will take its nomination.

Coroner Levy and his jury finished yesterday their investigation into the death of Patrick H. Dolan, who was killed by a Third-avenue elevated train at the Ninth-street station early on the morning of March 18. How Dolan got on the platform and afterward under the train remains unexplained.

Frey and Malone started last night's play in their pool match at Daly's rooms in Washington-street. Brooklyn, with scores of 16 and 15 respectively. The boy began with somewhat weak play, and Malone captured two games, giving him a lead of one, which, however, he did not retain very long.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 29.--The latest addition to Canada's fleet of cruisers for the protection of the fisheries was launched to-day at Shelburne. She is named the Triumph and registers 105 tons. She will be commanded by Capt. Lorway, late of the cruiser Howlette. The Howlette's armament and furnishings will be placed on board the Triumph.

TRENTON, N.J., March 29.--The House last night amended in unimportant particulars the bill granting the consent of the Legislature to the lease of the west Shore to the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, and the Senate to-day concurred in the amendments. This lease was executed two years ago, and the legislation just secured was necessary for the legal completion of the matter.

The furniture store of Epstein, Kantrowitz, Co., at 99 Bowery, was burned out last night. It was in a four-story brick building, 25 feet front and 100 feet deep, filled with furniture and carpets.

Ex-Superintendent of Dockmasters J.L. Liscombe told the Commissioners of Accounts yesterday that he knew of many instances where Dockmasters had failed to return to the city all the money collected from the owners of vessels. He gave instances which involved Dockmaster Smith.
LONDON, March 29.--Mr. Gladstone resumed the debate in the House of Commons this afternoon on the Irish Criminal Law Amendment bill. He was loudly cheered when he arose.

The milk farmers of Orango County are exercised over railroad rates on milk bound for this city under the inter-State railroad law. They cannot understand why they should be charged 35 cents per can for a distance of 40 or 50 miles, while other farmers living at double that distance pay no more.

MELBOURNE, March 29.--Two schooners laden with natives of the Tonga Islands, all converts to Wesleyanism, have arrived at Suva. PARIS, March 29.--The bill establishing a surtax on cereals will be gazetted to-morrow. The Government will introduce a bill fixing a term of exemption for cargoes afloat.

The residents of Pelham, through the authorities of that town, having asked the authorities of this city to join in an application to the Legislature to repeal the act of 1884 which pro vides for Pelham Bay Park, Mayor Hewitt wrote to the Aldermen yesterday commending the suggestion.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., March 30.--The mystery of a murder committed here 17 years ago has been cleared up by a deathbed confession of one of the murderers. On May 27, 1870, Jefferson Yohe, 18 years of age, was shot and killed on the Ringtown Mountain, a mile out of town.

BOSTON, Mass., March 30.--A special to the Journal from St. John's, Newfoundland, says: "The steamer Eagle, from the sealing grounds, is reported lost with 200 men. No particulars have been received."

Marco Stanwick, a Turk, liming at 35 Mott-street, was led into the Harlem Court yesterday. Following him was a huge bear, led by a light chain. He had been arrested for leading the beast through the street. The bear stood before the bar on his hind legs, and his master put him through a series of tricks to show Justice Patterson that the animal was perfectly docile. Both prisoners were discharged.

ST. LOUIS, March 30.--A final order was filed to-day in the United States Circuit Court by Judge Brewer in the case of the Central Trust Company, of New-York, against the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway Company.

SAVANNAH, Ga., March 30.--Capt. W.G. Raoul, ex-President of the Georgia Central Railroad, has been elected President of the Mexican National Railroad. The election took place 10 days ago in New-York. SAN FRANCISCO, March 30.--Exchange--NewYork sight drafts 20; telegraphic, 25.

CHICAGO, March 30.--Master builders from nearly every part of the United States are meeting here in a national convention. The gathering is an important one, and is likely to have great influence in settling the relations between the builders of the United States and the men they employ.

Many of your readers may possibly be surprised to learn that the people of Marseilles have raised by public subscription a statue to the memory of Rouffe, a kind of Joey Grimaldi, who had long delighted the people of the south by his amusing powers as a mime and mummer.

The will of John H. Sherwood, long connected with banks and insurance companies, has been admitted to probate in the Surrogate's office. It bears date of Nov. 22, 1886. INDIANAPOLIS, March 30.--Gen. Lucius Fairchild arrived at noon to-day, and was met by a Reception Committees and taken to the Bates House, where he was called upon during the afternoon by a large number of people. He is visiting the Grand Army, and will stop at three points in Indiana-- Lafayette.

CHICAGO, March 30.--An evening paper says: "The two big Chicago operators, Nat Jones and N.B. Ream, are now on their way to New-York, and it is confidently expected that the result of this trip will be an old-time whirl in Wall-street.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 30.--The difficulties between Jesse W. Starr, Jr., of Philadelphia, who contracted to furnish this place with electric light, and his creditors were to-day adjusted after several hours' cousultation. The plant, which had been seized, was released to-day, and workmen will complete the circuits at once, when a local corporation known as the Relvidere Electric Lighting Company will purchase the outfit.

LONDON, March 30.--The steamship Dalton, (Br.,) Capt., Russell from New-York March 16, for Liverpool, passed Kinsale to day. The steamship Galileo, (Br.,) Capt. Jones, sld from Hull for New-York to-day.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 30.--Bishop Harkins will be consecrated in the new cathedral in this city on April 14, the Most Rev. John. J. Williams, Archbishop of Boston, officiating as consecrator, assisted by the Right Rev. P.F. O'Reilly, Bishop of Springfield, and the Right Rev., Lawrence F. McMahon, Bishop of Hartford.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, March 30.--Albert Koschniscki, alias Bismarck, occupied the witness box this morning in the Haddock murder trial.
INDIANAPOLIS, March 30.--The train upon which Mr. Blaine reached this city to-day was over one hour late and it was nearly 1:30 o'clock when his car was pulled into the station.
The creditors of Edmiston Waddell, the absconded dealers in agricultural implements, of 95 Broadway, Williamsburg, had a despairing conference yesterday afternoon at the Astor House.

SAN ANTONIO, March 30.--Meagre details have reached here of a wreck on the Southern Pacific 300 miles west of here. At Dryden, a station in the second division, a west-bound engine and caboose smashed full tilt into a freight train coming east. The trainmen had no time to jump, and the breakage is very severe. Engineer McCanless was pinched and scalded to death.

The ex-Fenian and ex-Communist, Cluseret, still continues his treatise on civil war in the columns of a revolutionary paper with absolute impunity. His instructions are laid down with a precision worthy of Count von Moltke himself, and he calmly tells his readers how to erect barricades and to defend them against cavalry.

John Lamb, in a drunken frenzy, stabbed James Conlin, a boy, in West Thirty-fourthstreet, last October, and killed him. He was put on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part I, for murder in the first degree. Lamb's counsel used great care in selecting a jury, and finally the box was filled. The last juror was August Roesler, who was one of the...
HAVANA, March 30.--Smallpox is becoming epidemic in Sancti Spiritus.

James H. Howard, who lives on Monroestreet, near Broadway, Brooklyn, and runs a real estate office, was arrested yesterday on a charge of uttering a forged tax receipt and the larceny of $30. Last October sven Johansen, a Swede, bought property on Bay-avenue from W.P. Shepherd.

J.L. Colby rates very solidly on the Produce Exchange. Ten years ago the firm of Drake Colby, prominent grain exporters, failed. The failure hurt a good many people, and very little was saved from the wreck.

CHICAGO, March 30.--The Democratic Party of Chicago is still without a candidate for Mayor, and the leaders are again looking to Carter Harrison, notwithstanding that he has twice accepted and twice declined the nomination.
WASHINGTON 30.--The President today appointed the following-named Postmasters:

James King, an able and industrious stonemason, 44 years old, working for Mark Eidlitz, left his home, 208 East Fifty-ninth-street, yesterday morning, and returned shortly after noon because frost was in the stones he was to cut.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 30.--The Rev. J.W. Klinger, Pastor of the Lutheran Church of Centreville, Penn., one of the oldest organizations of this church in the country, has been deposed from the ministry by the Classis of Eastern Pennsylvania on charges of intemperance, immorality, and conduct unbecoming a minister, to which he made no defense.

CINCINNATI, March 30.--It is stated here that the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company will pay no regard to the inter-State commerce law, but will do business in its own way. If the Commissioners call it to account it will go into court and test the constitutionality of the law.

SANTA FE, New-Mexico, March 30.--It was reported here last night that Mexico Leyba, the notorious outlaw, leader of the gang who have terrorized Central New-Mexico for six months, had been killed while resisting arrest near Antelope Springs, 70 miles south of here.

ST. LOUIS, March 30.--Ex-Gov. Thomas C. Reynolds, Missouri's most prominent statesman, committed suicide a few minutes after 2 o'clock this afternoon by plunging head foremost from the third floor of the Custom House through the freight elevator shaft to the basement, a distance of 80 feet.
Emil and Gussie Borck the two children who have distinguished themselves by crossing the continent alone, arrived at the Pennsylvania station Tuesday evening at 10:30.
Five days have now clapsed since the comely lass was butchered in the little city of Rahway, N.J., and the murderer is not yet found and the girl has not been satisfactorily identified.
NYACK, March 30.--The excitement in Piermont and Sparkill over the alleged ghost seen between those two places had become so great recently that some timid persons were talking about moving away.

CHICAGO, March 30.--The Congress of Churches and Christians commenced its session here to-day, its objoct being the inauguration of a movement to crush out secret societies. About 300 delegates, mostly men beyond middle age, were present from several states.

The twelfth annual intercollegiate field meeting will be held in this city May 28, probably at the Manhattan Athletic Grounds. Columbia will be represented in nearly all the contests. As far as can be ascertained at present her team will consist of the following: S.S. Derrickson, ...

DETROIT, March 30.--The State public school at Coldwater, an institution which has the care of the dependent and pauper children of the State, has a scandal investigation on its hands. The board are now in session inquiring into alleged improper acts on the part of its Principal.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 30.--Snow has been falling all day, and at 8 o'clock to-night it is 11 inches deep. No such snowfall so late as March is within the memory of the oldest inhabitant. The roof of Featherstone's livery stable was crushed in with the weight of snow and destroyed many vehicles. No one hurt. Other roofs are considered to be in an extremely perilous condition.

One of the biggest building strikes that have occurred in this city for a long time past took place yesterday afternoon at the Equitable Building, where the addition to that edifice is being completed.

The unusual prominence which, from various causes, was given Mrs. James Brown Potter before her departure for Europe created a very general curiosity concerning the success or failure of her principal essay as a professional actress.

CHICAGO, March 30.--The National Association of Builders met again this morning and adopted rules for its government. It was unanimously decided to hold the next convention at Cincinnati in February, 1888. Officers elected were as follows: President--J. Milton Blair, Cincinnati; First VicePresident--John S. Mme. Dory Burmeister-Peterson gave her second and last recital of pianoforte music at Steinway Hall yesterday evening.

The third night's play of the pool match between Frey and Malone at Daly's rooms in Washington street, Brooklyn, resulted in a Waterloo for Malone. Frey won the first 7 games before Malone gained 1, and then Frey won 5 more straight games. The result was: Frey, 16 games; Malone, 5 games. This makes a total for the three nights' play of 48 games for Frey and 32 for Malone.

The Bakers' International Union yesterday celebrated the event of the admission of the fiftieth local union, which the Executive Committee was informed was just organized in Saginaw, Mich. The entire union now counts some 11,000 members.

Family troubles were aired with vim and spirit on the part of all the witneeses in Justice Walsh's court, Brooklyn, yesterday. Mr. and Mrs. Gertrude J. Canfield, of 531 Pacific-street, gave a dinner party on Thursday. Gertrude is the stepdaughter of Mrs. Euphemia Freeburn, with whom she and her husband do not get on well.
It may be that the concession of home rule to Ireland is nearer than has generally been thought, even by the most sanguine supporters of the measure.

Commissioner Coleman does not evidently approve of the new sanitary regulations in regard to the removal of ashes and garbage. Writing to President James C. Bayles, he says that his department is prepared to remove ashes and garbage separately if, for sanitary or other reasons, it is deemed advisable.

Way back in the fifties there was organized in this city an extensive gang of men who had reduoed the forging of wealthy men's names to a science and who for a long time made the opening of bank accounts a very risky means of saving money.
All the principal walks of life were represented in the assemblage that attended the funeral services of William R. Travers yesterday morning at Trinity Chapel, Twenty-fifth-street, near Broadway.
CHICAGO, March 30.--It is believed by railroad men here that the new agreement of the Central Traffic Association cannot be carried out.

LONDON, March 30.--At the Northampton meeting to-day the race for the Ascot Plate for 2-year-olds was won by Gen. Pearson's blk. o. Anarch with A. Taylor's b.c. Pull Together second, and J. Ryan's ch.f. Lllybud third. There were six starters. Anarch won by three lengths and there was the same distance between second and third.
BUFFALO, N.Y., March 30.--Patrick Walsh, of New-York, adopted the Hebrew faith yesterday and was married this morning to Lena Levi, a young Jewess, also of New-York.
PESTH, March 30.--Three cases of Asiatic cholera have been discovered here, and the nature of the malady in each has been clearly established. Much alarm prevails in consequence.

The committee of the dry goods dealers met again yesterday and discussed the trunk line freight classification which it expects to test before the Inter-state Commissioners. There are some points upon which the members of the committee are not agreed, and it was decided to submit them to a meeting of the trade.

After waiting until 8:30 o'clock for the appearance of Chairman John Cochrane, the Tammany General Committee convened last evening, and selected ex-Fire Commissioner Roswell D. Hatch as presiding officer.

A barn on the premises of the late Daniel Van Winkle on Garrison-avenue, Jersey City, was destroyed by fire on Tuesday evening, and Edward Stevens, a boy who had been in Mrs. Van Winkle's service, was arrested on suspicion of having set it on fire.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 30.--The Democrats to-day nominated an exceptionally strong municipal ticket, headed by Brenton D. Babcock for Mayor.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 30.--The falling of a lighted chandelier in the lecture room of the First Presbyterian Church, where a praise service was in progress, almost created a panic last night. A portion of the floor and a number of seats were burned before the flames were extinguished.

A gentleman who were gold-rimmed blue eye glasses and was fashionably attired, but who appeared to have neglected himself for some time, went last night to Milton Merrill's drug store, 357 First-avenue, and introduced himself as a practicing physician.

Buffalo Bill tears himself away from his native land this morning. The State of Nebraska., which he and his partner, Nate Salsbury, have chartered for a trip across the ocean to show the offete Europeans just what real life in America is like, will leave Leroy-street dock at 10 o'clock, and along with Mr. Cody and Mr. and Mrs. Salsbury there will sail 50 guests.

Mrs. H.M. King lives at 919 Fourthavenue. Her husband is out of the city-traveling for a firm. Tuesday night Henry F. King, a young man living at 121 East Fortieth-street, rang the door bell of Mrs.King's residence. She had never seen him before, but when he asked if he was talking to Mrs. King the lady informed him that he was.

PARIS, March 30.--Messrs. Leon Say, Renaud Yves, Emile Guyot, Charles Camille Pelletan, Maurice Rouvier, and Louis Charles Paul le Passy have joined the committee of the Anti-Corn Law League, recently organized for the purpose of combating the protective tendency of the French Parliament.

The latest thing in the way of a device for heating and lighting railroad cars was exhibited by means of a model at the Grand Central Station yesterday. BERLIN, March 30.--In consequence of the protest of Herr Neumann, Director of the Royal Opera, the Intendent-General has canceled the arrangement with Herr Scidl to assume the musical direction of the opera.
NEW-ORLEANS, March 30.--The weather to-day was windy and partly cloudy, and the track was dusty. Following is a summary of he day's events:

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 30.--The Northwestern Miller says: "With fairly good power and desiring to get out all the flour possible before freights advanced, the millers last week rolled up a large output--141,150 barrels, averaging 23,520 barrels daily, against 97,000 barrels the previous week, and 123,410 barrels the corresponding time in 1886.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 30.--The heavy snowstorms of the past week have completely demoralized traffic on the Intercolonial Railway. Another storm raged lastnight bewteen Campbellton and St. Flavie, greatly retarding the work of clearing the road.

LONDON, March 30.--A dispatch to the Sportsman from Queenstown says that Capt. Samuels, of the yacht Dauntless, attributes his defeat by the Coronet to the interference of Mr. Colt, the owner of the Dauntless, who was on board the vessel.
The joint committee of the trunk lines and the Central Traffic Association met in Commissioner Fink's office yesterday afternoon, but failed to settle the Grand Trunk difficulty.

ALBANY, March 30.--If any complaint has been made against the operations of the Chapin primary election law, which regulates the political organizations of New-York and Brooklyn, it has not been heard in Albany.

TORONTO, March 30.--The trial of the alimony, issue in the Chicago Cole divorce case, which was practically concluded here to-day, excited considerable interest. It decides an interesting point in regard to divorce cases where alimony is allowed.

MANCHESTER, March 30.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "The experience of most sellers has been unsatisfactory. They have been unable to obtain other much business or full prices, despite the stimulus of a strong report from Liverpool.
Mayor Hewitt, Controller Loew, and Commissioner of Public Works Newton opened yesterday bids for lighting the city for one year from May 1.

CINCINNATI, March 30.--Fire broke out in a closet near the stairway on the third story of St. Joseph's Children's Home, in Corryville, this morning, while the janitor was on the lower floor and while the matron and two assistants were at mass. In the third story about 20 children, from 4 to 10 years of age, were sleeping.

The funeral of William H. Howe, stepson of ex-President Robert B. Nooney, of the Board of Aldermen, will take place to-day at 11 o'clock young Howe had been out of employment for some time and had become very despondent. Tuesday night he went with his stepsister, Mary Nooney, to visit friends at 379 Fourth-avenue. It was not noticed that he was more despondent than usual.

The will of Mrs. Eliza Weathersby-Goodwin, wife of Nat Goodwin, was offered for probate yesterday. She executed the instrument on June 8, 1880, in the presence of Paul West, E.B. Callender, John F. shea, and William B. French, and named Mr. Goodwin and Mr. Callender the Executors.

BRUSSELS, March 30.--The Belgian paper La Meuse prints a report of a conversation which it says Prince Bismarck had with an illustrious Belgian during the recent fetes at Berlin in honor of the ninetieth anniversary of the Emperor's birth.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29.--The brawny fishermen of the Delaware River, chiefly those living in New-Jersey, have started a crusade against the sturgeon pirates of Delaware Bay, and the battle is to be fought out in the legislative halls at Trenton.

ERIE, Penn., March 30.--William Miller, a milk dealer, committed suicide this morning by hanging himself in his bedroom near his sleeping wife. The unfortunate man had been visibly affected by the suicidal mania which carried away three of his neighbors by the noose within a month, and several others within the same time in the county.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 30.--An interview was had to-day with the authorities of Vassar College relative to an article in a New-York paper stating that at least 275 of the pupils were displeased over the refusal to allow them to wear a uniform of cap and gown. "There is not one word of truth in it," said Treasurer Dean at the college.

Major J.R. McNulty, President of the Harlem Democratic Club, cut the string which connected the circuit and lighted 15 are lights scattered along One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet, between Fourth and Eighth avenues, last night.

Miss Cora E. Fisk, a teacher in the public school at Flushing, has, through her counsel, ex-District Attorney B.W. Downing, brought suit in the Supreme Court against Charles W. Bardun, to recover $1O,000 damages for malicious libel.

The Essex Market Police Court was filled with Polish Jews yesterday afternoon. As many as could get within the rail were clamoring to make complaints against Charles Bringer, who said that he kept an employment office at 171 Eldridge-street.

The will of Capt. James B. Eads was filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It was probated at once and letters testamentary were issued to James F. How and E. McHenry, both of St. Louis. President Bayles, of the Health Department, yesterday sent a circular to the chiefs of the seven sanitary divisions, urging them to prepare, as soon as possible, reports on the organization and work of their divisions and the best means to promote efficiency among their subordinates. They are requested to express themselves freely as to the qualifications of each subordinate.

Sylvester H. Allis, a compositor, of 96 Washington-street, Brooklyn, whose hat, filled with lead and containing a letter saying he was about to drown himself to escape from his wife's terrible tongue, was found on the Brooklyn fereryboat Winona late Tuesday night, is not believed by his companions in the Evening Post composing room to have committed suicide.

As soon as Capt. Ruffat, of the stranded steamship Scotia, submits his report to the French Consul the latter will investigate the causes of the disaster. Capt. Ruffat will not come to the city until it is definitely decided whether or not the vessel can be got off Fire Island beach.

Ice piling up in Dove's Bay, Nova Scotia, has caused the Commercial Cable Company a great deal of trouble. Yesterday one of the company's cables was working badly, and last night it had given out entirely. Messages were sent and received over the other wire, but it, too, was working slowly. A steamer has been sent to repair the damage, but the ice may hinder her work for a number of dave.

Lord Taylor's up-town store, at Broadway and Twentieth street, had its opening day yesterday, and was the great centre of interest for all the better class of shoppers, who found that the firm's Spring importations exceeded in novelty and elegance what had been expected.
Tiernan, of the New-York, has recovered from his illness, and will join the club in a few days. Hall, of the Metropolitans, will run any ball player in the country 100 yards, straight away, for $100.

ST. LOUIS, March 30.--The Missouri Pacific, St. Louis, Iron Mountain and Southern, and St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas Railroads to-day gave out to a few shippers advance sheets of the new schedule of rates that will go into effect under the inter-State commerce law.

A warrant was issued at Paterson yesterday for the arrest of a man giving his name as Schwarz, on a charge of obtaining money under false pretenses. BERLIN, March 30.--Authentic information has been received from St. Petersburg that a fresh attempt was made upon the Czar's life at the Gatschiua Palace yesterday. The Czar was not injured.

NEW-ORLEANS, March 30.--On Monday night, at the corner of Poydras and Prisur streets, George Mahoney, a one-legged young man, was shot in the back and fatally wounded by Thomas J. Newhouse. Superintendent of bridge gangs in the Department of Public Works at the City Hall. Mahoney made his dying statement to the Recorder yesterday morning.
An afternoon performance of "Theodora" will be given at the Star Theatre to-day by Mme. Bernhardt.

Henry Irving Lang wrote to Mayor Hewitt yesterday that he was a painter, but could get no work owing to the boycotting practices of the Painters' Union. The reason for this, he says, is that he has served a term in prison for burglary. He is anxious to reform and asks the Mayor what he should do. Mr. Hewitt said that he would answer the letter.

R.T. Bush, owner of the Coronet, has sent a check for $500 to the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Hall, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Beecher Memorial. In his letter accompanying the check Mr. Bush states that the check is out of the premium from the Coronet-Dauntless race.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--Fifty recruits have been ordered to such points in the departments of Texas and the Missouri as the commanding Generals shall designate for assignment to the Tenth and Sixteenth Infantries. Leave of absence for two months on account of sickness has been granted Capt. Chambers McKibbin, Fifteenth Infantry, recruiting officer.
The readers of our esteemed contemporary the Evening Post were furnished yesterday with a good specimen of the ingenuous ignorance--or worse--with which the pending Civil Code is discussed.

ALBANY, March 30.--The Rev. Justin D. Fulton, of Brooklyn, began his work of converting Roman Catholics to Protestanitsm by a most vigorous onslaught on Catholic theological teachings before the Senate Committee on Literature this afternoon ...

ALBANY, March 30.--The evils of special legislation were depicted in a special message from the Governor to the Legislature, which was read in both houses to-day. It is generally conceded that much of the Governor's lament is well grounded.
The continuation of the sale of the Haseltine collection of paintings at Moore's auction rooms last evening was not as successful as had been expected.
It seems hardly necessary to say that the politics of the future are not disturbing Mr. Cleveland's hours of work or slumber. There is no second term sheming going on at the White House.

James J. Murray, 35 years old, who gave his address as 157 West Thirty-fourth-street, New-York, attended the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, last evening, to see "Pa." As the play progressed Murray became more and more excited, and during the third act, while there was dancing on the stage, he could not contain himself...

When the Bacon investigating committee meets again in Brooklyn it will find that two very important witnesses have left town. Both of these men are Justices of the Peace of Gravesend, who have become frightened at the facts...
