The Shoe and Leather Manufacturers' Association held a secret meeting yesterday at 168 Church-street, with George Silver, of Tarrytown, in the chair. The main subject for discussion was the advisability of adopting the freeshop system, leaving to every manufacturer the liberty of employing union or non-union men, as he sees fit.

An interesting lecture, entitled "An Evening Abroad," was given by Mrs. W.F. Bainbridge last night at the Central Presbyterain Church, in West Fifty-seventh-street, where the Women's Home and Foreign Missionary Society of that institution celebrated its third anniversary.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, March 30.--A cable dispatch received from St. John's Newfoundland, this evening, says the sealing steamer Eagle is reported lost. There were on board about 200 men. It is said the steamer's boilers were unsafe when she sailed.

Very few of the parishioners of the Rev. R. Heber Newton, of the Anthon Memorial Church, were on board the steamer Indipendente, of the General Italian Line, at the WallStreet Stores, Brooklyn, yesterday, to see their Pastor set sail for sunny Italy.
CHICAGO, March 31.--A special meeting of the Chicago Railroad Association was held today, at which the question of differential fares eastward from Chicago came up for consideration.

The third and last concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place last evening at Steinway Hall. So great has been the interest excited by the advent in New-York of this admirable body of musicians that the large auditorium was filled with an audience that bestowed enthusiastic approval upon the entire entertainment.

The announcement of the dimensions of the Scotch cutter Thistle, now in process of construction to compete for the America's Cup, has given rise to considerable discussion among yachtsmen on this side of the water.

Police Commissioner Voorhis has been making a personal inspection of the so-called "dives" along the Bowery and in the Fourth Ward, to ascertain the truth of the reports made about these places by the police, and complained of by the Mayor.

ALBANY, March 31.--The Crosby High License bill was passed in the Senate this morning by a vote of 18 to 14 without amendments, and ought now to be in the hands of Gov. Hill. The Democrats voted solidly against the measure, and they were joined by Senators Worth, of Brooklyn, and Coggeshall, of Utica, who deserted the Republican ranks. The affirmative vote was solidly Republican.
The funeral of the Rev. Dr. Ray Palmer, the writer of many noted hymns, took place yesterday afternoon in the Belleville-avenue Congregational Church at Newark.

The strike of the men employed upon the Equitable Building is the latest application of the great saying that an injury to one is the concern of all. Happily there was nothing at all tragical about it, and it is seldom that the Knights of Labor treat the community to pure comedy.

Ladies who visited Bloomingdale Brothers' large store at Fifty-ninth-street and Thirdavenue yesterday at the Spring opening found countless pretty things and novelties there, too many to inspect at one sitting.

Herr Anton Seidl has confirmed the report that his engagement as conductor of the Royal Opera at Berlin has been canceled, owing to the protest of Herr Neumann, the director, in a cablegram to Director Edmund C. Stanton, or the Metropolitan Opera House.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 31.--A great sensation has been created here by the discovery of considerable crookedness in connection with legislation during the late session of the General...

The High License bill was passed by the Senate yesterday and is now in the hands of the Governor. Every Democrat and two Republicans--COGGESHALL of Oneida County and WORTH of Brooklyn--voted against it. So far as this makes it a party measure it is the fault and the mistake of the Democrats in the Legislature.

Buffalo Bill's Wild West show sailed for England yesterday morning on the steamship State of Nebraska, which had been chartered by the managers. The scene on board the big vessel before she started from the foot of Leroy-street was as gay as a Kiralfy ballet.

CHICAGO, March 31.--The Builders' National Convention finished the business before it early this afternoon and adjourned until the next annual meeting, which is to take place in Cincinnati next February.

The acrimonious contest over the estate of James T. Soutter, in which William K. Soutter was first sued for an accounting by his brother's wife, Charlotte, the Duchess D'Auxy, and then made by her the subject of a criminal charge, came to an end yesterday. Timothy Griffith, Master in Chancery in the United States Circuit Court, filed a report which ends the civil suit and practically disposes of the criminal charges as well.

FRANKFORT, N.Y., March 31.--Express Messenger Leake, who was robbed between Clark's Mills and Frankfort last night, reached here about midnight and was able to proceed to the office of Drs. Skiff and Richards, where his wound was dressed.
The attachments which his creditors placed upon the property of Charles A. Herpich, the Mercer-street fur dealer, last December, were vacated yesterday by the General Term of the Supreme Court.

Weights for two of the important handicaps for the races of the American Jockey Club to be run at Jerome Park are announced. These are for the Croton Handicap, at a mile, and the Fordham Handicap, at a mile and a quarter. These are the weights allotted to the entries:

The Commissioners appointed to report on the advisability of opening Rider-avenue east of the Mott Haven Canal have levied their assessments, and on May 27 they will ask the court to confirm their report.

TRENTON, N.J., March 31.--The Senate to-day passed the bill appropriating $125,000 for the erection of a new soldiers' home in Kearney Township, Hudson County. The Senate also passed the bill to pay the newspapers...

Last night's series of the pool match between Frey and Malone, at Daly's rooms, on Washington-street, Brooklyn, began with 48 games to Frey's credit and 32 to Malone's. Frey led off and won 8 games before he gave Malone a chance.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Acting Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild has been appointed Secretary of the Treasury by President Cleveland, and Second Controller Isaac Maynard, of New-York, has been made an Assistant...

With a special act of the Legislature to back them up, the Commissioners of Education appeared before the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, yesterday, and asked that the difference between the appropriations granted ...
LONDON, March 31.--At the meeting of the Conservative Party to-day it was decided that the House of Commons shall sit until the Irish Criminal Law Amendment bill has passed...

Some injustice has been done the Equitable Life Company in recent accounts of a compromise in the Dwight case. The Equitable never contested the claim, but investigated the facts immediately after Dwight's death, and decided that the case was honest and promptly paid its policy of $50,000. It was the only company that refused to dispute its policy.
SING SING, N.Y., March 31.--The total expenditures at Sing Sing Prison for the month of March were $14,203 71, the total earnings were $6,406 38, leaving a deficiency for the month of $7,797 33.

With bright skies and not too boisterous weather for good work the first great pigeonshooting match between England's champion, W. Graham, and J.H. Brewer, the champion of Pennsylvania, took place yesterday on the Jersey City Heights Gun Club ground at Marion, ...
LONDON, March 31.--The White Star Line steamship Britannic, Capt. Perry, from New-York March 23, for Queenstown and Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 5 P.M. to-day.

The Emigration Commissioners at their meeting yesterday raised the salary of Dr Schultz, the resident physician at Castle Garden, from $1,200 to $1,500 a year, and appropriated $1,500 toward repairing the Castle Garden hospital.

Three weeks ago Charles L. Watson, a young business man of Chicago, an employe of the Lincoln Ice Company of that city, married Miss Lillian Snavely at the house of the young lady's mother in the town of Sterling, Ill.

There is no truth in the rumor that NewYork offered Manager Watkins, of Detroit, $1,400 for the release of Shindle, the third baseman. President Day said yesterday that he never negotiated for the services of that player.

CHICAGO, March 31.--The Rev. J.A. Cole, of Sierra Leone, Africa, was the central figure at the Convention of Churches and Christians to-day. Stout and squat, unattractive, black as night, thick-lipped, low-browed, heavy-featured, Cole is the typical African.

Those who think that in time of peace it is well to prepare for war will doubtless flock to C.C. Shayne's fur store, 103 Prince-street, next week, for a special sale of furs will then begin. The increase of business in this establishment had led Mr. Shayne to make extensive alterations in the store.

We have in this city many lingering proofs of the utter inadequacy of the old system of town government as applied to large cities, and we are gradually changing this system to one of concentrated power and responsibility.

Most of the workmen employed in the Equitable Building, who struck on Wednesday because they would not work with non-union electric wiremen, assembled in the neighborhood of the building yesterday morning, and the Board of Walking Delegates were also on the spot at an early hour.

Capt. Wharton, of the brig Mary C. Mariner, which arrived yesterday from Tuspan, reports that he passed Cape Hatteras three weeks ago and since then had encountered nothing but gales from west and northwest, which occasionally blew with hurricane force.

Several more of Hanan Son's workmen who went on strike several days ago called at the factory yesterday and asked to be taken back. Mr. John Hanan informed them that the vacant places had all been filled, and that he had about 200 applications in writing for work. However, when vacancies should occur in the factory, preference would be given to the old hands.

The Rev. Dr. H.A. Brann delivered a lecture last evening in the Academic Hall of the College of St. Francis Xavier on "The Right of a Man to Own a Lot." The speaker showed that the views of the gentlemen engaged in preaching the new land theories were contrary to the Constitutions ...

Although over 30 paintings were passed without being sold last evening at the auction of the Haseltine collection, the proceeds amounted to $53,480, and the total amount realized from the three evenings' sales was $107,177.

Many of the longshoremen are still suffering from the effects of the great strike. Some 5,000 of them are still out of work, and it is said that no one known to be a member of the Ocean Association can get work along the North River. Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor will ...
NORWICH, Conn., March 31.--Marvin Smith, of Montville, died to-day, aged 102 years 4 months and 12 days. He was born Nov. 18, 1784, and spent his whole life in his native town.

Powers's "Greek Slave" and the other specimens of sculpture in heroic size will remain in the Stewart mansion to be taken by a buyer of that property, unless some one shall meanwhile arrange with the Executors to get them. They were withdrawn from public sale yesterday because no one would give the asking price.

ERIE, Penn., March 31.--The boiler department of Nagle's Engine Works was the scene of a frightful accident to-day, in which five men were the victims. A boiler was being tested by Patrick Kelly, the shop inspector. Near him were several employes.

ERIE, Penn., March 31.--The attendance at the shooting tournament of the Erie Gun Club includes crack wing shots from New-York, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. The match between W.W. Derby, of Erie, and Hiram Twist, 25 birds for $200, was shot off, Derby winning, with London rules, from Twist, with New-York State rules. Twist was matched tonight to shoot P.E. Shelden, of Cleveland, 100 live pigeons, New-York State rules, for $200 a side.

City Marshals James Boylan and Thomas J. Blessing, attached to the Eighth Civil District Court, presided over by Judge Gedney, testified before Controller Loew yesterday that they had paid illegal fees to a man named Philip Maverick.
The Metropolitan Transit Company applied to the Supreme Court, Special Term, several months ago for the appointment of Commissioners who sould determine the compensation ...

A rowing trip to Baltimore in a ten-oared barge will be entered upon about July 1 by 12 members of the Atlantic Boat Club of Hoboken. They last year made trips of the like character to Albany and Philadelphia, and found them so delightful that they determined upon extending the distance this year.

Justice O'Reilly yesterday committed for trial without bail, George Louis Wolf, accused of killing Adam Fernbach on March 20, at the ball of the Pennyverein Association at John Ross's Hall, 335 West Thirty-ninth-street. A new witness, John Gombert, of 338 West Thirty-eighth-street, ...

The sale of the Stewart collection closed last evening at the American Art Galleries with the disposal of the third lot from the library. There was much less interest manifested in the sale than on previous nights.
The series of Thomas Popular Concerts entered upon at the Metropolitan Opera House last Fall was brought to a close with yesterday afternoon's performance.
People walking along Flatbush-avenue, Brooklyn, at 6 o'clock yesterday morning saw an old man, clad only in a night shirt, staggering on the roof of 130, a flat house.

Mrs. Erving Winslow gave her second reading yesterday at the Hotel Brunswick before an audience composed almost exclusively of ladies. Mrs. Winslow began by saying that she would read "The Story of a Short Life," by Mrs. J.H. Ewing.

Coquelin, the famous French actor, will not visit America next year unless some new arrangements are made. He was to have visited this country under Mr. Chizzola's management, provided that gentleman deposited 25,000f. to secure his services to-day.

When the Western mail came into the Post Office a little after 11 o'clock Tuesday evening there were, among others, two big pouches of registered matter brought into the pouch room of the registry division.

LONDON, March 31.--Capt. Samuel Samuels sailed to-day for New-York on the steamship Adriatic. His leaving of the Dauntless so hurriedly and his abrupt departure for NewYork are much commented on in yachting circles and are attributed to a rupture between Mr. Caldwell H. Colt and himself.

William E. Fletcher was yesterday made Custodian of the Produce Exchange, a new office, at a salary of $3,000 per year. The appointment is considered in the line of promotion, of which the Exchange considers Mr. Fletcher in every way worthy.

"The Gentlemanly Savage" may be a great go. There were no indications to the contrary last night for a large audience that was rather cold in the beginning sat contentedly to the end, and there was more applause for the last act than for the first.
John W. Bookwalter, of Ohio, is at the Albemarle Hotel. Clayton McMichael, of Philadelphia, is at the Hotel Normandie.

A year ago yesterday the Grant Monument Association held its first meeting under its charter and effected an organization. Although seven members constitute a quorum, not enough have attended a meeting until yesterday to transact business, nor has a quorum of the Executive Committee met until last week.

Judge Ingraham yesterday issued a mandamus commanding the Musical Mutual Union to restore Matthias Merscheim to his membership.
The only up-town office of THE TIMES is at 1,269 Broadway, between Thirty-first and Thirty-second streets.

There is the strongest reason--so strong as to be almost final--that the girl murdered at Rahway a week ago to-night was Mary Creney, of Fairport, a little village on the New-York Central Road 10 miles this side of Rochester.

ST. LOUIS, March 31.--The remains of exGov. Thomas C. Reynolds, who committed suicide Wednesday afternoon, were conveyed from Scott Lynch's undertaking establishment this afternoon to the residence of Edward Cunningham, 3,500 Laclede-avenue.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 31.--This afternoon, from 2 to 6 o'clock, the Committee on Railroads had a hearing upon the resolution directing them, among other things, to examine the manner in and the purpose for which the sinking fund of the Consolidated Road had been created.

A meeting was held yesterday morning at the parlors of the Woman's National Christian Temperance Union, 3 East Fourteenth-street, to discuss the attitude of the New-York Legislature on the temperance question.
The employes of the Brooklyn City Road are again complaining of the treatment received at the hands of President Lewis, and many predict that a strike will be ordered.

The Getty House, the principal hotel of Yonkers, was sold yesterday afternoon by Charles E. Warring to Franz Blatzhein, a Yonkers baker, for $125,000. William H. Doty will remain proprietor of the hotel.

EL PASO, Texas, March 31.--Quarantine was instituted here to-day against cholera. The State has been under paper quarantine since Feb. 7, but the proclamation has not heretofore been enforced at this point.
Some of the railroad managers are radiant. A fight which was threatened against some of their arbitrary plans is going to be avoided, so they believe.

Commander Chadwick was at the navy yard yesterday, inspecting the place selected for the building of the new 6,000-ton cruiser. He was favorably impressed with the location. "Bill" Furey was also around laying plans in ...

BERLIN, March 31.--Russian advices state that the execution of the persons actually concerned in the recent attempt upon the Czar's life has been postponed in the hope of obtaining further disclosures from them regarding the plot.

James G. Brevarde, who for the last four years has been one of the principal dancers of Mr. Harrigan's Park Theatre company, died of consumption at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday morning. He was a remarkably good dancer, had appeared successfully in minor parts, and was universally popular in the company. He will be buried from the Church of the Transfiguration on Sunday, the Actors' Fund taking charge of the funeral arrangements.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 31.--Dr. Lewis Swift, Director of the Warner Observatory, announces the renewal by H.H. Warner, of this city, of the Warner comet prize of $100 for each unexpected comet discovered by any one anywhere in the world during the year ending March 31, 1888. The comet of 1815 is expected, as it is reported to be due this year. About $5,000 in money and medals has been awarded under this prize since 1880.

Jacob H. Clare, of Pocahontas, Va., is 26 years old, robust, and ambitious. He tired of farming in 1886, and went to Charlestown, West Va., where he joined the staff of the Eureka Detective Agency. NEW-ORLEANS, March 31.--Charles de Lesseps, eldest son of the French engineer, Count Ferdinand de Lesseps, is staying here on his way from Colon to Havre. He has just passed five weeks along the works on the Isthmus of Panama, and says that everything is progressing finely.
There was a meeting at the rooms of the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday of men who are opposed to the construction of the Poughkeepsie bridge.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 31.--Exchange--NewYork sight drafts, 20; telegraphic, 25.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 31.--A forest fire which originated from a spark from a locomotive on the Camden and Atlantic Railroad yesterday afternoon destroyed about 300 acres of young timber, burning a tract of wood two miles long.

Prof. T.B. Price lectured yesterday afternoon on "Shakespeare in Shakespeare" at Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, under the auspices of the Shakespeare Society of the college. His main theme was the method to be pursued in studying Shakespeare, saying that thereby the foundation of the knowledge of the man could be laid.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 31.--H.C. McDowell, of Lexington, had sold the b.c. Alma Tadema, 2 years, by Dictator, dam Elfrida, by Harrold, to Charles M. Reed, of Erie, Penn., for $4,000; also to J.W. Gaulbert, of Louisville, Ky., the b.f. Cordova, 2 years, by King Rene, dam Carita, by Dictator, for $1,000.

The North German Lloyd steamship Elbe, which arrived yesterday from Bremen, sighted the disabled steamship Salerno on March 27, in latitude 41 28' and longitude 51 23'. She was heading to the eastward under sail, and showed her letters, S.Q.W.B.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 31.--The Republicans to-day nominated William M. Bayne for Mayor and a full city ticket. Mayor Gardner was defeated for renomination.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., March 31.--Henry L. Stimson, of New-York City, won the Yale College junior exhibition prize, at the contest in the Battell Chapel this afternoon. His subject was "Beranger and France."

The mean temperature of March just closed was colder by the sum of 74.6 than the average mean temperature of the month for 15 years.

BOSTON, March 31.--At a little past 2 o'clock this afternoon the rising of the curtain at the Boston Museum disclosed a drawing room scene, and through the opening at the rear appeared a conservatory.

WELLAND, Ontario, March 31.--The third trial of the case of the United States Express Company against "Clutch" Donohue, who is serving a sevenyear term for burglaries committed in Canada has been decided in Donohue's favor.

CHICAGO, March 31.--Judge Gresham today received from Judge Cooley his resignation as Receiver of the Wabash system, to take effect to-morrow. No action was taken toward the appointment of a successor, as Judge Gresham received a request from Gen. Swayne and others not to act at once.

WASHINGTON, March 31.--Major Joseph W. Wham, Paymaster, has been ordered to West Point. The leave of absence of First Lieut. William Crozier has been extended to Nov. 1, 1887, with permission to go abroad.
ALBANY, March 31.--The mania for taxing everything which has moneyed interests at stake has taken the form of numerous bills in this Legislature.

CHICAGO, March 31.--The indications are that next Tuesday Chicago will present the remarkable spectacle of a city which for eight years has been governed by the Democrats in the throes of a municipal election with no general Democratic ticket in the field.

The hare and hounds clubs will be busy to-day. Besides the runs of the New-York Hare and Hounds Club, the Crescent Athletics, and the Eureka Hare and Hounds will have runs, starting from their clubhouses in Brooklyn.

BOSCOBEL, Wis., April 1.--Postmaster Pepper was arrested this morning by the United States Marshal on a charge of misappropriating funds of the Government to the amount of $400. In default of bonds for his appearnce in court he was taken to Madison to await trial.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 1.--John W. Smith, the murderer of Bonner Barker, was resentenced at Franklin, on Monday, to be hanged on May 27. He shot Barker dead while his victim's wife was clinging to his knees begging him to desist.

BOSTON, April 1.--There has been something of a riot in the ranks of the Boston Museum Company, and Mr. Vanderpelt, the leading man, has gone forth avowing that never again will he darken the Museum doors with his presence. He has relented, however, so far as to consent to appear at Wilson's benefit to-morrow ...

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 1.--Last night while Assistant General Manager Kruitschnitt and party were traveling over the Southern Pacific Railway on a tour of inspection, the special train which carried them was ditched east of this city.

The trial of John Lamb for the murder of James Conlin was concluded on Thursday in the Court of General Sessions, Part I. The jury failed to agree that night and was locked up until yesterday morning, when it brought in a, verdict of guilty of manslaughter in the first degree, with a recommendation to mercy. Judge Gildersleeve sent Lamb to prison for four years.

The decennial dinner of the Class of '77 of the College of the City of New-York was held last evening at the Hotel Brunswick. A special feature of the dinner was the presence of the entire Faculty of the College. President Alexander S. Webb responded to the toast.

Dampness came to earth yesterday in a shape that well fitted the 1st of April, for no one was positive whether it was snow or rain. It fell alike on the Polo Grounds and the rest of the city, but at the Polo Grounds it was particularly disheartening.
At last the Academy has seen the wisdom of limiting to half a hundred the paintings and statuary of the Spring exhibition, and the result justifies the step.

LONDON, April 1.--The Leicester Spring meeting began to-day. The race for the Excelsior Breeders' Foal Stakes of 1,000 sovereigns, for 2-year-olds, was won by Mr. Craven's b.c. Barleythorpe by six lengths, Baron de Rothschild's bay filly by Robert ...

READING, Penn., April 1.--Charles, a 3-year old son of William R. Lord, died to-day from the effects of drinking atropine yesterday. It was moving day, and the child, left alone in a room, climbed to the top of the bureau, where it caught sight of the vial containing the poison. There had been a half teaspoonful in the bottle, all of which the child drank.

Albert Frey won the pool match with James L. Malone last night in Daly's billiard rooms In Brooklyn. He won the requisite 80 games, while Malone got only 40. When the evening's play began Frey had 64 games and Malone 35.

ST. LOUIS, April 1.--The Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway was changed to-day into the Wabash Western Railway and passed into the control of the Wabash Purchasing Committee, under the order of the United States Circuit Court.

CHICAGO, April 1.--Some interest was taken yesterday at the County Clerk's office in a man who took out a license to marry "Theo" Kries, whom he represented for some unknown reason to be "Theo" the celebrated French actress now playing in Paris. He gave his name as Herbert Charter, and said he was an actor in her company.

Mr. Charles Reed, who was the gentlemanly but irrelevant "bones" at Dockstader's for a time during the Winter, will be Robin Oakapple in Mr. Stetson's production of "Ruddigore" at the Globe Theatre, Boston, next Monday.

James McCreery Co., of Broadway and Eleventh-street, have no formal "opening day," but announce when their Spring importations are ready, and the best class of shoppers come without any further urging. Yesterday the weather was unfavorable, but there was a goodly assemblage of ladies who came to buy.

ROME, April 1.--Further earthquake shocks have been felt at Savona. Prof. Falb has gone to study the phenomena on the spot.

Gossips on the north side of Long Island were busy yesterday discussing the disappearance of Joseph Monfort, who was to have been married on Thursday to Mrs. Anna Jones, a widow, at Port Washington. The wedding was to have taken place in the Methodist church.

New-York has been alive with Railroad Presidents and railroad managers during the last week. Mr. Oliver Iselin has already arranged a match for his new yacht, the Titania, which will be launched in May and which was designed to defend the America's Cup in case the size of the Thistle should place her in the second class.

The Grand Jury for March ended its term yesterday by handing in to Judge Gildersleeve, is Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, a long presentment touching upon the condition and management of various institutions which the jury had been inspecting during the past month.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 1.--W.U. Hensel, well known as a prominent Journalist in this city, and as Chariman of the Democratic State Committee of Pennsylvania for several years, has formed a law partnership with J. Hay Brown, under the firm name of Brown Hensel.
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 1.--The Central Railroad system has been thoroughly reorganized. The line from Atlanta to Savannah will hereafter be known as the Main Stem Division.

After the strikes alongshore were settled and the police reserves were withdrawn Capt. Gastlin obtained a short leave of absence to recruit his health, which had been somewhat impaired by his incessant work.

A citizen from whom he had solicited alms brought Charles Albrecht, a lad 12 years old, to the Twentieth Precinct Station House Thursday evening. The lad has hungry and cold, his clothing was in rags, and his appearance indicated that he had been living on short rations.
A dispatch from El Paso, on the Texas border, contains a statement which, if it be true, is of great importance to the people of the United States.

The theory that the girl found murdered at Rahway seven days ago was Mary Craney, a Brooklyn servant girl, met the fate yesterday which has befallen so many of its predecessors. Two sober business men and positively identified the body as that of Mary Craney.

PITTSBURG, April 1.--The Americus Club, the foremost Republican organization of this city, will celebrate Gen. Grant's birthday, April 27, with a banquet. A large number of prominent Republicans have been invited. Among those who have promised to be present are the Hon. Roscoe Conkling, of NewYork, and Gov. Foraker, of Ohio.

BOSTON, April 1.--Before the Railroad Commissioners to-day, in the investigatinn into the railway bridge disaster at Roslindale, Prof. George F. Swain, of the Institute of Technology, civil engineer, testified that he had made a special study of bridges and bridge manufacture.
State Senator John Raines is at the Morton House. Sir C.A. Fairlie Cunninghame, of England, is of the Gilsey House.

TROY, N.Y., April 1.--Pleuro-pneumonia has broken out in Guy Darrow's herd of cattle at Hebron, Washington County. The infection came from Western calves Darrow bought in New-York last Fall. He will kill his entire herd to-day.
Two plays, a three-act comedy and a oneact farce, were presented at the Thalia Theatre last evening, and each proved attractive. The comedy was Benedix's "Der Vedder," or "The Cousin."

Commissioner Coleman wrote to President Bayles on Thursday that he had made arrangements to remove ashes and garbage by night in the Nineteenth Precinct, beginning at midnight April 1 and continuing until all are collected, or 7 A.M. He asked the co-operation of the sanitary officers.

In a way that was sometimes suave and bland, sometimes vigorous, but always earnest, the dry goods merchants yesterday talked about the troubles of their committee which was to do battle with the railroads, and which met only to disagree.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1.--J. Edgar Holl, the wholesale liquor dealer who is accused of defrauding the Independence National Bank by means of false acceptances, surrendered himself to a detective to-day.

More inter-State rate catalogues were yesterday added to those hung up in the ticket offices of the Pennsylvania Railroad. The assortment now consists of about 200 pages of names of stations and columns of figures. Very few purchasers of tickets seemed to care about trying to read over tho schedules.

Seeburger, Collector of the Port of Chicago, charging him with violation of the civil service law. The league charges Collector Seeburger with peremptorily demanding the resignation of George A. The only up-town office of THE TIMES is at 1,269 Broadway, between Thirty-first and Thirty-second streets.

ST. LOUIS, April 1.--The stove molders' strike will, within the next four days, spread to all the leading stove manufacturing centres in the United States. After three years of sensational litigation the Supreme Court has granted Edith Allen an absolute divorce from Col. Vanderbilt Allen on the ground that he has been guilty of marital infidelity.
Mistress Sarah Bernhardt was in fine humor yesterday. With her affection for the odd and unique she discovered a desire to see and hear Marshall P. Wilder, the humorist whom all New-Yorkes applaud.

WASHINGTON, April 1.--At noon to-day plans were opened in the office of the Secretary of the Navy for an armored cruiser and a powerful battle ship under authority conferred by the act of Aug. 3, 1886.

An indiscriminate slaughter of young calves from one hour to three days old and shipped to New-York, where they are put up as canned chicken, is being carried on quite extensively in this and Herkimer County, says the Utica Press.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., April 1.--The scohooner Silver Heels, of Tremont, Me., from New York for this port with grain, is ashore on West Chop. She lies easy and will probably float without damage.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 1.--Events are slowly justifying the official course of Auditor Brown, of impeachment memory. One of his acts was to require the Monarch Insurance Company to increase its assets. It was done, and the company was duly certified.

The Police Commissioners yesterday took cognizance of a resolution passed by the Manhattan Temperance Union on Sunday, which contained the statement that "the plea of the Police Commissioners repeated by the Mayor-- that it is impossible to enforce the laws against the opening of drink dens on Sunday--is either false or a confession of official dereliction."

Enough circumstantial evidence appeared yesterday in connection with the reported disappearance of the wife of Charles T. Watson to give a very different turn to his case. Watson's story excited a good deal of sympathy so long as he confined his woes to a limited circle.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 1.--When the InterState bill came up in Congress the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce was the first to telegraph a demand for its passage. Now that it is in force the same body is the first to object. Rates on many articles to the South are doubled.

Considering the manner in which Mayor HEWITT was elected, it is perhaps not to be wondered at that the professional tax eaters around the City Hall should be in advance dividing the spoil of the offices in which the terms of the present incumbents are shortly to expire.

The stock company to be associated with the Lyceum Theatre next Autumn and Winter under the management of Mr. Daniel Frohman is now practically completed, as only a few engagements of actors to fill comparatively unimportant parts are to be made hereafter.

The business meeting of Plymouth Church congregation was largely attended last evening. Cornelius S. Van Wagoner presided, and when Thomas G. Shearman advised the restive ones not to think of going because some very important business was to be transacted the meeting settled into a state of somewhate excited suspense.

Wallace Ross, the oarsman, visited the Sporting Times office yesterday and issued a challenge on behalf of himself and Georve W. Lee to row George Hosmer and John McKay, the Boston scullers, a series of races.

The two young shoplifters, William Foeller and John Williams, who were arrested Wednesday for stealing wearing apparel from clothing stores in this city, were brought before Justice Duffy, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday. They look alike and wear clothes of fashionable cut, exactly alike.

CHICAGO, April 1.--Extraordinary efforts have been made lately by the various roads running east from this city to secure all the freight they could before the inter-State commerce law goes into effect, when at least some of them may not be able to take through freight at such low rates as have prevailed during the last few weeks.

Henry Lestrange was recently alloyed to plead guilty to manslaughter in the first degree for the killing of William Walker last Winter in a Hester-street saloon. Yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part II., Recorder Smyth sent Lestrange to State prison for 14 years and 5 months.

The best tonic in the world for a town perhaps is not an earthquake; yet neither is an earthquake always the extingusiher that tradition has generally represented it. Charleston, as live and energetic and hopeful to-day as ever she was, testifies to this.

The ship Canara. Capt. Dexter, lying in the East River at the foot of Baltic-street, Brooklyn, was the scene of a tragedy at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, which resulted in the death of Mrs. Ida Wade, the stewardess.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, April 1.--A dispatch from Moncton to-day contains news of the stalled trains on the northern division of the Intercolonial Railway.

LONDON, April 1.--In the Mincing-lane market beet sugar is active and firmer; came is steady; refined has an upward tendency. Prices of coffee are firm to hardening; there is sharp competition: Ceylon is dearer. China tea is dull; Indian is firm; Ceylon is advancing. White Singapore pepper is firm; black is unchanged.

BERLIN, April 1.--Advices received from St. Petersburg fully confirm the report that another attempt has been made upon the life of the Czar. It is learned that on Tuesday, while the Czar was exercising in the park connected with the Gatschina Palace, he was fired upon by an officer of the army, the ball passing close to his person. The officer was immediately seized by attendants and imprisoned.

Agnes Folsom, the willful young lady who abandoned the pink ballroom in "Erminie" for apartments in West Fifty-eighth-street, and chose Dr. Cate instead of a gorgeous lover in theatrical panoply, sat by the window in exJudge Samuel Jone's office, at 291 Broadway, yesterday afternoon, looking blue.

NYACK, April 1.--The Hesdra will case was on again to-day before Surrogate George Weiant. The testimony was in the line of that given two weeks ago to attempt to prove the genuineness of the signatures on the document which purports to be the will of the late E.D. Hesdra.

PORTLAND, Me., April 1.--There are doubts about the constitutionality of the new liquor law. The Constitution provides that all penalties and punishments shall be proportioned to the offense, and that excessive fines shall not be imposed or cruel or unusual punishments inflicted. Under this act a single sale of a glass of simple new cider as a beverage would subject the seller not only to a heavy fine, but to imprisonment.

The public rehearsal prefatory to the sixth and last concert to be given by the Philharmonic Society this season took place at the Academy of Music in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. The music performed made up what is known as a "request programme," from which it may be inferred that it was popular rather than propound.

THE TIMES presents its compliments to the 700 lawyers who have petitioned the Senate against the Civil Code, and courteously invites them to show cause why any particular attention should be paid to their wishes.

ALBANY, April 1.--Since his arrival here yesterday morning Charles S. Leake, the National Express messenger who was robbed near Utica on Wednesday night, has maintained a singular silence about his exciting adventure.

BALTIMORE, April 1.--The Baltimore and Ohio Telegraph Company has signed a contract with the French Cable Company for an exclusive interchange of business. It does not abrogate the relations between the Baltimore and Ohio and the Mackay Commercial Cable.

Prof. Rodolfo Lanciani, Director of Excavations for the city and province of Rome, lectured yesterday under the auspices of the Archaeological Institute of America at the Madison-Square Theatre on "The Theatres and Circuses and the Police Regulations of Rome," describing in detail their organization and management.

HELENA, Montana, April 1.--Chief-Justice Waite to-day rendered a decision in the case of Montana Territory against Rhodes, a commercial traveler recently arrested for selling goods without paying a Territorial license.
BUFFALO, N.Y., April 1.--John B. Sackett, the new Postmaster at Buffalo, took possession of the office today. He appointed Eugene Bertrand, Jr., deputy.

The loyal sons of Cornell University, brimming over with recollections of former happy days, met last night at Delmonico's. There, under the inspiring influence of gastronomy properly understood, they became once again a set of jolly good fellows, over whose heads time seemed to have passed lightly.

Col. Robert G. Ingersoll was admitted yesterday to the Bar of this State. The ceremony took place in the General Term of the Supreme Court. Mr. Ingersoll declined to take the usual oath and was allowed to affirm. Col. Ingersoll has hitherto been allowed to practice here by favor of the courts. Now he is a member of the New-York Bar in good and regular standing.

SAN AUGUSTINE, Texas, April 1.--A terrible fight occurred this morning 10 miles below Hemp. hill, in Sabine County, between Capt. Scott and his little company of State Rangers on the one side and old Willis Conner and his sons on the other.
DETROIT, Mich., April 1.--The most hopeful town in the State of Michigan just now is Sault Ste. Marie. Two great railroad systems are about to cross the international boundary there.
FAIRFIELD, Ill., April 1.--There was argued before the Circuit Court this week a quo warranto proceeding against the Ohio and Mississippi Railway to dissolve the corporation.

To-morrow the Barnum and Forepaugh shows will begin the performances of the grand Roman hippodrome in Madison-Square Garden in addition to the regular acts of the circus.

Mme. Adelina Patti returned yesterday morning to New-York after a long tour through Mexico, California, and the Western States. Her trip was marked by success, adventure, and pleasure. She returns in good health, high spirits, and with pleasant words for the people she met and the places she saw.

SEATTLE, Washington Territory, April 2. --The Pacific coast steamer Mexico, plying between San Francisco and Puget Sound, was wrecked Thursday night four miles south of Plumper's Pass, Vancouver Island. All hands were saved. The loss on the vessel is $150,000. The loss on the cargo is not yet known.
It leaked out yesterday that several prisoners in the Kings County Penitentiary had been concerned in a bold attempt to escape Thursday last.

The late Bishop Fraser kept his private accounts in a very methodical way, and it appears that during the time he occupied the See of Manchester his charitable expenditures amounted to 31,536, which was considerably more than half the amount he received as stipend, and, until the Bishop's marriage, his private means were very limited.
PARIS, April 2.--Leconte de Lisle, who was publicly received on Thursday by the Academy, is one of the most notable singularities among French literary men.
CICINNATI, Ohio, April 2.--J.S. Burdsal Co., wholesale druggists, 14 East Fourth-street, assigned this afternoon to B.H. Cox. Liabilities, $35,000; assets, $20,000.
Rahway's murder mystery is nine days old now. Wide and deep it remains as on the Saturday morning when the dead girl was found by the roadside.

Giovanni Romero, one of the Scotia's immigrant passengers, found his way to the Tombs yesterday in search of justice. He said that Nicolo Fluero, of 140 Mulberry-street, told him that he would get work for him for $2.

BALTIMORE, April 2.--William M. Clements, of the Erie, who has been appointed General Managers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, vice Dunham, resigned, was formerly Master of Transportation of the Baltimore and Ohio and resigned because he could not agree with Mrs. Dunham, his superior.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 2.--The Journal de St. Petersbourg says the Ameer of Afghanistan has no grounds for proclaiming a holy war against Russia, and cites the resumption of negotiations at St. Petersburg for the delimitation of the Russo-Afghan frontier as showing that the Ameer's fears are goundless.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 2.--The preliminary baseball season was inaugurated to-day by a onesided game between the Pittsburgs and the Buffalo Club, of the International League. The day was bright and cool, but notwithstanding the chilly atmosphere fully 4,000 people were attracted to the grounds, and very few left before the game was ended.

The City of New-York, which came to her dock on Monday night at a late hour, brings advices from the Hawaiian Islands, from which it is ascertained that the eruption of Mauna Loa has almost entirely ceased, although steam is still issuing from fissures along the mountain side, showing that the great internal fires are still smoldering.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 2.--Phill Armour, the Chicago packer and speculator, applied to-day for free transportation over the Big Four Railroad from this city to Chicago for a corpse and one person attending it. CINCINNATI, April 2.--Steamboat men since the passage of the inter-State commerce law have anticipated that they would be much benefited by the new order of things. Preparations have been made for doing an increased business, and it has been considered certain that better rates could be commanded.

MORGAN, Texas, April 2.--News has reached here of a very destructive fire in the Cedar Brakes, on the Brazos River. 10 miles east of here. CHICAGO, April 2.--It was decided late this afternoon to begin the trials of the counts boodlers on Wednesday, April 13. Warden McGarigle's case will be called first, and in order to finish the cases as fast as possible both branches of the Criminal Court will be kept running. Judge Tuley will preside when McGarigle's case is called, and the other court will be run by Judge Shepard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 2.--The second exhibition game between the Indianapolis League and the Cincinnati Association Clubs was witnessed by nearly 3,000 people. The game was not by any means a contest of pitchers, both clubs batting strongly and effectively.

PATERSON, N.J., April 2.--Ernest Krause, a German silk weaver, has been living happily with his wife, Caroline, at 30 Lawrence-street. Last night and to-day Mrs. Krause was very ill, and suffered so excruciatingly that she implored her husband to end her anguish by poison or the pistol. He hired a woman to attend her, and this afternoon, worn out with long watching, he lay down to rest.
The French Consul has received a detailed report of the stranding of the steamship Scotia from Capt. Ruffat. It was stated at the French Consulate yesterday that the report would not be made public.

MALDEN, Mass., April 3.--The stables and car house of the Boston Consolidated Street Railroad Company were burned this morning, together with 50 horses, 40 tons of hay, 43 sets of harness, and some rolling stock. The fire originated from the bursting of a kerosene lamp. The total loss is estimated at about $15,000; insurance, $9,000.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 4.--The Spring election for town and city officers was held to-day. The Republicans also elected the Board of Selectmen, and Charles Wilmot, Town Clerk. The Democrats elected the City Clerk. Very little interest was taken in the election and a light vote was cast.

The official investigation into the death of Mrs. Ida Wade, the stewardess of the ship Canara, who was found with a bullet in her brain on Thursday morning and who died in the Long Island College Hospital, was held last night by Coroner Rooney, of Brooklyn.

BANGOR, Me., April 4.--A company has been formed here which will put on a line of freight propellors between here and New-York. It will be called the Penobscot Steam Navigation Company, and has a large capital. Frank K. Clergue is President and Charles E. Field, Treasurer. The men connected with the company are prominent business men.

After the lawyers had had their wonted dispute about the relevancy of testimony and the method of taking it, yesterday, in the McMahonFlynn subway suit ex-Senator T.C.E. Ecclesine, the counsel for Mr. McMahon, took the witness chair.

The opening at E. Ridley Sons' big stores on Grand-street to-day, to-morrow, and Thursday promises to be even more interesting than usual. Carpenters and painters were hard at work yesterday and chaos reigned.

Williams, (of London,) Smith, Bristol 84 ds., with iron and empty barrels to order--vessel to J.E. Brett.

The Inter-State Commerce act goes into effect to-day. Already several important applications have been made to the commission, and it will be compelled at the outset to settle some of the most difficult questions arising under the provisions of the law.

Hyman Hafft, who was arrested about a week ago for violating the factory law of 1886, was tried in Special Sessions yesterday and the complaint was dismissed. James Connelly, State Inspector of Factories, was the prosecutor.
Senator GORMAN, of Maryland, denies that there is anything wrong in Maryland politics, and specially protests that the Federal appointments in that State have been of the proper sort.

CHICAGO, April 4.--Jacob Schaefer played the most remarkable game of billiards ever seen in a match at Central Music Hall to-night, and George Slosson made the biggest average ever made in 500 points cushion carroms and won the game.

DETROIT, Mich., April 4.--A heavy snow storm prevailed throughout the entire northern part of the State to-day and nothing of consequence had been heard from that region up to midnight. Returns from the central and southern parts of the State ...
MONTEREY, Cal., April 4.--The site where lately stood the Hotel del Monte was surrounded yesterday with a crowd of people who gazed sadly at the wreck.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 4.--Local Assembly No. 84 of the Knights of Labor has formed a co-operative association of its members for the purchase and sale of coal and other fuel, and will lease or purchase a site for an extensive yard.

If Gov. HILL were to decide according to the weight of argument or on its merit the question of high license, to whose advocates and opponents he gave a hearing yesterday, he would be constrained to sign the Crosby bill.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 4.--Capt. John Grant died this morning at his home in this city in his ninety-first year. He was one of the most remarkable men in the South. He was born in Chester, Penn., in 1796, and went to school only three weeks in his life.

CINCINNATI, April 4.--The Labor candidate for Mayor has received at to-day's election a plurality of 10 over the Republican candidate and a plurality of 6,000 over the Democratic candidate. The Republicans have elected their entire ticket with the exception of Mayor.

LONDON, April 4.--The Right Hon. W.H. Smith, First Lord of the Treasure, replying to a question in the House of Commons this afternoon said that under the proposed Irish Crimes bill one of the two magistrates exercising summary jurisdiction must have sufficient knowledge of the law.

To-day may bring an important change in the manner of conducting the sale of tickets to the West in Castle Garden. The New-York, Ontario and Western Road is understood to have given notice that it will stop selling its tickets through the joint agency at the Garden.

The work performed on Saturday evening was Flotow's "Marta," an opera which many people having a reputation for connoisseurship to keep up affect to despise and everybody listens to with more or less of pleasure.

Louis M.J. Valinquet, wholesale dealer in boots and shoes at 133 Duane-street, made an assignment yesterday to John E. Hedges, giving preferences for $9,250. He has been in business here about five years, and was previously at Boston. He Claimed a capital of $10,000, and controlled a good trade.

Francis Gerry Fairfield, a newspaper writer for 20 years, died yesterday morning at the Southern Boarding House, at Forty-secondstreet and Third-avenue. He was taken there on Wednesday last, when very ill.

Mr. Frederic Bryton was cordially welcomed at the Grand Opera House last evening, where he appeared in Mr. Clay Greene's pictaresque play "Forgiven," which has already been seen at several city theatres. Mr. Bryton was suffering from hoarseness, but managed nevertheless to act his part so well as to win hearty applause, as he will all this week.

Secretary John H. Bird, of the New-York Yacht Club; Ernest Staples, and J.T. Howard, who crossed the ocean on the Dauntless in her race with the Coronet, are expected to return by the 20th. Commodore Gerry and his family will sail for home on May 4.

SANDWICH, Mass., April 4.--An unknown large two-masted schooner ran on tha shoals several miles off Cotiut, between Nantucket and Hyannis, during the storm Saturday and sunk, only the mastheads being visible from the shore. A boat was sent to her rescue yesterday afternnon, but the vessel's crew were not found and are supposed to have been lost.
Joseph Monfort, who disappeared on Thursday last, the day he was to have married Mrs. Florence Jones at Port Washington, is believed by his friends to have met with foul play in New-York.

HALIFAX, April 4.--A Shelbourne dispatch says the fitting out of the cruiser Triumph was completed Saturday. This morning she put to sea in the wake of several American vessels which had found shelter in that harbor during the recent storm. The Triumph is the largest sailing cruiser in the Fisheries Protection Service. She carries 1,800 yards of canvas, and sails like a racer.

LONDON, April 4.--A Lahore paper announces that the Ameer of Afghanistan is seriously alarmed by the discovers that a number of native tribes are combining against him, and has appealed to the Indian authorities for help and advice.

The proposition to build a railrold through Montague-street, Brooklyn, from Courtstreet to Wall-Street Ferry, has aroused opposition already, although the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company was organized only a few days ago.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 4.--Gov. Biggs, to-day appointed John Biggs Attorney-General of the State. The appointee is a son of the Governor and has been deputy of the Attorney-General for two years.

The Rev. Dr. Richard Lalor Burtsell, Rector of the Church of the Epiphany, in Secondavenue, near Twenty-first-steet, has been removed from his office of "Defender of the Matrimonial Bond" by Archbishop Corrigan for his presence at the McGlynn meeting Tuesday night last and his published comments on the suspended priest's case two days after.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 4.--Paul Boyton, the swimmer, is to leave Hudson at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning to swim to New-York. He is to be entertained at Rondout and Newburg by amateur oarsmen. He will have no trouble with floating ice, as hardly any is visible for a distance of 50 miles.

ROME, April 4.--The Polyglot Academia in honor of Cardinal Gibbons was held to-day. The exercises opened with a triumphal hymn and chorus specially composed and conducted by the Rev. Francisco Borghi. This was followed by a Latin address from the Rev. Mr. Mooney, of Chicago; a solo by George Lyons, ...

MADRID, April 4.--In consequence of the finding of a case of gunpowder, with a cartridge and fuse attached, in the doorway of his bureau, the President of the Cortes has canceled all cards of admission to the Parliament buildings held by journalists, both foreign and native. The newspaper men are very indignant at this action.

CHICAGO, April 4.--Twenty thousand was the lowest figure placed upon the majority for Mr. Roche and the other Republican nominees for city offices at the Sherman House headquarters to-day. Such leading Democrats as W. C. Goudy, Congressman Lawler, H.F. Murray, Charles Kern, and a score of others dropped in to see Candidate Roche and assure him of their support.

Catharine Lorillard Wolfe died at 6:40 o' clock yesterday morning at her residence 13 Madison-avenue. The end came calmly and peacefully, and she passed away without a struggle. In fact throughout all her long illness from Bright's disease she suffered very little. She was in her fifty-ninth year.

There was a story yesterday that the failure of Register Slevin to get out searches as rapidly as wished for by certain lawyers was to be made the subject of investigation and subsequent charges to the Governor.

LONDON, April 4.--The Mark-Lane Express in its review of the British grain trade during the past week says: "English wheat is tending lower in London, and in a number of provincial markets there has been 6d. to 1s. decline. The feeling of the trade is one of extreme depression.
BOSTON, April 4.--John Stetson's Ruddigore company gave the first rendition in Boston of Gilbert and Sullivan's latest production at the Globe Theatre to-night.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 4.--In the Criminal Court this morning Judge Irvin specially charged the Grand Jury respecting the tally sheet forgeries committed last November, and by which the Judge was counted out of his office.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 4.--Reports from the Upper Hudson to-night show that all the ice north to within seven miles of Albany is broken up and moving with the tide except a piece between Schodack and Castleton, and without doubt that will move before morning.

After the election for Justice of the Peace in Gravesend to-day the citizens of that town will hold their annual meeting, and some fun is expected. MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 4.--Nine persons were seriously poisoned by eating ice cream yesterday. Police Sergeant Hedrick had invited several friends to the Sunday dinner. The dessert consisted principally of ice cream, which Mrs. Hedrick had made the evening before.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 4.--The Yale University Baseball nine and the Bridgeports of the Eastern League, opened the baseball season here today. It was the first game Yale has played this season, and for this reason it was watched with much interest by the collegians.

Newark's swell society is very much agiitated just now over a disagreemont which has arisen between Mrs. Edward Balbach, wife of one of the city's richest business men, and the Girls' Friendly Society, a charitable organization composed of members of Trinity Church.

CINCINNATI, April 4.--It is current talk here that if the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is secured by the Ives-Staynor syndicate, the Cincinnati Hamilton and Dayton, and the Dayton and Canton Road will be pledged for the deferred payments for Baltimore and Ohio stock.

Colombia, College will celebrate its centenary to-worrow week. The college's royal charter was granted in 1754; April 13, 1787, it was revived and confirmed by the New-York Legislature, and it is this latter event which is to be commemorated.
Louis L. Lorillard is at the Murray Hill Hotel. J.W. Albaugh, of Baltimore, is at the St. James Hotel.

ALBANY, April 4.--Our worthy Governor, who prides himself upon his power to dig pitfalls for others, is himself in a hole at last. He sat in his chair in the Executive Chamber this afternoon and carefully scrutinized the faces of the group of 100 persons who appeared either for or against the Crosby High License bill.

The remains of John Godfrey Saxe, the poet, who died in Albany on Thursday last, were brought to this city yesterday, arriving on the 2:12 train, and were taken to the family lot in Greenwood Cemetery and there buried.

CHICAGO, April 4.--Judge Gresham to-day appointed Gen. John McNutta, of Bloomington, Ill., to be Receiver of the Wabash Railway lines lying east of the Mississippi River. Gen. McNutta is a lawyer.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 4.--Major Barak G. Thomas, of the Dixiana stud farm, lost by death today the chestunt mare Miss Millar, 6 years old, by Craig Millar, dam imp, Malvina, by Scottish Chief. CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 4.--A dispatch from Glen Mary, Tenn., says Theopolius Griffith, a young man recently from Scranton, Penn., was killed yesterday by Joseph Brooks without provocation. Brooks is under guard to prevent lynching.

The Chinese attendants upon the Sabbath school of Calvary Baptist Church gave their teachers a testimonial entertainment at the church in West Fifty-seventh-street last night. Literary and musical exercises in English and Chinese--the performers all Chinamen--were followed by a tasteful collation, which the Mongols, assisted by the young ladies of the church, had spread in the church parlors.

PALESTINE, Texas, April 4.--Col. William H. Martin, the Democratic nominee, was to-day elected to Congress from this (the Second) district to fill the unexpired term of John H. Reagan. A very light vote was polled. The Republicans presented no candidate.

That windy evangel of the "No God, no soap" party--Johann Most--mounted the platform at Cooper Union last evening in the presence of a motley crowd of curiosity impelled strangers, good-natured Germans, beetlebrowed Anarchists, and babbling cranks, numbering in all about 3,000 people.

Frederick and Henry Webber, quarrelsome young shoecutters, of 431 East Fifteenthstreet, had a fight Monday evening in McGovern O'Connor's saloon, 412 East Seventeenthstreet, with a little Englishman, William Welsh, employed by the Metropolitan Publishing Company.

Mme. Maria Lacombe moved her household effects yesterday from 223 West Twentysixth-street to 173 West Twenty-fifth-street. CLEVELAND, April 5.--The Democratic majorities for city officers elected yesterday range from 900 to 4,000. Ten out of 15 Aldermen elected are Democrats, and the Democrats will have a majority of 3 on joint ballot in the Common Council.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 5.--Miss Agnes Folsom, the pretty comic opera singer, whose affairs are just now attracting so much public attention, is very well known in this city.

LONDON, April 5.--The Nottingham Spring Meeting opened to-day. The Nottingham Spring Handicap was won by Mr. Vyner's 3-year-old br.c. Gloriation, with Mrs. J. Chaloner's 4-year-old br.c. Distinian second, and Mr. J. Hammond's 4-year-old b.g. Ripon third. There were nine starters. Gloriation won by a neck, and there was only a head between second and third. The betting was ten to one against Gloriation, and seven to one each against Distinian and Ripon.
PARIS, March 22.--The subject of M. Camille de Saint-Saens's late work, "Proserpine," produced last week at the Opera Comique, in spite of its title, has nothing whatever to do with mythology.

The brig Johanna, with a crew of nine, under charge of Capt. Brands, and loaded with 734 hogsheads and 65 tierces of molasses, left Havana for New-York March 11. March 21 she sprang a leak, and the men labored incessantly at the pumps until March 25, when the vessel was down to the water's edge.

Capt. John Christian, of the brig Curlew, had his cargo and crew on board Saturday ready to sail from Pier 11 East River for a French port in Africa. A United States Deputy Marshal, however, had an attachment in his pocket and proposed to keep the Curlew at her pier until certain debts for repairs, provisions, and other things should be paid or arranged for.
SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 5.--The defense submitted evidence of a very positive character in the Arensdorf trail to-day which is startling if true, and very bold if false.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5.--Two more persons were arrested to-day in connection with the fraudulent land survey cases. They were George W. Baker on one charge of conspiracy and George H. Perrine on six charges of conspiracy and one of perjury. Both are surveyors. Perrine was arrested at Los Angeles, and will be brought here for trial. Reilly and Slack, arrested yesterday, and Baker, have been released in bonds of $2,500 on each charge.

BARRIE, Ontario, April 5.--The mail train from Penetanguishene met with an accident this after noon near Munesig by sand being washed over the roils in a deep cutting. The engine and two freight cars were derailed, but the passenger coaches re mained on the track.

The Archbishop of York, Lord Lytton, Sir Theodore Martin, and many other leading lights of literature, art, and science are to appear on the 23d of April upon the stage of the Lyceum Theatre under the Presidency of Mr. Irving. The cause of their meeting is to devise the means of providing a Jubilee Shakespearean Library in the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre on the banks of the Avon.

Commissioner Donnelly, of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, said last evening that the recent decision of the Supreme Court of the United States, legalizing the taxation of national bank shares, did not surprise him. He expected it, and he was of the opinion that the banks would give up the fight.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 5.--Corrupt pol itics received another blow in the courts to day. Two weeks ago the Reform League gained a big victory in a case of political crookedness in which the Sheriff of this city was involved.

Mrs. Agnes Booth-Schoeffel resumed her part, in "Jim the Penman" last evening, though still suffering from the cold which prevented her from acting on Monday. Mr. W.J. Le Moyne did not appear as Baron Hartfeldt, which he has played acceptably ever since "Jim the Penman" was produced.

The magnificent displays in the windows of the florists form an attractive feature of the popular up-town promenades. The demand for flowers for household and personal decoration is evidently steadily increasing.

DETROIT, April 5.--At a late hour last night the returns began pouring in from all parts of the State and have kept up in a steady stream throughout the day. The facts as briefly telegraphed to THE TIMES last night are fully confirmed, although exact figures are still wanting.

In Yell County, Ark., last week, Mrs. Sarah Dimnitt was riding along the road with her little boy behind her, and in passing a burning tree saw that it was going to fall across the road. DENVER, Col., April 5.--The sixth General Assembly adjourned sine die at 2 o'clock this morning.
