We have from time to time had differences with our neighbor, the New-York Sun. The views entertained by the Sun about the silver dollar, about the protective tariff, about civil service reform, and about the President are unlike our own views, and...
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., April 5.--The city authorities placed two private stables in quarantine to-day having ascertained that cattle had been purchased that were affected with contagious disease.

"On Monday, Nov. 29 last, at 10:15 A. M., I was, pursuant to Mr. Thomas's call, attending a rehearsal of 'The Huguenots.' The second act had been gone through without any other hitch excepting a discussion between Mr. Candidus and Mr. Hauk with regard to the swords.

A trial has just taken place here before the Chief Tribunal in which the late City Governor of Odessa and a number of officials were implicated. The indictment occupied eight hours in reading. The charges of wholesale bribery and peculation which it contained were almost incredible. This trial had been pending about two years.

The question of an elevated railroad in Broadway with the strict limitations that it shall be wholly of steel, even to the crossties, which would thus interfere as little as possible with the light, with the rails laid only on so...
LONDON, April 5.--The second reading of the Irish Crimes Act Amendment bill was formally moved in the House of Commons this afternoon by Mr. Balfour, Chief Secretary for Ireland.
CHICAGO, April 5.--The Socialists got a blow squarely between the eyes in the municipal election to-day, and to-night are seeing stars where they expected to see successful candidates.
RANCH NEAR POWDERVILLE, Custer County, Montana, March 20.--The lay of the land here is peculiar and would at once attract the attention of a man from the Eastern States.
ALEXANDRIA, La., April 5.--An act of incorporation was passed on April 2, filed to-day, and will be recorded tomorrow, of the Alexandria and Texas Railway Company, with the following charter...

A gentleman in this city well known on account of the possession of a fine baritone voice, and who is a member of an east side church choir, was recently boasting of his great capabilities as an eater. He went so far in his estimate of what he could accomplish in the way of stowing away food that a friend who was present jokingly offered to wager that he could not accomplish...

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 5.--Upon a tele graphic order from Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild, the 1,500 mares seized here by the Feder al officials as contraband have been released, the parties being allowed to pay the duty nune pro tune, and the Government declining to prosecute them.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 5.--The only election to-day was for Associate Judge of the Supreme Court. Harlow S. Orton (Dem.) was re-elected without opposition.
BOSTON, April 5.--Robinson Brothers, dealers in boots and shoes, of 120 Pearlstreet, have assigned to C.C. Houghton, of Worcester.

Patrick McNamara, who, during a row in Mescall's saloon in Jersey City on Monday night, Killed John Murray, surrendered to the police yesterday morning. Murray was a peddler known as "Big Jack," and bore an unsavory reputation. He had been arrested at least twice for making brutal assaults upon policemen.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 5.--The committee of the House appointed to investigate the charges that money was being contributed by the private banks of the State for the defeat of the bill creating the office of Bank Examiners, which has twice been defeated in the House this session, held its first meeting to-night.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, April 5.--In connection with the recent failure of the Mari time Bank it has been discovered that bills of exchange which passed between the Stewart firm, Guy, Bevan Co. and the bank were ...

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 5.--The Democrats elected their city; ticket here to-day, with the possible exception of City Attorney, by decisive majorities. The votes are not yet fully counted, but the indications are that Hay (Dem.) gets a majority of about 600. Two years ago the Republicans carried the city.
HUDSON, N.Y., April 5.--Capt. Paul Boy ton, the navigator, started on his swimming voyage at noon to-day. He entered the water at this point and his destination is New-York.
PATERSON, N.J., April 5.--Henry Foster, living at 163 Division-street, shot himself in the mouth this evening with a revolver, the bullet passing up and lodging in the forehead.

DANVILLE, Va., April 5.--There is considerable of a sensation among the colored people here, and some whites also, over the finding of a number of skeletons in a small piece of woods just on the edge of the corporation of North Danville. A large chest, a shoe box, and an iron kettle were ...
ALBANY, April 6.--The propeller Adriatic arrived from New-York this afternoon, the first boat of the season.
Over $60,000 represents the receipts for the advance sales for the Patti opera season at the Metropolitan Opera House which opens on Monday evening.

ERIE, Penn., April 6.--The Evening Herald building took fire this evening, and the progress of the fire was so rapid that the editor and one of the staff had to be taken from the second story by the Fire Department. The flames were controlled, but the damage is fully $2,500. Otto Phister, a fireman, was thrown from a truck, run over, and it is feared, was fatally injured.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 6.--J. Valney Ryan has been pardoned by Gov. Taylor, and released from the penitentiary. Ryan is known as an insurance crook, and successfully operated in this State some years ago. He first made his appearance in Jackson, and soon won the confidence of the most prominent business men.

MANCHESTER, April 6.--The Guardian, in its commercial article, says: "There is a small and well distributed business in some cloth departments, but chiefly for home and minor foreign outlets. The demand for India is almost extinct. Merchants have very few orders and those are mostly at limits hopelessly unworkable. The whole Eastern trade is light, and there is no prospect of a full scale ...

CAPE MAY, N.J., April 6.--The Rev. H. Sterling Watt, Pastor of the Baptist Church of Cape May Court House, died this morning of pneumonia. Mr. Watt had served the church but a few months, and had just settled as its regular Pastor. Eleven days ago he preached the funeral sermon of Mrs. Dr. J.F. Leaming, who had died of pneumonia, and R.M. Crawford, who dug Mrs. Leaming's grave, died of the same disease on Monday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6--The Kissane case has ceased to be a sensation here, the opinion of the best people being that it looks too much like a blackmailing scheme to be worthy of serious attention.
Mayor Hewitt is not yet satisfied that all the places in New-York commonly reputed to be "dives" are in reality conducted on quiet and law-abiding principles.

LITCHFIELD, Ill., April 6.--A political riot was the result to-night of the city election held yesterday. The contest in the First Ward over the Alderman was bitter from the commencement, and the Thorp and Concidine factions were crying for "blood."

In the large lecture hall of the Cooper Institute last night there was a mass meeting of Odd Fellows from lodges in all sections of the city. Past Grand Master James H. Godwin presided, and was supported by Past Grand Patriarch Elias Goodman. Grand Master of the State Edgar Whitlock, and many other prominent Odd Fellows.

The American Society of Civil Engineers talked guns last night at their clubhouse, 127 East Twenty-third-street. All the talk was based on a paper read a month ago by William Metcalf on "Steel; Its Properties and its Uses in Structures and in Heavy Guns." Lieut. W.H. Jaques, of the United States Navy, criticised Mr. Metcalf's advocacy of the Rodman system, and closed in this way:

Benjamin Kerr, a harnessmaker of 156 East Twenty-ninth-street, had Daniel Hayes, of 233 East Seventy-fifth-street, arrested yesterday on a charge of bigamy. Hayes was married May 23, 1877, to Margaret Dolan by the Rev. Thomas McCabe, of St. Patrick's Cathedral, according to the testimony of Margaret, who made an affidavit to that effect in the Yorkville Court.

Louisa De Forest Cock's will was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. She was the wife of Thomas F. Cock. The property held in trust for her under the will of her brother, W.W. De Forest, is broken up into two parts, her husband getting a life interest in half, with a transfer at his death to Mrs. Cock's nephews and nieces.

Dr. C.H. Weissberger, of 744 Sixth-street, reported to Capt. Schultz, at the Union Market police station yesterday morning that he had been called in to attend Bernard Gruenfeld at 90 Pitt-street, and found him suffering from some stomach trouble having many of the symptoms of poisoning. The patient insisted that he had been poisoned by one Philip ...

CLEVELAND, April 6.--A special meeting of the Cleveland and Canton Railway Directorate was held to-day in Canton to ratify the code of regulations, which does not differ from the old code, but the legality of passing on which had been in doubt.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 6.--The opening of the Wilkesbarre and Western Railroad, now in course of construction from Watsontown to Shickshinny, will take place to-morrow as far as Millville, to which point it has been completed.
WASHINGTON, April 6.--Indian Commissioner Atkins has received the following letter from Indian Agent E.C. Osborne at the Ponca, Pawnee and Otoe Agency, Indian Territory, under date of April 2, 1887;

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 6.--In the Haddock case to-day James Junk, Joseph S. Borsch, and others testified as to the reputation of Leavitt and Bismarck. The witnesses were saloon keepers. They pronounced the reputations of both men very bad.

Mr. William J. Le Moyne, whose sudden dismissal from the Madison-Square Theatre company was noticed in yesterday's TIMES, has sued Manager Palmer for $400 damages. Mr. Le Moyne gives the following account: That he made a verbal ...
SAN FRANCISCO, April 6.--Exchange--NewYork sight drafts, 15 cents: telegraphic 20 cents.

ERIE, Penn., April 6.--William Bush, who was to have paid the death penalty to-morrow at Ridgeway, McKean County, for the murder of his brother, Charles Bush, has escaped the halter, and under a commutation to imprisonment for life was to-day taken to the Western Penitentiary at Allegheny. Bush, who was a lumberman, got into a quarrel with his brother...

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 6.--The annual regatta of the Burlington Ice yacht Club was held this morning on a triangular course of five miles, the starting point being at Rockpoint, three times over the course, making a distance of 15 miles. The ice was good, the sky clear, and there was a good breeze from the northwest.

James Slattery, the contractor who gave some pertinent testimony about dumping in Central Park at a previous hearing before the Commissioners of Accounts in the Park Department investigation, was recalled at yesterday's hearing.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 6.--President Dwight, of Yale University, announced to-night that through the generosity of the Hon. Simeon B. Chittenden, of Brooklyn, the erection on the university grounds of a library building would be commenced immediately. It will be placed between the Art School and the present library and will be connected with the latter.

CHICAGO, April 6.--The sensation of today in commercial circles in this city was the revival of recent rumors to the effect that a squeeze on the wheat shorts is being engineered for May. It is said that the two principal firms on the long side have bought an aggregate of ...

ALBANY, April 6.--Assistant Corporation Counsel Scott appeared before the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon and submitted a bill relating to the Subway Commission, upon which Mayor Hewitt is alleged finally to have taken a bold, resolute, even defiant, stand.

The design for a monument to Dr. J. Marion Sims will not be selected until Autumn. That was settled yesterday, when Alexander Doyle, Giovanni Turini, Wilson MacDonald, and Carl Schmidt, sculptors, who had submitted designs to the committee in charge of the monument fund, received letters from Dr. Shrady, ...

Mrs. Adele Musto, a poorly dressed woman, penniless, and carrying a 5-months-old baby in her arms, went to Police Headquarters and asked the aid of the police in looking for her husband, Dominico Musto, who has deserted her. She told Inspector Steers that her husband was an interpreter in the employ of Hugh Allen, a...

Fearing that the Ives pool selling bill might not pass the Legislature and determined no longer to submit to the blackmailing operations of the politicians of Brooklyn, a few gentlemen interested in racing have taken time by the forelock and prepared for the inevitable.

CHICAGO, April 6.--Constable Richardson, of Justice White's court, to-day voluntarily confessed that he had sold for $50 a warrant which he was directed to serve on a gambling house at 70 Adams-street. This confession he made to the Justice. "I was drunk, however, when I did it" he explained, "and intended returning the ...

The funeral of the Rev. Wakeman H. Dikeman, who, when he died, was in his fortyeighth year of service in the Finance Department of the city, were held last evening in the Allen-Street Methodist Episcopal Church. The deceased was a regular licensed preacher of the Methodist Church, and was especially friendly with the clergymen attached to the Allen-street church.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 6.--Last evening, at Wesleyan College, the annual Junior exhibition contests for the Howell and Reed prizes took place. The former prize was won by Roland W. Guss, of Philipsburg, Penn., who spoke on "Lessons from Locksley Hall," and the latter by Harry P. Beattys, of Brooklyn, N.Y., whose...

The suit of John R. Duff, of Boston, against William J. Hutchinson, his broker, for an accounting was continued yesterday in the Supreme Court before Judge Barrett. A fairly large assembly of persons gathered in the court room to listen to the expected revelation of how things were done in Wall-street, but though ...

About four weeks ago a little boy, 5 years old, was taken into Bellevue Hospital. A barber's pole had fallen on the little fellow's head, crushing in the bone. The condition of the little patient was critical in the extreme. He was suffering from severe shock.

WHEELING, West Va., April 6.--Just after eating her breakfast at her suburban home, this morning Mrs. Homer Briggs, wife of a prominent citizen of this county, repaired to her bedroom and cut her throat from ear to ear with a butcher's knife, half severing the head from the body. The cause of her act is unknown.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., April 6.--Hayes Brothers, proprietors of the Daily Globe, of this city, have been missing small sums of money left in the drawer of their establishment over night. Yesterday afternoon A.L. Bowser, a compositor on the paper for over 10 years, and...

A delegate from the Italian Marine has recently visited Baku to study the Russian naptha industry there. His report is most favorable, and the Italian Navy, it is stated, intends to introduce naphtha as a substitute for coal. All seems to be ready for the new kind of fuel, but no large orders can be delivered until the pipe which is to convey the naphtha from Baku to Batoum has been completed.

Messrs. E.B. Bartlett Co. were sum-- moned to appear before the Managers of the Produce Exchange yesterday to answer the charge made by G. Amsinck Co., who claimed that Bartlett mixed a quantity of screenings with the No. 2 wheat which they purchased on or about the 12th of March.

LONDON, April 6.--The great permanent infantry barracks at Aldershot took fire to-day, and burned rapidly. The flames started at noon and were fanned to fury by a gale of such severity as to make the efforts of the firemen to extin-- guish the fire practically useless. Seven-eighths of the barracks were destroyed.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 6.--The American fishing schooner Everitt Steele arrived to-day from the Western Banks in distress, having encountered the recent storm. Her dories were all washed overboard and lost. The Captain wished to purchase new boats here, but the Collector of Customs refused to allow him to do so, as it would be a violation of the treaty.

The Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company earned during the fourth week in March $51,734, an increase of $13,080 over the corresponding period of last year, and during the month, $155,765, an increase of $35,367; Canadian Pacific, fourth week, $273,000, an increase of $24,000; month, $656,000, ...
PARIS, April 6.--M. Rouvier has been elected President of the Budget Committee of the Chamber of Deputies.

The passion of avarice seems to be running riot in connection with the Rahway murder. The positive identifications of the body of the murdered girl are so numerous that they can be accounted for in most of the cases only upon the supposition that it is the $200 reward which is sought and not a desire to clear up the mystery.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., April 6.--The remaining assets of John M. Masterton, late owner of the bankrupt Mount Vernon Bank, consisting of promissory notes of little value, mining stocks, and seenrities of less consequence were sold yesterday at Mount Vernon. The total amount realized by the sale was $12,000, which had been put in among the assets of the bank at over $30,000. The depositors will suffer correspondingly.

Angelo Genorti, the Italian ragpicker who was assaulted with an axe by Pasquale Gilgaro at 171 Thompson-street Tuesday evening, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. The hospital authorities sent a notice to the Coroners' office of the death and requested the immediate attention of a Coroner to the case.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., April 6.--J.W. McGinnis, a clerk in Surveyor General Reicher's office, was arrested yesterday in connection with the fraudulent land survey cases, but was subsequently released on bail in the sum of $2,500.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 6.--Miss Carrie Sharp, of Shelbyville, was accidentally shot and killed at her home last night under peculiarly distressing circumstances. During the evening she was visited by Mr. A.H. Ruth, to whom she was to be married to-morrow morning, and at 11 o'clock Mr. Ruth was preparing to leave ...

The commotion in fire insurance circles, paused the withdrawal of the Williamsburg City Fire Insurance Company from the Metropolitan Association of Fire Underwriters, is akin to the consternation caused among valley residents by the bursting of milldam. In this case the Metropolitan Association was the milldam, and the giving way of the Williamsburg Company has effected its utter ruin.

Mary Ellingsworth, a 19-year-old blonde, of 104 Storm-avenue, Jersey City, figures in a horse whipping incident. She came from Glasgow two years ago and sought her aunt in Brooklyn, but learned from a Long Island Railroad brakemen that she had gone West.

BOSTON, April 6.--The largest fire that has occurred in Boston for many months came shortly after noon to-day, when the building on the corner of Milk and Oliver streets, and running through to Post Office-square, was gutted by the flames.

There are giants in these days, as there were in the days of old. For Several days past Henry Richner, of Vail, Crawford County, Iowa, has been taking in the sights of the city. He is 22 years of age, 7 feet 4 inches in his stockings, and weighs 270 pounds.

ALBANY, April 6.--A gentleman who has had opportunities for observing the inside of legislative life told THE TIMES'S correspondent ten days ago that arrangements had been made to kill the Cullen Telephone bill in the Assembly. The Senators, he said, were, for reasons, quite anxious to get it off their hands.

WHEELING, West Va., April 6.--A cold blooded and deliberate murder occurred on the streets of Parkersburg at about 11 o'clock last night, Taylor Fountaine being instantly killed by Charles Sergeant. Fountaine and Sergeant had had a misunderstanding early in the evening, and were with difficulty kept from settling...
COLUMBUS, April 6.--The result of Monday's election in Ohio still continues to be earnestly discussed by the politicians of both parties.

"It is true that I have left the National Opera Company," said pretty Maria Giuri last evening as she reclined gracefully beneath a mammoth floral horseshoe, in the bend of which was wrought Onore al merito. "I started for San Francisco with them--sono briganti--but only got as far as Albany.

Mr. George I. Seney has followed closely in the footsteps of Mr. Cornelius Vanderbilt in making valuable gifts to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Vanderbilt's contribution was made March 26. Two days later Mr. Seney wrote to S.P. Avery asking him to present for him to the museum 12 pictures, which he hopes will "contribute something to the pleasure and the instruction of the visitors at the museum."
WASHINGTON, April 6.--The Secretary of the Navy to-day invited sealed proposals from the shipbuilders of the United States for building five new war vessels.
ROME, April 6.--The Pope persists that Dr. McGlynn must come to Rome.

In four or five months from date, if the present stated plans of the Metropolitan Transit Company are carried out, an elevated railway will be whistling melodiously up Broadway, and those hundreds of thousands of people who, according to the impressions of the company, are weeping and wailing and tearing their hair for an elevated railroad on Broadway, can mop their eyelids and smile.

President Adams, of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, came to the city yesterday for "an outing," but called on Elijah Smith. In consequence of the call Union Pacific stock took a jump in the market.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 6.--A gang of counterfeiters were brought here to-day from Franklin County. The officials have been watching them for six months and finally pounced down upon two well known and highly respected residents, J.M. and A.M. Peeples. With them was taken William Horn, an old-time counterfeiter. On the premises were found dies, molds, and metal to make a complete outfit, and about $600 of bogus silver money.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 6.--Gov. Ormsbee was notified yesterday that a case of pleuro-pneumonia had been discovered in a car of cattle shipped from Bennington County, and that Vermont cattle have been quarantined. This morning the appointment was announced of a Board of Cattle Commissioners, consisting of Col. John B. Mead, of Randolph; L. A. ...

The season for the Hudson River navigation commences unusually late this year. In fact only twice within the last 20 years has Winter been so tardy in relinquishing the useful river to traffic. It is now comparatively free from ice, with which it has been blocked since early Winter.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 6.--The one prisoner spared by the Yorkville lynchers will not be prosecuted by the State, neither will about 30 others belonging to the same band, but will be released on bail. In alluding to the lynching the News and Courier says:

CHICAGO, April 6.--Two hundred and fifty carpenter contractors, representing fourfifths of all the employers of carpenters in the city, held a meeting this afternoon and agreed to concede some of the demands of the 8,000 striking men, but the compromise was to-night rejected by the carpenters' Executive Committee.
HARRISBURG, Penn., April 6.--The investigation of the reports charging the use of money in the defeat of the Bank Examiners bill was resumed to-night.

At the Board of Education meeting yesterday a letter was received from John W. Fleck, who had been reported by the committee for appointment as Trustee of Ward 14, asking that his name be not considered, as his business consumed all his time, and he was about to go to Europe for three months.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 6.--In the House to-day the usual yearly resolutions were unanimously passed, sympathizing with Ireland in her distress, protesting in the name of humanity against the course of the Tory Government, tendering moral support to Parnell and greeting to the "father of all living statesmen," ...

Thursday as Marion Davis, of Athens, was walking down the street he saw a badge of the Alpha Tau Omega Fraternity on the lapel of Tom Cook's coat. Cook is a black, burly negro, and sported the badge of this prominent and influential fraternity in a most conspicuous manner.

Mr. Wilson Barrett has played his last card--"Clito" was done at the Star Theatre last evening--and we doubt if he takes the trick. The American tour of this capable British actor has been badly mismanaged.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6.--The failure of Henry Bower Son, manufacturing chemists, on Gray's Ferry road, was made public to-day through the entry in Common Pleas Court of judgment notes amounting to $57,794, all of which were confessed.

The railroad war was waged merrily yesterday. Circulars burdened every mail, dispatches were as plenty as letters on ordinary days, and communications passed between the Broadway ticket offices so frequently that the stranger traveling through the thoroughfare lessened his grip on his pocketbook as he made up his mind that he was in a district where nothing but brotherly love prevailed.

Fire was discovered shortly before 7 o'clock yesterday morning in the stock room of the paint shop on the fifth floor of the building 217 to 223 East Forty-third-street, which is owned by the Sebastian Manufacturing Company, and occupied by the company as a cart and wagon factory. Nearly all the workmen employed in the big factory had arrived, but work ...

The Columbia College nine met defeat at the hands of the New-Yorks on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. There were very few spectators, and the wind swept dismally through the empty grand stand. The Columbia boys turned out to about the number of 200 to encourage their players.

PHILADELPHIA, April 6.--Mr. C.F. Gildersleeve, who is a brother-in-law of the gentleman who died on the roadside near Andalusia Station on Thursday morning a week ago, arrived in Bristol this morning a little after 9 o'clock, having traveled all night from his home in Belleville, Ontario.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 6.--Great consternation and excitement prevails among the colored people in Allegheny over an incident which occurred at the Brown African Methodist Episcopal Chapel, corner of Boyle and Hemlock streets, last night.

MILWAUKEE, April 6.--Final returns from the remote towns in the county did not reach the city until this morning. Complete returns show that D.H. Johnson and George H. Noyes, Citizens' candidates for the Circuit and Superior Judgeships, carried the county ...
The funeral services over the remains of Miss Catharine L. Wolfe, which will be held this morning at Grace Church, will be of the simplest description.

RED BANK, N.J., April 6.--Mrs. Helena, Loweree has been granted a divorce from her husband, Francis M. Loweree, by Chancellor Runyon. Mrs. Loweree is a daughter of Henry E.J. Shroder, a retired New-York merchant of wealth, who has resided here over 20 years.

A new scheme was revealed in the Harlem Court yesterday. A young man called on Mrs. George Lester and Mrs. Charles Mackay and sold them five pounds of tea each with a promise of a gift of a set of chinaware with the tea. He went out to bring the china and another young man delivered the tea and collected the money, but the ladies never received the china.

In August, 1885, George W. Ryan, an insurance broker, had a deposit in the Tradesmen's National Bank of this city, which, by mistake in that month, refused payment of six of his checks on the ground that there were no funds in its hands to meet the same.
The efforts of the Compagnie Francaise du Telegraphe de Paris a New-York, better known as the French Cable Company, to disentangle itself from the cable pool took a new direction yesterday.

BALTIMORE, April 6.--A movement is now going on to establish at Curtis Bay an extensive steel pipe works, and a party is here from New-York who asks of Baltimore only one-half of the cost of the plant. It is proposed to make steel guns of heavy calibre without boring. Mr. Robert Garrett is interested in the enteprise, and has offered to take $25,000 of the stock.

The will of William R. Travers was filed and admitted to probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. It was executed Oct. 20, 1886, and witnessed by D.B. Van Emburgh, J.F. Atterbury, and R. Duncan Harris. The Executors are his wife, Mrs. Maria Louisa Travers, and his son, John Travers.

A workman engaged in demolishing the old church at the corner of Lafayette-place and Fourth-street yesterday unearthed an old copper cent that had lain under the foundation of the church for many years, and Frank Seagrist offered him half a dollar for the coin. He had no change, and started across Broadway at Fourth-street with a dollar bill in his hand to ...

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera House Company, held yesterday, was a formal affair, resulting in the re-election of the old Board of Directors, this being its personnel: James A. Roosevelt, George Henry Warren. Luther Kountze, George G. Haven, William K. Vanderbilt, William H. ...

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Capt. J.G. Butler, Ordnance Department, has been ordered from Springfield, Mass., to Colt's firearms manufactory, Connecticut, to inspect Gatling guns now being constructed for the Ordnance Department. Second Lieut. Frank Greene, Signal Corps, has been granted four months' ...

The Grand Jury of Bergen County, N.J., in session at Hackensack, examined yesterday three witnesses in the case of the Rev. Charles W. Ward, of Englewood, who is under bonds on the charge of feloniously assaulting his wife. The witnesses were Col. Jameson, Chief Marshal of Englewood; a servant in Mr. Ward's house, ...

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Several very long and very circumstantial stories have been sent from this city to different newspapers in the country about an alleged rupture between the President and the Secretary of War, growing out of the supposed interference by Mr. Endicott with the details of the office of the SurgeonGeneral of the army.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 6.--George Welsh, who has been for a long time addicted to the too free use of liquors, was found dead on the porch of the Schoonberger Park saloon this morning. The Coroner's jury found that he died from congestion of the brain. He was 45 years old, and leaves a widow and one son.

CLEVELAND, April 6.--One of the most complicated railroad cases ever put on trial was begun to-day in the United States Circuit Court. Judge Gresham, of the circuit which includes Illinois, Indiana, and Wisconsin, met Circuit Judges Jackson and Welker at Cleveland to determine certain questions which arose in the foreclosure of the mortgage of the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railway.

CHICAGO, April 6.--W.W. Irons, James Outland, and W.H. Hamilton, all of Indian apolis, filed a creditor's bill in the United States Circuit Court to-day against M.T. Martin and J. Martin, the Marine, Grain, and Stock Exchange, Carrie E. Martin, C.H. Horton, William Skakel, L.H. Brisbee, and the Union National Bank on ...

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 6.--By a rear collision of freight trains on the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railway, near Bedford, to-day, Conductor Ealy, of New-Albany, and Mrs. Corder, of Guthrie, were fatally injured and Mrs. Noah Pritchett and daughter seriously hurt.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--Mr. Isaac H. Maynard to-day ceased to be Second Controller, and assumed the office of Assistant Secretary of the Treasury. Leaving the little office on the main floor, which he has occupied since he came to Washington, he moved up one flight, to the room vacated a week ago by Mr. Fairchild, and began work with Mr. Brennan, formerly private Secretary to Mr. Manning, as his Secretary.
The elections of the last week must be simply agonizing to the ordinary professional politician.

Henry M. Cormack applied yesterday for a dissolution of partnership and a Receiver for the firm of Latasa Co., importers of iron and iron ore, at 1 Broadway, composed of F. Latasa, Henry M. Cormack, and John S. Dodge.
Some years ago Mr. Hunnewell, in his "The Imperial Island; England's Chronicles in Stone," gave us the architectural details of cathedrals and castles, and his work was as excellent is instructive.

An alarm of fire from the primary school No. 6, at 15 and 17 East Third-street, brought out a number of engines shortly before 10 o'clock yesterday morning, and several firemen rushed into the school room and excitedly inquired of Miss. Cunningham, the Principal, where was the fire.

The Tribune of yesterday states that Mme. Fursch-Madi's agent presented Manager Locke's check at the Second National Bank before banking hours and that this was the reason why no funds were there to meet it. As against this statement is the following letter from Mr. Ruben:

WASHINGTON, April 6.--The Evening Star to-night says: "There have been numerous points of controversy between Second Controller Maynard and Secretary Endicott. The Secretary of War has not in all cases been willing to accept the decisions of the Second Controller, and has tried on several occasions to have them reversed or overruled in some way.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 6.--A dispatch was received to-day at the Merchants' Exchange stating that the bark Eldorado, Capt. Humphrey, from Seattle, March 3, for this port with a cargo of coal, foundered off Cape Flattery and all but two of the crew of 12 men were lost.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, April 6.--The San Antonio and Belknap Rifles have changed their minds regarding their withdrwal from the national drill at Washington next month. The change was occasioned by the following telegram received this afternoon, in response to one sent from here asking if the colored troops would camp and drill with the whites, and if they would be recognized in the appointment of officers of the day:

CHICAGO, April 6.--The leaders of the Labor Party had their hands full to-day trying to explain their defeat after their confident claims of a big majority. On Monday night the Associated Press sent out an interview with the Socialist organizer, Joe Greenhut, who is a city employe in the Health Department, in which Greenhut declared that the Labor ticket would poll 38,000 votes.

A curious meteor appeared in the sky to the northward of this city about 9 o'clock on Saturday night and shed a very vivid light over the face of the country. It seemed like a globe of fire about a foot in diameter and immovable. After glowing with great brilliancy for about a quarter of an hour it gradually paled and disappeared.

The German-American Citizens' Association which is composed of the kickers of the German-American Independent Citizens' Association held a meeting last evening at Steinway Hall and did all it could to make itself heard in public.

MONTEREY, Cal., March 23.--The rains have come and the face of the country is transformed. What a few weeks ago seemed to be barren slopes, arid plains, and inhospitable deserts have put on a new garment that clothes the mountains to their summits, falls down to their feet, and spreads over the valleys in folds of delicate green that deepens day by day.

The feelings of the undergraduates of Columbia College at the failure of the Trustees to provide for any celebration in which the students could have a good time and "paint the town blue and white," were expressed in the anonymous circular distributed by a messenger boy yesterday to the students on their arrival at the college.

WASHINGTON, April 6.--A petition was received by the Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day from John B. Peck, General Manager of the South Carolina Railway Company, for relief from the operations of the fourth section (the long and short haul section) of the inter-State commerce law.

ALBANY, April 6.--The Railroad Commissioners returned the Dalton bill, for the protection of elevated road employes, to the Railroad Committee of the Assembly this afternoon, with the statement that they had repeatedly urged the elevated road managers in NewYork to provide for the safety of their employes by building walks along the tracks.
Henry Adams, of Boston, is at the Brevoort House.

If paterfamilias had been at O'Neill's store, Sixth-avenue and Twentieth-street, yesterday, he might have been tempted to gather together all his available assets and skip to Canada, for his wife and daughters found it hard to escape from the fascinating displays on counter and in showcases without making many purchases.
TRENTON, N.J., April 6.--The Legislature was in session until after midnight last night, emasculating the incidental bill and clearing the calendars, preparatory to final adjournment tomorrow.

The indictments found by a Federal Grand Jury in San Francisco are the result of an inquiry concerning very extensive fraudulent surveys of public lands. Owing to investigations made by Commissioner MCFARLAND during the Administration of President ARTHUR, and by his successor, ...

S.L.M. Barlow presided at the adjourned annual meeting of the Grant Monument Association yesterday afternoon. Others present were Peter A. Cassidy, Alonzo B. Cornell, Frederick Kuehne, William Lummis, Adolph L. Sanger, George C. Magoon, George N. Williams, and Secretary R.T. Greener.
"W.S."--Yon can vote without taking out citizen's papers. The Manhattan Benevolent Association will have its annual ball Monday evening at Adelphi Hall, Broadway and Fifty-second-street.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 6.--The twentyfifth anniversary of the battle of Shiloh and the death of the Confederate Commander Albert Sidney Johnston was selected for the unveiling of the bronze equestrian statue of the latter surmounting the mound in Metarie Cemetery, which constitutes the tomb of the Veteran Benevolent Organization of the Army of Tennessee.

There is sharpness about Mr. Hallowell, hardly the true spirit of the Friend when he takes up the cudgels for "The Pioneer Quakers." The very neat outline in gold on the cover of the book shows temper.

It is very surprising that the bold project for reviving the charter of the Metropolitan Transit Company and authorizing the construction of an elevated railroad in Broadway, with extensions through various other streets, should receive any countenance from the Railroad Committee of the Senate, and yet it is understood that a favorable report is to be made on the pending bill.
BURLINGTON, N.J., April 6.--The Rev. G. Heathcoto Hills has accepted an invitation to be assistant minister of St. James's Church, at Madison-avenue and Seventy-first-street, New-York.

Mrs. Mary Considine, an old pensioned nurse, died yesterday at 349 East Fifty-secondstreet. Mrs. Considine, some 55 years ago, entered the service of Seixas Nathan, a prominent stock broker in his time. Five years later she became nurse in the family of Montague M. Hendricks, a relative of the Nathans. She remained with that family until 18 months ago, ...

Ex-Senator Thomas C.E. Ecclesine was the only witness examined yesterday before Commissioner Shields in the McMahon-Flynn subway suit, and told some of the details of the consummation of the scheme by which William McMahon and Maurice B. Flynn, for himself, and Judge W.H. Kelly, for the Dorsett Company, ...

The trial of the suit of Frain, Smith Co., of Boston, against Charles B. Kendall and John L. Taylor, which began Monday in the Supreme Court before Judge Beach and a jury, will last until the middle of next week. Gen. Francis C. Barlow and Edmund Wetmore are counsel for the plaintiffs, and J.A. Mapes and Anderson Man represent the defendant.
ST. PAUL, Minn., April 6.--The Pioneer Press says this morning: "The natural sequence of an eighteen-cent flour and grain rate from Minneapolis to Chicago developed yesterday.
The Superintendent of Schools in Illinois summarizes as follows his objections to the adoption of uniform test books in the common schools:

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., April 6.--The advent of petticoats in politics has occasioned a social warfare here that dwarfs into insignificance the most bitterly contested issues of the older parties. Leavenworth prides herself on the claim, more or less conceded, that she is the social centre of the State.

Not a great while ago a west side family were discovered in a destitute condition, whose chief subsistence had been the cats and dogs the man of the house could succeed in capturing for slaughter. The family finally went to the almshouse. Probably cats and dogs are oftener eaten by the poor in this country than the public are aware.

PROVIDENCE, April 6.--Midnight.--The election returns are not all in and the city of Providence and four of the larger towns are yet to be heard from. The independent Republicans have achieved an absolute triumph and the Democrats are doing the cheering. Davis, the Democratic nominee for Governor, probably has a majority of 1,000, and as far as can be calculated now.

Messrs. Field, Chapman Fenner, of 364 and 366 Broadway, yesterday sold at auction 2,560 packages of white and printed goods by order of Messrs. Lewis Brothers Co. Merchants have been somewhat late in purchasing Summer goods this year on account of the tardiness of the season.
HARRISBURG, Penn., April 6.--A bill was passed by the Senae to-day providing that the punishment for murder in the first degree may be death by the use of electricity.
A cable dispatch from London informs us that JOSIAH CALDWELL, "railway promoter," has failed, and that his liabilities are supposed to be enormous, inasmuch as he failed once before for 1,000,000.

The integrity of the emigrant pool is now threatened by a new move on the part of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company. This company has been unable hitherto to play any very prominent part in the business of emigrant transportation, being brought by its Western connections directly in competition with roads which themselves claimed a large share of the traffic.

Miss Jennie Baker, the sister of Minnie Baker, or Vancaeyezeele, the young woman whose absence from her home, 320 East Fortysecond-street, since last Thursday has caused so much distress to her parents, called at Police Headquarters yesterday, and informed Sergt.

When William Prout, and ink manufacturer of New-York, died over a year ago he left an estate worth $1,800,000, which he wished divided into equal shares among his relatives. Mrs. Annie F. Barker was entitled to $200,000 as her share. Mrs. Barker had been lost track of for years, and a search was instituted in the hope of finding her.

The railing of the Metropolitan Opera House, weighing some two tons, was removed recently and stored in a shed back of the Charlier Institute. Post McCord, of 102 Broadway, owned the railing, and found, when they went to remove it, that it had been stolen.

LONDON, April 6.--The Council of the Liberal Federation met in London to-day. There were numerous delegates present from the provinces. The President, Sir James Kitson, denounced the policy of the Government as brutal, and said that they here trying to reduce the Irish to the level of the Hottentots.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 6.--Robert Thompson, a night switchman in the yard at the Union Station, in this city, met a terrible death this morning at 5 o'clock under peculiar circumstances. He stepped out of the switch house to signal the shore line owl train, bound for New-York, and in doing so he stepped within six feet of the cowcatcher of an ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 6.--Paul Boyton, the swimmer, had a fine day for his trip today. He reached Rhinecliff from Barrytown at 8:15 A.M., having encountered considerable ice. Quite a crowd witnessed his arrival and followed him to a hotel on the wharf, where he remained until 12:45 P.M., when he donned his suit, ...

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 6.--Rufus Fuller, a prisoner in irons, jumped from an east-bound train on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad near this ctly last night while the train was running at the rate of 45 miles an hour, and escaped ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 6.--The Northwestern Miller says: "The mills more than met expectations last week, making the biggest run since November. Facilitated by ample water power the week's product reached 155,400 barrels--averaging 25,900 barrels daily--against 141,150 barrels the preceding week and 129,100 the corresponding time in ...

Patrick Mallon, who has been an Irishman for 63 years and yet has the bad habit of pounding his wife when drunk, returned to his home at 1,435 Avenue A about 11 o'clock last night somewhat the worse for liquor. He proceeded to quarrel with his wife, and then beat her until she was insensible. Mrs. Mallon was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital, and Patrick was arrested and locked up.

The supply of bogus boots carried to Egypt by one of the last drafts of our forces there ought not to result in fortune to the unscrupulons maker, as a similar piece of enterprise did during the Crimean war. On investigation being made, according to the correspondent of a contemporary, into the badly shod condition of the men it was discovered that the ...

ST. LOUIS, April 6.--The deduction to be drawn from yesterday's election is that the decent men in politics triumphed for once. The good effect of the exposures and resulting prosecution of election frauds was noticeable at every polling place.
Much misunderstanding exists in Episcopalian Church circles regarding the important changes in the Prayer Book made by the General Convention of 1886.

BOSTON, April 6.--Boston yachtsmen were surprised to-day to learn that Gen. Paine, not satisfied with owning the last winner of the America's Cup, had decided to build another competitor, and that the designs had been made, and the contract actually awarded. Such is the case, however.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 6.--A brief announcement in the papers to-day stated that Thomas Brown, of Decatur, Ill., and William Crider, of Lima, Ohio, would run a 60 yards' foot race at 10 o'clocK at Athletic Park, for a purse, the amount of which was not designated.
Ship Lansdowne, (of Windsor, N.S.,) Lockhart, London 40 ds., with cement and barrels to order --vessel to J.F. Whitney Co.

--Cookery for Invalids. By Thomas J. Murrey. New-York: White, Stokes Allen.--Mr. Murrey, well and favorably known as the author of many books on cookery, presents here the various kinds of food available for invalids.

George Baker, a trainer employed by Adam Forepaugh, had charge of a carload of wild beasts that reached Jersey City early yesterday morning on their way to Philadelphia. A royal Bengal tigress became uneasy in her cage and Baker supplied her with water.

BOSTON, April 6.--The second day of the New-England Kennel Club's bench show continued the success of the first. The dogs, always the main consideration, were in fine condition and as noisy as ever. The judging rings were in constant use until late this evening, ...

Capt. Webb is settled upon by the rank and file of the police force as the candidate likely to be succeseful in the struggle for the vacant Inspectorship. One facetious patrolman says that excellence in arithmetic is one of the most exacting Headquarters requirements, and that the champion of the biggest sum is always appreciated. A knowledge of French is no drawback. The civil service examination is soon to be begun.

Herman Rosenberg, aged 15, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Pentz, at Yonkers, on the charge of juvenile vagrancy made by Dr. G.B. Balch, President of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 7.--The Gloucester fishing schooner Everett Steele, which put in here yesterday to replace her dories and anchors, lost on the Western Banks, is to be allowed to buy gear here. The Ottowa authorities were communicated with by telegraph before the Collector would give the necessary permission, and a favorable reply was received.

SAN FRANCISCO, Apri1 7.--The accounts of the wreck of the bark Eldorado, which foundered in the Pacific, 50 miles off Cape Flattery, on the morning of the 1st inst., are meagre, but it is known that all hands were lost except the second mate and one seaman. The vessel carried, all told, 14 persons.
The Hon. JOHN I.PLATT evidently believes that the first duty of an Assemblyman is to his own pocketbook. Mr.PLATT is a member of Assembly from Poughkeepsie.

Members of the General Committee of the United Labor Party occupied the greater part of that body's session last night in berating the party's official organ, the Leader, and sticking the knife of criticism into its late editor, Col. Hinton.

WASHINGTON, April 7.--Secretary Endicott, as already retated in a preceding dispatch, recently became the object of an angry attack from some of the medical officers in the War Department because he discovered in the SurgeonGeneral's office some evils of administration that demanded immediate correction.

ST.JOHN, New-Brunswick, April 7.--News has reached here that the fishery cruiser Vigilant, when sailing out of Beaver Harbor a few days ago, sighted an American fishing vessel within the threemile limit and evidently after bait. The Vigilant gave chase and gained on the "Yankee," who refused to heave to even when a blank shot was fired.

Mrs. Aline Estelle Noyes, an Indian woman living at 314 West Fifty-fourth-street, sought police protection yesterday morning against her husband, Stephen W. Noyes, a Montauk Indian of the Shinnecock tribe. She said he had escaped from the Queens County Lunatic Asylum, at Mineola, and had come to this city to kill her. She feared that he would do it, as he was a bad man, of ungovernable temper.

ST.PAUL, Minn., April 7.--A creditor's bill has been filed in the United States Circuit Court against D.M. Sabin by the Merchants' National Bank of Chicago and the First National Bank of Ithaca., N.Y.,...

Luxuries, it appears, are not not confined to the rich. The poor, and the very poor at that, are beginning to indulge in some of them, and it is problematical where this extravagance will find its limit.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 7.--The Republican City Convention to-night nominated Frank L. Janeway for Mayor. Mr.Janeway is a reform Republican who voted for Cleveland for President. He will be a union candidate, the Prohibitionists having united with the Republicans in supporting him.

Joseph Aronhold, a dealer in tailors' trimmings at 109 Throop-avenue, Brooklyn, was tried in the Brooklyn Sessions Court yesterday on the charge of receiving stolen goods. Three boys, Herman Cooke, Charles Steers, and John Scherer, the oldest 14 years, testified to selling gloves stockings, and spools of cotton which they had stolen to Aronhold.

John Grigg missed his watch in the Third-avenue train just after it left the Grand Central Station on the evening of March 23. He had been jostled on the station platform by a smooth-faced young man. The case was reported to the police and to the station men.

The investigation into the management of the Dock Department was continued yesterday before Commissioners of Accounts Shearman and Adamson. Francis E. Moon, chief clerk of the department, testified in reference to his official duties.

The following regular ticket for officers of the Stock Exchange was announced yesterday: J.D. Smith, President: D.C. Hays, Treasurer; G. Ely, Secretary: J. Mitchell, Chairman; A. Henriques, Vice-Chairman.

The residence of Edward F.C. Young, President of the First National Bank of Jersey City, at 85 Glenwood-avenue, was entered by burglars on the night of March 22 and robbed of 160 pieces of silverware valued at $400. One of the thieves took a new hat belonging to Mr.Young and left his old hat in place of it.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 7.--John Fitzsimmons, who testified for the State last week that the man he saw shoot Haddock ran in the direction of the bridge, again appeared on the stand this morning and swore for the defense that he was mistaken concerning that point. He now thinks the man who did the shooting ran in a northerly direction.

Mayor Hewitt in another letter which he yesterday sent to Senator Low on the Broadway Elevated Railroad scheme, said: "I fully agree with you that no railway should be erected in Broadway until the property owners consent, and a much better defined sentiment shall be developed in its favor among our citizens.
The adventures of the Telephone Rate bill since it was passed by the Senate have caused its friends to regard its course in the Assembly with more than ordinary solicitude.

An excursion party consisting of 60 Yale students started for Old Point Comfort, Va., yesterday afternoon on the steamship Roanoke, of the Old Dominion Line. The excursion is under the charge of the Yale Glee Club, the members of which will...

The Prospect Harriers had their second moonlight chase last night, starting from their clubhouse, on Third-street, Brooklyn. Through Prospect Park, bare-legged athletes raced over the well kept paths and meadows for nearly seven miles, making the occasional wayfarer wonder whether he had seen ghosts or flitting figures in real flesh. The first men in at the finish were scully, Bate Mellor C. Paynter,...
TRENTON, N.J., April 7.--The Legislature adjourned sine die at noon to-day. With its dissolution there went out of existence the worst Legislature New-Jersey has ever had.

CHICAGO, April, 7.--Dr. W.N.Williams, of 3,262 Vernon-avenue, had a narrow escape last evening from death at the hands of an infuriated Anarchist. He was called to attend the 7-Year-old son of Frank Moeck, the boy having been run over by a Thirty-first-street car.

The New-York City Woman Suffrage League held its monthly meeting last evening at 4 Lexington-avenue. Mrs. Clara Neymann spoke on "German and American Independence Contrasted." She seemed to think the American woman was in a far better position than her German sister, though the position of Germany toward its women was consistent...

Col. Fackner, of the Thirteenth Regiment, Brooklyn, was a witness yesterday at the courtmartial of Privates Malbro Walker, George A. Wilson, and James Knudson, of Company H, who are accused of insubordination in having, on Jan. 19, removed the lock on the company door in the face of...

At the meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday the Committee on Internal Trade and Improvement made a vigorous report on the Poughkeepsie Bridge project, protesting against any plan involving the construction of piers in the bed of the river.

The second annual meeting of the Macy Mutual Aid Society, composed of the employes of R.H. Macy Co., was held last evening. Reports were read showing the society to have 329 members in good standing. Benefits have been paid to members since its organization amounting to $2,251.22.

CHICAGO, April 7.--The new east-bound freight tariff adopted under the new interState commerce law has been in effect only since last Monday, and already reports are current that the new rates are not strictly maintained.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 7.--A sensational attempt at murder and suicide occurred three miles south of Chatham, Sangamon County, Ill., early this morning. Two brothers, William and Joseph Warford, quarreled about the use of the farm team. They disputed for some time and finally came to blows.

LONDON, April 8.--A disturbance occurred at the town of Zabern, Alsace, yesterday, during which a number of recruits hauled down the German flag from the official buildings. About 20 men were concerned in the affair, several of whom have been arrested.

CHICAGO, April 7.--Through the efforts of B.P. Hutchinson, who saw the necessity of a means whereby wheat trading might be successfully carried on, a call board has been organized with the following officers: President--Charles Counselman; Vice-President--C.J. Singer; Directors--F.M. Baxter, W.B. Andrews, Robert Lindbloom, W.S. Booth, and B.P. Hutchinson.

The new library to be erected on the grounds of Yale University, through the generosity of the Hon. Simeon B. Chittenden, of Brooklyn, will be built under the direction of Messrs. J.C. Cady Co., architects, of this city. It will be fireproof, of the red sandstone used in the new Dwight Hall, four stories high, and in the shape of a short-armed cross.

At the meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine last evening, Dr. Arpad G. Gerster read a paper on "The Comparative Danger of the Use of Chloroform and Ether as Anaesthetics." His own experience as a hospital surgeon, Dr. Gerster said, showed him that choloform was the more powerful,...

Capt. Murray, of the ship Sapphire, which arrived yesterday from Antwerp, reports that at sunrise on March 4, in latitude 40 10' and longitude 39 18', he sighted on his port quarter a vessel apparently flying her flag at half mast.

The town of Milburn, N.J., was on last Sunday evening the scene of a ruffianly assault upon Lizzie Feely, a pretty little girl of 16, who is employed to do housework by Roger Marshall, an expressman and teamster, who lives at Spring and Taylor streets.

DETROIT, Mich., April 7.--John Q.Faulk, a small, squarely built man, dressed in the garb of a workingman, passed through Detroit last evening on his way to New-York, to look up evidence in support of his claim as an heir at law to the estate of A.T. Stewart.

CHICAGO, Apri1 7.--The excitement caused by the action of the Pennsylvania Company and the Eastern trunk lines in ordering the tickets of Western roads which refused to pledge themselves not to pay commissions for the sale of tickets to be "turned to the wall," is somewhat abating.

ST.JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 7.--The sealing steamer Arctic arrived here from the icefields at 5 o'clock this evening with, 5,000 young and old seals. She reports having spoken the steamer Wolf on the 1st inst. The latter ship saw two plains of ice on the 27th ult. containing a number of seals belonging to the Eagle and marked by that ship's name and flag. It is therefore pretty certain the Eagle is all right.

Coney Island is a very interesting spot to thousands of residents of this city and Brooklyn, but even its admirers admit that it could be improved by a thorough investigation at the hands of the Bacon Committee, and from the talk in Brooklyn yesterday such an investigation will be begun to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 7.--Wreckage drifting ashore in Lynn Haven Bay is recognized to be from the Philadelphia schooner Mair and Crammer, Capt. John W. Budd, bound from New-York to Norfolk, Capt. Crosby, of the schooner James Boice, reports having passed a three-masted schooner sunk off Cob's Island in just sufficient water to cover her decks,...

That there is likely to be a good deal of voting next year not on the lines of old party divisions is a foregone conclusion. Probably the greater number of active politicians are busy now studying the problem of what direction this independent voting may take and how far it may be guided.

The cigar and other stalls adjoining Knox's down-town hat store, on the Fulton-street side, which have stood on the ground for 40 years, and have been an obstruction to travel at one of the most crowded spots in the city, were demolished yesterday and carried away to the corporation...
On the Polo Grounds yesterday the NewYorks met worthy foemen when they defeated the strong Newark team, but only by a score of 3 to 2.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 7.--There was a lively row in the House to-day, in the course of a debate on the Merritt Conspiracy bill, which makes two or more persons conspiring to do an unlawful act responsible for all the crimes growing out of the act.
WASHINGTON, April 7.--The following correspondence explains itself:

The men who run the political department of the Paterson Knights of Labor tried the same ingenious Scheme this Spring that worked so successfully last Fall, and placed in nomination a full ticket for all the city and ward offices to be filled at the election next Monday. For Mayor they named Nathan Barnert, one of the wealthiest owners of mill and tenement house property in the city.

"The inter-State commerce law is likely to prove a boomerang to its authors," said a railroad manager to a TIMES reporter yesterday. "If it was designed by them to be a ladder by which to ascend the heights of political fame you are likely to hear something drop, with the dull and sickening thud attachment, too.

The trial of the suit of William D. Leonard, the Receiver of the property of James R. Keene, against E.A. Kent Co., in which the plaintiff seeks for an accounting of the transactions of the famous lard deal of 1879, was continued in the Special Term of the Superior Court, before Judge Truax, yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 7.--Exchange--Drafts on New-York, sight, 10; telegraph, 15.

Policeman Quinn heard the report of a pistol in Central Park yesterday afternoon. It came from the walk west of the old reservoir, opposite Eighty-second-street. Hurrying to the spot whence the report proceeded, he found a young man lying on the ground shot in the head.

The Rapid Transit Commission held another meeting yesterday afternoon in E. Ellery Anderson's office in the Mutual Building to hear what interested parties had to say about the proposed building of additional lines of elevated road by the Manhattan Company.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 7.--A horrible suicide occurred to-day at the Soldiers' Home. Christ Bogeman, an inmate, ended his life by throwing himself under the wheels of a Home-avenue train. His body was literally cut to pieces. Instanity is supposed to have been the cause of his rash act.

Some very important work in the field of administrative reform at Washington has been done without a blowing of trumpets. Our Washington correspondent's dispatches concerning the Record and Pension Division of the Surgeon-General's office show very plainly and forcibly what has been accomplished there in three months by the use of business methods.

DETROIT, April 7.--The exact figures on the prohibition amendment are still unknown. Slowly the majority against the amendment has been cut down, but it is thought unlikely that it will go much further. All published reports vary more or less, ranging from 1,550 to about 6,000.

MONTREAL, April 7.--An evening paper gives a ludicrous account of the jealous quarrels between the Hon. Mr.Chaplean and his two French Canadian colleagues in the Cabinet, Sir Hector Langevin and Sir A.P. Caron. Sir Hector, it was said, had refused to attend the banquet to be given to Mr.Chapleau here on Monday,...

NEW-ORLEANS, April 7.--The steamship Morgan, from Havana, brought the chess champion, Capt. George H.Mackenzie, who has just completed a visit of several weeks to the Havana Chess Club. During his stay in that city he placed two matches with Judge Celos Golmayo and Senior A.C. Vasquez, respectively, the former being the recognized Cuban...

The programme of yesterday afternoon's public rehearsal, which prefaced the sixth and last concert to be given this season by the Philharmonic Society, embraced two symphonies and Weber's "Concertstueck," for piano and...

Prof. J.D. Quackenbos lectured yesterday on "The Elizabethan Stage," in Hamilton Hall, Colum bia College, under the auspices of the Shakespeare Society of the college. The lecturer briefly reviewed the development of the theatrical exhibitions in English towns from the earliest times to the improved methods of the age of Elizabeth, when drama...

WEST CHESTER, Penn., April 7.--A valuable brood mare belonging to the stock farm of Norman Barnard, near Avondale, broke its leg recently, and Dr. Ewing, of West Grove, set the broken limb and left it in good condition. In the animal's plunges afterward the leg was again broken, and Dr. Huidekoper, of the University of Pennsylvania, having been sent for, advised amputation.

The trial of Henry D. Garrett, the alleged lawyer who has been on trial for the past, three days in the Court of General Sessions for swindling Mrs. Rosalie Charpentier out of $25,000 was concluded yesterday. Garrett's counsel put in no defense. They argued that their client could not be convicted, as the evidence showed that he was co-conspirator with Mrs. Charpentier to defraud.
ALBANY, April 7.--Assemblyman Mulry astonished his associates in the House to-day by the evidences which he furnished of life, activity, and purpose.

CHICAGO, April 7.--The proposition made by the contracting carpenters to their employes that they return to work on an 8-hour day at 30 cents an hour was this morning rejected by the latter on account of the refusal of the former to recognize the union of the employes.

The financial statement of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, recently published, showed that on the 1st of January last the company had become one of the largest and strongest institutions of its kind in the world.
DUBLIN, April 7.--Father Keller, the imprisoned Catholic priest, has been appointed Canon of Cloyne by the Bishop of the diocese.

Arthur S.Austin, the queer Vermonter who has been giving cigars away to everybody on Broadway and in the hotel corridors who pleased his eye, and squandering his money in other ways, was arrested yesterday at his wife's instance, with a view to a judicial inquiry as to his sanity.
The war upon the "commission railroads" was yesterday prosecuted with a determination and vigor that soon pierced the lines of the enemy and brought some of them into camp.

There was a lively demand for fish yesterday for Good Friday. All the markets were well stocked with most everything edible in the aquatic line. The displays at Fulton Market were especially attractive. An event of the day was the arrival of the first North River shad of the season.

Long before 10 o'clock yesterday morning the hour set for the funeral of Miss Catharine L. Wolfe, throngs of people passed through the portals of Grace Church, and quickly filled all the available seats except those specially reserved for the immediate relatives and friends of the family.

It is understood that by the provisions of the will of the late Miss Catharine Lorillard Wolfe her magnificent collection of paintings has been given in its entirety to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Jean Henri Dupin, the oldest of the French dramatic authors, died in Paris on Wednesday, in the ninety-sixth year of his age. M.Dupin is scarcely known to the present generation of playgoers, but in the earlier years of the century his name was familiar to every Frenchman who patronized the theatre.
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., April 7.--The Hygeia Hotel was sold to-day for $352,500. It was bought by Mrs.Phoebus.

The Baptist Social Union of Manhattan Island indulged in a dinner at Delmonico's last night, and after that interesting feat had been accomplished talked for two or three hours, discussing "the moral influence of the secular press of to-day."

People who held stock in the American Opera Company, Limited, are about to have a chance to realize how much easier it is to get into an enterprise than it is to escape from its consequences, even afser the enterprise has become bankrupt, changed its name, and flitted to the Pacific slope.

When Peter F.Murray, a boss painter, and his assistant, Daniel Afford, both employed by J.B. J.M. Cornell, the Centre-street iron manufacturers, went to work yesterday morning in the unfinished Aldrich Buildine at 41, 43 and 45 Broadway, they made what they believed to be a firm scaffold in the seventh story over the stair well.

WASHINGTON, Apri1 7.--Lieut.-Col. Amos Beckwith, Assistant Commissary-General of Subsistence, has been appointed as inspector of certain equipage and stores at St. Louis. The leave of absence of Chaplain Francis H. Williams, Tenth Cavalry, has been extended three months. The following transfers in the Fourth Artillery have been made: First...

The Beecher Memorial Committee held a meeting last evening at 44 Court-street, Brooklyn, and after receiving a letter from Dr.Parker, of London, extended an invitation to him to come over to Brooklyn and deliver as oration at a Beecher memorial meeting.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 7.--A coal train going north on the Lackawanna and Bloomsbarg Railroad came into collision with a locomotive at Taylorville this afternoon. The engine and several cars were thrown from the track and demolished. No one was injured. Through passenger trains en route for Scranton were delayed for some hours, and passengers were compelled to walk from the scene of the wreck to Scranton, a distance of four miles.
About 400 enthusiatic students crowded Prof. H.T. Peck's lecture room yesterday afternoon to arrange for a special centennial celebration next week.

SYRACUSE, April 7.--Prof. J. H. Durston today resigned his position as editor of the Syracuse Standard, owing to a disagreement as to the policy of the paper on the question of supplying the city of Syracuse with water. Howard G. White, chief proprietor of the paper, to-night appointed Charles R. Sherlock managing editor, to succeed Mr.Durston.
HARRISBURG, Penn., April 7.--About 175 delegates, representing the various assemblies of Knights of Labor in Pennsylvania, arrived in this city to-day.

The trial of the suit of J.R. Duff, of Boston, against his former broker, W.J. Hutchinson, of this city, was continued yesterday before Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court. Counsel for Mr. Duff announced that it would be shown that Mr. Hutchinson, acting as Mr. Duff's agent, had sold stock from his own account to his client at a profit to himself, and had purchased stock from...

A lover's quarrel was the basis of a suit in Justice Rhinehardt's court in Brooklyn yesterday, brought by John McCrandle, a shoe dealer, of 1,272 Broadwaym this city, to recover $12.50 for seven pairs of shoes supplied to Lizzie Davitt, a young lady who lives with her mother at 410 South Fifth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

John H.Hodgson, Chairman of the Committee of Rooms and Pictures of the Produce Exchange, was so anxious to take a quiet departure for Europe that he requested some of his friends to see that no demonstratious were attempted. He slipped quietly home Tuesday night, fancying himself secure, and on Wednesday he as quietly boarded the Germanic.

The celebration of the Jewish feast of Pesach, or the Passover, will begin at sunset this evening, and will continue for a week. The feature of the celebration is the substitution of the matzoth or unleavened cakes for bread in all orthodox Jewish households during its continuance. On the first night of the festival a peculiar and solemn service takes place in the households.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 7.--William Bookstaver, George Blair, and Enos W. Barnes, constituting the Prison Labor Reform Commission, to-day concluded an investigation of the charges made by one Thomas Shot, an alleged ex-Keeper at Auburn Prison, and published in a New-York evening paper on April 4.

JOLIET, Ill., April 7.--The Board of Directors of the United Wire Company, a national barb wire association or pool, has completed arrangements by which they can hold perfect control of the barb wire output. The Directors allege that barbed wire is still sold for less than cost, and that it was necessary for the United Wire Company to devise a scheme to reduce the manufacture by buying up a portion of the...

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 7.--The ninety-seventh session of the New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church convened in this city this morning, Bishop Charles A. Fowler presiding. At the opening 180 ministers answered the roll call. The Rev. L.H. King startled the conference by a ringing speech in reference to Mayor Hewitt's...
The circle of seats around the floor of the Seventh Regiment Armory and the balconies were filled last evening with a large and appreciative gathering who had come to see the boys...

CINCINNATI, April 7.--At a meeting of the Chicago and Ohio River Railway pool in this city to-day it was decided to continue the pool as a statistical bureau under the inter-State commerce law, with Pool Commissioner L.D. Richardson in charge. During the first two days the inter-State commerce law was in effect it...

NORFOLK, Va., April 7.--The wholesale boot and shoe house of S.N. Brickhouse Co. assigned to-day. Their liabilities are $90,000 and their assets are above that amount. Their preferred debts are $42,000. Bad collections are said to be the cause of the failure.

A well dressed man with a blond beard appeared in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon followed by a policeman of the Nineteenth Precinct, and a young, plain-looking woman, who was neatly dressed and carried a handsome boy baby. The policeman said that he and the gentleman had arranged that the affair should be kept private.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 7.--Sidney C. Burton, the Cleveland man who followed Kissane for years, and who spent $59,000 in the endeavor to bring him to justice, kept a complete record of all his movements.

The Inter-State Commerce Commission seems to us to have gone quite beyond the limit of discretion laid down in the law in granting the application of the Southern Railway and Steamship Association for a temporary suspension of the operation of the fourth section of the Inter-State Commerce act so far as it affects the lines in that association.
WASHINGTON, April 7.--The Cabinet met at 11 o'clock to-day in accordance with the plan for the Summer months, and remained in session over three hours.

Capt. Sam Brown, the millionaire horseman of Pittsburg, announces that he will start Blue Wing, who is a candidate for Suburban honors in the Railroad and Levee Contractors' Stakes and for the Troubadour Stakes at Nashville. If he wins these two he will not try for the Suburban, but instead will run Bob Fisher, on whom Garrison will have a mount.

A correspondent of the American Grocer sent that paper "a sample of black pepper" and asked what it was worth. In reply he was told: "Our chemist reports that the sample referred to contained very little pepper. It consisted mostly of ground nutshells, farinaceous matter, and mucilaginous seeds."

PROVIDENCE, April 7.--The reform element in the Republican Party in this State has made good its quiet determination to kill off the men that have brought discredit on the party throughout the country, and have made unmistakably...

When the cable road along Park-avenue, Brooklyn, was completed the company purchased some very handsome cars. They are wider and heavier than ordinary cars, as they weigh about 7,000 pounds each. The weight of the regulation street car is 5,000 pounds.
The pig tin market, in which there is always considerable speculation going on, has for the past few days been apparently subjected to a little shaking down at the hands of A. Strauss Co.,...

A movement has been started in this city to revive the old order of the Knights of St. Crispin, the former organization of the shoemakers. The Knights of St. Crispin included nearly all of the shoemakers of this city and Brooklyn, and won more than one strike. It was reported yesterday that the nucleus of that order that managed to survive the...
