CHICAGO, April 7.--Mr.P.D.Armour explicitly denies that he has any present connection with the wheat market of this city other than as one who "carries" the grain, buying it for one month, selling it for a more distant one, and taking a profit on the use of the money needed to hold the property while it is being traded in by the speculators.
Here are two letters that will interest yachtsmen. Commodore James D. Smith received the first yesterday and wrote the second in enthusiastic response.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 7.--A fire occurred this morning in a large boarding house on State-street, kept by Mrs. James Hutchinson, by which four persons were badly injured. The fire was caused by the explosion of a kerosene lamp in the kitchen.

The truth about the Rahway murder mystery is as far from discovery as ever. The body of the dead girl has not been identified beyond reasonable doubt, and there is not evidence sufficient to warrant an arrest for the crime.

TUSCARORA, Nev., April 7.--The hoisting works of the Nevada Queen mine were completely destroyed yesterday by the explosion of a box of giant powder which had been placed near the boiler to thaw. The boiler also exploded.
The village of Mount Vernon was overflowing yesterday with clergymen, it being the opening day of the thirty-ninth session of the New-York East Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church.
There was a terrible scene of excitement late last night in the double tenement house, 12 and 14 Essex-street, resulting from a fire which broke out at 11:40 o'clock in the basement of the building.

The withdrawal of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railroad Company from the emigrant pool caused a small cartload of telegraph messages from various directions to pour into the office of that corporation yesterday inquiring what they intended to do about rates. The company's answer was that it had no intention of seeking a fight.

A committee of the New-York Maennerchor waited upon Mayor Hewitt yesterday, accompanied by Deputy Tax Commissioner Autenreith and City Court Judge Nehrbas, to call his attention th an order given by the police which effectually prevents the society from continuing their rehearsals as a singing society.

Good Friday will not be universally observed at the theatres this year as it was last. Daly's, the Madison-Square, the Lyceum, and Harrigan's will be closed to-night, however, and so will the Standard, which has not been opened at all this week.
SING SING, April 8.--Capt. Boyton arrived here this evening at 9:15 o'clook, after a swim of 12 miles against the tide, and put up for the night. He was quite ill and had to have medical attendance.

Mayor Hewitt has recently publicly announced that he would not reappoint Fire Commissioner Edward Smith, and has made the announcement in such a manner as to have offended many of Mr. Smith's friends, who called upon him to urge favorable action in the matter.

The exceedingly uncomfortable and eventful life which Louise Hardcastle--known on the stage as Louise Balfe--has led her husband, George Herbert Leonard, came to an end yesterday, when Judge Donohue granted him an absolute divorce.

There are contractors who do a thriving business in purchasing and removing the material of buildings on sites to be occupied by new edifices. The doors, sills, and window frames are preserved and repainted, the outside walls are carefully taken down, and the bricks cleaned and used in other buildings.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 8, via Galveston.--The officers of the British war vessels Bellerephon and Pylades, which are now lying at Vera Cruz, are visiting this city and are the recipients of many attentions.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 8.--P.H. Hacke's 5-year-old trotting stallion, Prince Harold, by Harold, dam Winnie Nutt, by Nutwood, died suddenly this morning of colic. Prince Harold was one of the most promising animals in Hacke's stable.
The Episcopal and Roman Catholic churches always put forth greater efforts for the celebration of Easter than for that of any other day in their calendars.

At the morning session of the New-York East Methodist Episcopal Conference at Mount Vernon yesterday the General Conference resolution calling for a change in the proportion of ministerial and lay representation in the session next year was debated and rejected.

Edward Harrigan was "out of the bills" on Thursday night for the first time this season, owing to an indisposition, which gave the actor, play writer, and manager a chance for some well earned rest and amusement. His place in "McNooney's Visit" was taken by Joseph ...
The first move in the expected contest of the heirs of Jose Sevilla over the disposal of his vast estate was made yesterday by Antonio Pastor Sevilla, one of the next of kin.

TRENTON, N.J., April 8.--The State Board of Health met at the Capitol to-day, and during the meeting discussed the legislation enacted in the interest of public health during the session of the Legislature just ended.

Max Weil, who died yesterday morning at his residence, 133 West Twelfth-street, at the age of 67 years, was connected with one of the oldest wholesale dry goods houses in the country. Mr. Weil was born in Germany and came to this country when a lad of 17.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 8.--Edward Cummings and wife, of Davis City, who have been married 10 years, recently separated on account of quarrels, the wife going to her father's.

DETROIT, April 8.--It now seems that the prohibitory amendment has been defeated by 3,800 votes, or 300 more than the estimate sent by the Associated Press Tuesday night. Several towns are yet to be heard from, but they will not materially change this result.

The Suburban Harriers, a recently organized cross country club, is to have a run through a portion of the annexed district this afternoon, starting from the Woodbine Hotel at High Bridge. Among the runners will be E.C. Carter, A.P. Roth, C.E. Smith, P.D. Skillman, and P.E. Hjertberg.

TRENTON, N.J., April 8.--The Catholics and Irish citizens generally in this city and vicinity are agitated over the refusal by Gov. Green to preside over a meeting to be held here next Friday evening to protest against the proposed English policy of coercion in Ireland.

There were lively times in the village of Port Chester early yesterday morning when several attempts at burglary were made. One man got slightly wounded and was locked up. About 2 o'clock, Mr. C.W. Davis was awakened by hearing some one trying to open one of the windows on the ground floor.

The Italian bark Unico left Pensacola for Newport, England, with a cargo of lumber on March 1. After crossing the Gulf of Mexico she got out of her course, and on March 16, when among the Little Bahamas, was driven upon a reef five miles northeast of Memory Rock and became a total wreck.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.--An inquest which was held to-day on the suicide of John Noetzer, a one-armed and one-legged German, 52 years of age, showed that during the closing years of his life he was remarkably unfortunate.

Capt. Peter F. Murray, one of the victims of Thursday's accident at 41 Broadway, was buried yesterday afternoon at Calvary Cemetery. The funeral took place at the residence of his brother, George Murray, 246 West Nineteenthstreet.

CARLISLE, Penn., April 8.--College and society circles are greatly excited over the departure for Philadelphia this afternoon of a Deputy Sheriff to arrest W.L. Boswell and W.L. Boswell, Jr., prominent brokers and insurance agents at Fourth and Walnut streets, Philadelphia.

CHICAGO, April 8.--Alvin Hill and G.W. Archbold, the former the son of the President of the Adams County National Bank of Decatur, Ind., and the latter a dry goods merchant of Pleasant Mills, in the same State, arrived in this city yesterday, and ...
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 8.--The Sloss Steel and Iron Company, with a capital stock of $4,000,000, and the Coalburg Coal and Coke Company, effected a consolidation to-day.
LONDON, April 8.--The ship Prince Victor, (Norw.,) which arr. at Bristol April 4, from New-York, capsized to-day. The Captain's wife and child were drowned.

PROVIDENCE, April 8.--By the new elections in South Kingstown and Little Compton to-day the General Assembly stands in grand committee 50 Democrats and 46 Republicans. Four Senators and eight Representatives are yet to be elected.

CHICAGO, April 8.--It was Good Friday to-day and the Board of Trade and the open board were both closed. There were no cables and no "gold and stock." Very few of the offices were open, and only to answer correspondence or to undergo a cleansing and renovating process.

While the ferryboat Passaic, of the NewYork, Lake Erie and Western Railroad service, was on her trip to this city at 10:40 o'clock yesterday morning, a man who passed through the gentlemen's cabin astern noticed smoke coming from the seats near the horse gangway.
PROVO, Utah, April 8.--At the General Conference of the Mormon Church to-day an epistle was read from Presidents Taylor, Cannon, and Smith, who comprised the first Presidency of the church.

It is an extraordinary thing that a State like New-York, which leads both America and England in all matters of legal reform, should be so far behind Great Britain in legislation in regard to the "little slaves of the loom."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 8.--George Fishback, the 4-year-old son of Jacob Fishbank, of New-Albany, was run over this morning by a freight train on the main track at the crossing of South-street north of the "Y," killing him almost instantly.

James McCready is lying ill at 109 Washington-street, Brooklyn, and is worrying over the mysterious disappearance of $650 which he had drawn from the bank and placed in a bureau drawer. Detectives were put on the case and soon discovered that the money had been stolen once before.

BELVEDERE, N.J., April 8.--Advices from Sussex, Warren, and Hunterdon Counties, the centre of the New-Jersey peach-growing industry, state that never were the prospects for a full crop more favorable than now.

At 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the steamer Adriatic was sighted off Fire Island and at 9:30 in the evening her anchor dropped swiftly with a rush and roar into the water abreast of the Quaratine station.

DETROIT, April 8.--Chairman I.M. Weston, of the Democratic State Central Committee, has fallen into the hands of an interviewer and has given forth some highly cheerful and birdlike warblings as to the future of the great party that he has been steering for the past two campaigns.

DETROIT, April 8.--Francis Palms, of Detroit, by a life of frugality, (not to say parsimony,) industry, and intelligent and unremitting application to one purpose, accumulated one of the largest estates in Michigan.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, April 8.--The station of the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Railroad at Edenburg, Penn., 14 miles east of this city, was, at 3 o'clock this morning, the scene of a brutal assault, bold robbery, and arson.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 8.--Some startling developments were made to-day during the trial at Carthage of W. Gigger, who shot and killed Capt. James Higgins for an alleged insult to his wife. Gigger, under the new law, was allowed to testify in his own behalf.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--The Commissioners of the District of Columbia have decided to revive the Blue Laws on Sunday next and prevent the opening of any places of business except apothecary shops and undertaking establishments.

The water color artists are in more active demand at the clubs this Spring than ever before, especially in view of the exhibition in Boston. The Union League exhibition will be followed by one at the Manhattan Athletic on Tuesday, and the Lotos on April 23 and 25.

The statement that Col. Edward Fackner was about to resign the command of the Thirteenth Regiment was industriously circulated in Brooklyn yesterday, but was found to be based solely on a proposed European trip which the Colonel is soon to make with his father-in-law.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--No publication that has been made concerning any undertaking of the new Administration, has interested the clerical force more than the two chapters in THE TIMES of Thursday and to-day about the efforts of the Secretary of War to improve the business methods and results in the Bureau of Records and Pensions of the Surgeon-General's office.
FORT SMITH, Ark., April 8.--Patrick McCarthy was hanged here to-day for the murder of Thomas and John Mahoney in the Cherokee Nation on Feb. 16, 1886.

PARIS, April 8.--The Government has ordered a man-of-war now in West Indian waters to proceed immediately to Port au Prince to protect the Europeans there in view of reports of a threatened massacre by the Haytians in the event of their Government complying with the demands of Great Britain on account of some old claims.

Justice Hyatt, of Sing Sing, yesterday morning committed Thomas Lynch, aged 26, to the Poughkeepsie Asylum on the certificates of Drs. Fisher and Helm that he was insane. At 1 o'clock in the morning the man appeared at the home of Oscar Haines, a little way out of the village, in a semi-nude condition.

Yale colors and Yale's fair friends occupied prominent places at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon when the Yale nine in all its blue beauty came forth to battle with the Giants.

Capt. Allaire, of the Eldridge-street station, resolved yesterday to make a raid on Hester-street. Hester-street on Fridays is like the vicinity of Washington Market on Saturdays. It is so infested with peddlers of all kinds of wares, from horseradish to "old clo's," that a pedestrian who attempts to pass through it from Orchard to Essex street must be a skeleton man or take to the road if he is in a hurry.

NORFOLK, Va., April 8.--Forty Yale College students arrived here to-day by the Old Dominion Line steamship Roanoke from New-York on an excursion trip to Old Point Comfort, Washington, and Baltimore. Their Glee and Banjo Clubs are among the party.

The sun rose clear and bright over the little city of Rahway yesterday morning. The air was fresh and balmy. There was an odor of new-plowed fields borne in upon the gentle breeze and the ear was greeted with the songs of feathery vocalists, singing their "home again" after their southern sojourn through the Winter.

The shifting changes of the Bacon investigation brought to the front yesterday two Coney Island Justices of the Peace whose display of nerve edified greatly the small but admiring audience.
Charles Stoll, the Hoffman House waiter who had the trouble with Mme. Bernhardt., and who proposes to sue her for assault, isn't a waiter at the Hoffman House any more.

Dr. Leo Schuepp was before Judge Donohue yesterday upon the complaint of his wife, Laura, who has begun an action for a limited divorce on the ground of abandonment, claiming that he was about to leave the State. Judge Donohue required him to furnish $1,000 bonds as security, which he did.
Arthur S. Austin, the crank from Birmingham, Ala., who came to New-York for the purpose of defending the Aldermanie boodler, O'Neil, was a prisoner in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

RED BANK, N.J., April 8.--Vice-Chancellor Bird was to have tried yesterday the suit of Mrs. Annie B. Farrie, of New-York, against Mrs. Emily V.B. Beach, the second wife of the late Henry D. Beach, but in the morning the case was amicably settled.

CHICAGO, April 8.--Mr. Blaine's sons, who are in this city, have received several dispatches from their friends at Fort Gibson, Indian Territory. The dispatches of yesterday said that Mr. Blaine had caught a severe cold on his journey to Fort Gibson and it was feared that pneumonia might result.

There is in President CLEVELAND'S letter to the President of the American Fishery Union a quiet tone of dignity and firmness which shows that he fully appreciates the responsibility placed in his hands by Congress in providing for retaliation upon Canada for the treatment of our fishing vessels, but is not disposed to shrink from its exercise on any proper occasion.
It is scarccely extravagant to say that Miss WOLFE'S munificent bequest of her collection of paintings to the Metropolitan Museum distinctly raises the rank of that institution.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 8.--The coal miners throughout the country are discussing the formation of one gigantic organization by the amalgamation of the National Federation of Miners and the Miners' National Assembly of the Knights of Labor.
CHICAGO, April 8.--Mrs. Harriet Austin Murphy, the oldest female resident of Chicago, was buried from the Second Baptist Church this afternoon.

At a meeting of the New-York Tariff Insurance Association yesterday a resolution was passed, fixing the rate for brokers' commissions in the district of the old Metropolitan Association at 20 per cent.

There was a large attendance of worshippers last evening at the Temple Emanu-El, at Fifth-avenue and Forty-third-street, attracted by the Passover services. The Rev. A. Rubin, the reader of the temple, led in the devotions, and the Rev. Dr. Gottheil offered the evening prayer. At the morning services to-day he will preach a sermon.

The full text of the Southern roads' decision in classifying cotton goods has been received by dry goods shippers in this city. The classification is broad, and includes, besides a specified list of cloths, "all articles of similar value made entirely of cotton." This is one of the points sought to be obtained by the shippers in their present fight with the trunk lines.

WINCHESTER, Va., April 8.--The morning session of the court was taken up with argument by counsel as to the admissibility of the statement made by Ridenour at the preliminary trial before a Justice. Broy's father asked the prisoner at that time who was security on the note for $75 given by Ridenour to young Broy in payment for a horse.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 8.--A negro girl employed as a servant by Dr. J.P. Hunter, a physician of Laurens County, attempted to kill the doctor and his family by putting rat poison in their dinner. All who partook of the poisoned food became violently ill, but are now out of danger.

The lawyers who have recently raised a storm in a teacup in France by answering in the affirmative the question as to whether a husband should open his wife's letters have now given the reasons for their decision.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 8.--Exchange--Drafts on New-York, sight, 10; telegraphic, 15.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 8.--The strike of the cotton handlers still continues, but a conference of all the parties will be held to-morrow with a view to adjusting the troubles existing between the old and new councils.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 8.--Two men last night entered a room at 134 Eagle-street, occupied by Mrs. John Gillespie, threw a quilt over her head, and robbed her of $230 which she had concealed in her stockings. One of the robbers was arrested and gave his name as John Leader. The other escaped.

It is not surprising that E.B. Bartlett, of E.B. Bartlett Co., will not "discuss the censure" passed on him by the Board of Managers of the New-York Produce Exchange. It doesn't admit of much "discussion"--from his view point--and it suggests its own comment from any other view point.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 8.--The taking of depositions for the defense in the one-hundredthousand-dollar damage suit brought by Surveyor of the Port Lancaster against Congressman Glover came near terminating tragically today.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 8.--The village of Cochecton, Sullivan County, is again flooded, for the fourth time this year. The warm weather and rain on Monday night made high water in the Delaware River.

TAUNTON, Mass., April 8.--Rice M. Blakely pleaded guilty this morning to the charge of assault with intent to commit murder on John J. Callahan and Stephen Littleton, and was held in $3,000 bail in each case for the Grand Jury of the June term.
Chief of Police Campbell, of Brooklyn, had Inspector Byrnes for a guest yesterday afternoon, and the two officers were joined by District Attorney Ridgway, Inspector Reilly, and Detective Corr.

CHICAGO, April 8.--The strike of the carpenters is nearing an end, and it is possible that to-morrow morning the ranks of the strikers will be divided and fully one-half of the men go to work on the proposition made by the employers, 30 cents as the minimum rate per hour and eight hours' work per day.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 8, via Galveston.--The movement for extending the term of President has taken a new phase and Congress, instead of acting on the project for making a flexible term, will probably adopt a resolution repealing the amendment to the Constitution forbidding the immediate re-election of the chief magistrate.

In attempting to close the disreputable resorts of this city Mayor HEWITT has undertaken a crusade that will give him a great deal of trouble. If he succeeds in it he will be entitled to the gratitude of his fellow-citizens.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.--Additional liabilities of the firm of Henry Bower Son, manufacturing chemists, came to light to-day by the filing in the Court of Common Pleas of judgment notes aggregating in amount $113,658 55.

CHICAGO, April 8.--Vice-Chairman George H. Daniels has called a meeting of the passenger department of the Central Traffic Association to be held at the association rooms next Tuesday.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 8.--The Knights of Labor did not get away this afternoon, as they expected to do. The Committees on Legislation found the task of hearing the bills affecting labor pending in the Legislature more onerous than they anticipated.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 8.--James Artery, a former employe of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, to-day got a verdict in the Federal Court for $13,500 damages against the company. He was run over by a hand car and his lower limbs and back paralyzed.

A novel sale was that at the American Horse Exchange yesterday, being a lot of Shetland ponies, bronchos, and burros, the latter mostly mouse-colored donkeys of diminutive size from the ranch of I.P. George, of Elkins, NewMexico.

At 12 o'clock on Thursday William Brinkman ate dinner with his wife, Christina, in his cheerless little room in the attic of the tenement house at 33 Rector-street.

The scene around the burned tenement house on Essex-street was a busy one yesterday morning. Soon after sunrise the tenants who had escaped the flames rushed back to see what condition their rooms were in, and crowds gathered to see the damaged building.

MONTREAL, April 8.--The annual convention of the National Amateur Lacrosse Association is being held here to-night. Fourteen new clubs were admitted to the association. The action of the Committee of Management in awarding the disputed championship last year to the Montreal Lacrosse Club was sustained by a vote of 46 to 14. The vexed question is thus definitely settled, this being the final court of appeal.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 8.--The body of Elias Bohnestial was found floating in the Susquehanna River at Marietta last evening. He had been seen walking along the bank a few hours before and it is supposed that he fell in while gathering willows. He was nearly 80 years old.

Plymouth Church lecture room was crowded last evening. The prayer meeting lasted longer than usual, and it was past 9 o'clock when the Chairman called the congregation to order, in business meeting adjourned from last Friday evening.

CHICAGO, April 8.--City health officers began making the rounds of the Italian district to-day, where the case of smallpox was discovered yesterday, and have commenced inoculating all the residents of the infected district.
There were two desolate homes in Yonkers last night. At one was the deserted wife of Joshua J. Beck, with her 15-year-old daughter and little baby.

A Board of Trade return of the quantity of fish landed and its value at each of the principal ports of the United Kingdom during the year 1886 is issued as a Parliamentary paper. The total value of fish landed on the English and Welsh coasts last year was 3,957,075.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 8.--A dispatch from Tacoma, Washington Territory, says that the schooner Fannie Duttard has arrived at Port Townsend, having on board two seamen, the only survivors of the bark Eldorado, which foundered 50 miles off Cape Flattery on the morning of April 1.

The Wine and Liquor Dealers' Association of the First Assembly District met yesterday at the Stevens House, 27 Broadway. Peter McQuade presided. The chief topic of discussion was, of course, the High License bill.

HELENA, Ark., April 8.--The agent of the Iron Mountain Road at Nettleton, Ark., yesterday morning upon opening a car of moss billed through from Baton Rouge, La., to St. Louis, found the well dressed corpse of a man in an advanced stage of decomposition.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 8.--Leavitt was recalled this morning by the defense to identify the copies of his confession. The defense offered extracts from his confession in evidence, but on objection it was overruled.
Yesterday was another busy day in the Broadway railroad ticket offices, and all interest centred in the fight of the commission-giving and the commission-refusing roads.

Capt. Paul Boyton, who is now on his aquatic trip down the Hudson River, has just been engaged to travel with the Barnum and London shows the coming season. He will make his appearance in Madison-Square Garden on Monday next in the large tank at present used by the Beckwiths for their swimming act.
The English, especially those who live in London, now have an opportunity to take to heart one lesson which they have taught us --that pauper immigration is not a blessing.
William Kelly went to Bellevue Hospital with a fractured skull at 8 o'clock Thursday night. He said first that he had been injured by a gambler.

WASHINGTON, April 8.--Post Chaplain Henry Swift (recently appointed) has been ordered to duty at San Antonio, Texas. Post Chaplain William F. Hubbard (recently appointed) has been ordered to Fort Buford, Dakota.
Clara Sachs is a plump and not ill looking girl of 19. Her mother died some time ago, and since then she has been her father's housekeeper and taken care of a brother 14 years old and a sister of 10.

WOONSOCKET, R.I., April 8.--Louis Gaudin 109 years old, who was never sick until a week ago, died last night. His wife died two years ago at the age of 102 years. Gaudin's mother lived to be 108 years old.
LONDON, April 8.--Col. King-Harman, Conservative member of Parliament from the Isle of Thanet, division of Kent, has been appointed Under Secretary for Ireland.
Mr. Henry Sire, one of the owners of Harry Wilkes, the now famous trotter, says he will trot his speedy horse against Maud S., for fun or for a trophy, if Mr. Bonner will consent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 8.--A number of citizens of Defiance have sent a petition to Gov. Foraker urging him to send a regiment of troops to Paulding County to prevent the destruction of the Wabash and Erie Canal by citizens living along its line.

NEWPORT, N.H., April 8.--Upon complaint of 13 voters of Croyden that in their belief the law against bribery at elections was violated in connection with the annual March meeting legal proceedings were instituted yesterday, Justice Elisha M. Kempton examining five witnesses. The evidence implicated prominent Democrats.
Calvin Graves, a desperado and murderer, of Hancock, Me., was captured and lodged in the City Prison of Oakland on Monday by Detective Holland. A few days ago the detective was out sunning himself.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 9.--The Clearing House exchanges for the past week were $14,785,224. Drafts on New-York, sight, 10; telegraphic, 15 cents.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--The President to-day designated Thomas P. Kellogg and Charles T. Jewell as cadets at large at Annapolis. Thomas Kellogg is a son of Lieut. Col. S.C. Kellogg, aidede-camp to Lieut. Gen. Sheridan; Charles Jewell is a son of Commander Jewell, United States Navy, and nephew of Vice-Admiral Rowan. Both of the lads stood near the head of their classes in the high schools.

CHICAGO, April 9.--The Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railway has followed the action of the Pennsylvania Company and given official notice of the withdrawal from sale of all tickets over such of its Western connections as refuse to stop the payment of commissions.

WASHINGTON, April 9.--The President this evening appointed as Commissioners to investigate the affairs of the Pacific Railroads under the act passed by the last Congress, Robert E. Pattison, of Pennsylvania; E. Ellery Anderson, of New-York, and David L. Littler, of Illinois.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9.--The rainstorm which began yesterday continued all night, and to-day it gradually worked south into the San Joaquin Valley, where it was most needed. Rain also fell along the coast as far south as San Diego, and although not sufficient to insure full crops, yet the prospects have been materially increased, particularly of early sown grain.

SALEM, Ill., April 9.--The coal miners here have gone out on strike. The prices paid by the company are 13 cents per box of five bushels and one peck. The miners demand 15 cents, but the company refuses to give it.

The taking of a salmon at Winterport has surprised some of our local fishermen. It is the earliest that the king of fish was ever taken here, and indicates probably a large run this Spring. This one was a beauty and tipped the seales at 19 pounds, and has excited the sportsmen very greatly.

CHICAGO, April 9.--A.C. McNeill, whose nephew, "Bobby" Caruthers, the ball player, it is said, has lost $9,000 to the gamblers in Chicago, appeared in Judge Gary's court this morning for the purpose of commencing a war of extermination against the entire gambling craft.

The arrangements for the America's Cup races of 1887 are going forward with all possible speed under the management of ex-Commodore James D. Smith, President: William Krebs, Secretary, and the other members of the NewYork Yacht Club's Special Committee having that matter in charge.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio. April 9.--The Junction Iron Works, at Mingo, closed down to-day for an indefinite period. About 600 men are thrown out of work. The cause of the shut-down is said to be the unwillingness of buyers to pay greatly increased freight rates under the inter-State commerce law.

The sixteenth day of search for the murderer of the poor girl whose remains were found on the country road near Rahway, ended with all known clues run down, and a more impenetrable mystery enshrouding the case than ever.

Some of the Bangor druggists have been greatly surprised this week to have drafts for $100 brought to them for payment. Upon examination it has been found that the drafts were from the National Protective Association.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 9.--The world's champions achieved another victory to-day, defeating the Chicagos after an exciting game by a score of 9 to 7. Both pitchers were hit freely, but Foutz particularly distinguished himself by cool-headed work at critical points of the game.
NEWPORT, R.I., April 9.--The good weather of the week brought many visitors to Newport, and the "City by the Sea" begins to show great signs of activity. However, but few houses were rented.

DETROIT, April 9.--Some of the principal members of the grain trade of Detroit were met by THE TIMES'S correspondent on Change to-day and asked for an expression of their opinions of the inter-State commerce law and its probable effect upon the business of their city and of the country at large.

The buffalo gnats appeared in the lower part of the parish last week on Thursday, and within 48 hours of their appearance they had done much destructive work. We are told that at least 75 head of miles and horses were killed in the Fifth, Sixth, and Eighth Wards by the seemingly unpretentious little gnats.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 9.--The Erie Road opened a fast passenger train to Scranton via the Hawley and Wyoming Railroad to-day. The NewYork train, consisting of ten cars, passed here at 10 o'clock. The time from Scranton to New-York is five hours.

WATERTOWN, Dakota, April 9.--A severe wind which toward nightfall culminated in a tornado lasted throughout the day in this section. About 11 A.M. it drove the prairie fire up to the western limits of the city, destroying some buildings.

SING SING, N.Y., April 9.--Capt. Paul Boyton is again in the Hudson River, swimming for NewYork. He made a dash for the water from the steamboat pier here at 11:30 A.M. in the presence of an immense crowd of people. The river at this point is clear of ice, and as the Captain started on the first of the ebb tide he will probably reach the Battery to-morrow afternoon.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 9.--The third session of the New-York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was held here to-day. The Goss scandal matter came up again. The jury appointed to try Mr. Goss met yesterday, but no evidence was taken.

Columbia College is being cleaned and polished for its great celebration. The buildings will be decorated, so said one of the janitors, in blue and white. The whole week the students will enjoy a rest from studies so as to "celebrate" more vigorously and also to permit the decoration without hindrance.

Ex-President White, of Cornell, hae recently added some very rare political pamphlets to the library of 100,000 volumes which he presented to the university.

A verdict of suicide while of unsound mind was returned this morning at an inquest on the body of Robert Mckay, who had thrown himself out of a top-floor window of a lodging house at Westminster. Peter McKay, a brother of the deceased, said all the members of theif family were subject to suicidal fits. His father and three of the children had committed suicide.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 9.--Gov. Wetmore was seized with a fainting fit this afternoon caused by taking internally medicine intended for external application. He soon rallied under medical care and nothing serious is feared.

The storm which has been muttering for some time past in the Vestry of Trinity Episcopal Church, Newark, is likely to break out in an ugly fashion in the parish election, which takes place to-morrow evening.

Gabriel Wenger, a well known resident of Lancaster County, while driving to Lancaster City on Saturday afternoon, handed the reins to his wife, saying that he did not feel well. His wife, after driving a short distance, turned to speak to him, and discovered that he was dead. He was taken to the Lancaster County Hospital, where it was found he had been stricken with apoplexy.

The Seventh Regiment athletic contests, eleventh series, took place in the armory on Sixty-sixth-street last evening. They were accompanied by the intercollegiate tug of war. The semi-cylindrical hall was brilliantly lighted.

TRENTON, N.J., April 9.--Some time ago about 1,500 quail from Tennessee and North Carolina were distributed in the five lower counties of New-Jersey by the West Jersey Game Protective Society. The birds are all doing well, and give promise of becoming thoroughly acclimated. They are fat, plump, and apparently not the least bit homesick.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 9.--Rabbi Hahn, of the Tiffereth Israel Reform Synagogue, has been delivering Sunday morning lectures to his congregation on the lives and characters of men celebrated in science, art, literature, and philosophy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9.--The Louisville Club received a second defeat from the Indianapolis team to-day in the presence of about 1,000 people--and it was a bad one. BALTIMORE, April 9.--There is a growing conviction here that there has been no deal, nor will there be any serious movement to divert the control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to any syndicate nor to any other railroad combination. The general belief is that President Garrett has purchased all the stock offered, and has now, with the stock of two or three large holders, the entire control.

DETROIT, Mich., April 9.--After making two abortive attempts the bill making capital punish ment the penalty for murder finally passed the lower house of the Legislature to-day by 3 votes more than the requisite majority.

PARIS, April 9.--All the newspapers, especially those of the most Radical persuasion, are deeply incensed about the English naval failure to salute at Cannes, owing to the playful sleepfulness of the Duke of Edinburgh.

HURON, Dakota, April 9.--A prairie fire last night swept over a great portion of Grant Township, in this county, doing immense damage. Fred Towns's house, his barn and other buildings, together with furniture machinery, and several head of stock, were destroyed.

CHICAGO, April 9.--Civil Service Commissioner Lyman arrived here to-day to conduct the investigation of the charges made by George A. Webster, a removed employe, against Collector Seeberger.
CHICAGO, April 9.--It is now certain that the new freight rates recently established by the roads between Chicago and St. Paul and those between Chicago and Omaha will not be maintained very long.
BOSTON, April 9.--George Purdy Hunt, aged 50, cabin passenger on the steamer Catalonia, and an Engineer in the United States Navy, died on the passage April 5, and was buried at sea.

Some months ago, when Sir Alfred Goollis was in this country, he promised Capt. Jack Hussey, the veteran life saver of Castle Garden, that the Royal Humane Society should give him a medal. Yesterday the Captain received an imposing looking communicatton from that society.

An insane girl named Kate Triarty arrived at Castle Garden by the steamship Schiedam on March 12. The Commissioners of Emigration sent her back by the same vessel. On April 2 she again landed at Castle Garden. She was sent back yesterday on the steamship Belgenland. When she was placed on that steamer she declared that she would yet become an American.

The necessity for a prompt settlement of the boundary dispute with the republic of Venezuela is strikingly illustrated by a few items of intelligence we take almost at random from British Guiana newspapers just to hand. One item tells of about 200 laborers and others--the laborers would be chiefly negroes--leaving Georgetown in one day for the gold mining districts in the tributaries of the Massaruni River.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 9.--The prohibition question is rapidly assuming a front rank among the political issues of Texas. The late Legislature passed an act submitting this question to a vote of the people in August. The antiprohibitionists are organized for the battle.

Since its organization the Theatrical Mechanical Association, made up of men employed behind the curtain in the theatres of this city and Brooklyn, has paid out in sick benefits and for burial of members $10,393. Each member receives $6 a week if he is sick, and $50 is paid to his family in case of death.

An interesting phase of the troubles of the creditors and stockholders of the American Opera Company was developed yesterday. An injunction was obtained from Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, restraining the creditors of the company from beginning or continuing any suits against it until the further order of the court.

Woodford, 92, who died Sunday, and Mrs. Truman Woodford, 94, a sister-inlaw of Mrs. G.B. Woodford, who died in Hartford on the 1st. CHICAGO, April 9.--All the iron molders employed in stove factories throughout this State except those at Peoria and Bloomington, quit work to-day or were locked out, and the event is considered the inauguration of a long and obstinate strike.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., April 9.--The Democratic Convention held here last night nominated John O. Hudson for Mayor. Mr. Hudson has held the office four times. The Republicans nominated James Tantum. The nomination was tendered to Asher Blakely, the present Mayor, but he would not accept it.

The funeral services of Mrs. Emma J. Conly, widow of George A. Conly, the basso, drowned at Spofford Lake, Vermont, May 27, 1882, were held at her residence, 40 West Twenty-fifth-street, last evening. The Rev. Dr. Swope, of Trinity Chapel, officiated.

GALVESTON, Texas, April 10.--The past week has been one of expectancy and disappointment to the people of Texas, no rains of any consequence having fallen throughout the immense area now suffering from drought.

Shortly after 11 o'clock last evening a twostory frame building on Sedgewick-avenue, near Morris Dock, caught fire and was destroyed. Among the colored miners who boarded there was Michael Turner, 28 years old. He was asleep when the fire broke out, and before he could be rescued he was burned to death. The building was worth about $500.
A well dressed man fell dead in Chathamsquare at 12:50 o'clock last night just after descending the steps to the Second-avenue elevated road. The body was taken to the Oak-street police station.

TALEQUAH, Indian Territory, April 10.--The Cherokee Female Seminary situated one mile from here, burned down at noon to-day and the loss is $250,000. The seminary was built in 1858 and was intended to accommodate 200 girls. It cost originally $150,000, but a few years ago an addition costing $80,000 was erected. No lives were lost, but the loss is the greatest ever experienced by the Cherokees.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 11.--An extensive landslide occurred at Muldoon's cut, on the Boston, Hoosaac Tunnel and Western Road yesterday afternoon. It will cause considerable delay in traffic. A gang of men are clearing away the debris to-day. Trains will be unable to run from Sarotoga to Mechaniesville for two or three days.

The week's ball playing at the Polo Grounds opened yesterday with a one-sided game between picked nines from the New-Yorks, captained by Ewing abd Ward. The attendance was not so large as the pleasant weather seemed to warrant. There were numerous errors and fumbles, but to make up several remarkable plays called out the wildest applause from the spectators.

Mme. Helene Hastreiter was a passenger br the Arizona, which arrived here yesterday. Queen Elizabeth of Roumania devoted such a large amount of time to singing that her attendantss lately assured her that her voice entitled her to rank with the most celebrated of singers. Buckholtz was horribly burned and is sinking under the shock and his injuries.

Patti has come back, and the world is at her feet again. She tripped, like a buoyant, happy girl of 20, to the footlights of the Metropolitan Opera House last night and bowed to one of the most notable audiences that have gathered within its walls since the opening of the house. The orchestra chairs were all occupied.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 11.--The Constitution of to-morrow will say, introducing the views of Gen. E.P. Alexander, President of the Central Railroad system, on the Inter-State Commerce act:
POUGHKEEPSIE, April 11.--Another monument to the memory of Matthew Vassar and to the worth of John Guy Vassar known as the Vassar Brothers' Hospital was opened to-day for the reception of visitors.

LONDON, April 11.--The Mark-Lane Express in its review of the British grain trade during the past week says: "The wheat markets have been of a holiday character. Prices are unchanged. Foreign wheat is a shade weaker. Corn, oats, and all rather articles are dull. The trade for wheat cargoes on passage or for shipment is at a standstill. There was no marekt to-day."
Greenville, (N.J.) gossips are discussing the elopement of Emma Kirchner, of that settlement, with Christopher Lauer, of West Bergen. Emma's father keeps a grocery store in Greenville.

Final arrangements hare been made for the parade to-morrow morning in the centennial celebration of Columbia College. The Alumni will form by classes on Fourth-avenue, north of Forty-ninth-street, the Law School on the sidewalk in Forty-ninth-street, in front of the college;

TRENTON, N.J., April 11.--Two employes of the Pennsylvania Railroad were killed yesterday. The first was a track walker, Gardner Newcombe, aged 55 years, a resident of Lawrence Station.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 11.--The cruiser Triumph was at Shelburne yesterday. She reports that American fishing vessels are fulfilling the requirements...

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 11.--Joseph Lafferty, 17 years old, who says his home is in Brooklyn, and that his father is foreman of the Fireside Companion composing room, was taken to the City Hospital today to be treated for severe burns about the feet.

The growing virtue of the French in the matter of tobacco smoking bids fair to create yet another difficulty in the arduous task of balancing the budget of the republic. It appears that the tax on this pleasant vice producted last year 6,000,000f. less than in the year 1885.

Brooklyn's Bureau of Charities is after the $15,000 to be donated to charitable institutions in that city. Many ladies have received the following circular soliciting their co-operation. It will be remembered that at the time of this distribution, $20,000 will be given to New-York charities as well.

NYACK, April 11.--Eugene C. Fiske, the Democratic Town Clerk and manager of the Democratic newspaper in this place, who left these parts a few weeks ago, after appropriating considerable money belonging to the newspaper proprietor, has been heard from in a town in New-Hampshire, where it is believed he is engaged in business.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 11.--A year ago Bryant B. Crandall, quite a well known man here, disappeared and was supposed to have committed suicide at Niagara Falls. William B. Sirret, ex-County Treasurer, returned from his California trip yesterday.

LONDON, April 11.--The day appointed for the great demonstration in London against the Irish Coercion bill now before the House of Commons opened brilliantly, the weather being balmy and the sun shining brightly.

PATERSON, N.J., April 11.--The Republicans to-day re-elected Charles D. Beckwith Mayor by nearly 1,000 majority and five, if not six, Aldermen. The Labor vote was very light. Passaic elects Charles M. Howe (Republican) Mayor by 400 majority, 10 Republican Councilmen out of 12, and all three Republican Chosen Freeholders.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 11.--At Association Track this morning Poteen and Montrose, two conspicuous Derby candidats, received their first real trial at a mile and a quarter.
F.J. Osorno, Mexican Consul at Hamburg, is at the Metropolitan Hotel. Theodore M. Pomeroy, of Auburn, N.Y., and John K. Paine, of Cambridge, Mass., are at the Windsor Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--A decision was rendered by the Supreme Court of the United States to-day in the railroad permit case of Henry S. Barron vs. George W. Burnside, Sheriff of Lynn, County Iowa.--In error to the Supreme Court of that State.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 11.--Mrs. Marie Dalvi, an Italian, 30 years of age, living at 87 Austin-avenue, was fatally stabbed by her husband Nicolai Dalvi, last evening. Dalvi was jealous of his wife, and during a quarrel drew a stiletto and plunged it into her right breast. The blade penetrated the lung, causing internal hemorrhage. A bad wound was also inflicted in her right arm. Dalvi was immediately arrested.

BURLINGTON, Vt., April 11.--The State Board of Cattle Commissioners to-day issued an order prohibiting the introduction into this State of cattle from the State of New-York, except such as may be loaded in cars for transit through the State. This order was based on the information that contagious diseases exist among cattle at Bonnington which had been brought over from New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--Detectives are looking for Mr. J.A., alias F.W., alias W.F., Bacon, of Boston and New-York alternately. He and his wife paid Philadelphia a visit, but they did no other paying while here. Mr. Bacon is a Boston swell.

Samuel S. Cox--not "Sunset" Cox, but a patrolman attached to the Thirteenth Precinct-- had a lively time Sunday night. As he was passing along Lewis-street he found George Ambruster, an old man of 50, crying on the sidewalk.

BOSTON, April 11.--James M. Ward, the Irish comedian, who began an engagement tonight at the Bijou Theatre in his play "The Red Fox," was painfully wounded during the third act by a supernumerary named Cohee.

The Brooklyn Parnell Parliamentary Fund Committee, which sent $25,000 to Ireland last year, met last night in the rooms of the Constitution Club and denounced the proposed Coercion bill as unjust, tyrannical, and opposed to the spirit of the English Constution.

CHICAGO, April 11.--Several of the Western lines are now securing evidence upon which they can prosecute the Eastern roads for refusing to sell through tickets over their lines, in direct conflict with the new law, which provides that all connecting roads should be treated alike.

Wall-street had a lively day yesterday. Reading stock climbed up above 45, being now only a few points below its price on that famous day of last December when the youthful Morris Wormser toppled over and carried the whole stock market with him.

ALBANY, April 11.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued a certificate authorizing the Ninth-Avenue Bank, New-York City, to transact a general banking business under the State laws, with a paid-up capital of $100,000.

Simpson, Crawford Simpson, of Sixthavenue and Nineteenth-street, are now selling an assortment of imported wraps, suits, and parasols that in their class are unexcelled for quality and cheapness. The new wraps are of velvet, jet, and silk. Some are solid jet, but the majority jet combined with silk or velvet.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 11.--The funeral service here to-day over the body of young Raymond Belmont, in Memorial Chapel, which is the gift of his father, was strictly private, only the family being present.

An elderly man, who appeared to be intoxicated, was found leaning against a tree on Sixthavenue, Brooklyn, on Sunday afternoon, singing and shooting in a noisy way. An officer ordered him to move on, but was answered with oaths and a repetition of the disorderly behavior.

The crew of the schooner Eliza Cook, which left Halifax on March 27 for Bermuda, arrived at this port yesterday on the French steamship La Normadie. Capt. Daac, of the Cook, reports that he abandoned his vessel in a sinking condition on April 6 in latitude 40 50', longitude 61 37'.
Arthur S. Austin, the Vermonter who went to Birmingham, Ala., and made a fortune by speculating in land, was before Judge Donohue again yesterday.

Oh, such limbs! And oh, such daring, dancing, wicked eyes! There is no use in talking about it. The Harvard chorus girls are in town, the dudes have surrendered at discretion, and before the new-comers the fairies of the Casino and the Bijou must hide their diminished feet.

Andrew Kolber, who was employed in a surgical instrument factory and lived at 629 East One Hundred and Fifty-fourth-street, rose early yesterday morning and told his wife he was going for a drink of water.

CHICAGO, April 11.--The effects of the inter-State commerce law upon the business of the Chicago east-bound roads are quite forcibly shown by the statement of eastbound shipments of dead freight from this city last week, the first one in which the new law was in force.

The cornerstone of the Townsend pavilion annex to Bellevue Hospital was laid with impressive ceremonies at 11:30 o'clock yesterday morning. Lively times may put in an appearance at the Western Union Building to-day. The big telegraph company's shareholders have been summoned to vote on a project that proposes to increase the capital stock and float an indefinite lot of collateral trust bonds.

At the morning session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Mount Vernon yesterday, the principal order of the day was the consideration of reports of the Presiding Elders of the New-York and Brooklyn Districts, the Revs. B.M. Adams and Ichabod Simmons, respectively.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 11.--County Treasurer Williams has just received $15,796 legacy tax under the law of 1885 taxing collateral inheritances 5 per cent. Miss Mary E. Miller, a wealthy maiden of the town...
LISBON, April 11.--The Portuguese Government has concluded a treaty of friendship with China.

CHICAGO, APril 11.--Judge Gresham was engaged to-day in hearing the foreclosure case of the Central Trust Company against the Central Iowa Railway Company, which came up on complainant's motion to strike out certain portions of the answer.

The Chamber of Deputies having voted the supplementary credit of 1,040,000 demanded by the Minister of Marine, the following new vessels will at once be built: At Cherbourg, a first-class cruiser, to be named the Alger, which will be 360 feet long by 42 feet in beam, with a 20-feet draught of water, a displacement...

The city of Rahway gave a decent funeral yesterday to the unknown girl who was murdered in the suburbs of the place over two weeks ago. The body was robed in a while satin shroud and placed in a beautiful white casket, with silver trimmings.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--J. Edgar Hall, the handsome young wholesale liquor dealer, who is charged with forgery by Richard L. Austin, of the Independence National Bank, had a further hearing before Magistrate Durham to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11.--The sixth annual banquet of the Young Republicans of Philadelphia took place at St. George's Hall to-night, and was largely attended. The following letter from Senator John Sherman was read, and its sentiments received with applause:

MONTREAL, April 11.--The body of Medical Student Hamer, who has been missing for some time, was been found in the snow about two miles from where he was last seen alive. He had evidently wandered away, and being overcome with the cold laid down to sleep.
SIOUY CITY, Iowa, April 11.--The day has been spent in the Haddock murder trial by counsel arguing law points relating to conspiracy and the application of the term "reasonable doubt."

ST. LOUIS, April 11.--Mr. R.C. Kerins and Dr. Mudd, of this city, the latter of whom went to Fort Gibson to examine and treat Mr. Blaine, returned home to-night. Mr. Kerins stated to a reporter that when he and Dr. Mudd left Fort Gibson Mr. Blaine was getting along nicely and was well on the way to a quick recovery.

A.P. and W. Man, the attorneys of Catharine Lorillard Wolfe, filed in the Surrogate's office yesterday the petition of David Wolfe Bishop and David Wolfe Bruce, Executors, for the probate of Miss Wolfe's will, citations to be returnable on May 31.

RICHMOND, Va., April 11.--The first unionmeeting of the International Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers held in the South took place here yesterday under the auspices of Division No. 46 of Richmond.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 11.--The Federal Government is negotiating with a French steamship company with the object of establishing fortnightly steamship service between Canada and France. The Government scheme will be subsidized to the extent of $50,000 annually.

The great Abyssinian chief Ras Alula is at present a person of much interest to the Italians, and the Riforma is publishing a sketch of his life, in the course of which it is stated that he is the son of Abyssinian peasants.

For the first time in the annals of the great Paris salesroom called the Hotel Dronot the furniture of a member of a royal family was disposed of by auction there yesterday. The articles offered for sale were of a magnificent description,

HARTFORD, Conn., April 11.--Department Commander Taintor, Grand Army of the Republic, of this city, has issued an order urging the different posts in the State to arrange for public services on the 27th of this month, the anniversary of the birth of Gen. Grant.
A farmer in Luther was awakened on Tuesday night last by some person prowling abort in his residence. He arose, and with his son drove the intruder out and fired some shots after him.

The Actors' Fund will be domiciled at the southeast corner of Fifth-avenue and Twentyfirst-street after May 1. Rooms for an office and headquarters were yesterday secured in Park Tilford's building, and the work of fitting them up will be begun at once.

The trial of Otto White, charged with the murder of Louisa Wolf on the night of Feb. 10, began before Judge Van Brunt in the Court of Oyer and Terminer yesterday morning. District Attorney Martine and ex-Senator Fitzgerald, his assistant, appeared for the prosecution,

WILMINGTON, Del., April 11.--A meeting of the Delaware peach growers was held at Smyrna on Saturday to take steps to combat the stand taken by the New-York commission men in their refusal to return empty baskets.

RICHMOND, Va., April 11.--United States Senators James B. Beck, J.C.S. Blackburn, and Representative C.R. Breckinridge, of Arkansas, left here last night. Their visit here was to examine the statue of John C. Breckinridge, which Valentine, of this city, has nearly completed.

Charles Nichols, a young Englishman, who was employed in John Simmons's iron works at Centre and Leonard streets, met a horrible death yesterday. About 2:50 o'clock in the afternoon he was working at the drilling machine, and in adjusting a belt to a pulley he was caught up by the belting.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 11.--Caldwell, who stroked the Yale crew last year, has been decided upon as stroke of the crew to row against Harvard next Summer. Eleven men are now in training and will be kept until the race. Welles, who was a candidate, has been dropped. Stewart, a promising candidate, has retired from the boat on account of illness.

About a hundred members of the St. Nicholas Society made the lodge room at Delmonico's ring last night with the joyous enthusiasm of their celebration of the "Paas." That event is annually made much of by the society, ...

WESTMINSTER, Md., April 11.--Carroll County celebrated to-day the semi-centenary of its organization. About 15,000 persons were present, and there was a procession and trades display. There were large delegations from Baltimore, including the...

DETROIT, April 11.--A.M. Stanton, who ran away last week with $7,500 belonging to George K. Sistares Sons, a branch of the New-York house, and besides was short $21,000, returned to-day, gave up the cash, and will not be prosecuted.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 11.--The decree in the Toledo, Cincinnati and St. Louis claims cases, which were argued at Cleveland last week before Judges Gresham.

A curious action for libel has been before the French tribunals for some months. It was brought by the Marquis de Val Carlos, a diplomatist, against Mme. Ratazzi, widow of the late Signor Ratazzi and wife of a member of the Spanish Cortes and whilom Secretary-General of the Sagasta Cabinet.
LONDON, April 11.--The Newcastle and Gosforth Park meeting began to-day. The race for the Gosforth Park Juvenile Plate of 50 sovereigns, for 2year-olds, was won by C. Perkins's b.f. Belle Mahone.
CHICAGO, Ill., April 11.--The visible supply of grain on April 9 shows an increase of 331,000 bushels of wheat, 1,330,000 bushels of corn, and 337,000 bushels of oats.

The Russian Government cares nothing whatever for the commercial prosperity of Sebastopol, and would much prefer to see its increasing export and import trade diverted to some other Crimean outlet.

PARIS, March 30.--After much discussion and numerous adjournments of both of which the motive--not expressed overtly--was a lurking expectation that a change of regime might render the measure inexpedient, the French crown diamonds are really to be put up at public sale.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 11.--A 10-year-old daughter of Leon Glovensky, a paper hanger, who resides at 879 Grand-avenue, was playing at an open second-story window to-day when she got up on the window sill, lost her balance, and fell headlong to the flagged sidewalk.

Another move was made yesterday in the struggle of the creditors of the American Opera Company to have their claims satisfied. William W. Badger, the lawyer, moved before Judge Nehrbas, in the City Court, to advance three cases to the short cause calendar next Friday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 11.--Shippers, merchants, manufacturers, and railroad men here dream about the inter-State law and see in it some new and unpleasant phase every night. They entertain, but fear to express, the belief that this city will he sidetracked.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., April 11.--About a year ago Thompson, Hiatt Co. opened a mine known as Chamberlain Colliery, south of St. Clair, a mile from here. This place was the scene to-day of the most shocking tragedy that could be imagined.

A peculiar domestic scene was enacted in Newark late last night. About 10 o'clock, as a Broad-street car reached Hill-street, it stopped suddenly, when a handsomely dressed gentleman alighted, followed by a lady and two small children rather poorly dressed.

Umpire Pearce should be a little more careful in his decisions. All of the New-York players are not infallible, and he should not tempt them to break the rule about swallowing the umpire's decisions cheerfully and in silence.
The robberies upon the Pan Handle Road, which have just come to light, are very different from the ordinary pilfering of fares, against which all railroads have trouble to protect themselves.

UTICA, April 11.--The warm weather of the past two days, aided by rain this morning, has swollen the creeks and the Mowhawk Rivereast of here and flooded and washed out railway trackes to an such extent that traffic on the Central Railroad is suspended. Eastbound trains have been held here since noon, and no through trains have reached Utica...

The storm that had been expected at the annual meeting at Trinity Church, Newark, yesterday came, and was breasted in a manner that compelled the acquiescence of Rector Reed's opponents in his progressive methods of management.

The Commissioners appointed by the President to conduct the inquiry provided for by the act of Congress of March 3 into the affairs of the railroads receiving aid from the Government in bonds are men whose character gives fair assurance of a thorough and honest investigation.

The Veteran Corps of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, Col. Thomas Lynch presiding, met last night at their headquarters, in the armory at Tompkins Market, and perfected arrangements for the celebration of their departure for the war on April 23, 1861.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 11.-- The dispatch to THE TIMES of Thursday last respecting the safety of the sealing steamer Eagle has been verified in the most complete and satisfactory manner.

A boy 7 years old was taken in charge last night by Matron Webb. His name is Michael Lippmann, and he lives at Annandale, N.J. He came to the city yesterday with a man peddling picture frames, and went to the house of a cousin, whose name he does not know, somewhere on Cortlandtstreet.

The Rev. Dr. James T. Curran, whose, spiritual retreat of ten days in the Passionist Monastery at Hoboken ended at midnight on Saturday, was again assigned by Archbishop Corrigan yesterday to take charge of the parish at Ellenville, N.Y.

CARLISLE, Penn., April 11.--The State Commissioner of Insurance was here to-day consulting his attorney in regard to the Boswell insurance. He will return on Wednesday and go before the Grand Jury. He is confident of obtaing convictions.

A number of toughs attended a picnic yesterterday at Washington Park, at Sixty-ninth-street and East River. They got into a light, and William Connor drew a pistol and blazed away, shooting William Walker, of 401 East One Hundred and First-street, in the left leg, and James Hughes, of 438 First-avenue, in the heel. Connor, who lives at Seventy-second-street and Avenue A, escaped.

TROY, April 11.--William Coffey, a reporter for a mercantile agency and brother of the Mayor's private secretary, wanted Lena Levi for his wife. Miss Levi is a Jewess, while her lover is a Roman Catholic.
The members of the Prohibition County Committee met last evening in the parlors of the Women's National Christian Temperance Union, 3 East Fourteenth-street.

A terrible tragedy has just occurred at Toulon. M. Aubergat, the conductor of the orchestra at the Grand Theatre, in that town, went to the apartment occupied by an actress--Mme. Lery--and shot her dead with a pistol of heavy calibre.
The Trustees of the gratuity fund of the Produce Exchange submitted their fifth annual report yesterday. The assets of the fund are $939,250 invested on bond and mortgage...

WASHINGTON, April 11.--Col. John M. Wilson, Lieut.-Col. Peter C. Haines, and Major Garrett J. Lydecker have been appointed members of a board to meet in this city to consider such matters relating to the proposed Bennington Battle Monument as may be referred to it.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 11.--Trade prospects are more gloomy than ever. The reckless conduct of those in authority has reduced the financial affairs of the colony to a most deplorable condition, and the exodus from our shores goes on with ever increasing impetus. We are rapidly drifting toward confederation or annexation. Which shall it be? The people prefer the latter.

The inquest in the case of Jack Murray, who was killed on April 4 on Thirteenth-street, Jersey City, was held last night by Coroner Burke. The jury rendered a verdict that Murray was killed by Patrick McNamara. The latter claimed that he voted in self-defense. He was remanded.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 11.--One of the most outrageous proceedings ever known in an Ohio court took place to-day in the Common Pleas Court, resulting in the ousting of the Prosecuting Attorney, and the swearing in of an assistant to conduct the cases that may be brought before the Grand Jury.

LONDON, April 11.--The Times's correspondent at St. Petersburg says it is reporter that the Czar, before returning to Gatschina on Wednesday, found letters on his writing table in the Winter Palace threatening him with death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 11.--Exchange-- Drafts on New-York, sight, 15; telegraphic, 20 cents.

Orders have been received here from St. Petersburg directing that all cafes, places of amusement, and the railway stations are to be closely watched, and all suspicious persons are to be asked to show their passports. If they have not passports with them they are to be arrested. Odessa is and has been for a long time under martial law.

After a long contest the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railway has succeeded in rescuing 300 shares of its capital stock from the wreck of the firm of Grant Ward, unless the higher courts reverse the decision in its favor which Judge Ingraham made yesterday.

A still in the basement of Hegeman Co.'s drug store, 203 Broadway, exploded yesterday afternoon at 1:45 o'clock, causing a concussion which shook that building and those immediately adjacent and a fire which resulted in damage to the extent of about $80,000 and a blockade of travel in Broadway.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 11.--John M. Hathaway, dealer in lumber and railroad ties at Cannonsville, is reported to have fled from home to escape arrest on the charge of uttering forged commercial paper.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 11.--Long before the Connecticut farmers welcomed the first blue bird of the season they became acquainted with another bird of different feature. He traveled in flocks, wore high hoots, and bore curious looking instruments.
One peaceful Sunday was not enough to put a damper on the war over ticket commissions, and the railway trunk lines and their Western enemies resumed the battle at their old stands yesterday.

The state of the real estate market and the amount of money that is being used in the erection of new buildings, as well as in altering and repairing old ones can be judged no better than from a few moments' consultation with the clerks at the new Fire Hall in Sixty-seventhstreet, near Third-avenue.

For the first time since he became a member of the Board of Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge on Jan. 1 Mayor Hewitt went over to a Trustee meeting in the Sands-street station yesterday. He had 12 associates around him.

Gen. Paine, who has been stopping at the Brevoort House, will leave the city this morning for Wilmington, Del. He goes there to consult with Pusey Jones, who are to build the new steel yacht with which he expects to defend the America's Cup against the Thistle.

TRENTON, N.J., April 11.--The Democrats who have been in control of the City Government for six years were swept out of power to-day, Frank A. Magowan, the Republican nominee for Mayor, being elected by an estimated majority of 250.

ST. PAUL, April 11.--The bull clique at Chicago that is running the May wheat deal is banking heavily on the fact that the grain rates from Minneapolis are now 18 cents, while they were only 7 cents, the nominal rate, when the Northwestern elevator men and millers sold short for May delivery.

WASHINGTON, April 11.--The President to-day appointed the following-named Postmasters: Joseph St. Clair Wiggins at Brunswick, Ga., vice James T. Blair, resigned; I.H. Harrison, Sulphur Springs, Texas, vice William A. Wortham, resigned; E.J. Farlow, Ashland, Oregon, vice A.P. Hammond, ...
NEW-IBERIA, La., April 11.--Reports have been received here of a duel yesterday in front of the Catholic church, at Larcanville between Henri Hebert and Y. Fournet. Both were slightly wounded.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., April 11.--The Acushnet Mill Corporation voted to-day to increase its capital by $250,000, and to build a new mill of about 30,000 spindles.

LONDON, April 11.--The steamship City of Chester, (Br.,) Capt. Lewis, from New-York April 2, for Queenstown and Liverpool, was signaled off Brow Head at 9 o'clock to-night.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 11.--A paper entitled "Mobilization and Concentration of Canadian Militia for the Defense of the Frontier," printed in the journal of the Military Service Institution, has created no little comment in military circles here.
We gave in our Washington dispatches yesterday some facts of a very interesting nature regarding the condition of the departments and the need of thoroughly overhauling them.

R.J. Horner Co., furniture manufacturers and dealers of 61, 63, and 65 West Twenty-third-street, by reason of their progressiveness, are obtaining a great deal of the cream of the trade, although they have been only six months in the business.

Chancellor Runyon rendered a decision yesterday in Newark that made the city authorities whistle and set lawyers and business men talking over a case in which the legal possibilities are bewildering.

A small delegation of well known NewYork lawyers took an airing in Westchester County yesterday and invaded the old stone Court House at White Plains. They had come up to initiate Judge Dykman into the intricacies of a ticker suit.

WARSAW, N.Y., April 12.--The Women's Christian Temperance Union of Pavilion, Genesee County, bring a novel suit against Patrick Quinlan, whom they wish to bring to terms, as he keeps a licensed hotel, but sells bad whisky with poor judgement. They bring the suit in the name of the Overseer of the Poor to recover $40 in penalties for the failure of said landlord to erect a hotel sign as required by statute.

The London meeting of protest against the Coercion bill was much more significant than such meetings are apt to be. It would have been of some value if it had merely impressed the English mind with the practical unanimity of the Irish people themselves in favor of home rule and in opposition to coercion.

Chairman John F. Develin being ill, First Vice-Chairman Voorhis presided over last night's meeting of the County Democracy's County Committee, in Cooper Union. Joseph P. Fallon, from the Committee on Resolutions, reported a number of whereases and resolves, among which ...

BOSTON, April 12.--There is a slight misunderstanding in the commercial community regarding the position of Boston merchants before the Inter-State Commerce Commission. Two parties have brought their grievances before the commission.
Prof. M.B. Riddle, of Hartford, is at the Grand Hotel. Judge Irving G. Vann, of the New-York Supreme Court, is at the Westminster Hotel.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 12.--The most closely contested municipal election ever held in this borough was decided yesterday. The town is a stronghold for Prohibition, and the old parties found it necessary to fuse in order to elect an antiProhibition ticket. Owing to the great amount of scratching the count was not completed until early this morning. The combined citizens' ticket won by an average of 30 votes, re-electing George W. King Mayor.

CHICAGO, April 12.--The Chicago Tyre Spring Works, which failed recently, began a suit to-day against the Union National Bank, C.R. Cummings, J.J.P. Odell, Charles H. Ferry, and W.G. Stephens, to recover $250,000.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 12.--This was the second day of the Spring meeting of the Louisiana Jockey Club. There was a good attendance. The track was dusty. Following were the events:
Walter A. Lamb, with several members of the John T. Raymond company, accompanied the body of the dead actor, which arrived in this city yesterday morning by way of the Pennsylvania Road.

Since Sunday afternoon, April 3, Barbara Steckinger, the 16-year-old daughter of Joseph Steckinger, who lives at 224 North Eighthstreet, Brooklyn, Eastern District, has been missing, and her parents have an idea that she has eloped with a married man.

A committee from the Stock Exchange, consisting of James D. Smith, President; R. Keppler, Vice-President, and O. Wheeler, went to Albany yesterday to appear before the Committee on Ways and Means, of which ex-Speaker Erwin is Chairman.

The story of how Lyman S. Weeks was shot and killed at his house on De Kalb-avenue, Brooklyn, by John Greenwall, is told by two of the alleged murderer's "pals." Paul Krauss and John Baker, contains several assertions which agree with the facts as far as they have been given to the public, but a TIMES'S reporter ...

The Governor does not rest his disapproval of the High License bill explicitly on the ground that it is special legislation, but on the ground that it would make the excise laws bear unequally upon different parts of the State. He contends that such laws should be "substantially uniform throughout the State."

BELLEVILLE, Ill., April 12.--The trial of G.W. Voice and Patrick O'Neill, the two East St. Louis policemen indicted for the murder of ex-Mayor Bowman, was set for yesterday in the Circuit Court in Belleville.

The case of M.G. Clapp against Atterbury Tillinghast, stockbrokers at 15 Broad-street, which will come up for trial in Judge Dugro's branch of the Superior Court next Monday, will furnish the fourth trial of an important suit growing out of Wall-street transactions during the April term of the courts.
Police Justice Stilsing, of Jersey City, before whom Henry K. Lynch, of 399 Newarkavenue, was arraigned yesterday for a series of brutal assaults upon his invalid wife and three ...
Miss Yolande De Comeau, wearied of her loneliness in this city and following the bent of her inclinations for many years, has sought a residence at the Convent of the Francescan Sisters at Buffalo.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 12.--The Right Rev. Alfred Lee, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of Delaware, died at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon of typhoid fever, after an illness of nearly two months. For the past month the condition of the venerable prelate had been such as to cause his family and friends the greatest anxiety.

Collector Magone is about to take vigorous measures to stop cigar smuggling on the Havana steamships. Two of the Ward Line Captains have already appeared before him. They disclaimed responsibility for what has been going ...

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., April 12.--A marriage under difficulties most extraordinary took place in Bismarck, Dakota, last week. The bride was Miss Nellie Rice, of this place, a beautiful and highly accomplishad young lady, and one of the leaders of society.

"Rat-tat-tat" went Jesse Williams's stick against his music rack last evening, and the orchestra went through the familiar overture. Then the sage-green curtain rose on "Erminie" for the three hundredth time in its Casino history.

An exciting capture of two thieves took place on Market-street, Newark, last night. One fellow attempted to steal some hats from a rack in front of Mr. Barth's store while his companion stood on the sidewalk. They were detected by Mrs. Mina Oliver.
The sale of the furniture and library of ex-President Chester A. Arthur yesterday at 5 East Nineteenth-street did not attract a very large throng.
The Rev. Charles H. Ward was brought to the bar of the Bergen County (N.J.) court yesterday to plead to the indictments found against him recently for atrocious assault upon his wife and daughter.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 12.--A match race is being arranged for the third day of the coming Spring meeting, between Montana Regent, Elkwood, Troubadour or Blue Wing, and Jim Gray or Punka, for $500 a side, $1,000 to be added by the Memphis Jockey Club; distance, one mile and a quarter. Sam Brown's entry is the only one that is not certain. The other horses are now at the track and rapidly attaining their racing form.
