The bulls had another happy day yesterday. Reading got up above 46 and staid there, Jersey Central took another step toward the par that the "pool" has been predicting for it, and various specialties were active and strong.

Sarah Bernhardt's matinee in the Academy of Music on Saturday afternoon promises to be the most successful performance she has yet given here from a financial point of view. Last evening Mr. Abbey had received nearly 500 applications for places, although the sale does not begin until Thursday. He expects the takings at the box office will reach close to $5,000. "Theodora" is to be the play.

To the Assembly: Assembly bill No. 455, entitled "An act to further amend chapter one hundred and seventy-five of the laws of eighteen Hundred and seventy, entitled 'An act regulating the sale of intoxicating liquors,'" is herewith returned without approval.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 12.--The Union Labor Party of this city met yesterday and placed a city ticket in the field for the election next October. All the wards were represented, and there was a show of considerable interest. The Democracy made a feint to capture the convention, but was beaten.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--The leave of absence of Second Lieut. James A. Goodin, Seventh Infantry, has been extended one month on account of disability. Leave of absence for four months has been granted Capt. Jacob A.A. Augur, Fifth Cavalry.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 12.--In the municipal election to-day the Republicans gained one in the Common Council. William Strong was re-elected Mayor on the Democratic ticket for the fourth time by less than 100 majority. C.T. Warner (Republican) was re-elected Collector of Taxes by a reduced majority.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12.--The atmosphere of Point Bridge was blue early this morning with the curses of 350 railroad laborers of several nationalities. The timely arrival of the police prevented a riot. The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company tried to lay frogs across the ...

Chief of Police Tooker, of Rahway, said last night that he had obtained what he believed to be an important clue in the murder mystery. One of his assistants came to this city and consulted an astrologer, who advised an immediate inspection of the old well on the Froat premises.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., April 12.--A case involving an intricate legal problem and all the features of a weird romance was brought to the attention of the court here to-day. In 1872 old Jacob Stahley, a man of eccentric habits, died in Shaver's Creek, leaving an estate worth $30,000.

Ex-Gov. A.B. Cornell presided at the meeting of the stockholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company yesterday, and by way of explanation told the dozen gentlemen who were on hand that the object of the meeting had been fully explained in the circular issued by President Green and published in THE TIMES. "And we will proceed to necessary business at once," remarked the bland and portly Chairman.

A California sporting paper is authority for the statement that E.J. Baldwin has received from A.J. Cassatt a letter accepting his [Baldwin's] challenge to race Volante, 5 years old, against any horse in the world, at a mile and a half, for 10,000 a side. This authority further states that Mr. Cassatt has named. The Bard, 4 years old, as his representative, and that the race is to take place at Monmouth Park next July.

Adam Bauer, of 157 Boerum-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, was in Justice Naeher's court yesterday morning on a charge of intoxication and was sent to jail for 29 days. He is a German, about 50 years old, and was accompanied to court by his wife.

UTICA, N.Y., April 12.--The interference with travel on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad by the high water which be gan yesterday continues to-day. At noon to-day the tracks from Fort Plain to Fonda were under water at some points to a depth of three feet and directly in front of Palatine Bridge Station the water was ten feet deep on the track.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 12.--The Constitution of to-morrow will contain a double leaded editorial announcing that President Cleveland will visit the Piedmont Exposition, to be held in Atlanta early in October. The editorial states that Mr. Cleveland has positively consented to come, and has agreed that announcement of the ...

CHICAGO, April 12.--At 3 o'clock this morning a freight train on the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railway was derailed near Roselle in consequence of a railroad tie having been placed across the track. The engine and four cars were badly wrecked and a brakeman seriously injured.

ALBANY, April 12.--The city election to-day called forth only a light vote. The Democrats were successful by reduced majorities, Danahar and Wilkinson being elected City Justices by about 1,400. The Board of Supervisors in Albany County will stand: Republicans, 15; Democrats, 16, ...
The members of the New-York East Methodist Episcopal Conference, in session at Mount Vernon, yesterday listened to the report of Presiding Elder W.H. Wardell, of the New-Haven District.

Mrs. Sarah Hunter, of Nyack, wife of John H. Hunter, Secretary of the New-York Consolidated Gas Company, was put on trial yesterday in the Court of General Sessions, Part III., to answer a charge of grand larceny. The indictment was found on the testimony of Mrs. Lena Mansfield, of this city, who swore that two years ...
Capt. Bradford, who sails the Galatea for Lieut. Henn, came from Europe on the Devonia yesterday. He will immediately take charge of the yacht.

LONDON, April 12.--The House of Commons resumed its sittings this afternoon. After Speaker Peel had thanked the House for its indulgence during his illness, the Right Hon. Hugh Holmes, Attorney-General for Ireland, reopened the debate on the Government's side in favor of the Irish Crimes bill.
Den Thompson and his company gave their one hundredth performance of "The Old Home stead" at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre last evening, which was remarkable because there wasn't a souvenir.

The programme for the Fall meeting of the National Rifle Association at Creedmoor was arranged yesterday at a special meeting of the association. Gen. John B. Woodward presided, and there were present Gens. George W. Wingate and Charles F. Robbins, Col. Joseph J. Story, Majors L.B. Bell and George L. Fox, James Duane, and John S. Shepherd, Secretary of the association. The week beginning Sept. 12 was set aside for the matches.

The George C. Flint Company's store, at 104, 106, and 108 West Fourteenth-street, is a favorite resort just now for the people who have country places to fit up for the Summer or city houses to be brightened with handsome furniture. The firm show parlor sets upholstered in tapestry and the finest plush, very different ...

The marriage of Miss Hattie King, daughter of Vincent C. King, to Albert Brown Hilton, son of Judge Hilton, took place yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride, 110 East Sixteenth-street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton, of the Church of the Divine Paternity.

The opening of the new banking room of the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank at 49 and 51 Chambers-street, yesterday, attracted a large number of people. The room occupies the entire first stork of the building, and is a beautiful specimen of workmanship, being finished entirely in marble and bronze. The ceilings are of gray Knoxville marble, laid out in panels with bronze rails.

Mr. WILLIAM BLAIKIE contributes to our columns this morning a letter upon rapid transit. It is an extremely readable letter because it is full of ideas and treats in a live and intelligent fashion a problem in which every man and woman who has occasion to move about in the streets of New-York has a vital interest.

The Bacon investigating committee will strike out in a new direction in Brooklyn on Friday, it is understood. They will take up the electric light combine and may, perhaps, bring out some very interesting matter. Several men deeply interested in this electric light business have skipped, and the subpoena servers have a hard time following their trails.

CHICAGO, April 12.--Civil Service Commissionors Edgerton and Lyman began the investigation of the charges made by George A. Webster against Collector Seeberger yesterday.
Students from the Columbia School of Mines made things very lively at Dockstader's Minstrels last evening. It was a night off for them, and they formed a big party to laugh at and with the minstrels.

Three married sisters. One of them has a Jew for a husband, another a Protestant, and the third a Roman Catholic. They met by appointment at the residence of the latter in Madison-avenue on Easter Sunday night. The Jewess, presiding at the piano, sang, the touching Methodist hymn, "Shall we know each other there?"

The Commissioners of Accounts, at their session Monday, had decided to give the Dock Commissioners a rest for day or two, but suddenly changed their tactics by summoning witnesses to appear before them yesterday afternoon. Simon Stevens, the lawyer, who was accused by George O. Beach of desiring to improperly "size up" the financial necessities of ...

An investigation of the shooting affray which occurred Monday night in Washington Park, at the extreme eastern end of Sixty-ninthstreet, shows that there was a premeditated attempt at murder. Up to the time when the shots were fired the picnic, which was under the auspices of the Shadyside Association, a social organization composed of young working people of the Eighteenth Ward, had proceeded in an orderly manner.

TANGIER, April 12.--The expedition sent out by the American Consul, in furtherance of his efforts to break up the infamous usury system which has grown up in Morocco under the protection of foreign Consuls, has returned to ...

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., April 12.--A curious state of things exists in the Northwest. On its face the inter-State commerce law promised to make the farmer richer. In reality it will force him to the wall. The lowering of local and raising of through rates will not benefit him. The farmer of the Northwest, as a rule, does not stand on his own bottom.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 12.--The State Board of Agriculture is receiving very discouraging reports of the condition of Winter wheat from nearly all parts of the State.

ALBANY, April 12.--The expected veto of the Crosby High License bill reached the Assembly to-night--only eight hours behind the veto of the other bill prohibiting the sale of liquor in the Capitol. It is generally conceded that this has been a great day for run around the Executive Chamber, though a poor one, perhaps, for the present leader of the Democracy of this State.
The trouble in Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, at Astoria, was amicably settled at a meeting of the brethren in the church on Monday night.

MONTREAL, April 12.--The City Council today passed a resolution condemning the Coercion bill now before the British House of Commons. The resolution will be forwarded to Lord Salisbury, and assurances of sympathy will be sent to Mr. Gladstone and Mr. Parnell.

CHICAGO, April 12.--The Illinois and Michigan Canal, as well as all other navigable water ways, will be greatly benefited by the inter-State commerce law. Already boatmen on the canal are beginning to reap the benefits, for ...

DETROIT, Mich., April 12.--Mr. William H.M. Sistare, of New-York, has been in town several days, straightening out the tangled affairs of his branch office here. So quiet has he been about this that it was only yesterday that the newspapers learned positively that he was in town, although they had many reasons to conjecture that such was the case.

REIGLESVILLE, N.J., April 12.--Negotiations are pending between the Reiglesville Delaware Bridge Company, of this place, owners of the wooden structure spanning the Delaware here, and the Durham Iron Company, which, if successful, will result in a new iron bridge across ...

CHARLOTTETOWN, Prince Edward Island, April 12.--A peculiar case of suicide occurred here Saturday. Mrs. Cross, aged 60, who had become insane by bad whisky and grief, has often expressed a wish to die. On Saturday while alone she stuck a poker down her throat and was found on the floor in great agony. She lingered till 4 A.M. on Sunday, dying in great pain.

The fair but wayward Agnes Folsom, wearing a stylish dark suit and a jaunty turban, tapped her small foot impatiently and hummed airs from favorite comic operas in Judge Jones's Broadway office yesterday afternoon pending the disposition of the habeas corpus proceeding instituted by her father to get her home and away from Dr. Cate.

AMSTERDAM, April 12.--The seventieth anniversary of King William's birthday, which fell on Feb. 19 and was then duly observed as a holiday by the people of The Hague, the other capital of Holland, was celebrated here to-day ...

Fifty male lunatics, some of them pretty wild, were transferred from the Flatbush Asylum to the new County Farm at St. Johnland yesterday morning. Superintendent G.N. Ferriss, who had charge of them, took them to the station of the Long Island Railroad on Flatbush-avenue in covered wagons. A special car was waiting and the patients were transferred to it in safety.
The Ladies' Health Protective Association held its regular monthly meeting at the residence of Mrs. Fay Pierce, 31 East Thirty-firststreet, yesterday afternoon.

FALL RIVER, Mass., April 12.--Among the passengers who arrived in this city from New-York on the steamer Pilgrim this morning were two men, each about 35 years of age. One of them was of medium height and wore dark brown clothes, while his companion was of more dignified appearance, tall in stature and apparently a respectable business man.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--Bordley F. Colhoun, son of Rear-Admiral E.R. Colhoun, United States Navy, was married on his deathbed to-day to Eleanor M. Semmes, daughter of a retired grocer of this city. He died a few hours afterward of pneumonia. They had been engaged for three years, and when Colhoun learned that he could not live he had a license procured, and, his affianced being willing, they were immediately united in wedlock.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 12.--At the municipal election to-day the Republicans elected a Police Justice, Constable, and Justice of the Peace, two Supervisors, and two Aldermen, the latter a gain of one. The Democrats elected the City Treasurer, Overseer of the Poor, two Aldermen, and two Supervisors. In the county the Republicans gain three Supervisors, making the board a tie.

BUFFALO, April 12.--Fredonia is a Chautauqua County village, 40 miles from Buffalo, where natural gas was first need in this country many years ago. A well has been going down for some time by the Fredonia Gas, Fuel, and Light Company, and gas was struck this morning at a depth of 2,150 feet, making a showing of 10,000 feet per day at first and steadily increasing as the drill proceeds.

CHICAGO, April 12.--The stove molders strike has extended throughout the entire Fourth District of the Manufacturers' Association. The country is divided into four districts, each having its own officers, and all under the control of a Central Committee, of which Mr. W. H. Cribben is President. The strike in Chicago was made complete to-day when the 60 union molders employed by the Chicago Stove Works quit work.

The election in Jersey City yesterday was for a new County Board of Freeholders, for six of the twelve Aldermen, and three of the six Police and Fire and Board of Works Commissioners respectively. The Labor Party put tickets in ...

ALBANY, April 12.--Our worthy Governor vetoed to-day the bill forbidding the selling of rum in the Capitol restaurant, and immediately after the veto was disposed of a score or more of Assemblymen went out into the restaurant and worshipped at the shrine around which the Governor has thrown his protecting mantle.

WASHINGTON, April 12.--A difference of opinion has arisen between the Collector and the Naval Officer at the Port of New-York in regard to the classification for duty of imported merchandise under the Obereuffer decision.

Judge Potter, of the Supreme Court, has granted to Dorothy G.A. Strenger a limited divorce from Albert Strenger, a liquor dealer at 235 Grand-street. She is a very large woman weighing about 250 pounds, and he, although a good deal smaller in bulk, weighs about 200.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 12.--A fire in St. Augustine this morning destroyed the St. Augustine Hotel, the old Spanish Cathedral, which was the pride of the city and one of the most interesting structures in America, and a number of stores.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 12.--At 7 o'clock this evening in the Moravian Church, Miss Beneigna Magdalene de Schweinitz, daughter of the Right Rev. Edmund De Schweinitz, S.T.D., Senior Bishop of the Moravian Church in America, was married to Franklin Henry Brunner, of Bethlehem. The Rev. Charles B. Shultz was the officiating clergyman. The church decorations consisted of a ...

CHICAGO, April 12.--A ghastly discovery was made by Charles G. Conley, of 132 Adams-street, while hunting about a mile east of Mud Lake, south of this city, yesterday. A skeleton in broadcloth clothes and Grand Army slouch hat was found in a quagmire, where the unfortunate had evidently been smothered to death or stuck in the mud and starved to death.

AUBURN, N.Y., April 12.--Four months ago Francis L. Vincent, of this city, made a desperate attempt at suicide by cutting his throat with a razor and stabbing himself with shears. He was visiting relatives in Rochester at the time.
The possibility of the inter-State commerce law's provisions, securing all travelers the same accommodations, causing trouble in the South, was an interesting subject for the railroad men yesterday.

At the meeting of the Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon a letter was read from a property holder, stating that one result of its deliberations should be to run 50 more trains on the elevated railroad than are at present available for the public.

At 8 o'clock this morning the students of the College of Physicians and Surgeons will meet at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street and will march to their position in the line of march at Columbia College. At the college the Alumni associations will form by classes in Fourth-avenue, north of Forty-ninth-street, ...

A timetable meeting of all the railroads in the country will be held to-day at the Hotel Brunswick. Among reports received will be that of a special committee to fix grain rates for lines west of Pittsburg. Preliminary meetings of Superintendents of various systems centring here were held yesterday to make arrangements for to-day's convention.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 12.--Benjamin F. Glidden, David T. McNamara, and Thomas F. Mulcahey, the three men who were recently convicted of boycotting the Courier and Journal Publishing Company, were brought up in the Superior Court this morning for sentence. They were each fined $50 and costs, the amount aggregating $393, which they paid.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 12.--Two important bills were passed finally in the House of Representatives to-day. The first, the Billingsby bill, makes a reduction of about 25 per cent. in the charges imposed by the pipe line companies on the oil producers for storage, pineage, wastage,

CHICAGO, April 12.--The latest rumor in connection with the much-talked-of wheat deal in this city, is that the persons engineering it have arranged to obtain outside of Chicago all the money they want to carry the scheme through.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12.--The b.c. Ward Gilmore, 2 years, by Leonatus, dam Crescent, by imp. Australian, died here to-night from a ruptured blood vessel. He was owned by James W. Guest, of Danville, Ky.

The Health Department was informed yesterday that a negro miner employed at one of the new aqueduct shafts near Tarrytown was sick with smallpox, and was asked to have the man removed to North Brother Island.

The scandalous facts brought out by the Bacon investigating committee in Brooklyn have given some satisfaction to the original opponents in both parties of the charter under which the affairs of that city are conducted.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 12.--A settlement of the Afghan question has been effected by the Governments of Great Britain and Russia.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 12.--The wholesale arrests of the employes of the Pan Handle Railroad for robbing freight trains continues to be the principal topic of conversation among railroad men and citizens generally.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., April 12.--Edwin B. Bush, a student at the Potsdam Normal School, committed suicide by shooting himself through the head with a pistol about 11 o'clock to-day. Young Bush was the son of E.H. Bush, formerly Cashier of the Black River Bank, in Lowville. No cause is assigned for the act.

Gen. Charles J. Paine, the owner of the Mayflower, remained at the Brevoort House yesterday until afternoon, when he took the 4:30 P.M. train for Boston. While he was here the expected letter from Mr. Tankerville Chamberlayne, owner of the English cutter Arrow, ...

OTTAWA, April 12.--Charles Caron, clerk in the patent branch, Department of Agriculture, has absconded. The amount of has defalcation is not known. Caron is supposed to have gone to the United States. The Government has intrusted the case to Dominion detectives.
BERLIN, April 12.--Gen. Kaulbars, who is en route to St. Petersburg on the way from Vienna, will visit Berlin.

CINCINNATI, April 12.--It is now definitely settled that the centennial exposition to be held here in 1888, to celebrate the hundredth anniversary of the settlement of the State of Ohio, will be situated at and above the Music Hall.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 12.--Edward Burgess, the designer of Gen. Paine's yacht, which is to defend the America's cup against the Thistle was in the city to-day arranging the details for the immediate construction of the craft. A movement is on foot here to present the new yacht with a handsome set of colors in behalf of the city.

CARLISLE, Penn., April 12.--A fireman on the Cumberland Valley Railroad shoveled hot cinders from his engine this afternoon, and set fire to the fields of Christian Eberly, a farmer in this county. The flames spread rapidly, and burned the grass and the fences. It took 30 people to fight it and keep it from the barn buildings which they managed to save.
Major Herman Here Holzborn came to grief yesterday in his suit to recover $15,000 from Nelson Pardee for alienating the affections of Mrs. Holzborn.

Irving Hall was handsomely decorated last evening with bunting, flags, and banners, the latter the property of the "Grips" of the various theatres in this city and Brooklyn.

LOUIS, April 12.--Jay Gould and party left to-night for Kansas City, but the railroad magnate stopped over here long enough to be interviewed regarding the recent franchise granted by the Municipal Assembly to the Bridge and Tunnel Company. LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 12.--Jerry Johnson, Louis Graham, and Alexander Perkins were brought in prisoners from Larne County last night by United States Deputy Marshals C. McDonald and Wiseman for violating the internal revenue laws.
SCRANTON, Penn., April 13.--An acrimonious fight is in progress here between the Women's Christian Temperance Union and the liquor sellers.

GUAYMAS, Mexico, April 13.--Cajene Yaqui the Indian chief, was captured yesterday by Gen. Martinez at a ranch 10 miles from Guaymas, where he had been hiding for two months. His capture ends the war between the Yaquis and Mexicans which has been waged in Sonora for two years.

ST. Louis, Mo., April 13.--Judge Barclay, in the Circuit Court, rendered an important decision to-day, overruling the motion of the NewYork Central Sleeping Car Company in the suit of a man named Root against the company.

In some way word got to the ears of Capt. John Brennan, of the Brooklyn Police, that there was to be a prize fight in the Seawanhaka Boat Club house, at the foot of South Tenth-street, on Tuesday night.

Assemblyman Frank M. McDermitt, of Newark, was married yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Newark, to Miss Jennie Welsh. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Coone. Sheriff N.H. Brown was the best man. After a wedding breakfast the bride and groom left for Washington.

In the Harlem Court yesterday Justice Welde refused to issue a warrant for Contractor Parkins, who was engaged in building cellars in One Hundred and Thirty-seventh-street and drew money to pay the men. This money he is said to have run away with, but Justice Welde decided that Parkins had come into possession of it honestly and could not be accused of stealing from a partner.

FARIBAULT, Minn., April 13.--Forty delegates representing smaller towns of Minnesota are assembled here for the purpose of devising plans for the enforcement of the provisions of the inter-State commerce law. The organization as effected this morning, declares that the body shall be known as the Minnesota Business Men's Association.
CINCINNATI, April 13.--The stockholders of the Cincinnati, Washington and Baltimore Railroad Company held their annual meeting here to-day.

The Senate committee having in charge the investigation of the question of undervaluation of dutiable imported goods have practically completed their inquiries and decided on the lines on which they will construct a remedial measure.

Nearly 100 railroad Superintendents and General Managers met in the ballroom of the Hotel Brunswick yesterday to hold their general time convention, which meets twice in every year to settle questions involved in the practical management of the roads.

The laundry at the Sing Sing Prison was completely gutted by fire yesterday morning, and only its four brick walls are left. The exact cause of the fire is not known, but from all that the authorities can learn it originated in the east drying room.
The centennial evening reception of Columbia College was held last evening, and was attended by more than a thousand people.

The work of erecting the Carnegie Library in Allegheny was about to be commenced when it was discovored that it would be impossible to complete the building in accordance with the present elaborate plans and have the outlay come within the sum given by Mr. Carnegie for the purpose.

The Metropolitan Transit Company, which seeks to build an elevated railroad through Broadway, was again before Judge Donohue in the Supreme Court, Chambers, yes terday, and again won a victory in the preliminary legal skirmishes.

WHEELING, West Va., April 13.--A construction train on the Ohio River Railroad jumped the track at Willow Grove, near Parkersburg, to-night, wrecking the engine and nine cars, and killing three men and wounding eight or ten others, several of them fatally.
VIENNA, April 13.--The new turret barbette ironclad Kronz Prinzessin Erzherzogin Stephanic will be launched at San Rocco tomorrow.

BOSTON, April 13.--The following public bequests have been made according to the will of the late Denis H. Tully: To the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Cross, $10,000, to be used in reducing the debt thereon; to the Archbishop and his successors, $10,000, to be applied and devoted to ...

WHEELING, West Va., April 13.--A United States Board of Engineers, consisting of Col. Merrill and Major Post, of Cincinnati, and Col. Craighhill, of Baltimore, will sit at Charleston to-morrow, and at Point Pleasant on the succeeding day, to take testimony regarding the proposed railroad bridges across the great Kanawha at those points.
LONDON, April 13.--Lord Hartington will return to London especially to vote for the second reading of the Coercion bill.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13.--The ferryboat Atantic, owned by the Cooper's Point Ferry Company, was almost totally destroyed by fire while tied up at the freight wharf at Cooper's Point (Camden) tonight. The loss will be about $30,000, which is fully covered by insurance.

TRENTON, N.J., April 13.--The Democratic League, of Trenton, tendered a reception to Gov. Green in Masonic Temple to-night. The affair was slimly attended, and the absence of Irish Americans was a noticeable feature.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 13.--A recount of the votes cast yesterday will be neces sary before it can be determied who is Mayor of this city, William S. Strong or Frank L. Janeway.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13.--The rare collection of animals at the Zoological Garden was to-day enriched by two specimens which, if they live, will enjoy the proud distinction of having no counterparts in this country.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 13.--The House Committee on Railroads to-day adopted a report as a result of its investigations into the alleged violations of the State Constitution by the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, and will present it to-morrow.

TEXARKANA, Texas, April 13.--It is very seldom that the killing of one, two, or even three men by an expert pistol practitioner creates more than a passing comment in the land where the long and short haul of the revolver is so strikingly illustrated.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 13.--Referring to the report that the steamship Gulnare is on the Irish coast with a cargo of dynamite, it may be proper to state that the original and only Gulnare is now in the fruit trade between this port and the Bay Islands.

MARTINSVILLE, Ind., April 13.--Dr. R.H. Williams, who was recently appointed Postmaster at Cope, Ind., has become disgusted with the position and forwarded his resignation to the PostmasterGeneral. He assigns as a reason for his action that the pay of the office is inadequate to the labor and responsibility.
ELMIRA, N.Y., April 13.--The village of Barton, Tioga, County, was the scene of an accident about 5 o'clock this afternoon, by which three persons were instantly killed.

At a meeting of the Board of Trade and Transportation held yesterday afternoon resolutions were read favoring the adoption of the Field Civil Code, now before the Legislature. F.B. Thurber thought that the board ought to hesitate before indorising any specific codification.

It was under date of March 9, writing from San Francisco, that Mr. E.J. Baldwin said: "I will run (Volante) a match with Montana Regent or any other horse after the Latonia meeting in June for $10,000 or more, the distance to be one and a half miles, play or pay, half forfeit."
BOSTON, Mass., April 13.--At a meeting of the Overseers of Harvard College to-day, the Hon. Charles R. Codman was chosen President of the board.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 13.--The schooner Scylla, of Lunenburg, Nova, Scotia, has been seized here for an alleged infringement of the fishery laws. The Scylla is engaged in fishing and trading. She got in here on Good Friday from New-York with a cargo or corn.

John Code, of the late firm of Thompson Code, jewelers, of Elm-place and Fulton-street, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on the charge of having given Wililiam S. Rosenfield, a Maidenlane jeweler, a worthless cheek.

The Brewers' Association held a very long meeting yesterday at the headquarters, 2 Irving-place. Hill was declared to be a truly good fellow, a Democrat to the backbone, and deserving of their admiration.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 13.--The forthcoming sale of the property and franchises of the Pennsylvania, Slatington and New-England Railroad is an event of much interest to the people of the section concerned in the future of the enterprise.

The strike of stove molders which has been spreading over the West promises to extend throughout the entire country within 10 days or a fortnight and it is possible that the manufacturers may forestall the men and declare a lockout.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 13, via Galeston.--Mr. T.B. Connery, the newly appointed Secretary of the United States Legation here has arrived at Vera Cruz.

The centenary of Columbia was celebrated yesterday with spirit as well as with dignity. The recent and memorable celebration of Harvard has deprived this of some of the claims to public interest it world otherwise have possessed.

BALTIMORE, April 13.--The Baltimore and Ohio deal seoms to hang fire after the most reliable assurances that it was consummated two weeks ago. Just what its present status is no one seems to know, and interest in it has almost died out.

BALTIMORE, April 13.--A steamer arrived today from the Rappahannock River, Virginia, reports the destruction of the village of Farnham by fire on Monday last.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 13.-The first session of the sixth Parliament of Canada opened do-day, Lieut.-Col. Ouimet was unanimously chosen Speaker. The House then adjourned until to-morrow when the members will visit the Senate to learn why Parliament was assembled.

Thomas M. Doremus is a Wall-street young man whom the Stock Exchange Governors have been disciplining for a year or so. Young Mr. Doremus is the son of Prof. Doremus, the chemist, and altogether as amiable and nice in young man as often ventures down into Wallstreet.

CORYDON, Ind., April 7.--Dr. D.S. Fisher of Valley City, this county, has for some time past been corresponding with a firm of alleged attorneys in New-York with a view to recovering his interest in a large estate in Germany, to which the attorneys discovered the doctor was entitled.

The Democrats in Jersey City gained control of the Board of Aldermen and the Board of Police Commissioners at the election on Tuesday, lost the Board of Fire Commissioners and the Board of Works, which they had controlled, and increased their majority in the County Board of Freeholders.

The Phelps Induction Telegraph Company and the Railway Telegraph and Telephone Company have consolidated under the name of the Consolidated Railway Telegraph Company, with a capital stock of $2,500,000.
MINNEAPOLIS, April. 13.--A divorce suit has been instituted in the District Court which beings to light some romantic and interesting facts regarding the persons involved.

WASHINGTON, April 13.--The Senate Finance Committee's sub-committee to examine into the undervaluation of imports sat until late this afternoon and devoted the time to analyzing the information they have received bearing upon the subject of their inquiry.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 13.--Yesterday the two great copper ore companies that own the Lake Superior copper mines and control the markets of the world in this article secured an act of incorporation from the Legislature for a joint smelting company to be called the Calumet and Hecla Smelting Company, with headquarters in Waterbury, Conn.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 13.--Burrillville today elected a Republican Senator and one Republican Representative and failed of an election for one Representative. The Senate is now complete and stands--Republicans, 29; Democrats, 16. The House stands--Republicans, 29; Democrats, 41; Prohibitionist, 1, and 1 yet to be elected.

The one hundredth consecutive performance of "The Taming of the Shrew," which occurred last night, passed off--as passes off everything at Daly's--quietly. No red fire was burned and the managerial trumpet was not flourished. And yet the event was a very notable one in the history of the American stage.
Gore has been party disabled by a lame arm since his first game on the Polo Grounds, but it is now much improved.

A man was found dead in bed yesterday morning in the lodging house 89 Bowery. He had 10 cents when he entered on Tuesday night, and had mailed a letter to Miss Jennie Haley, of 44 Seventh-avenue. Before retiring he told a fellow-lodger to had not eaten food in eight days.
LONDON, April 13.--The Rev. Dr. Joseph Parker, Pastor of the City Temple, states that he is almost certain he will accept the proffered honor of delivering the eulogy on the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher.

At the annual meeting of the Canadian Club, which occurred last evening at the clubhouse, 12 East Twenty-ninth-street, officers were elected for the coming year.

The steel cruiser Atlanta left the Navy Yard about 6 o'clock yesterday morning for a trial cruise in the Sound. On board were Engineers Loring, Howell, Harris, Kearney, Webster, and Allison, who had been sent from Washington to examine the working of her engines. A speed of 15 knots an hour and a horse power of 3,500 will be required of the cruiser.

CARLISLE, Penn., April 13.--The Boswell case is being watched here with the most intense interest, and the pending trial will probably attract more people to the court room that it has held for years.
The baseball nines of the Classes of '87 and '88 of Columlia, College will play at the Polo Grounds this morning.

CHICAGO, April 13.--Dr. C.W. Bennett, of the Garrett Biblical Institute, at Evanston, Ill., was questioned to-day regarding the purchase of the great Von Ranke historical library, which was accomplished through him, for Syracuse University.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 13.--Thomas W. Keene, the tragedian, appeared here in Music Hall this evening in "Hamlet" for first time since his illness, lasting 15 months. He was greeted by a very large and appreciative audience. He seems to have gained additional strength and vigor as an actor in his retirement, and never appeared to better advantage in his many performances in this city.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 13.--A colored Baptist evangelist by the name of Williams, who has been holding revival meetings in De Soto, Mo., among his colored brethren, was taken from his house by five masked men last night and unmercifully beaten with hickory switches. He says they took turns and kept up the flogging for an hour.

CINCINNATI, April 13.--The jury in the case of John B. Mannix, formerly Assignee of Archbishop Purcell, after remaining out 30 hours, reported a disagreement and were discharged.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 13.--The Memphis and Little Rock Road was sold to-day and was bidden in for the Dow party, the present controllers of the road, for $72,530.

LONDON, April 13.--The steamship Marengo, (Br.,) Capt. Abbott, from New-York March 27, for Hull, passed the Seilly Islands to-day. The steamship Slavonia, (Ger.,) Capt. Schmidt, from New York March 30, for Copenhagen and Stettin, passed Dunnet Head to-day.

CINCINNATI, April 13.--The new oil fields of Northwestern Ohio are traversed by the Miami and Erie Canal. The product of the wells can be brought here very cheaply, and an interesting question is being discussed in that connection in business circles.

In the suit of Matthew H. Maynard, Assignee, against Andrew H. Green and other Executors of Samuel J. Tilden, Judge Shipman, of the United States Circuit Court, handed down a decision yesterday. The decree results from litigation pending in the Federal courts for some time.

John Greenwall, the burglar who is charged with the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, in Brooklyn, was taken to Police Headquarters in that city yesterday, and all the detectives brought in to look at him. None of them had ever seen him before.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 13.--There is now another point of railroad practice under the inter-State commerce law to settle. The Buffalo railroad ticket brokers have not been inactive since the law went into effect, and have pushed for an interpretation of an important question to them.

LANSING, Mich., April 13.--Fifty Republican members of the Senate and House met in cancus last night to take counsel on liquor legistation. The sense of the caucus was that the Committee on Liquor Traffic should prepare a bill for high license ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 13.--Col. L.C. Galoway this afternoon disposed of his half interest in the Daily Appeal, and will retire permanently from journalism after 50 years' active service, 17 of it on the Appeal.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 13.--Julia Lawton, or Mihna, the woman who was arrested on Monday charged with being implicated in causing the fire which resulted in the cremation of Matthew Massock and three children at Meyer's Point, this county ...
Mr. Wilson Barrett revived "Claudian" at the Star Theatre last evening, and that picturesque, romantic play of Messrs. Wills and Herman may be seen there again to-night. It is worth seeing.
PARIS, April 13.--A dispatch from Dieppe says the packet steamer Victoria is ashore on the rocks near that city. She stranded during a log.

George Brunswick, a Philadelphia bartender, shot himself in Central Park March 7 and recovered. Yesterday in the Court of General Sessions he pleaded guilty to attempted suicide, with the pro viso, however, that it "was not quite his intention to kill himself," and Judge Gildersleeve sent him to prison for 30 days.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 13.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

DENVER, Col., April 13.--Rain has been falling here for the last two days. Reports received show that the rainfall is general throughout the State. The rain is of the greatest value to the farmers who have been ready for the Spring plowing some time, but have ...
M.D. Carrington, of Toledo, Ohio, a member of the New-York Produce Exchange, died March 22 at Marseilles, France, and the occurrence promises to cause a fuss in the gratuity fund of the Exchange.

All who speak or pray in public would do well to look closely into the words they use, and ascertain just how many pet phrases they have. One Pastor was noticed never to use the word prosperity without adding "perfection and glory."

The business of real estate conveyancing is very seriously embarrassed. Many hundreds of thousands of dollars are lying idle and all because, according to the numerous complaints, the present Register's financial ambitions as a citizen are not adequately requited by his salary as an official.
QUEENSTOWN, April 13.--The arrivals here of emigrants on their way to the United States are at present enormous. The railways are running special trains to accommodate this class of travel.

RICHMOND, Va., April 13.--On July 3, the twenty-fourth anniversary of the battle of Gettysburg, the survivors of Pickett's Virginia division, which took such a conspicuous part in that conflict, will erect a monument to mark the point where they made the most gallant ...

ST. PAUL., Minn., April 13.--Considerable mystery surrounds the supposed relations between Chester W. Greene, the burglar shot at Jamestown, N.Y., Friday night, and the two girls, Lillie and Katie Davey, concerning whose departure from Rochester for Windom. Minn., a memorandum was found in his diary.
PITTSBURG, Penn., April 13.--The accomplices of the railroad thieves are resorting to threats to intimidate the Pan Handle Railroad officials.
An entertainment will be given at the Madison-Square Theatre next Monday evening to help swell the fund now being raised for the Masonic Asylum.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13.--The threemasted schooner, Parker M. Hooper, Capt. John Harkness, which, in company with the schooner Gertrude Abbott, left Havana for this port Feb. 26, has never been heard from, and it is believed she foundered in a gale.
ALBANY, April 13.--In the most perfunctory manner the Republicans of the Assembly dragged forth their bill for a Constitutional Convention to-day.
CHICAGO, April 13.--Judge T.M. Cooley, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, is in the city engaged in settling up his accounts as Receiver of the Wabash Railway.

At the session of the New-York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Mount Vernon, yesterday, Rufus T. Cooper, Edward R. Foley, Charles Paulson, Odell H. Smith, William E. Smith, and Edward O. Tree were admitted on trial, and the Rev. Drs. M.L. Scudder, L.S. Stowe, and R.H. Loomis were put upon the superannuated list.

A man in a white jacket, greatly excited, ran into the Nineteenth Precinct Station House at 8 o'olock last night and begged earnestly that an ambulance be sent to the Paisley House, at Twenty-eighth-street and Sixth-avenue, as a woman bad poisoned herself there. He then rushed away.
MISSOULA, Montana, April 13.--The city jail was fired from the inside early this morning, in an unknown manner. A man named Chambers, who was confined for vagrancy, was burned to death.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 13.--Advices from different sections in Texas note the fall of copious rains for 300 miles along the Texas and Pacific Railroad ...

PHILADELPHIA, April 13.--The bulletin of the American Iron and Steel Association in its issue to-day calls attention to the continued heavy importations of iron and steel and adds: "This is a serious business and in more respects than one.

The sale of the art collection of Asher B. Durand, National Academician, deceased, was begun at Ortgies Co.'s galleries, 845 and 847 Broadway, last evening, by order of the Executors of his estate. The first evening's lot comprised engravings by himself and several other prominent artists and ...

MILWAUKEE, April 13.--Goodrich Wagner, successors to Ball Goodrich, the oldest wholesale grocery house in Milwaukee, made a voluntary assignment to-day to B.K. Miller, who furnished bonds in the sum of $170,000.

The Metropolitan Opera House was crowded to its utmost capacity last night when Mme. Patti and Mme. Scalchi appeared together once more in their remarkable performance of Semiramis and Arsace in Rossini's opera Semiramide."

TRENTON, N.J., April 13.--Gov. Green made the following appointments to-day: For Prosecutor of the Pleas in Monmouth County, Charles Haight; for Lay Judge in Morris County, Charles H. Munson; for Judge of the District Court in Paterson, Frank Van Cleve; for Trustee of the State Reform School for Boys, Patrick Farrelly, of Jersey City.

HARTFORD, Conn., April 14.--The first phase of the fight to remove the Storrs Agricultural School (the gift of Augustus Storrs, of Brooklyn, N. Y.) from Mansfield to Wallingford was decided to-day in the Senate in favor of Mansfield. The vote was one of reference to the Appropriations Committee. Of $26,000 for a permanent building $12,000 are asked for investigating the pollution of streams by the State Board of Health.

UTICA, N.Y., April 14.--The examination of Chael Roark, the alleged West shore express robber, charged with assaulting Express Messenger Carlos S. Leake with a deadly weapon and robbing the National Express Company, took place to-day before City Judge Bulger.

Lots of indignation was shown in Wallstreet yesterday. The Governors of the Stock Exchange, in whitewashing Henry S. Ives, stirred up a lively storm. Nowhere was their action approved; everywhere in Wall-street criticisms that were severe along with well developed sneers were to be heard.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--The President to-day appointed Andrew A. Slosson to be Postmaster at Waverly, N.Y., vice Charles C. Brooks, removed, and William J. Phillips at Wolcott, N.Y., vice Stephen E. Bullock, commission expired.

A dispatch from Washington says that President Cleveland yesterday pardoned Eugene B. Walton, who was serving a sentence of five years in Sing Sing for having made false entries while Teller in the First National Bank, in this city.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 14.--Gov. Desvoenx has been called home to give evidence, it is said, in connection with the bait question. He leaves for London by way of Halifax per steamer Portia to-morrow. Today a rumor is current to the effect that he will be appointed Governor of Mauritius, and that Sir Ambrose Shea will succeed him in the Governorship of Newfoundland.

"Faust" is the opera at the Metropolitan Opera House this evening, and Del Puente will make his first appearance this season, singing Valentine. Mme. Patti will of course be the Marguerite, Vicini the Faust, Mme. Scalchi the Liebel, Mlle. Valerga the Martha, and Signor Novarra the Mephistopheles.

The following condemed Government vessels, which had been stripped in Port Washington harbor, were sold at auction at Great Neck, Long Island, yesterday: Congress, $7,800; Ohio, $7,400; Worcester, $5,500; Shawmut, $2,050; Roanoke, $9,350; Susquehana, $4,500; Savannah, $5,650. The first five were bought by Gen. D.W. Richards and the others by Stannard Culley, of Philadelphia.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 14.--D.M. Garson Co. ago merchants doing a large retail business in the boot and shoe and ready-made clothing trades, and occupy a large store on Main-street, a few doors from the Post Office entrance. For some time past the firm has suspected that it was being systematically robbed of goods.

ST. PAUL'S--Glen Cove, Long Island.--Wardens James B. Pearsall, William Eastment. Vestrymen --Samuel C. Frost, E.M. Lincoln, Madison Ham, James Luyster. Jr.; George F. Valeutine. Wilmot T. Cox, James Townsend, William C. Frost.

BOSTON, April 14.--Desiger Burgess returned from Wilmington. Del., to-day, and for the first time was enabled to look over the original conditions of Mr. Tankerville Chamberlayne for the Mayflower-Arrow race.

A numerous audience gathered at the Phelps Mission last night upon the occasion of a convention of those social and charitable associations of this vicinity which find their motive in the Rev. Dr. E.E. Hale's little book, "Ten Times One is Ten."

CLEVELAND, April 14.--Like many of its neighbors Cleveland began preparing for a boom some time before the inter-State commerce law became effective. Without knowing exactly why, except that he understood the law was to be in a general way unfavorable to railroad interests and beneficial to all other interests, the ...

The boldness of the attempt made by the Metropolitan Transit Company to grab Broadway for an elevated railway structure was, until a very few days ago, a strong point in favor of the success of the scheme.

Sanderson Son, the agents of the disabled steamship Salerno, of the Hull Line, about which some uneasiness has been felt, received a cable dispatch yesterday that she was sighted on April 4 in latitude 45 and longitude 35 , and again on April 7 in latitude 47 and longitude 27 .

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 14.--The Dominion Parliament opened to-day. The GovernorGeneral, in his speech from the throne, congratulated Parliament on the general prosperity of the country and on the prospect of a coming season of peace and progress.

The Alumni of the Homeopathic Medical College had their annual dinner list evening at Delmonico's. It was a jolly crowd of homeopaths which gathered around the handsomely arranged tables, and among them were some who could lay no claim to the title of M.D.

The four sawdust men, Joseph Little, William J. Beecher, Joseph W. Lawson, and George Blotts, whom Capt. Killilea arrested at 332 West Fortyseventh-street on Wednesday, were arraigned before Commissioner Shields yesterday.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 14.--The weather today was cloudy and warm and threatened rain. There was a good attendance at the races. The track was dusty. Following were the events:

Major Herman Hero Holzborn is still languishing in Ludlow-Street Jail, and Judge Bookstaver says that he will continue to languish until he delivers to Cornelius J. Kane, the Receiver of his property, on Lawyer Louis J. Grant's judgment against him, the "presentation sword with a gold handle studded with gems, and a silver seaboard, worth $350," ...

The steel cruiser Atlanta, which left the navy yard for a trial trip up the Sound Wednesday morning, arrives off the yard near daybreak yesterday. Capt. Bunce was very reluctant to make any definite statement with regard to whether the cruiser had made the required speed of 15 knots per hour and had shown an indicated 3,500 horse power.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 14.--The body of Abraham Lincoln was to-day removed from the spot where it has been secreted since an attempt was made in 1878 to steal it, and placed in a new tomb.

OMAHA, Neb., April 14.--The National Opera Company returned to Omaha last night, and at 10 o'clock to-night are still here. After leaving this city Manager Locke was informed by telegraph that the Central Pacific had annulled his special baggage contract, and on account of the inter-State ...

BALTIMORE, April 14.--At a meeting of the Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal to-day it was determined to reduce the tolls on coal from 40 to 36 cents from Cumberland to Georgetown and Washington. On coal east-bound or coastwise the toll is reduced from 38 to 34 cents.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 14.--Some time ago the Grand Lodge of Connecticut ordered Hiram Lodge, No. 1, of this city, the oldest Masonic lodge in the State, to change from its ancient style of secret work, and adopt the so-called "new work."

ALBANY, April 14.--Both houses considered to-day measures allowing the licensing of reputable places in New-York and Brooklyn where vocal or instrumental concerts are given. Senator worth was the author of the measure discussed in the upper house and Assemblyman Cantor of the one that came up in the lower.

Ought further restrictions to be imposed on immigration? The careful consideration of this question in and out of Congress cannot long be deferred. Recent events in this country and the prospect that an enormous number of immigrants will seek our shores this year serve to give it some prominence now.

The vigorous letter of the Mayor to the President of the Board of Police, taken in connection with the improvements in the method of removing ashes and garbage, indicates that at some day not unimaginably remote the streets of this city may actually be cleaned and kept clean.

The "Dandy Seventh" was out in the panoply of peace last evening. It had on its steel-pen coat, pale necktie, and company smile. The occasion was the benefit at the Academy of Music to endow cots for militiamen the Hahnemann Hospital.

COMMONS, Ottawa, April 14.--Col. Herchiner, Commissioner of the Northwest Mounted Police, has arrived here. Speaking of the alleged depredations of Canadian redskins south of the boundary line in Montana, he said only six Canadian blood Indians are off their reservation at present.

Business was rushed through at the Time Table Convention of the railroad men at the Hotel Brunswick yesterday, and when the adjournment was reached the members felt proud that they had disposed of all the matters that came before them in two days. There was a large attendance, and the questions settled were of great interest to railroad men all over the country.

LONDON, April 14.--The language used by Mr. Chamberlain in speaking at meetings in Ayr has inflamed the Irish against him, and he has received numerous letters warning him that he will not leave Scotland alive.
The following epistolary emanations from the fertile and ever-working brain of Mayor Hewitt explain theselves:
George H. Disque, who cut his wife's throat from ear to ear after a quarrel at his home, in Hoboken, in October, 1885, was sentenced, for the second time, to be hanged by Judge Knapp yesterday.

There is a movement among insurance men to put the Tariff Association again on a sound footing. To that end a number of brokers propose to organize a company to be known as the Alliance, which shall turn all the business it can solicit into the companies forming the Tariff Association and shall in turn be patronized by the members of the association to the exclusion of other brokers.
LONDON, April 14.--Further particulars of the loss near Dieppe of the Newhaven and Dieppe packet Victoria show that the vessel struck the rocks amidships.

Coroner Eidman began an inquest yesterday into the case of the four men who were killed on March 8 by falling from the elevated railroad on Third-avenue, near the Fourteenthstreet station, during a blockade caused by a fire in the Bowery.

CHICAGO, April 14.--The announcement shortly after noon yesterday that the Washington-street jewelry house of Clapp Davies had failed created no little excitement among the agents of Eastern firms, who were, with scarcely an exception, drawn into the long list of creditors, whose name is legion.
Emil H. Kosmak, who keeps the hotel without beds at the bridge entrance, says that never again will he send money to Aldermen or any one else for the purpose of betting on horse races.

ALBANY, April 14.--The Broadway property owners have finally become thoroughly alarmed over the prospect of the erection of an elevated railroad along that thoroughfare, and to-day, not an hour too late, began to enter their protests.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 14.--At Association Course this morning Poteen, a prominent Kentucky Derby candidate, bled freely from the lungs while being worked a mile and a quarter with Montrose immediately after passing the five-eighths pole.
An explosion in the torpedo factory of Nelson Klucher, on Eldert-avenue, Brooklyn, caused a fire at 8:30 o'clock last evening, in which a man lost his life.

The Queens County Circuit Court was occupied yesterday in the trial of the suit brought by F.L. Fisk against the cathedral corporation at Garden City to recover back salery and damages for being ousted from St. Paul's School, where he had been employed as steward and head bookkeeper.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, April 14.--Blair Co., private bankers, have made an assignment. The firm suspended at the time of the Maritime Bank's failure. It is feared that the assignment will bring disaster on other business people of this city.

It was a very busy day yesterday at the Rahway morgue, a number of people calling to identify the murdered girl. Those who could give anything approaching a description of the body lying in the upper room of the building were admitted, but none of them were able to do more than the scores who had gone before them.

At the regular meeting of the Union League Club last night it was expected that some definite action would be taken by the members on the recent veto by Gov. Hill of the High License bill. There was a sort of tacit expectation that some ironclad resolutions would be adopted. Nothing of the sort, however, was done, and the meeting was a very quiet one.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 14.--A gift of $25,000 from some source that is not as yet made public has been made to the law department of Yale College. It is to be used for the furtherance of the study of contracts and commercial law, and the fund is to be known as the Phelps Fund, it being named after Prof. Phelps, now United States Minister to England ...

The attempt to force Dr. R.F. Leighton out of his position as Principal of the Brooklyn Central Grammar School developed yesterday into a personal matter between Dr. Leighton and Postmaster Hendrix, who is Chairman of the Central Grammar School Committee of the Board of Education.

DETROIT, Mich., April 14.--The big stove molders' strike in St. Louis and Chicago is traveling East with rapid strides. It reached Detroit to-day. Devlin Assembly No. 3,954, Knights of Labor, is composed almost entirely of stove molders, and has a membership of over ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 14.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
CARLISLE, Penn., April 14.--The body of an unknown man was found dead last night on the road between Yorkana and Wrightsville.

Nearly 2,000 persons met last night at Grand Army Hall, on Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District, to express their sympathy for Dr. Edward McGlynn. Among them were many ladies, who applauded every mention of Dr. McGlynn's name. Mr. Thomas S. Gill, the Chariman ...

WASHINGTON, April 14.--The resignation of Capt. John J. Kane, Assistant Surgeon, has been accepted, to take effect April 13. First Lient. F.E. Phelps, Eighth Cavalry, has been detached as inspector on certain recruiting property at Lexington, Ky. Ordnance Sergeant John Barr has been placed on the retired list.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14.--Harry G. Roop, Harry J. Senay, and Harry A. Chesley, the "dive" keepers convicted of keeping disorderly houses, and Elizabeth Mettler, who pleaded guilty of keeping a disreputable house, were to-day sentenced by Judge Gordon to the full extent of the law.

BOSTON, April 14.--Mrs. Howe's famous Woman's Bank or Ladies' Deposit is again brought into public notice, but the eminent financier who deludes poor women with her glamor of 8 per cent. interest per month has eluded a warrant issued for her arrest this morning and left for parts unknown.

Pictures of ancient Greece adorned the walls of the bid banquet room of the Hotel Brunswick last night, and a large framed oil painting representing "The ruins of the Parthenon at Athens," and loaned by Morris K, Jesup, was in the centre of the long dining table.

ST. JOHN'S, New foundland, April 14.--A terrific gale raged along the west coast of this island all Tuesday and yesterday, causing serious loss of life and great destruction of property. Near Rose Blanche two large skiffs, one belonging to Petites, ...
ST. LOUIS, April 14.--A sensational, revelation was made in the Federal court to-day by William Bergesch, a witness in the case of Deputy Recorder Thomas J.Mallory, on trial for election frauds.

Brooklyn's opinion of the Irish Coercion bill was emphatically manifested last night in the Academy of Music. Every seat was occupied, and a fringe of strong, healthy Irishmen reached around the interior and did not grow tired as speech piled upon speech. Rounds of applause followed each other as waves on a mighty ocean.

Ministers and laymen of all denominations sat behind a bank of lilies on the platform of the Brooklyn Tabernacle last evening and faced several thousand persons who had come to say good-bye to the Rev. Chickering Hall was very comfortably filled yesterday afternoon at the twenty-seventh annual Commencement of the New-York Homeopathic Medical College.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday requested the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund to lease the buildings on Ward's Island for the use of the insane under the charge of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction.

DENVER, Col., April 14.--A special dispatch from Buena Vista says: "A rock slide occurred today in a deep cut on the work of Kyner, Higbee Bernard on the Midland grade near this place. Several men were killed, and Mr. Bernard was badly injured. The full extent of the disaster cannot be learned at this time.
Pursuant to public notice Controller Loew was ready at noon yesterday to sell at public auction two surface railroad franchises under the amended Cantor act.

During the first week of April the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad earned $36,698, an increase of $13,065; St. Paul and Duluth, $26,724, an increase of $3,644; Wisconsin Central, $38,145, an increase of $8,288; Wheeling and Lake Erie, $13,678, an increase of $4,363; since Jan.1, $177,314, an increased $36,886; Chicago and West Michigan, $23,619, a decrease of $605.

The quarterly meeting of the Trustees of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company, held yesterday afternoon at 155 Broadway, was disturbed by a decapitation. The victim whose head was practically chopped off is none other than the redoubtable P. B. Armstrong, whose services as Secretary ...

The price of ice in Brooklyn during the coming Summer will not be materially changed from the rates charged a year ago. The Retail Ice Dealers' Association has issued this schedule: Families, 15 pounds daily, 70 cents a week; 20 pounds, 80 cents a week; 25 pounds and upward, 50 cents per 100 pounds; storekeepers, 30 cents per 100 pounds.
The flag for the Hawaiian Navy has been designed by Mrs. Strong, and contains in the centre, on a white background, a gold crown resting on a yellow shield.

A Kingston woman attended Conference yesterday afternoon, and she heard a number of the addresses. When she returned home she said to her husband: "I have made up my mind that women will never make good jurors.

Otto White's counsel said he did not kill Louisa Wolff and did not wound his stepmother. The prosecution claimed that he did both. One side trusted to an alibi and the other to disproving it. Both sides admitted that it was murder in the first degree or innocence. The jury decided last night that it was neither.

The young Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District have been incorporated as the Federal Club, with the following gentlemen as Trustees: Edward F. Brown, President; James H. Phipps, Secretary; John H. Guion, Treasurer; Edward ...

Mr. JOHN G. CARLISLE has been making another brave speech to his friends down at Covington, Ky. With the utmost respect for the Speaker of the House, we take the liberty of suggesting to him that his acts do not compare favorably with his speeches.

The death of Alfred Torrance, the well known gentleman rider, at Paris, on Tuesday, was discussed in most of the up-town clubs yesterday by his numerous friends. Mr. Torrance was riding in a steeplechase handicap at Croix de Berny, in the suburbs of Paris, a few miles from the Bois de Boulogne.

CHICAGO, April 14.--The report to-day that a vessel had been chartered to bring a cargo of wheat from Milwaukee to this city and that the charter had been canceled on the ground that storage could not be obtained created a sensation in the wheat market.
Ferdinand P. Earle, Treasurer of the Citizens' Auxiliary Committee for the observance of Decoration Day, has received these subscriptions:

On March 15, 1886, E.H. Abbott, Supreme Secretary of the Order of the Royal Templars of Temperance, Buffalo, New-York, made application to the American Surety Company, of NewYork, for a bond of $10,000 to secure the Order for any dishonest act of his as such Secretary.
READING, Penn., April 14.--Miss Sallie Sperling, a prepossessing country girl, of Salisbury, aged 19, walked several miles to the farm where her lover, Ambrose Henninger, was employed.

Queen Kapiolani, it is announced now, will sail on the 16th of April on her intended visit to Europe. It is said the Queen will be accompanied by Mrs. Iaukea. Col. J.H. Boyd will also accompany the Queen as secretary.

Cable dispatches cheered up the Wallstreet bull heart yesterday by announcing that the Bank of England had reduced its rate of discount to 2 per cent. Large orders came from London to buy stocks in this market, one Wall-street firm declaring last night that over 50,000 shares of American securities passed into English ownership yesterday.

The Rev. Mr. Hopper, a missionary attached to St. Barnabas's mission in Mulberrystreet, on one of his recent visits to the workhouse on Blackwell's Island had his attention directed by the Matron to a Hungarian woman, who had been committed to that institution as a vagrant.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--Secretary Whitney to-day awarded to the Bethlehem Iron Works Company, of Pennsylvania, the contracts for furnishing about 1,400 tons of steel gun forgings and 4,500 tons of steel armor plates, at a total cost of $4,512,938.29.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 14.--As predicted, the Grand Jury before whom the charge of perjury against Prosecuting Attorney Huling, in drawing the warrant for the arrest of Dr. C.R. Montgomery, was considered, reported that the evidence did not sustain the charges, and no indictment was found. Mr. Huling will now resume his duties and make another attempt to solve the tally-sheet forgery cases.

The second name between the Boston League Club and the Brooklyns at Washington Park yesterday was a fine exhibition of ball playing, and apparently the 1,700 poople present thought so. Stemmeyer pitched and Tate caught for the Bostons, and Henderson and O'Brien did the battery work for Brooklyn.

Register Slevin yesterday sent to Mayor Hewitt a communication in reference to the charges that he has failed to properly facilitate the work of getting out searches, and at the meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment the matter was referred to Controller Loew for examination. The register complained...

ATLANTA, Ga., April 14.--The trouble over the enforcement of the prohibition law has resulted in a raid upon the drug stores. The law forbids these stores selling liquor even on physicians' prescriptions, but allows the sale of pure alcohol for scientific and mechanical purposes.

Louis Adler, one of the solicitors for the Consolidated Telegraph and Electric Subway Company, a party defendant in the McMahon-Flynn subway suit, obtained an order yesterday from Judge Shipman requiring the plaintiff to show cause why he should not give bonds in the sum of $2,000 for costs.

CARLISLE, Penn., April 14.--P.H. Lesher, W. B. Smith, and P.W. Davis, three well known citizens of this county, who were arrested a few weeks ago on the charge of breaking into the Adams Express office at Donors and stealing a package of gold watches, were tried to-day.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 14.--There is a conflict of jurisdiction between the State and Federal Courts in Georgia which is likely to assume considerable importance.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 14.--Attorney-General Cunningham to-day filed in the name of the State of Louisiana, in the Civil District Court, a petition against the American Cotton Oil Trust and others asking for an injunction and a Receiver ...

The sale of the paintings of the late Augustus L. Brown and of George Fawcett Rowe was begun last evening at Moore's Art Galleries. Seventy-four pictures brought a total of $10,150, or an average of about $137.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 14.--William J. Ramage, of Knoxville, was to-day elected Department Commander of the Tennessee and Georgia Department, G.A.R. After the close of the business meeting ...

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 14.--To-day the Right Rev. Matthew Harkins was consecrated Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence, which covers the entire territory of the State, the impressive ceremony being performed in the new cathedral, the building of which was left unfinished at the death of Bishop Hendricken in June last, who laid the foundation stone nearly 10 years ago.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 14.--"Here is a strange story," said the editor of Home and Farm this morning. "One of our contributors, Mrs. M.T. Daviess, has been furnishing us a serial for several months, devoted chiefly to domestic life in the blue grass, but touching incidentally on its political and social features.
BOSTON, April 14.--The West End Railway Company gave publicity to its schemes today, when a hearing was granted by the legislative Committee on Railways.

Capt. "Billy" Ricketts, the genial crier of the Court of Oyer and Terminer, was made the pleased recipient of a letter and two packages yesterday morning. The letter is written from the store of Dunham, Buckley Co., and is as follows:

The fight that has been in progress in the Forty-seventh Regiment, Brooklyn, for two years in regard to the Captaincy of Company D, has been settled by the election of George L. Davenport, who was opposed by Col. Gaylor and his friends.

Capt. Richard and the Columbia College boat crew had a good spin yesterday. Stevens, about a week ago, injured his leg so severely that he has been confined to his bed. W.B. Peet, the coach, was also sick, so that of the three weeks the crew have been out they have not had the benefit of much coaching.

Yesterday was the anniversary of the death of this country's greatest President. There was no public evidence of the fact, however. The majority of men in the pressure of personal affairs forgot it entirely. But a poet, an old man bent with years and tottering through the sunset of life to the twilight and the dark, came feebly forth from his retirement to lay his wreath upon the grave of his friend.
KEYPORT, N. J., April 14.--The body of a man was found floating in Raritan Bay, near East Point, this afternoon by men who were oystering. The features were unrecognizable, but papers in the...

The property owners on Broadway appear at last to be waking up to the fact that that preposterous scheme for building an elevated railroad in that thoroughfare is a serious business, with some prospect, strange as it may appear, of being carried through the Legislature unless more vigorous opposition is shown than has appeared heretofore.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 14.--Edward F. Cody, night distributer of mails in the Toledo Post Office for more than two years, has been looked upon by the world as a model young man until he was marched through the streets of that place to-day noon handcuffed, and after a hearing before a United ...

LEBANON, Penn., April 14.--During the absence of the parents last night Raymond Shay, aged 5 years, lighted a stick at the stove and set fire to the clothing of his brother Ernst, aged 2 years. Before assistance could be rendered Ernst was burned to death.

The trunk line age fell again yesterday and lopped off another branch from the tree which blossoms perennially with through tickets to the wild West beyond Chicago. This time it was the Chicago, Miilwaukee and St. Paul that was attacked, and half an hour after the circulars relating to it were issued from headquarters ...

ALTOONA, Penn., April 14.--An extensive forest fire is raging on Brush Mountain, near this city. A large amount of valuable timber is being destroyed and all efforts to subdue the flames have so far proved futile. It is reported to-night that the house and contents of a farmer named Damin were burned, the family fleeing for their lives.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 14.--Late yesterday afternoon the wholesale grocery house of Goodrich Wagner made an assignment to B.K. Miller, and the business of the firm is to be settled up.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 14.--The Chickasaw Guards' Club purse for all ages, one and an eigth miles, which was to be run on the second day of the Spring meeting of the Memphis Jockey Club, April 26 ...

Bewitching Kate had spoken charmingly her last and wisest words, the choristers had repeated the refrain of "Should he Upbraid," and the red curtains shut from view the gorgeous banquet hall in Lucentio's house. The shrew had been tamed and Hortensio's widow had learned her lesson.

Lieut. Edmund L. Zalinski read a paper on the "Pneumatic Dynamite Torpedo Gun" before the Military service institution at Governor's Island yesterday afternoon. Lieut. Zalinski has, according to his account, in the dynamite gun an admirable weapon.

WHEELING, West Va., April 14.--There was a wholesale jail delivery at Charleston this evening at dusk, six inmates making their escape by raising the heavy stone flagging in the corridor and digging their way out.

VIENNA, April 14.--A commission of Bulgarian officers en route from Krupp's ordnance works to Sofia, with a large quantity of war material, has arrived here. Austria has permitted the passage of the material through the empire.
The Union Boat Club will build a twelvethousand-dollar boathouse by July 4.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 15.--The Detroits defeated the Louisville Club again to-day in an uninteresting game, characterized by hard batting and poor fielding. Score:

MONTREAL, April 15.--A young NewYorker, who gave his name as Frank Braisted, came here a few weeks ago, and on the pretense that he was about to open a branch of a leading New-York bank, hired one of the best stores on St. James-street, and engaged a number of employes at salaries ranging from $1,000 to $5,000, exacting from each of them a deposit in proportion to the salary.

ST JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 15.--Advices from the west coast give additional details of loss of life and property in the severe gale of Tuesday and Wednesday. Nothing has been seen or heard of the schooners missing from Rose Blanche.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 15.--The remains of the Right Rev. Alfred Lee, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Diocese of Delaware, were interred in the old Swedes churchyard this afternoon.

BOSTON, Mass., April 15.--In the House this afternoon the Liquor Committee reported a High License bill fixing the price of a first class license at $1,000, second and third class at $750, fourth class at $500, and fifth class at $150.

Col. James H. Mapleson, of her Majesty's Opera, though he has left this country for a while, still does a little something to make the lives of musicians exciting, and adds his mite, as of yore, to the litigation in New-York courts of law.
There can be no doubt that the public is imbued with the spirit if not acquainted with the words of that delightful poem of Horace beginning "Eheu, fugaces."

WASHINGTON, April 15.--The Superintendent of the Recruiting Service has been ordered to send 40 recruits to the Twenty-second Infantry in the Department of the Missouri, 40 to the Third Infantry at Fort Snelling, Minn., and 100 to the Seventh Cavalry at the same point.
Chancellor Runyon has granted a divorce to Mrs. Wilhelmina Seidel, of Newark, from August Seidel, who is now in the California State prison.
The formation of an Authors Club in Boston rouses the same brood of misconceptions which awoke at the founding of the Authors Club of New-York five years ago.

As the 1st of May approaches the politicians are concentrating their energies in an effort to determine what Mayor Hewitt intends to do with respect to those Commissioners whose terms of office will expire that day.
