OMAHA, Neb., April 15.--The National Opera Company finally left here this morning, and if not detained at Ogden can reach San Francisco on Sunday night.
WASHINGTON, April 15.--Some points that are coming up before the Inter-State Railroad Commissioners are making it plain that they must adopt a positive course in treating them.
CHICAGO, April 15.--There was another flurry in May wheat to-day, and the excitement was greater than on the previous day. In the morning May was boomed up to 86 1/8 cents.

Expressions of indignation were still abundant yesterday among members of the Stock Exchange, who were disgusted by the white washing proclivities of the Exchange Governors. No further resignations from the Governing Committee were chronicled, but John Hone's spirited act, though not copied, was heartily applauded. An independent ticket will be in the field for the coming election. If John Hone would consent he could have the nomination for President.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--The committee having charge of the election of officers for the Pennsylvania division of the League of American Wheelmen, completed their labors this morning. The polls closed on Tuesday, but as the ballots ...

TORONTO, April 15.--The particulars of a horrible poisoning case in a small village called Thedford, about a hundred miles west of here, on the line between Toronto and Detroit, have just become known.

"It is an outrage," forcibly remarked Fish Commissioner Eugene G. Blackford yesterday when he heard that Mr. Finn's bill repealing the law against catching lobsters less than 10 inches in length had passed the Senate on the representation of Senator Murphy that Mr. Blackford no longer opposed it.
ALBANY, April 15.--The relief sought by the New-York Real Estate Exchange and by lawyers generally who are compelled to patronize the office of Register Slevin cannot be granted this year.

President George L. Whitman, of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company, declined to be interviewed yesterday about the sudden removal of Secretary P.B. Armstrong at the quarterly meeting of Trustees Thursday afternoon.
The Salt Lake Herald, an organ of the Mormon Church, recently declared that, while the Mormons could easily gain control of the State of Nevada, they did not want the State at any price.

Proceedings have been begun in the Supreme Court by A.P. and W. Man, representing Nathaniel P. Bailey, Amos R. Eno, and other owners of property on Broadway, to secure an injunction perpetually restraining the New-York Arcade Railway Company from constructing its underground road, and until final judgment restraining it from taking any preliminary steps toward the construction.
The Bacon investigating committee yesterday began looking into the electric light company phase of Brooklyn municipal crookedness.
Prof. F.S. Sahulka, the instructor in gymnastics of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association, was the recipient of a complementary testimonial from the members of the association last evening.

The hatred that Assembly No. 49, of the Knights of Labor, bears to Assembly No. 126, which is composed of carpet weavers, and that of the members of the Home Club against Master Workman John Morrison, of No. 126, was again manifested yesterday by the calling out on strike of the 150 carpet weavers in Higgins's factory who belong to No. 49.

CHICAGO, April 15.--W. B. Clapp has sold the Academy of Music, on Halsted-street, to C. E. Pope, of New-York, for $135,000. In relation to this sale Daniel Shelby, lessee of the theatre, said to-day: "I know C. E. Pope very well.
The strike in Devoe's paint factory was continued yesterday. About 100 men were still out, and these included color grinders and mixers, firemen, and preparers of artists' materials.

CHICAGO, April 15.--The merchandise creditors of Clapp Davies, the jewelers who failed yesterday, held a meeting to-day and adopted a resolution agreeing that the merchandise creditors pool their issues and create a fund for the purpose of investigating the failure of the firm thoroughly, and for that purpose employ ...

An examination was held yesterday afternoon at the office of Cantor Seldner in the supplementary proceedings on the judgment of $450 obtained by Jordan L. Mott against Mrs. Mary Duffy, wife of ex-Alderman Duffy, the informer. George A. Haggerty and John Fray, contractors, were the only witnesses examined.

The examination in the case of O.B. Gould, as complainant against Dr. William M. Reynolds and Mrs. Jessie Reynolds, of 108 West Forty-seventh-street, whom he charges with fraud in attempting to collect insurance ...

UTICA, April 15.--Judge Bulger has decided to hold the wife of the alleged express robber, Roark, as an accessory after the fact. She was released on $1,000 bail, which was furnished by F.S. Davis, of Deerfield, an uncle.

Because Mr. Cassatt has offered to run The Bard against Volante and seems eager to make a match against the Western representative, some horsemen now believe that The Bard will be a certain starter for suburban honors.
NEW-ORLEANS, April 15.--This was the fifth day of the Spring meeting of the Louisiana Jockey Club. The weather was clear and warm and there was a good attendance. The track was dusty.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 15.--D.M. Thomas, Secretary of the Stove Founders' Defense Association, arrived from Detroit to-day, and met here representatives of the local association of stove makers, composed of 18 foundaries in Cleveland, Akron, Salem, Mansfield, Ohio, and Erie, Penn.
FALL RIVER, Mass., April 15.--The Printing Cloth market was dull and easier at 3 5-16c. for 64 squares, in consequence of outside sales at 3 c.; 60x56 Cloths without request.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--Marie Blanchard, a pretty girl of 18, died this afternoon at the house of her uncle, Wheaton Berault, a wealthy lawyer, of Vineland, N.J. On April 1 she shot herself, and since then she has been hovering between life and death.

BIDDEFORD, Me., April 16.--2 A.M.-- A large fire is in progress at Kennebunkport. Half of the business section of the town has been consumed. The Biddeford fire engines have been telegraphed for and are about to leave on a special train.
The American Magazine, of which the first number is the number for May, now just ready, is the periodical some time since announced as the forthcoming successor of the Brooklyn Magazine.

The flight of the notorious Mrs. HOWE from Boston as a fugitive from justice revives the reflections which her former career was adapted to excite upon the inexhaustible gullibility of the human species and especially of the female sex. Her re-...

The rash individual who advertised for 100 young men to escort the pretty girls employed by J. C. Johnston to their ball at Teutonia Hall would have been justly overcome by remorse if he had stood at the door last night and watched the arrived of the natty little maidens in their dainty toilets.

The trial of the validity of the will of Henry C. Bull, who was a resident of Bunker Hill, Ill., which was on trial for more than a week before Judge Van Hoesen and a jury, in in the Court of Common Pleas, came to an end yesterday morning, when the jury returned a verdict that Mr. Bull had not sufficient mental capacity therefor, and was unduly influenced when he made the will.

Not many houses in any line of business in this country can show a business career extending over a century. The drug firm of Hazard, Hazard , Co., successors to Caswell, Hazard Co., is one of half a dozen notable examples in this city.
PORTLAND, Me., April 15.--The refusal of Deputy Internal Revenue Collector Murphy, of Augusta, to testify in the Kennebee Superior Court in a liquor case raises an interesting and important point.
Another day has made very little difference with the situation in the railroad contest over the vexed question of commissions to ticket agents.

B. Altman Co.'s establishment on Sixthavenue has been thronged all the week with shoppers who were attracted, not by the advertisement of a regular opening, but by the display of imported garments, embracing the latest ...

NYACK, April 15.--About 4 o'clock this afternoon a colored man at work on the dock foot of Main-street, this village, saw the body of a man floating in the river a short distance away. Without much difficulty the body was secured and brought to the shore where it was recognized as that of Jacob Snyder, a well known ...
Grammercy Council, No. 114, C.B.L., will give an entertainment and reception at Tammany Hall on Tuesday evening.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 15.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.
Some disappointment was felt by those who attended the prayer meeting in Plymouth Church last night in the expectation that the letters to be read, which had come from individuals ...

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 15.--Willard White, of the Chautauqua Lake Railway, to-day gave the Lakewood School of the new theology several acres of land on the lake shore at Bemus Point.
Under the new Subways bill the city is to be hoodwinked and cheated in the good old way, and another corporation is to receive without charge a valuable franchise and monopoly.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15.--Willilam G. Nichols, master of the ship Belle of Bath, was given a summary hearing by Judge Butler, in the United States District Court, this morning upon the charge of cruelty to his sailors.

The Rev. Dr. Justin D. Fulton, of the Centennial Baptist Church, Brooklyn, recently obtained a leave of absence for one year, in order to prosecute as vigorously as possible the war against the Church of Rome which he has been carrying on for a number of years.

Grocers who make shipments to the West were happy yesterday and freight agents were reflective. It was all caused by the reduction the Star Union Line has made in its charges for transporting sugar in less than carload lots.

The position of Gov. HILL that one of the conditions prescribed in the High License bill for selling liquor to be drunk on the premises under licenses of the second class was unconstitutional should not be allowed to pass unchallenged.

There were few vacant seats last evening in the Sunday school room of St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal church, in West Forty-sixthstreet. Mr. Yarvo M. Neesan, a missonary student from Persia, told about the customs of his country in such an interesting manner that the audience was kept wide awake and good natured and the absence of fresh air was an evil scarcely noticed.
Seventy-six paintings from the collection of George Fawcett Rowe and the late Augustus L. Brown were sold at auction at Moore's Art Gallery, 290 Fifth-avenue, last night.
The Princeton College nine will play this afternoon at the Polo Grounds with the New-Yorks.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 15.--Adjt.-Gen. Porter has decided on his designations for service at the State Camp this Summer and will probably issue his order to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, April 15.--Gen. Sheridan is quoted to-night as saying: "There is not a word of truth in the statements published concerning the effort made to get rid of the notorious Keifer as orator at the unveiling of the Garfield statue."

A lot of amateur detectives went to work yesterday to excavate the well at Milton, a suburb of Rahway, in which an astrologer had said would be found evidence which would lead to the discovery of the unknown girl's murderer. They did not find anything, however, although they threw out a cartload of rubbish.
During the first week of April the New-York City and Northern Railroad earned $11,107, an increase of $2,068 over the corresponding period in last year; the Chicago and West Michigan, $23,620, ...
INDIANAPOLIS, April 15.--At a meeting of the Board of Trade to-day the following report was unanimously adopted:

CLEVELAND, April 15.--The business session of the Conference of Latter Day Saints, at Kirtland, adjourned to-day. Elder James A. McIntosh, of Alliston, Canada, preached this morning on "The Building of the Temple." The 90 Elders were assigned to stations to-day. Devotioned meetings will be held until and including Sunday next, when the Conference will end.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 15.--The trial of Charles Talbot, who stole Fanny Davenport's jewels while on duty as night clerk at the Gayoso Hotel, was brought to a close this morning by the jury bringing in a verdict of guilty, fixing the penalty at five years in the penitentiary.

Michael H. Murphy, for 16 consecutive years Water Register of the Democratic little town of Hoboken, has mysteriously disappeared and under circumstances which have given rise to the gravest suspicions as to his official honesty in the disposition of the city's funds in his charge.
ZANZIBAR, April 15.--A Somali trader from the Uganda country has arrived here bearing advices from Emin Bey. He was established when the trader left at Wadelai, north of the Albert Nyanza.

William Van Antwerp was before Judge Truax, yesterday, to ascertain whether his recent arrest by Pinkerton's detectives in Jersey City was not illegal. He was put into LudlowStreet Jail Feb. 10, an execution against his person got by his wife, in a suit against him for the wrongful conversion of $184,000 of bonds belonging to her.

Michael Nolan, who said he was the Treasurer of the Davitt Rifies, of Jersey City, and that he had not touched a drop of liquor for 20 years until the 1st of the month, came to New-York Thursday to buy a hat.

Mme. Bernhardt has canceled her engagement to play in Newark this evening, so that her appearance in "Theodora" at the Academy of Music this afternoon will be her farewell appearance in this vicinity previous to her departure for her tour across the continent.
Jersey Central's books closed yesterday for the annual election of Directors, and the parties interested in the new deal were inclined to be a trifle less mysterious over their plans.

At the April reunion of the Yale Alumni Association, the sixth of the season, held at Delmonico's last evening, a new departure was taken which every one present voted a great improvement on the usual programme.

Kane Lodge of Masons had a merry evening at its hall in the Masonic Temple last night, and many gentlemen high in the order joined in the celebration. It was a special communication, called for an official visit of District Deputy J.J. Little, who was to be presented with a handsome bronze bust of Shakespeare, to which was chained a silver plate with a suitable inscription.
Miss Mary Azelia Steele, daughter of Capt. Henry S. Steele, of the Seventh Regiment, was married to Mr. George Albert Holden, last evening, at the Madison-Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church.
The police last night made some progress in clearing up the mystery of the shooting in Jersey street Thursday night, but appear to have no clue to the principals in the affair.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 15.--The following decisions have been handed down by Justice Wallace, of the United States Circuit Court for the Southern District of New-York: Estes vs. Worthington Co., et al.--Plea overruled.

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 15.--The smoky city--for it is smoky and grimy yet in spite of the fight between natural gas and coal--has received a kick in the back and a porous plaster through the instrumentality of the inter-State commerce law.
ST. LOUIS, April 15.--Daniel Jewell, the wife murderer, expiated his crime in the jail yard at 6:50 o'clock this morning, the execution being almost private.

George G. De Witt returned yesterday from the Goelets, the Hamersley estate, the of the Geolets, the Hamersley estate, the Chemical Bank and others, and in opposition to the proposed elevated railroad on Broadway. To a TIMES reporter he said:

The examination into the mental condition of Arthur S. Austin, the Vermont lawyer who went to Birmingham, Ala., and made a fortune speculating in real estate, was begun yesterday before Commissioners Jerome Buck, Dr. J.W. Ranney, and Charles D. Leary, and the second panel of the Sheriff's jury.

LONDON, April 15.--At the Newmarket Craven meeting to-day the Newmarket Handicap race of 500 sovereigns was won by J. Hammond's 5-yearold ch. h. Eurasian. Lord Londonderry's 6-year-old b.h. Cambusmore came in second, and Sir G. Chetwynd's 5-year-old ch.h. Portnellan third.

The injunction obtained from Judge Donohue by attorneys of the American Opera Company, Limited, and the National Opera Company to restrain creditors from suing the stockholders of the corporations was yesterday found ineffective, because personal service could not ...

The second trial of Dr. Theus Taylor for the killing of his hired man, Thaddeus Gritman, at Hempstead, Long Island, took place yesterday at the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer, before Judge Barnard.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 15.--Parliament considered the speech from the throne this afternoon. The Hon. Edward Blake, leader of the Opposition, complained of what he characterized as the meagre references to the fishery question.

LONDON, April 15.--Sir William Vernon Harcourt, resuming the debate on the Coercion bill in the House of Commons this afternoon, said the present alliance between the Liberals and Parnellites was based on the Liberal recognition of the fact that the wisest policy in Irish affairs ...

Twenty steerage passengers on the steamship Chandernagor, which arrived on Wednesday and was detained 24 hours at Quarantine owing to a case of smallpox on board, complained yesterday at Castle Garden that they had been ill treated during the voyage.
CHICAGO, April 15.--The joint conference of the General Passenger Agents of the Eastern truck lines and Central Traffic Association roads ended to-day.

CHICAGO, April 15.--The managers of the various roads interested in the Northwestern freight traffic held another meeting today at the office of Chairman Faithorn and continued the discussion of the proposition to send, a committtee to Washington for the purpose ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 15.--It appears that the most important arrest in the Pan Handle case is yet to be made. A former conductor on the road named Connolly is supposed to have been the leader of the gang, and to have gotten away with an immense amount of plunder. Somehow he got wind some time ago that the raid would be made and skipped.
Archbishop Corrigan received a cablegram last evening from the Rev. Michael C. O'Farrell, at Paris, saying that Mgr. Quinn died there yesterday afternoon.

NEW-HAVEN, April 15.--Constable Rod Austin, of Wallingford, made a curious discovery in the house of Alton A. Fowler, in the Spring Farm District, last night. He had been informed that there was an infernal machine there, and upon searching for it he found an old paint keg, with six pounds of powder in it and a fuse attachment ready for operation.

J.P. Solomon, the editor of the Hebrew Standard, recently wrote to the Mayor regarding the enforcement of the Sunday law against those Hebrews who kept Saturday as the Sabbath. In his response yesterday the Mayor says:

SAN FRANCISCO, April 15.--E.J. Baldwin's string of 24 racers will leave Santa Anita Ranche on Monday or Tuesday next to fill their engagements east of the Rockies. The list includes all of that gentleman's best known horses, with the exception of Laredo, who has gone lame and has been turned out to grass.

After the verdict of murder in the second degree, rendered a few moments after midnight yesterday morning, Otto White was reconducted to his cell in the Tombs. Judge Van Brunt will not arraign him for sentence until some time next week.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 15.--Ben Brown was hanged at 11:17 o'clock this morning for the murder of Frank Arnold, colored. He died protesting his innocence.
BOSTON, Mass., April 15.--The best ridiculed man in Boston to-day is George Riddle, the actor and reader, who produced Mr. Fawcett's new play, "The Earl," for the first time ...

MEDINA, N.Y., April 15.--Domestic difficulties in the family of Frederick Hepner, of Prussia, so worked upon the mind of his wife that she took a large quantity of Paris green and jumped into a well yesterday from which she was taken dead. She leaves seven children and was only 30 years of age.

LIMA, April 15.--The new two and five sole notes, ordered from New-York to replace the onehundred and five-hundred sole notes, which were only received at a large discount, have arrived and been placed in circulation.

Two children who were admitted to the Brookly Nursery, at 396 Herkimer-street, about four weeks ago, introduced an epidemic of measles which has affected 35 of the 50 inmates of the place and caused the death of 9 little ones.
Money was made in Wall-street yesterday by the bears. London quotations were weak, and New-York was unable to rise above the English figures.
About 150 Italian stevedores engaged in unloading the raw sugar from the vessels assigned to Havemeyer Eldger, foot of South Fourth-street, Brooklyn, Eastern District, are now on a strike.

The tug A.J. Loughlin collided with the schooner Emma A. Higgins about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, when five miles southwest of the Penfield Light, Long Island Sound. The tug tried to beach the schooner, but she sank in a few minutes. Her crew were taken on board the tug, and no one was hurt. The schooner was built in 1859 at East Boston, and belonged in Provincetown, Mass. She measured 89.47 tons net.

SARATOGA, N.Y., April 15.--The forty-fifth annual convocation of the Troy Conference will assemble at the Washington-Street Methodist Episcopal Church, in this city, on April 21, and continue in session nearly a week.

DOVER, N.H., April 15.--The greatest fire Dover has ever experienced occurred this afternoon in the Cocheco Print Works. It will involve a loss of probably $200,000, and will throw 600 operatives out of employment for probably four to six months.
WHEELING, West Va., April 15.--A calamity, wide in its scope and sudden and terrible in its nature, fell upon the people of Belmont County, Ohio, yesterday afternoon.

Coroner Eidman and a jury yesterday continued the inquest upon the four men who were killed by falling from the Third-avenue elevated railroad structure during the blockade on March 8. The testimony given bore out the statement of Peter Berberich, one of the first witnesses, ...

When George V. Powell, who was arrested on the District Attorney's complaint, was taken before Judge Van Brunt, in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, yesterday, his face did not carry the pallor of a dungeon cell, but rather the rosy hue of the good living of the Grand Central Hotel, where he has been staying, under the care of a detective, for a week.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 15.--A deliberate murder was committed at the Southern Prison, in Jeffersonville, this evening, about 6 o'clock, Frank Harris, who was sent there from Putnam County to serve three years for larceny being the victim, and Macy Warner the perpetrator of the deed.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 15.--Parliament will be asked to grant $1,000,000 to build the Canadian Sault Ste. Marie Canal, referred to in the Governor-General's speech from the throne.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 15.--A handsome man and a fair girl walked up and down, arm in arm, in the New-York Central waiting room shortly before the departure of the midnight westward express last night, evidently totally, wrapped up in each other.

William Davidge, the genial and everywhere popular veteran of the Madison-Square Theatre Company, will reach his seventy-third birthday to-morrow.

A well dressed woman, about 35 years of age, carrying in her arms a pug dog, was taken to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. Her name was registered as Jane Doe, and all information about her residence was refused.

President James Howell, of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees, was satisfied yesterday that surface cable cars would have to be introduced on the roadways of the bridge in a short time. "Very soon," he said, "we will have to run ...

The market has acted kind of mean the past week. It has not gone down much on the whole, but it has been irregular; and once or twice fallen off in a way which gave the impression that a break was coming. Bear rumors have flooded the Street all the time, and if outside ...

The managers of the New-York Cooking School have leased for three years the house at 28 Lafayette-place, establishing the school in quarters adequate to its immediate needs. No one dares predict how soon even larger quarters may be required.

Mayor Hewitt and his cabinet met at noon yesterday and considered various bills now before the Legislature relating to this city. The bill providing for a plaza at Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Tenth-street was approved, ...

AMAGANSETT, L.I., April 16.--Capt. Edwards, of a whaling crew, was knocked insensible into the water off here to-day by the stroke of a whale's tail. He had just harpooned the monster. The crew rescued him and took him home, where he is lying in a precarious condition. The whale was captured.

Applications to list new securities on the Stock Exchange come in daily. There seems to be almost an epidemic of new stocks and bonds. Yesterday these requests were bulletined: The Columbus and Hocking Coal and Iron Company, ...

Yachtsmen in this city have about made up their minds that the Mayflower will not go to England to sail for the Queen's Cup. One gentleman yesterday said he believed that as soon as Mr. Tankerville Chamberlayne thoroughly understood the condition of matters he would change his centreboard stipulation so that Gen. Paine and Mr. Burgess would make no objection to it at all.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 16.--During the ceremony attending the unveiling of the statue of Albert Sidney Johnston on the 6th inst. Jefferson Davis, in his impromptu remarks, took occasion in a manner indirect but thoroughly understood to reflect severely upon Gen. Beauregard for his handling of the troops at the battle of Shiloh.

"How comes it that the counsel for the parties under investigation has a seat with the committee?" a gentleman who was for the first time present at the Brooklyn investigation asked of another, who has been a regular attendant.

The rod could not be pulled out until it was fastened into a vise and help given.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16.--Among the passengers of the barkentine City of Papeiti, which arrived to-day from Tapiti, were Capt. J. T. Virecke and ten others, all of whom belonged to the crew of the German steamer Raiatea which was burned at sea on her last passage to Papeiti.

WASHINGTON, April 16.--The President this afternoon made the following appointments: Newman W. McConnell, of Tennessee, to be Chief-Justice of the Supreme Court of Montana Territory, and George S. Peters, of Ohio to be an attorney of the United States for the Territory of Utah.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 16.--Drafts on NewYork, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents. The Clearing House exchanges for the last week were $15,692,929.
So many fires have occurred recently at the office of the New-Yorker Zeitung, 7 Frankfort-street, that the proprietors are beginning to supsect incendiarism.

Japanese officials are not paid exorbitant salaries. The Minister in the Foreign Department receives 1,000, while the Vice-Minister has 833, and the maximum for a Director of Bureau 500.

Among the hospitable body of telegraph clerks, to which every traveler in the country owes so much, are men of great intelligence, but the nature of their duty confines them to the village in which their testing station is situated.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 16.--An unknown Italian was struck this evening by a train on the Pennsylvania Railroad at Plainsborough and instantly killed. He was a workman on the road, and did not jump out of the way quickly enough. Another workman was slightly injured.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 16.--Judge Dykeman, of Logansport, while conducting a case in court at Delphi. Thursday lost his voice and was unable to speak above a whisper. The physicians are unable to account for the sudden affliction and it is feared he will not regain his speech. Judge Dykeman is one of the leading lawyers and politicians in Northern Indiana and is just now in the prime of life.

A fire which broke out early yesterday morning on the second floor of the five-story double tenement house at 647 Second-avenue resulted in the death of an aged woman and the injuring of another tenant and several firemen. The building is of the usual "double decker"...

The strike among the Italian stevedores employed on the docks of Havemeyer Elder, Brooklyn, Eastern District, remains unchanged. Several non-union men were engaged yesterday and succeeded in removing a portion of the cargoes from the vessels to the docks.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., April 16.--This was the sixth and last day of the Spring meeting. The weather was clear and warm and the attendance good. The track was in good condition, but dusty:

The popular movement in favor of the Elm-street improvement is expected by the projectors to react a climax within a few days. The city authorities are in favor of it, property owners and taxpayers ask for it, and it is plain that a demand has been created by the growth of the metropolis.

The private billiard match at the NewYork Racquet Club, Twenty-sixth-street, near Sixth-avenue, continued last evening. Mr. Knapp opened with a run of 46, which added to his lead of the night previous, put him 125 points ahead of Mr. Morton.

The past week was the liveliest in the history of the Coffee Exchange. Orders from the South and West stimulated demands, but pure speculation accounted for a large share of the trading.

An excellent Baptist lady (Mrs. Walker a member of the Rev. R.H. Pitt's church, in this city) mysteriously disappeared some time since, and many theories have been discussed in the papers as to what became of her.
Leonard Moody and his family, consisting of Col. Edward Fackner, of the Thirteenth Regiment, and his wife, sailed in the North German Lloyd steamship Eider yesterday afternoon.

Archbishop Corrigan will begin next Thursday an episcopal visitation of all the churches in the Archdiocese of New-York. It will extend over three months, beginning with St. Patrick's Cathedral Thursday, and ending with the church at West Hurley July 15.
Gen. Lawton, the new Minister to Austria, went to Washington yesterday. His stay in New-York was limited to a day.
LONDON, April 17.--Admiral Franklin, of the United States Navy, has arrived at Bologna.
Another effort--the fifth--was made yesterday morning to destroy the property of the New-Yorker Zeitung at 7 Frankfort-street. It was successful.
PORTLAND, April 17.--The amended liquor law goes into effect to-morrow, and the druggists, the hotel men, and the saloon keepers are in a quandary as to what they will do about it.

Saturday was one of the dullest days the railroad offices hereabout have seen for a long time. Travel westward, which has been light for two or three weeks, was lighter than ever, but the agents looked at matters cheerfully and said that the boom which is due with the Spring was sure to come soon.
Those who went to the Brooklyn Tabernacle yesterday, expecting to hear the Rev. Dr. T. De witt Talmage vigorously protest against all kinds of secret societies, were disappointed.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Mr. Algernon S. Sullivan, who has been in this city on a visit, had something to say on the subject of Mr. Cleveland's popularity to a reporter for the Sunday Herald.
There is trouble in the Women's Relief Corps of Mansfield Post, G.A.R., of Brooklyn, Eastern District.

The author of "The Invention of Printing" writes of types and their evolution with thorough acquaintance. He does not regard their mechanical or material excellence, but their letter form, descanting on their beauty and legibility.
WASHINGTON, April 17.--Charles S. Fairchild, of New-York, is the thirty-eighth Secretary of the Treasury. The first, Alexander Hamilton, also of New-York, was appointed at the age of 32 years.
CHICAGO, April 17.--"Bob" Miles, of the Bijou, came up from St. Louis yesterday and brought the news that Dixey has decided to abandon his proposed trip to San Francisco.

BOSTON, April 17.--Edgar Fawcett contributes further to the breeze aroused by comments upon his play, "The Earl," and offers a final defiance to newspaper opinion in a letter to the Post. His shaft is aimed at the Advertiser.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 17.--Advices from Honolulu received by the steamer Mariposa, which arrived here yesterday, state that a political confederation has been ratified between the Samoan Islands and the Sandwich Islands.

An incandescent electric light illumined the office of the Pennock Underground Conduit and Surface Telegraph Company yesterday. It was a clear, strong light, and fed from a battery of 15 cells arranged on a neighboring shelf.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 17.--Dr. Hawthorne's church, the most fashionable in the city, was crowded to-day by an immense congregation.

The fight for stock proxies to vote on at the coming election of the St. Louis and San Francisco Railroad Company waxes hotter day by day, and a regular market for the buying and selling of such proxies has been established. One-quarter of 1 per cent. was yesterday's bid price.

A large number of the members of the Gentlemen's Driving Club assembled at Fleetwood Park yesterday morning to see the flyers stabled there take their work and to talk over the prospects of the coming season.

LONDON, April 17.--The steamship Benalder, (Br.,) Capt. Ross, from Japan and China ports, for NewYork, passed Gibraltar yesterday. The French Transatlantic Line steamship La Gascogne, Capt. Santelli, from New-York April 9, for Havre, was signaled off the Lizard at 9 A.M. to-day.

The Mission House in water-street which was founded by Jerry McAuley was the scene yesterday of memorial services, and a white marble tablet which had been let into the wall of the meeting room was unveiled and dedicated to his memory.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--"Jim, the Penman" forged his way to Washington this afternoon. He came with the rush and roar of a special express and arrived with the dramatic effect of a sensational dispatch.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17.--Execrating all that is excellent, vituperating all that is noble, Johann Most, the Anarchist, delivered a most abusive and most vehement tirade in an hour and a half's speech at Redmen's Hall, Third and Brown streets, this afternoon.

The project of the Long Island Gun Club to buy or lease a ground of their own has been partly consummated. The Fountain and Coney Island Gun Clubs have taken the initiative and leased a plot of land at Woodlawn for a term of 10 years, and will put up a house on it.

The uncertainty as to what course Mayor Hewitt will pursue in filling the existing and impending vacancies in various city departments still continues. The politicians, with few exceptions, frankly admit that they cannot foretell the Mayor's purposes.

LONDON, April 17.--There was no demand for discount during the past week; rates have been rather firmer since the Bank of England lowered its rates to 1 to 1. On the Stock Exchange business was inactive, bnt prices showed a firm tendency.

All reports to the contrary notwithstanding, the Railway case is as much of a mystery as on that Saturday morning now a little over three weeks ago when the body of the murdered woman was discovered in the outskirts of the little city. At the select banquet given by the Massachusetts Club in Boston on Saturday Senator HOAR seems to have made the speech of the evening.

TRENTON, N.J., April 17.--Counsel for George H. Disque, the Hoboken wife murderer, sentenced to be hanged June 1, will apply to the Court of Pardons for a review of the case and a commutation of sentence to imprisonment for life.

The Queen has desired the Mayor of Birmingham to send to her photographs of himself and his wife. This is rather an equivocal compliment, as only a few days previously her Majesty, under similar circumstances, had requested to be supplied with the photographs of the principal animals at Olympia.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union the Socialists and Anarchists, through the Federation of German Trades, sent in another petition asking for money and other aid for the condemned Chicago Anarchists.

George I. Seney, of Brooklyn, has already brought together another collection of paintings, not so remarkable for the best work of various French painters as that which was dispersed for the benefit of his creditors, but a fine gallery nevertheless.
It was decidedly a dry day in New-York yesterday. During the afternoon hours lovers of the ruby and the foaming mugs of malt extracts were puzzled how to obtain their usual Sunday refreshment.

RICHMOND, Va., April 17.--Commonwealth Attorney S.B. Witt, of this city, at the instance of the Sinking Fund Commissioners of the State, has taken steps to prevent the $15,000 of forged Riddleberger bonds of Virginia, sent here by Blake, Brother Co., of Boston, and a firm in Baltimore, from being returned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 17.--The bears of the San Francisco wheat market are becoming very much excited, and it looks as if the game played some time ago on the mining stock brokers is to be repeated with effect on the grain speculation.

About 350 shoemakers met yesterday afternoon at 263 Bowery. Most of them belonged to the shop of Hanan Son, where District Assembly No. 91 ordered a strike some time ago.

TRENTON, N.J., April 17.--Gov. Green has appointed Prof. George H. Cook, Robert C. Bacott, and ex-Speaker Alfred B. Stoney Commissioners on the part of New-Jersey to settle the boundary line between New-Jersey and New-York, on Raritan Bay. The Governor on Saturday signed the bill providing for the sale of unused public property in Jersey City and the issue of bonds to make up $200,000 for a new City Hall.

The Faculty of Harvard College has promulgated the extraordinary rule that in all cases in which the college has heretofore required a physician's certificate to the fact of illness of absent students, such certificates must specify the cause of illness in order that the Faculty may be able to judge of the validity of the excuse for absence.

An ineffectual attempt was made yesterday to extort a confession from John Green wald, the burglar who is confined in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, under indictment for the murder of Lyman S. Weeks. Similar attempts...
TRENTON, N.J., April 17.--The New-Jersey Southern Telephone Company of Woodbury has filed articles of incorporation and received a charter. The capital stock is $250,000.
WABASH, Ind., April 17.--A serious epidemic is raging among the students at the Normal College at Valparaiso.

The reign of prosperity at the Casino includes Sunday evening concerts as well as the comic opera performances of other nights. The house was crowded to its utmost capacity last evening when the members of Mr. Henry E. Abbey's opera company now supporting Mme. Patti appeared in concert.
A party to of rowdies on one of the Jersey City and Bayonne horse cars became disorderly while passing through Bayonne last night.
Yesterday was the seventeenth anniversary of the organization of Emmanuel Baptist Chapel, in Suffolk-street, near Grand, of which the Rev. Samuel Alman is Pastor.

DUBUQUE, Iowa, April 17.--A prominent railroad official here is responsible for the statement that the Illinois Central has, after several months of hard work, bought up enough of the stock of its leased lines in this State to secure control of the lines.
Catcher Buckley, of the Syracuse Stars, is the latest addition to the disabled list. At Monitor Park, Weehawken, the Newarks yesterday defeated the Monitors by a score of 7 to 3.
OTTAWA, Ontario, April 17.--The Canadian Government's expedition to the Yukon country leaves here on Wednesday.
BERLIN, April 17.--Verdi's "Otello" was received here with less enthusiasm than at Milan. The same artists that took part in the opera at Milan performed here.
WHEELING, West Va., April 17.--From 6,000 to 8,000 people visited the cyclone district on the Ohio side of the river to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--The autopsy on the body of Chief-Justice Cartter, of the District Supreme Court was performed today by Dr. Lamb. It showed that death was due to cancer of the stomach. The body will leave here on Tuesday evening for Cleveland, Ohio where the funeral will take place.

Mrs. Bessie G. Wertz, a teacher in the South Eighth-street public school at Newark was seriously burned on Saturday. Her clothing took fire from some burning rubbish in a garden on Myrtle-avenue, and before assistance could be rendered the flesh on her limbs was burned to the bone. She lies in a critical condition.
May a clergyman wheel his own baby in a perambulator? One would suppose that he might, but not so think the people of Edinburgh. There a clergyman was seen carrying his baby.
Congressman Lloyd S. Bryce, of the Seventh District, has decided to allow the boys of his district to compete for a cadetship at Annapolis.

SAVANNAH, Ga., April 17.--Frank M. Fonda, Superintendent of the main stem of the Georgia Central Railroad, was shot and instantly killed to-day on board the tug William C. Turner by J.J. Abrams, a prominent lawyer of this city.

A meeting of the Jewish Immigrants' Protective Society was held last evening at the Rivington-street synagogue for the purpose of receiving a report of the work done by the society since its inception March 15, 1886, and of obtaining more mem bers if possible.

CHICAGO, April 17.--Most of the Chicago playhouses have done a good business during the past week, though the attractions, except at the Chicago Opera House, have been second rate.

A kerosene lamp exploded yesterday morning on the third floor of the tenement house at 173 Monroestreet, and set fire to the place. The tenants became alarmed, but all succeeded in escaping from the house without injury except Mrs. Eliza McCoy.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 18.--Judge Pardee, of the United States Circuit Court, now in Texas, has filed in the courts here a decision suspending section 4 of the inter-State commerce law so far as it applies to the Texas and Pacific Road, now in the hands of Receivers appointed by the courts. The order was issued on the petition of the Receivers in the interest of the trade with El Paso, Texas.

The Paine will case came up again yesterday before the Surrogate, and Charles J. Babbitt began a long argument for the proponent. All those interested in the contest were present.

The property owners of West Seventythird-steeet have been somewhat rudely awakened to the fact that, although the law forbids the planting of poles and stringing of wires in the public streets, the long-looked-for days of an underground wire system have not yet dawned.

CLEVELAND, April 18.--The stove foundries here are shut down, as everybody expected. The molders went to work as usual this morning. Boycotted patterns from Bridge, Beach Co.'s foundry were given to the men in the Cleveland and the co-operative foundries with orders to work on them before anything else.
BOSTON, Mass., April 18.--Collector Saltonstall this morning heard and decided a case said to be the first of its kind ever heard in this country.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 18.--A dispatch from Seven Mile Ford, Smyth County, says: "The house of a man named Browles, near here, was destroyed by fire last night, in which two of his daughters, aged, respectively, 19 and 21 years, were burned to death and three other persons so badly injured that they cannot survive. The fire was caused by defective flues."

CHICAGO, April 18.--Morris B. Curtis, the actor, known as "Samuel of Posen," began a suit to-day in the United States Circuit Court against the John B. Jeffry Printing Company to recover $50,000 for alleged assault and battery.

The Commissioner of Accounts examined more witnesses yesterday in reference to Park Department methods. John J. Odell, a clerk in the department for eight years, said that he had never been asked by any of the Commissioners to favor this or that political organization, and had never made any contribution to any political faction.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 18.--A heavy snowstorm mingled with enough rain to make the slush the worst of the year has prevailed all day, accompanied by high winds. The weather is the most disagreeable and trying in many months, and everything out of doors has the aspect of midwinter.

Jonathan Lawrence Slosson, the lawyer who went into the East River from the ferryboat Superior Sunday morning, was sufficiently recovered from his immersion yesterday to return to this city.

The law requires that a Police Justice be at Police Headquarters every night to take bail in any cases of felony that may be brought before him. The Mayor designates the dates on which each member of the Board of Police Justices shall in turn perform this duty.

LONDON, April 18.--Later dispatches confirm the report that a steamer has been wrecked off Bonifacio, Corsica. The name of the vessel is the Tasmania. All the women and children among the passengers have been safely landed. The majority of the passengers are still on board. Assistance has gone to the vessel from Ajaccio and Marseilles.

BRODHEAD, Wis., April 18.--The Rev. L. H. Cook, Pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church at Juda, was to-day expelled from the ministry for immoral conduct. He had until recently borne a high character, and was greatly beloved by his congregation.
Mr. Henry Probasco's collection of paintings was sold at auction last night in Chickering Hall, under the management of the American Art Association, with Thomas E. Kirby as auctioneer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., April 18.--Advices received from Sydney, New South Wales, per steamer Mariposa, give the latest particulars regarding the attempted assassination of Premier Baker, of the Tonga Islands, by converted Wesleyan natives.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 18.--Another step forward in the settlement of the long-pending litigation of the estate of the late Wilbur F. Storey was taken today. Judge Knickerbocker, in the Probate Court admitted the will of 1879 to record.

MADRID, April 18.--Marshal Bazaine was to-day assaulted by a Frenchman, who attacked him with a poniard, exclaiming, "J'ai venge ma patrie." The Marshal was dangerously wounded on the head. His assilant is believed to be a correspondent for the Paris newspapers.

Bridget McGinnis appeared in the prisoners' pen at the Yorkville Police Court yesterday while the court room was especially crowded and the space in front of Judge White's desk was completely filled. Bridget, who lives at 637 First-avenue, had been arrested for disorderly conduct.

MONTREAL, April 18.--The proposal to erect a residence here for the Governor-General in honor of the jubilee year having fallen through, Sir Donald Smith, member of Parliament, and Sir George Stephen, President of the Canadian Pacific Railway, have offered to give $500,000 each for a new hospital to be named, with the permission of her Majesty, the Royal Victoria Hospital.
The Essex Market Police Court was not big enough to hold the crowd which thronged there yesterday morning.

John Morrison, Master Workman of Assembly No. 126, of the Knights of Labor, against whom Assembly No. 49 is making a fight, returned yesterday from Philadelphia, where he had attended a meeting of the district assembly.

MERCER, Penn., April 18.--Father Donnelly, a widely known and able Catholic priest, who has had charge of the parishes of Mercer and Greenville for some time, has defied the authority of Bishop Mullen, of this diocese, and started on a lecturing tour.
TROY, April 18.--The employes of the Troy Steel and Iron Company have requested that their wages be advanced. The puddlers are the most dissatisfied of the men.

Five men who had escaped from a burning wreck in which two of their shipmates perished, and who had been picked up after drifting about for many hours in an open boat, arrived yesterday on the steamship Benefactor, of Clyde's Line.
One of the most splendid and numerously attended marriages ever held at the cathedral on Fifth-avenue was celebrated there yesterday morning by Archbishop Corrigan.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 18.--The weather was as cold as ice water this morning, and a driving snowstorm prevailed at the opening of court, but it did not deter the members of the Women's Christian Temperance Union and ...

DUBLIN, April 18.--The evictions at Luggarcurren of the tenants of the Marquis of Lansdowne who refused the terms offered by the agent of the estates will begin to-morrow. A special military force arrived on the scene today to be on hand for emergencies.

President James C. Bayles, of the Board of Health, has written a letter to Mayor Hewitt asking that the municipal dog pound, near the foot of East Sixteenth-street, be removed to the offal dock in West Thirty-eighth-street.

Upon the application of Howe Hummel Judge Donohue yesterday directed that the suit of Mme. Fursch-Madi against Charles E. Locke be placed on the short cause calendar of the Supreme Court for next Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 18.--The Supreme Court to-day delivered its opinion in the famous Maxwell land grant case, which was brought before it on appeal from the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia.

CLEVELAND, April 18.--The Ohio Wool Growers' Association will soon be called to meet to protest against the suspension of the long and short haul clause of the inter-State commerce law asked for by California wool growers. Heretofore the California wools paid about the same rate to New-York as Ohio wools. The Vessel Owners' Association is also preparing to protest on general principles against the suspension of the clause.

Last night's blast of Winter worked scarcely a perceptible influence upon the Common wealth Club, who met in the banquet room at the Metropolitan Hotel and left few vacant seats at the tables that stretched the length of the room.
Joseph W. Cushman, of Bonner Barbour, and William W. Merrill were elected members of the Cotton Exchange yesterday.
The American Bell Telephone Company proposes to kill the Telephone Rate bill now pending in the Assembly, and it will not fail to use all available means to accomplish its design.

We have many times called attention to the manner in which the Surveyor's Department of the New-York Custom House has been and is being worked by Mr. BEATTIE in violation of the reform principles of the Federal Administration.
RED BANK, N.J., April 18.--Samuel Rodgers, a retired farmer and the oldest inhabitant in the town, died last night from a paralytic stroke, in his ninety-first year.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--"The players came to play before the King." It was an event --the Actors' Fund benefit at the National Theatre to-night. In the language of the American pastime it was a "blaze." For all the brilliant courtiers in the great game of political diplomacy were scattered, face upward, over the brown-tinted auditorium.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 18.--A general assignment by John H. Clark, Edwin L. Ferguson, and Henry R. Clark, of the Clark Manufacturing Company, builders' hardware, on Niagara-street, to James E. Ford, was filed in the County Clerk's office this morning. The preferences foot up about $30,000.

Judge Patterson has made a decision in favor of Mrs. Mary Veerhoff in her suit against the Administratrix of the estate of her dead aunt, Mrs. Sophia Zeysing, to recover the balance of a wedding gift of $3,000 which Mrs. Zeysing promised her away back in 1873.

ALBANY, April 18.--The meeting of the Senate Railroad Committee, which was to have considered the Broadway elevated road to-night, was postponed until to-morrow, owing to the absence of Senators Pierce and Nelson.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 18.--The Board of Councilmen, which has a small Republican majority, met to-night, and on the presumption that the law under which the new Aldermen were elected is defective and that the Board of Councilmen constitutes the entire City Council, proceeded, in a stormy session, to re-elect the present Republican incumbents of the City Clerk's, Auditor's, Civil Engineer's, and other offices. Yesterday's storm had a very depressing effect upon trainers of race horses hereabout, as it has put the tracks in bad condition once more and has a tendency to interfere with the work of preparation for the Spring races which has been progressing so favorably.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., April 18.--A general order from Department Commander Griffin, Grand Army of the Republic, advised posts in this department not to answer questions contained in the recent circular emanating from the office of the New-York Tribune.

A change is being contemplated by the NewYork, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, which, if carried into effect, will result in the removal of some of the company's general offices from this city to New-Haven.

The Brooklyn police rarely neglect an opportunity to arrest some one in connection with the murder of Lyman S. Weeks, and on Sunday they sent two officers down to Canarsie to arrest Samuel Bowen, a local rough, who has been connected with innumerable robberies.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 18.--Navigation is practically open on Lake Erie, and many vessels are preparing to leave this port for Chicago and Milwaukee to-morrow and Wednesday. The propellers Jim Sheriffs and J.H. Farwell, the first arrivals of the season, came into port last night.

LONDON, April 18.--Col. King-Harman, the new Parliamentary Under Secretary for Ireland, for the first time since his appointment, answered interrogatories to-day in the House of Commons respecting Irish affairs.

BOMBAY, April 18.--The Ameer of Afghanistan has sent a battery of artillery, two regiments of cavalry, and two regiments of infantry to attack the Jaghoree Ghilzais, the Zoornatees, the Shilgaris, and the Wardaks, all of whom have sworn to fight against him to the death.

It is only a few years ago that one name was high above all others among the speculators on the Cotton Exchanges of the world. That was the name of Morris Ranger, a German, who to-day is to be buried in this city, where he has lived for some time, little known, not often seen in public, no longer powerful in the speculative world.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--Second Lieut. George I. Putnam, Sixteenth Infantry, has been granted three months' leave of absence from July 1. The leave of absence of Lieut.-Col. Joseph Fletcher, Jr., Second Infantry, has been extended one month. Ordnance Sergeant Eugene Weich has been retired.

ST. LOUIS, April 18.--The boycotted Western railroad lines have adopted a new plan of campaign, and, according to a high executive of one of the lines, will carry the war into the enemy's territory.

Eugene Conner, a shoemaker, 40 years of age, cut his throat with a penknife, yesterday morning, at Taylor's lodging house, Park-row. He had lived there for two years, and for four years had suffered from consumption.

PHILADELPHIA, April 18.--A novel train of cars was exhibited to-day at the Pennsylvania Railroad station, Market and Thiry-second streets. The train consists of five Pullman cars only, and will be the New-York and Chicago limited express.

Unusual preparations were in progress early yesterday morning at Wood's Gymnasium, on Twenty-eighth-street. Prof. Wood and his assistants were moving around with troubled faces carefully examining many articles of use to him who would possess strength and the knowledge to use it.

Capt. Michael Cregan looked as chipper as ever as he entered Stuyvesant Hall last evening to resume his sway over his forces in the Republican organization in the Sixteenth Assembly District.

Charles Roberts, Jr., occupied the stage of the Madison-Square Theatre all alone last evening and creditably performed the pleasing but difficult task of reading "Onnalinda," the poetic romance by J.H. McNaughton, for the benefit of the Masonic Asylum fund.
The way in which the Common Lands Commissioners of Gravesend kept a good thing for their friends when the opportunity offered was again illustrated to the Brooklyn investigating committee yesterday.
A raid was made Sunday night upon 24 Mottstreet, where 22 Chinamen were found playing fan tan. A full outfit for the game was captured.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18.--The expressed determination of Secretary Whitney to condemn the old flagship Hartford, and to place her in rotten row at Mare Island, has aroused an unexpected amount of sentimental interest in the veteran sloop of war.

Patti in a new role was an attraction whose strength no inclemency of elements could hope to conquer. The total depravity of Spring might have dashed the ardor of the public on any ordinary occasion; but last night was extraordinary.

The passage of the InterState Commerce bill and the resulting increase of railroad rates have greatly contracted the field for the sale of sugar refined in this city.

The New-York Classis met yesterday at the Collegiate Dutch Reformed Church, Fifthavenue and Twenty-ninth-street. The Rev. Dr. J.M. Dickson, the statistician, read a report which showed that the churches of the Classis had prospered during the year.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 19.--The National Opera Company, which arrived in this city about noon yesterday, instead of on Saturday evening as was at first expected, opened last night in "Faust" at the Grand Opera House.

MONTREAL, April 19.--The teamsters' strike is already at an end, the men having agreed to accept an advance of 5 cents per day instead of 20 cents.

It is interesting to notice that the Republicans who most deprecate agitation of the tariff are those who most persistently agitate it. The obvious explanation of this fact is that they have little else to agitate.

ALBANY, April 19.--The Western express on the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, due in this city at 2 o'clock A.M., ran into a landslide at a bend in the road about midway between East Creek and St. Johnsville last night.

Delegates from the Land League branches of this city met last night at the call of the Irish Municipal Council to report upon the work now in hand and to receive instructions calculated to stimulate renewed efforts in the Irish cause. Few of the branches had tried to do much lately, but all promised to hold meetings and spur enthusiasm and contributions in various ways.
Another period of suspended animation marked yesterday the very curious war over commissions which is now interesting the Eastern and Western railroads.

ALBANY, April 19.--The opponents of the Cullen Telephone bill appeared in force before the Ways and Means Committee this afternoon. They represented every telephone company from Long Island to Buffalo.

BOSTON, April 19.--The Mayflower will not go to England. There will therefore be no contest for the Arrow's challenge cup, and Boston's International cup winner is now for sale at a price equivalent to her original cost.
DETROIT, April 19.--Some months ago the shipbuilders in this neighborhood had trouble with their men and imported ship carpenters from Maine to do their work.
SAN ANAFRE, Cal., April 19.--A peculiar phenomenon has occurred here. Quantities of submarine vegetation have been thrown up on the beach, covering it for 16 miles.

Alexander Mitchell, President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, and one of the wealthiest men in the Northwest, died at his rooms in the Hoffman House just before 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had been gradually losing strength for two months, but the illness which resulted in his death began only a week ago.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19.--A party of about 40 gentlemen accepted an invitation extended by the Pullman Company to make a trip this afternoon from the Broad-street Station to Dowingtown, on the Pennsylvania Railroad, and return.

The hearing of the Evangelical Alliance before the Senate Committee on Literature concerning the proposed division of the common school fund with Catholic schools has been twice postponed, but will take place to-day at 3 o'clock.

President Ledyard, of the Michigan Central, and President Newell, of the Lake Shore, spent several hours in the office of President Depew at the Grand Central Station yesterday. Board meetings were held by the Directors of the Vanderbilt roads, and in the intervals everybody discussed the interState commerce law. The annual meeting of the New-York Central and Hudson River Road will be held to-day.

Arrangements were completed yesterday for the dinner of the Life Insurance Association at the Hotel Brunswick this afternoon. Plates have been ordered for 100 persons.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 19.--E.B. Lyon went over to Stamford March 1 and applied to the Rev. Mr. Scofield to marry him to Hattie B. Wright. Lyon produced a license. The pair were married and returned to Bridgeport. Mrs. Lyon is 18 years of age, has dark hair, clear complexion, and is very handsome.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 19.--The funeral of the Rev. Father William J. Bourke took place to-day. The procession was over one mile long, various local Catholic organizations participating. Interment was made in St. Agnes's Cemetery. Bishop McNierny officiated, assisted by many priests.

ROCKFORD, Ill., April 19.--The Register last night printed a letter from Gen. James Speed, of Louiseville, which strongly disputes the ancient yarn concerning the circumstances under which Lincoln wrote his famous Gettysburg oration.
CINCINNATI, April 19.--A call has been issued for a meeting of the Democratic State Committee on May 10. This is two months earlier than the committee usually meets.

Coroner Terrill and a jury of eleven men began investigating the Rahway murder mystery yesterday morning, and kept it up all day, with a short recess for dinner. The court sat in a dingy upper room of the City Hall, and was terribly deliberate in its proceedings.

MONTREAL, April 19.--Charles Grenier, a daring burglar, who was being brought to St. Vincent de Paul Penitentiary to-day to serve a three years' term for a burglary committed at Aylmer, escaped from the officers by jumping through a window of the car while the train was going at the rate of 35 miles an hour. By the time the train was brought to a stop Grenier had made good his escape.

A telegraph pole on a freight train bound east on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon crashed into the side of a western-bound passenger train near Jersey City. The windows of one of the coaches were broken, and some passengers were injured by broken glass, but none seriously. The passenger train was not delayed.

At the charter election in New-Rochelle yesterday the successful candidates were: President--Charles G. Burks, (Rep.;) Trustees--John Sheehan (Rep.) and Joseph Ross and Jacob Holwegs, (Dem.;) Treasurer--George Ferguson. (on both tickets;) Police Justice--M.J. Tierney, (on both tickets.)

A young woman of trim figure, regular features, and deep blue eyes startled the sailors of the American ship Grandee as she walked out of the cabin soon after the vessel sailed from Hong-Kong, just 100 days ago.
WASHINGTON, April 19.--The National Academy of Sciences began its annual meeting to-day at the National Museum. This morning a preliminary and private session was held.

Yesterday Senator VEDDER offered in the Senate Committee of the Whole a substitute for his Liquor Tax bill, framed with a view to obviating the objections urged by the Governor against the High License bill.

NEWAYGO, Mich., April 19.--Boston creditors to-day closed the Newaygo Furniture Company's works on claims for $50,000, throwing 250 men out of employment. The same creditors closed the Newaygo Manufacturing Company 10 days ago. Both companies are indebted heavily to their employes.
By a tie vote yesterday the Aldermen refused to give the room now occupied as a city library to the Judges of the City Court.

WASHINGTON, April 19.--Major-Gen. Terry, who commands the Division of the Missouri, will discharge the duties of General commanding the Department of the Missouri until a successor is appointed to succeed Gen. Willcox, retired.

BALTIMORE, April 20.--Charles C. Weiller and Harry C. Weiller, clothing, trading as Charles Weiller Sons, made an assignment to-day to Joseph Leopold for the benefit of their creditors. The bond of the Trustee is $100,000.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 20.--The contest in the Legislature at Tallahassee continues. Four more ballots have been taken in caucus without any result, the last standing: Perry, 37; Bloxham, 42; scattering, 7. The fight promises to be a long one, and it cannot be told when the end will come.

ALBANY, April 20.--Senators Knapp, Griswold, and Fagan, of the Senate Committee on Literature, listened to an argument this afternoon in opposition to the bill of Senator Murphy compelling the distribution of the public school funds to the Roman Catholic Protectory as well as to the various public schools.

To-morrow morning every Knight of Labor who has been hitherto employed in a silverware factory in this country will find his position vacant. He will be allowed to choose between seeking another trade, emigrating to another country, or resigning his membership as a Knight.

BERLIN, April 20.--The Crown Prince Frederick William, it is now stated, is suffering from chronic catarrh of the throat.

At the annual meeting of the Jerome Park Villa Site and Improvement Company yesterday afternoon James R. Keene, John Hunter, John Bloodgood, George S. Fearing, D. B. Van Emburg, W.A. Duer, and Theodore Moss were elected Directors.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 20.--The election for School Trustee last night was the first in the town since the law permitting women to vote went into effect. The women who voted cast their ballots for John Simerson, of the Journal, an eligible widower. Mr. Simerson was elected by a large majority.

LONDON, April 20.--Lord Salisbury, in an address delivered last night before the Primrose League at Albert Palace, the occasion being the sixth anniversary of the death of the Earl of Beaconsfield, said the hollow agitation carried on during the Easter holidays by the Opposition had failed, and that the Government's cause was the country's.

Gen. T.J. Brady, who has been staying at Taylor's Hotel in Jersey City for the past six months, is too ill to leave his room. He is suffering from an abcess. He has been confined to his bed for the last three weeks.

The reorganized Felix Baseball Club of the St. James Literary Union is looking for victories. Address H.A. Gilloon, 49 Henry-street.

A few days ago they arrived in Newark, where they were traced by their friends, and a warrant for their arrest was issued.

HARRISBURG, Penn., April 20.--Both branches of the Legislature adjourned to-night to Monday at 7:30 P.M. The Senate to-day defeated a bill providing for the pensioning of Judges after two years' of service on the bench.
Jeremiah Hopper was found drowned in the Passaic River at Paterson yesterday morning.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 20.--A convention of Presbyterian ministers and laymen of both branches of the church was held in this city this week and adjourned last night. COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., April 20.--George Clarke, probably the largest land owner in the State, made a general assignment to-day to Mr. Barnard, a banker, of Rome. His ruin has been caused by his mania for land. For years all his money has gone for the acquisition of additional real estate.

The Spartan Harriers will make their headquarters at the Manhattan Athletic Club's grounds during the coming season.

People who for the last week have been saying that the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad Company was in full unity with the trunk lines in their war upon commissions to ticket agents have been in a big majority, but they have been mistaken all the same.
The Servia, which arrived on Monday, had George Bubear, the champion sculler of England, on board. Wallace Ross met the Englishman and carried him to Harlem, where he is now stopping.
Tuesday night Alexander Kouski, a pressman, went to his home, 168 Orchard-street, and found his mother, Frederika Kouski, lying dead on a sofa in the front room.

"Boodle" Exile John Keenan has rented his house on Seventh-street to a friend of his, who has just moved into it. The wife of Exile De Lacy has also made all preparations for giving up housekeeping in this city, and will remain with her husband in Montreal.

Hill withdrew today the names of his Knight of Labor and of Granger Armstrong, and nominated two men whose names are well and favorably known to the public.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20.--It is an undeniable fact that the National Opera Company has not made a hit in this city. The second performance was given last night, and though the bill was "Aida" the audience was much smaller than on the opening evening.

WASHINGTON, April 21.--Major F.W. Benteen, of the Ninth Cavalry, was recently sentenced by a court-martial to be dismissed from the service for drunkenness. The President has commuted the sentence to one year's suspension from rank and duty on half pay.

Collector Magone finds that during the past year the exigency supplies at the Custom House, such as cutlery twine, tags, and nails, cost 30 per cent. above market price. One firm put in excessive charges of $569.20, one of $1,165,15, and a third charged $2,010,59 above market rates. Hereafter the Custom House will stand on a plane with common buyers, if the Collector can so arrange it.

"J.F."--Palm Sunday in the year 1836 fell on March 27. William Corcoran pleaded guilty yesterday to burglary, and Judge Cowing sent him to the State prison for six years.

SYRACUSE, April 21.--The enlargement of the five looks on the Erie and of the three locks on the Oswego Canals authorized and ordered by State law a year ago has been prosecuted during the past Winter and this Spring, and is expected to be completed before the opening of navigation next month.

PHELPS, N.Y., April 21.--During a thunderstorm this afternoon, a young man named Frank Tallis, while at work dropping mint on the farm of William Van Valkenburg, was struck by lightning and instantly killed. Another young man was stunned.

LONDON, April 21.--Mr. Goschen, Chancellor of the Exchequer, introduced the budget in the House of Commons this afternoon. It appears that during last year the revenues of the Government amounted to about 90,000,000, and the expenses to nearly the same sum.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 21.--The steamer City of Sydney, from China and Japan, which arrived here to-day, brought 153,000 trade dollars, which will be redeemed with standard dollars. The last Chinese steamer before the City of Sydney brought 270,000 trade dollars.

EVERSON, Penn., April 21.--While walking on the tracks of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad near here to-day two ladies--Mrs. Gettemy and Mrs. Andarson--were struck by a shifting engine and terribly mangled. The former died in a few hours, and Mrs. Anderson is in a precarious condition.

It was the intention of the Twelfth Regiment to make last night an occasion which people would remember, and celebrate the opening of the new armory on Ninth-avenue, between Sixty-first and Sixty-second streets, in an appropriately festive manner.

PHILADELPHIA, April 21.--The jury in the case of Mrs. Sarah Patterson, an alleged medium, charged by the county medical society with practicing medicine and surgery without being registered as a physician,this afternoon returned a verdict of guilty.

BALTIMORE, April 21.--Edward M. Kirkland to-day filed a cross bill for divorce from his wife, Eatelle M. Kirkland, on the ground of infidelity. Two weeks ago his wife applied for divorce, alleging abandonment.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 21.--The greatest anxiety exists among the fruit growers of the Peninsula in regard to the safety of the peach crop.

Wherever horsemen or men interested in racing met last evening there was the liveliest rejoicing over the passage of the Ives Pool bill by the Assembly. Talk of moving racing meetings to New-Jersey was abandoned,
United States Marshal Tate, of Brooklyn, seized the steamer Chandernagor yesterday at Dow's Stores on several charges.
LONDON, April 2l.--The second Spring meeting at Sandown Park began today. The race for the Esher Stakes was won by C.J. Merry's 3-year-old bay colt by Doncaster, out of Shannon.

DES MOINES, IOWA, April 21.--Gov. Larrabee has written a letter in reply to an inquiry from the Secretary of the Central Committee of the prohibitory campaign of Texas in regard to the workings of prohibition in Iowa.

TORONTO, April 21.--The reported offer of Lord Salisbury to settle the fishery question with the United States is not well received here. Several of the leading papers refuse to believe that the Imperial Government would perpertrate...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 21.--Manager J.E. McDonough will open his now opera house at this place next Monday night with Mr. Joseph Jefferson and company in the play of "Rip Van Winkle." ERIE, Penn., April 2l.--This afternoon three fishermen, James Murphy, William Schumaker, and Thomas McCullough were seriously injured in a very peculiar manner. They were standing on the dock watching a steam tug tearing down an old building, and were caught by a line which struck their heads, fracturing the skulls of two and injuring the third very seriously. All are in a precarious condition.

TROY, N.Y., April 21.--Mrs. John Benson, of Elizabeth, N.J., appeared in the police court here to-day as complainant against William H. and Fannie Grant, husband and wife.

ST. LOUIS, April 21.--The United States court room was crowded to-day by friends of the convicted politicians, who were called up for sentence. John J. Prendergast, Deputy Democratic Recorder, found guilty of false registration, was the first to face the music.

The investigation into the Rahway murder mystery was continued yesterday by Coroner Terrill and jury. At the rate at which the inquest is at present proceeding it is more than probable that it will last through the coming week.

For the third time this season the Master Car Builders' Association last night discussed lighting, heating, and ventilating passenger cars. The oil gas system of lighting used on some of the Erie's cars was shown, and so was a device to ventilate cars from the roof.

People couldn't get down town and travel was stopped. The ticket seller at the bridge station would not sell tickets for nearly half an hour. Commissioner Pierson, of the Trunk Line Passenger Committee, is a bit under the weather. His trip to Chicago last week resulted in a severe cold, and now he keeps at home trying to shake it off.

Everything was working smoothly at Higgins's carpet factory yesterday. The operatives did not seem to be alarmed over the report that their district assembly was going to be suspended.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 21.--Last night the Chief of Police ordered the enforcement of the ordinance forbidding the sweeping of dirt and dust into street gutters. This morning about 40 clerks were arrested for sweeping dirt thrown on the sidewalks by the sweeping machines last night into the gutters. They were discharged, the Justice holding that their cases did not violate the ordinance in question. There is considerable excitement over the affair.

Grand Army of the Republic posts in Western New-York were represented. Gen. William W. Rogers, of Buffalo, and Col. Sommers, of Tonawanda, were present. Past Senior Vice-Department Commander James Fitts made a enlogistic address at the grave.

William Ellis who has been on trial all this week in the Court of General Sessions, Part I., for the murder of his wife, has escaped the gallows.

LANCASTER, Penn., April 22.--Mrs. Mary Ann Goshert, who shot and killed Levi Books at her home in Elizabeth Township on March 4, was placed on trial for murder this morning and the trial occupied the whole day.
John R. Burdick, Vice-President and Manager of the American Insulated Conduit Company, was on the witness stand for four hours yesterday in the McMahon-Flynn subway suit.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--Major Morse K. Taylor, Surgeon, has been relieved from duty at Fort Sill, Indian Territory, and ordered to proceed to his home to await retirement. Assistant Surgeon J.M. Cabell has been ordered to temporary duty at Fort Omaha, Nebraska.

The striking silverworkers held a meeting yesterday morning at 5 East Fourth-street. The silversmiths and silverchasers' unions each appointed a committee to act in concert in trying to reach an understanding with the manufacturers.

CHICAGO, April 22.--The creditors of the defunct jewelry firm of Clapp Davies held another meeting to-day. The committee, consisting of H.S. Peck, R.A. Kettle, and J.W. Meacham, appointed to inquire into the causes of the failure, made a minute report.

Five cases of smallpox have appeared at Shaft No. 14 of the new Croton Aqueduct. The victims are all colored men. KEYPORT, N.J., April 22.--William Applegate committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the heart with a revolver. He was 25 years of age, unmarried, and a painter. He was a sufferer from melancholia and three years ago made an unsuccessful attempt on his life by cutting his throat. His people live at Cranbury, Middlesex County, where the body will be sent for burial.

NORWALK, Conn., April 22.--Hezekiah Lockwood, a venerable and white-haired old gentleman, a resident of Green's Farms, was run over and instantly killed this afternoon by the limited express going west.

CITY of MEXICO, April 22.--The Senate has received from the Chamber of Deputies a resolution repealing the clause of the Constitution forbidding the immediate re-election of a President. In the lower house it passed by a vote of 168 to 9. It will undoubtedly pass the Senate and then go to the various States for ratification. Under the contemplated change the President would be ineligible to a third term immediately succeeding a second term.

ERIE, Penn., April 23.--Joseph Nathan, a NewYork millinery jobber, was arrested here to-night on a charge of forgery in New-York. Nathan is very reticent, but the amount is said to be large. BALTIMORE, April 23.--Klinefelter Brothers, bag manufacturers, made an assignment late to-day to Thomas Fluharty for the benefit of their creditors. The bond of the Trustee is $150,000, indicating $75,000 assets.

Wilkinson, to whom he confesssed a shortage in his accounts of over $400. FLORENCE, April 8.--Among the developments of this age, so rich in the conception and carrying out of grand schemes, is a spirit for completing things which, striding from country to country of the Old World, is putting its stamp on so many time-honored and noble edifices hitherto beautiful indeed and majestic, but wanting in some important feature included in its design.

About 300 ladies braved yesterday's rainstorm to attend the last of Miss Juliet Corson's lectures on gas-stove cookery at the Metropolitan Opera House assembly room. An elaborate domestic menu was served, and the ladies were not slow to express their surprise at the end of the seance that less than 10 cents' worth of gas had done all the boiling, baking, broiling, frying, and roasting with a minimum of trouble and no handsoiling whatever.
STILLWATER, Minn., April 23.--Receiver Brown, or the Northwestern Manufacturing and Car Company, has completed his annual report, showing the condition of the company March 1 last.

The eleventh annual Spring dog show will open at Madison-Square Garden on Tuesday, May 3, and continue four days. There are over 950 entries. In point of quality the exhibition is expected to surpass the previous ones, and the dogs will be better handled and cared for.
BALTIMORE, April 23.--Mr. Staynor was here to-day and had a conference with President Robert Garrett, of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
