CITY OF MEXICO, April 23.--To all who approached President Diaz yesterday with congratulations upon the action of the Chamber of Deputies Thursday evening in paving the way for his reelection he replied that he was not seeking another term and was not a candidate.

It is not out of the way to fancy that the anonymous author of this volume has read his Amiel and conceived the idea of describing an existence tortured by physical pain, interspersing hours of agony with sage reflections.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 23.--The steamer Captain Miller, running between Centreville, Md., and Baltimore, was burned at her wharf at the for mer place this morning. The fire is supposed to have been of an incendiary origin. The loss is half covered by insurance.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 23.--Patrick H. Redmond, who for the past year was a member of the city staff of the Times, died quite suddenly last night in the Medico-Chirurgical College Hospital from blood poisoning, following a surgical operation for an internal trouble.
Prince Bismarck celebrated his seventysecond birthday to-day, immense crowds assembling, as usual, in Wilhelm-strasse, opposite the Chancellor's Palace, from an early hour.

The Ivanhoe Paper Mill, at Paterson, N. J., is one of the best known in the country, having been at the time of its erection, about 1850, the best equipped of any in the United States, the cost footing up $500,000. It is on Spruce street, opposite Market. Toward the street it presents a solid blank wall of brick.
The Rev. Basil Wilberforce, M.A., Canon of Winchester, is at the Brevoort House, accompanied by his wife and daughter.

NOTTINGHAM, England, April 23.--Three thousand persons who filled the Theatre Royal, Nottingham, from floor to ceiling to-night, witnessed Miss Mary Anderson's first appearance in "A Winter's Tale," acting both Hermione and Perdita.

BUTTE, Montana, April 23.--A Utah Northern north-bouned freight train broke in two last night in Beaver Canon and 18 cars ran down the grade for several miles, finally jumping the track. All the cars were completely wrecked. Conductor Lowery was caught in the wreck, had one of his legs broken three times, and was seriously burned. He cannot recover. The brakeman escaped uninjured.
DETROIT, April 23.--In 1884 W.G. Mitchell bought out the private banking business of Fisher Preston in this city, and since that time has conducted what he named the Exchange Bank at the same stand.
LONDON, April 23.--Mr. Chamberlain, speaking at Stornoway to-night, said the land was the gift of the Almighty and ought to be treated as a trust, not as an absolute possession of private owners.
OZARK, Mo., April 23.--The Grand Jury returned 16 more indictments for murder in the first degree in the Bald Knobber cases for the Killing of Charles Green.

The old story declaring that President King and about one-half of the Directors of the Erie Railroad had resigned was started upon a fresh round in Wall-street yesterday. "Internal dissensions" was the phrase quoted to account for the wholesale resignations. The story met the fate of its fac simile predecessors--everybody interested denied it.

CHICAGO, Ill., April 23.--The Thorn Wire Hedge Company filed a bill in the Superior Court yesterday against the Washburn Moen Manufacturing Company for an accounting with the defendant, alleging that an inspection of the books and accounts of the Washburn Moen Company will disclose an indebtedness to the complainant of $200,000. The claim arises on a contract between the parties in relation to wire and metallic fence patents. An accounting is asked for.

The week that closed last evening was not an exciting one in society. There were a few weddings, several dinners, and of course some amateur theatricals, but the unseasonable snowstorm of Monday seemed to have chilled the social as well as the natural atmosphere, and the days glided by without any notable events to mark their flight.

--The Summer camp is one round of labor for the plebe, as the firstyear man is called at West Point. If he were transported to another planet there could hardly be a greater change in his life than that which he experiences when he leaves the comforts of his home and plunges into the routine of military drill and discipline of West Point.

Paris, April 23.--Whether the fiercely debated Schnaebeles incident turns out to be a grave historic event or only a petty misunderstanding, everybody is agreed that it is fortunate that the production of "Lohengrin," owing to the need of further preparation, has been postponed until Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 23.--Missourians are given to "slopping over" when they talk, and some of the representatives of that State have permitted themselves to slop over in the Missouri, Republican with temporarily sensational effect.

Mr. George W. Childs has accepted the appointment tendered him by President Cleveland as one of the Board of Visitors to the Military Academy at West Point. He said yesterday that, although some of the most important positions in the country had been offered him, this was the first he had consented to accept. His action, he remarked, had been influenced by the method adopted in tendering the position.

The Queen gave some weeks ago what has since been called a home rule dinner, for no better reason than that Mr. and Mrs. Gladstone, John Morley, and Sir William Harcourt were the chief guests summoned to Windsor for the occasion.

CHICAGO, April 23.--The Hon. James G. Blaine received a delegation from the Irish-American and one from the German-American Club in his parlors to-day, but at his request no speeches were made. He remained standing while the gentlemen, numbering possibly 250, were presented to him, and shook hands with them all. At the close of the reception he thanked them for their courtesy, but excused himself for not addressing them, owing to his ill health.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 23.--Drafts on NewYork--Sight, 17 cents; telegraphic, 22 cents. The Clearing House exchanges for the past week were $13,264,109.

WASHINGTON, April 23.--The Inter-State Commerce Commission has made an order suspending the fourth section of the law for 75 days, subject to revocation, and with a proviso that intermediate rates shall not be raised above those in force on April 20. This applies to the Northern Pacific, Southern Pacific, Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe, and St. Louis and San Francisco Lines.

BERLIN, April 23.--The North German Gazette semi-officially states that the arrest of M. Schnaebeles took place on German territory. The authorities had received information that M. Schnaebeles had been conducting himself in a suspicious manner at Metz and other places on the frontier.

LONDON, April 23.--All the accounts which reach me from the Continent, while explaining why the seizure of Schnaebeles cannot possibly amount to anything, agree that it has stirred up a prodigious feeling, and, so far as the popular mind and financial pulse go, has revived at a stroke the pessimistic tremors of January.

CHICAGO, April 23.--The record in the Wilbur F. Storey case was filed in the Circuit Court to-day on an appeal from the Probate Court on behalf of Anson L. Storey to the admitting to record of the will of 1879, appointing Eureka C. Storey Executrix. Judge Trumbull also entered his appearance as counsel for Mrs. Storey.

KEENE, N.H., April 23.--The operation of the inter-State commerce law has compelled the abandonment of business at Sprague's box factory at Swanzey. The factory has been turning out over 3,000 boxes daily.

It is one of the most common of remarks that New-York ought to be the most healthy and comfortable city to live in in the world. For a large and populous city its situation is certainly unequaled. It has not simply a fresh water stream running through it like London or Paris.

Mrs. Jane Harris, of 273 East Fourthstreet, still insists that the victim of the Rahway murder was her sister, Mary Dorman. She said to a TIMES reporter last night that her sister Mary was born in December, 1862, at their house in Scotland. Another sister, Maggie, is the wife of Andrew Kirkwood, and now lives in Glasgow.

BALTIMORE, April 23.--Baltimore has the club fever. Clubs thrive more numerously and luxuriantly now than ever before in the city's history. New organizations are springing up every week. Political clubs are increasing so rapidly that the day is not far distant when they may rule the city.

The case of Train, Smith Co., of Boston, against Charles B. Kondall and John L. Taylor, which has been on trial in Part I. of the Supreme Court, before Judge Beach and a jury, for nearly three weeks, came to an end yesterday morning. The jury returned a verdict in favor of the plaintiffs for $5,771 87, the full amount of their claim.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23.--The ground was in bad condition to-day and the attendance meagre. The Athletics hit Cushman hard, particularly in the early innings. The Mets, except in the eighth inning, were unable to bunch their hits.

TRENTON, N.J., April 24.--All the subordainate lodges of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows are interested in a question which has recently arisen in regard to the terms of office of their officers.

NOGALES, Arizona, April 24.--The Chief of Police has received a dispatch stating that cholera is raging in the Mexican town of Mazatlan, and that the disease has broken out at Guaymas. People are leaving the infected districts in large numbers.
The Hoffman House apothecary shop is practically the New-York headquarters for traveling Californians.

BERLIN, April 24.--The commission at Metz investigating the case of the French Commissary Schnaebeles reports that the arrest was undoubtedly made upon German soil. There are numerous charges of high treason against Schnaebeles and the evidence against him is overwhelming.
CITY OF MEXICO, April 24.--The War Department makes known the facts of a doubly fatal duel.

ERIE, Penn., April 24.--Scientific and medical circles are surprised at what they regard as a miraculous recovery from paralysis at the Soldiers' and Sailors' Home.

ALBANY, April 24.--Democratic warhorses are beginning to sniff the smoke of convention from afar. In five short months their party will assemble at Saratoga, unless another place is indicated by their State Committee to nominate five State officers whose fate will have great bearing upon the party's prospects in the Presidental race of the succeeding year.

ST. LOUIS, April 24.--The Republican has it from as reliable source that the Directory of the Ohio and Mississippi Road are seriously discussing the propriety of removing the general offices to St. Louis. At present all the general offices except the general freight office are in Cincinnati.
WASHINGTON, April 24.--The truth is all out about the origin of the St. Louis Republican story that the President would on no account accept a renomination.

A marked change in the current of the grain-carrying traffic appears to be in progress. In March, 1886, there were no exports of wheat via New-Orleans, but last month a half million bushels were exported through that city.

Superintendent John Jasper on April 20 addressed an official letter to the Commissioners of Education saying: "I hereby recommend the removal of Mr. Edward J. Delaney, Principal of the male department of Grammar school No. 21, for incompetency."

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 24.--The feeling is rapidly growing among the Iowa shippers that the inter-state commerce law is a bad thing for them, and a movement is on foot to create a sentiment that will impel Gov. Larrabee to call a special session of the Legislature to devise means of relief.
The Rev. Dr. John J. Duffy , Rector of St. Mary's Catholic church, Rondout, will take a trip to Europe next month for the benefit of his health.

WHEELING, West Va., April 24.--The legislative Committee on Railroads will meet the Presidents and attorneys of the various railroads of the State to-morrow, in order that the views of the companies relative to the proposed railroad legislation may be learned. The pending bill regulates both freight and passenger charges, fixing the latter at a maximum of 2 cents per mile, and also appoints a railroad commission.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 24.--The Right Rev. Bishop Potter was here to-day administering the rite of confirmation in the three Episcopal churches. All of the churches were packed with people, and there was a profusion of flowers in each one. Nearly 100 persons were confirmed.
LONDON, April 24.--A disastrous fire has occurred at Arnautkeiu, Asia Minor. Five hundred houses were burned and many persons lost their lives.

DETROIT, April 24.--David Preston, for 35 years head of the banking house bearing his name in this city, died with startling suddenness this morning in the sixty-first year of his age.

Bishop Walker preached in the "Floating Church," at the foot of Pike-street, yesterday afternoon. The Bishop spoke of the sselfishness of the leaders in all wrongdoing, and referred directly to the leaders in strikes and labor difficulties of all kinds.

BOSTON, April 24.--The social event of the coming week will be the marriage of Mr. R. Montgomery Field, manager of the Boston Museum, to Miss Cynthia Endicott, daughter of the Hon. Charles Endicott, of Canton.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 24.--The jury in the Durning murder trial came into court this evening, shortly after 6 o'clock, with a verdict of murder in the second degree, after having been out for 49 hours.

TRENTON, N.J., April 24.--William Seman, an aged German night watchman at Dale Davis's pottery, was shot in the back of the neck by an unknown assailant at 3 o'clock this morning. Seman was shoveling coal, when some one sneaked up and fired with a revolver. The ball was extracted this afternoon, and he will recover. A tramp who had been driven off the premises by Seman is believed to have done the shooting.

RONDOUT, N.Y., April 24.--Detectives who have been at work on the Hasbrouck-avenue dynamite case say that there are no clues, and no arrests have been made. The attempt to blow up the buildings and to destroy life creates much indignation. District-Attorney Vanderlyn will investigate the crime to-morrow.

"Joe" Coburn, the notorious prize fighter, was a prisoner yesterday morning at the Jefferson Market Police Court, having been arrested for a violation of the theatrical law.

The Harlem River smiled under a cloudless sky yesterday, and so did the thousands of people who stood upon its banks, voyaged upon its waters, or hung suspended from the inviting rails of its bridges. It was a day of days. Every prospect pleased, and even the mud was not so vile as it might have been.

FORT SNELLING, Minn., April 24.--Lieut J.H. G. Wilcox, of the Seventh Cavalry, the regiment cut to pieces in the Custer massacre, will be tried here to-morrow under three charges, with their specifications.
The Rev. Dr. Talmage, at yesterday morning's service in the Brooklyn Tabernacle, poured out the vials of his wrath upon the proprietors of stores who ill treat their clerks.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 25.--Six chambermaids and 19 laundry girls employed in the Forest City House struck to-day. The chambermaids struck because the housekeeper ordered them at work at an earlier hour than formerly, and the laundry girls out of sympathy followed suit. Then all joined in a formal statement of grievances, which includes a complaint about the quality of food served to the working women.

The Seawanhaka Yacht Club met last night in Delmonico's and adopted a now constitution. Reports were made announcing that the new clubhouse, at 5 East Thirty-second-street, will be ready for occupancy in May, and that some of the rooms will be let to bachelor members. These gentlemen were proposed for membership: Edmund C. Stanton, J. Bryant Lindley, Gerald L. Hoyt, J. BeavorWebb, Lloyd Phoenix, George Griswold Haven, F. Augustus Schermerhorn, and Charles F. Leland.
Ezra Daggett, proprietor of the Cremorne Garden, in West Thirty-second-street, yesterday pleaded guilty to violation of the excise law, and Recorder Smyth fined him $100.

TEESWATER, Ontario, April 25.--Robert Moffatt, of Restigouche, member of the Dominion Parliament, was found dead in bed here this morning. He arrived here last night apparently in good health. He was on a visit to friends at this place.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 25.--The Princeton lacrosse team played against the Lawrenceville school team to-day and won by a score of 9 to 0. Edwards, '89, has been appointed Captain of the university scrub lacrosse team.
There were no new developments in the Rahway mystery yesterday. Interest in the case is beginning to die out, even in the little town in which the scene is laid.
PORT MONMOUTH, N.J., April 25.--The greatest catch of shad ever known along the bay shore was made to-day by the fishermen of this place.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25.--The Supreme Court finally decided this morning in favor of the heirs of the late Horace Binney, Jr., in the suit which they have been for several years contesting against a poor old colored man named Morris Brown.

HARRISONBURG, Va., April 25.--A local option election was held to-day in four of the five districts in this county. The Harrisonburg district gave 244 Prohibition majority, the Ash by district about 800, and the other two districts are claimed by the Prohibitionists by small majorities. Everything passed off quietly.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 25.--The Standard Oil Company perfected an organization under the laws of Indiana this afternoon.

A truly regal present has been sent by the King of Portugal to the German Emperor, which is worth all the other royal birthday gifts put together. It is a sword of honor, with a blade specially made at the Lisbon arsenal, and exquisitely chiseled. The hilt is of solid gold incrusted in every part with diamonds, sapphires, rubies, and emeralds. These were set after a design supplied by the Queen.
BRUSSELS, April 25.--Advices from the Stanley expedition for the relief of Emin Bey have been received from Matadi, on the Congo River, dated March 25.
The New-York and New-England Railroad's bear contingent got in its fine work yesterday, and the price of the stock was knocked down two or three points quite easily.

Health Officer William M. Smith, of the Port of New-York, was yesterday called to testify for the defense in the rag importers' suit against Bartlett Co. and himself. Dr. Smith was bothered a great deal by a frog in his throat, but the lawyers were pitiless and kept him hemming and hawing at frequent intervals all day.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 25.--The Chancery Court rooms were crowded this morning in anticipation of the beginning of the great Hocking Valley Railroad injunction suit, involving $8,000,000.

CHICAGO, April 25.--East-bound shipments of dead freight continue unusually light. The total shipments by the various Central Traffic Association roads from Chicago through to seaboard points last week amounted to only 29,822 tons, against 30,147 tons for the week previous.
The Hartrords and the Jersey City nine will play this afternoon in Jersey City.

PARIS, April 25.--It is stated that Herr von Leyden, the German Charge d' Affaires, has informed M. Flourens, Minister of Foreign Affairs, that Prince Bismarck regretted that the Leipsic court had ordered the arrest of M. Schnaebeles without consulting the Chancellor for an offense concerning which Prince Bismarck reserved his decision.

Coroner Messemer yesterday resumed the inquest in the case of Mrs. Lena Reich, who was found with her throat cut on the night of April 19 in the hallway of her residence, 144 Norfolkstreet. Her husband Adolph, who has been arrested on suspicion of having murdered her, was present, but as he does not understand English manifested little concern.
The factory of the W.C. Vosburgh Manufacturing Company in State-street, Brooklyn, was totally destroyed by fire early last evening, and stock valued at $150,000 was lost.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 25.--A special to the American to-night from Harper's Ferry gives the particulars of a terrific explosion of an old shell with serious results to six persons.

ALBANY, April 25.--The Republican majority in the Senate adjusted its accounts with Lieut.-Gov. Jones and with the Governor tonight by calmly declining to allow any mention of the latter's message to be made in the journal of last Friday's proceedings.

TROY, April 25.--A delegation of members of Mecca Temple, Nobles of the Mystic Shrine, of NewYork City, visited this city to-night. They were met at the railroad station by members of Oriental Temple and escorted to the hotel. Subsequently, in Masonic Temple, the degrees were conferred upon 70 candidates from Troy, Saratoga, Little Falls, and other places. A banquet followed the ceremonies.

That new Broadway Theatre on the site of the present Cosmopolitan Hall, at Broadway and Forty-first-street, is to be built after all, and Mr. Eliot Zobrowski is to have a box in it.

QUEBEC, April 25.--Three young men named respectively. Charles Moreau, August Rousseau, end Joseph Huard were drowned at St. Romuald yesterday by the unsetting of a boat. Honore Huard saved himself by clinging to a cake of ice.
Miss Annie Pixley appeared at the Union Square Theatre last evening in a new play expressly constructed for her by that practiced stage carpenter Mr. Archibald C. Gunter.

A strange life ended yesterday in the suicide of Emanuel Zuke, at Orange, N.J. On Sunday night Zuke asked Frank Fiske, a fellow-jorneyman hatter, to call at his rooms by noon yesterday, as he wished to make him some presents.

PORTLAND, Me., April 25.--The Schooner Parker M. Hooper, of Bath, sailed from Havana for Boston Feb. 26, and has not been heard from since. To-day a cablegram was received from Almeria, Spain, signed by Capt. Harkness, who belongs in Camden. This relieves the fears for the safety of the crew. They were probably taken off the schooner and carried to Almeria.

CHICAGO, April 25.--Goerge A. Wrisley, proprietor of a soap factory at 40 Fullerton-avenue, made an assignment to-day. TRENTON, N.J., April 25.--Robert Sanderson, aged 75, an old and prominent Odd Fellow, who has been missing from his home in Bristol, Penn., since Thursday last, was found drowned in Neshaminy Creek to-day. As the old gentleman was deranged, it is believed he committed suicide.

Bernhardt's work was very artistic, but even she could not rouse an indifferent audience into giving her anything like hearty welcome.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 25.--Waterbury people were much surprised to-night when it became noised about that senator Sherman and Gen. W.T. Sherman had arrived in that city and were anxious to be unobserved. Some of the old members of the Sherman family are buried at Woodbury, near Waterbury, and it has been learned that the brothers had merely gone to Waterbury to visit their ancestors' graves.
ST. LOUIS, April 25.--The most startling rumors are current to-night regarding the proceedings of the Federal Grand Jury.
MONTREAL, April 25.--The water commenced to subside about 5 o'clock this morning and has now fallen about a foot. The City Surveyor estimates that 26 miles of street were under water yesterday.

ALBANY, April 26.--Bank Superintendent Willis S. Paine has issued his certificate authorizing the State bank of Norwood, St. Lawrence County, to transact a general banking under the state laws with paid up capital stock of $25,000.

Yesterday's meeting of the New-York and New-England Railroad Company's Directors turned out to be innocent and harmless enough, and Wall-street was disappointed. There was no discussion of stock speculations and no criticisms of Directors who take "flyers" on the bear side.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 26.--Prof. Townsend, of the Yale Law School, and Lawyer Miller, of New-York, were in the Superior Court room this afternoon, as counsel for the city of New-York, to object to the release of Nathaniel Sands.
NEWTON, N.J., April 26.--The young women of this town have formed an "anti-vice" society, having for its object the regeneration of young men.

HACKETTSTOWN, N.J., April 26.--The work of demolishing the old frame Methodist. Episcopal Church, at Main and Church streets, began this morning. A new stone building capable of seating 900 will be erected on the site. It will be of Gothic architecture and will cost $40,000. The congregation is one of the strongest in the Newark Conference.

It is inside the Metropolitan Opera House, and is the most popular village in America just now, as its main industry is charity, its population consists entirely of young ladies, and the chief occupation of its inhabitants in flirtation.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 26.--A.J., Carter, an officer of Clay County, was shot and killed at Centreville yesterday by A.H. Clements after a quarrel about an old lawsuit. Carter, who was armed with a double-barreled shotgun, advanced upon Clements, who drew a revolver and fired. The bullet passed through the heart of Carter, who fell dead. Clements has not been arrested. Carter was a prominent man and Clements is a citizen of high standing.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 26.--The fire in the Grand Opera House last night was caused by defective flues in the heating apparatus. Steps will be taken immediately to make the heating apparatus perfectly safe.

HARRISONBURG, Va., April 27.--A freight train going north on the Valley Branch of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was wrecked near Timberville Station about 1 o'clock to-day. The Board of Education at a special meeting yesterday decided to lease for three more years, at $2,400 a year, from the Trinity Corporation, the site of Grammar School No. 29, at 97 and 99 Greenwich-street.

The jury in the case of Lockwood McClintock, the rag importers, against E.B. Bartlett and Health Officer Smith, could not reach a verdict last night.

BOSTON, April 28.--The latest railroad consolidation scheme to be carried into effect is that which gives the Boston and Maine absolute control of all the principal railroads of Northern New-England, and which is now positively consummated.

The long search for Edwin J. Dunning, a Wall-street note broker, who was indicted in August, 1886, for the larceny of $13,200 from S. Zeimer Feldstein, importers, of 624 Broadway, ended yesterday, in his arrest at his flat, 1,519 Broadway.

BOSTON, April 28.--For some days it has been reported that the plan of consolidating the horse railroads of Boston had been agreed upon, and that the proposition had commended itself to the holders of stock in the Metropolitan, Cambridge, and South Boston Roads. The Directors of the roads by formal vote, it is now known, have accepted the proposition.

PARIS, April 28.--The Journal des Debats publishes a dispatch from Berlin stating that the Schnaebeles affair has been amicably settled between France and Germany.

NYACK, April 28.--There are numerous Germans living in the vicinity of Closter who have long desired a place of worship where they and their children could be instructed in the doctrines of the Lutheran Church.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., April 21.--On Monday, the 17th inst., Mrs. Joseph Farnsworth, aged 25 years, ran away with her husband's father, Nathan Farnsworth, aged 60 years. Mrs. Farnsworth left two small children.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 28.--As a large audience was coming out of the First Presbyterian Church in this city to-night the flooring of the vestibule gave away, precipitating about 20 people into the cellar beneath. As soon as possible they were released, and it was found that at least half a dozen had been bruised and injured badly by the fall. The accident is attributed to rotten and decayed floor timbers.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 28.--The most important action taken by the Presbytery of Hudson at the semi-annual session just closed at Chester related to the overture handed down by the General Assembly of the church for determining the prohibited degrees of relationship in marriage.

Alfred Chancellor, the 12-year-old son of Mrs. Maria Chancellor, a widow living at 423 East Eighty-sixth-street, has been away from his home since the 5th inst., and his mother is in great distress at his absence.

WASHINGTON, N.J., April 28.--Warren County is again in a furor of excitement, this time over a scandal involving some prominent persons.

WHEELING, West Va., April 28.--The old established drug firm of Robert A. McCabe Co. made an assignment to-day, with liabilities of $20,000 to $25,000 and assets of perhaps half that amount. The firm has done business here for a generation and was supposed to be financially solid. The debts are mostly owing to Wheeling parties.

President Charles Francis Adams sat down with the Pacific Railroad Commissioners at 10 Wall-street yesterday morning and devoted the day to telling some of the things he knew about the Union Pacific Railroad.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--Mrs. Whitney gave one of the most elaborate dinner parties of the season this evening. Covers were laid for 24, and the invited guests were all unmarried people.
The Lincoln Club of Brooklyn, an organization of 300 business men, celebrated its tenth anniversary last evening by giving a reception to its lady friends.
CHICAGO, April 28.--A windstorm lasting only a few minutes blew down four half-finished cottages at Forty-ninth and Butterfield streets this afternoon, killing two men instantly.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 28.--The argument on the exception of the United States in the cause of action in the Oil Trust injunction suit was finished to-day. The court dismissed the injunction, so far as Glenny and Violet are concerned, and will rule on the other points next Tuesday.

Thomas C. Acton was the recipient of many congratulations yesterday on the report that he has agreed to accept the Presidency of a new national bank, soon to be established in this city in the neighborhood of the Metropolitan Opera House.

The troubles of the First Reformed Church, whose building on Joralemon-street, Brooklyn, was sold for $250,000 and torn down to make room for a panorama, came before a special meeting of the Classis in the Reformed Church on the Heights yesterday.
EDINBURGH, April 28.--The Duke of Portland's residence at Robertland, his seat in Ayrshire, has been destroyed by fire.

CITY OF MEXICO, via Galveston, April 28.--The Diario Official denies that cholera has reached the Isthmus of Panama, as stated in a dispatch from El Paso, Texas, to a Chicago newspaper.

Judge Donohue yesterday announced that he had decided to hear the petition of the Metropolitan Transit Company for the appointment of Commissioners to appraise the sum which the company should pay to the city for the use of its streets to build therein an elevated railroad.

OTTAWA, April 28.--The Fisheries Department propose to send another exploring expedition to the northern waters of British Columbia this Summer with the object of completing the survey of Black Cod Banks discovered in the Pacific, northeast of Vancouver Island. A number of fishing firms operating in the Gulf of St. Lawrence have sent representatives to British Columbia and if their reports prove favorable, they will commence this season dry curing fish for export.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--Second Lieut. Jacob F. Kreps has been detailed as Professor of Military Science and Tactics at Allegheny College, Meadville, Penn., relieving First Lieut. A.M. Fuller, Second Cavalry, who has been ordered to join his troop.

CHICAGO, April 28.--Notices were sent to the newspaper offices announcing that the picture of "Christ Before Pilate" was to be seen at one of the audience rooms of the Methodist Church Block. The picture was found in a darkened room, facing many rows of seats.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 28.--Sharp Smith, of Spartanburg County, went to work on his farm Wednesday and left three young children in the house not far distant. The building in some manner caught fire and the three children were burned to death. Two years ago the mother of the several children was killed in a tornado, which blew the house down.
The rain has ceased to fall and the warm sun has come forth and is now becking the wheat forward to have a head put on it.--Moscow (Idaho) Mirror.
LONDON, April 29.--A dispatch from Rome to the Chronicle says: "The Rev. Dr. McGlynn, of New-York, has again informed the Vatican that he refuses to come to Rome."
The contention of the two factions in the Seventeenth Assembly District cropped out again at the meeting of the enrolled Republicans of the district last night.
YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia, April 23.--The people living about the Tusket Islands and the neighboring mainland have passed 48 hours of terrible anxiety.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 28.--The will of Alexander Mitchell, the deceased banker and railroad magnate, has been read in private to his family. It has not yet been filed for probate, and may not be placed before the public for some time to come.

CINCINNATI, April 28.--Notice was served upon the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad officials a week ago by the President of the Union Passenger Station Company that its trains must cease running into the Union Station after July 1.

The sudden illness of Mr. Boucicault was given as the reason for closing the Star Theatre last evening. The illness was nothing serious, however, and but few people were disappointed, as but few went to the theatre to see "The Jilt."
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 28.--Sixty-six horses were sold at to-day's combination sale, the sale being then postponed on account of the rain.
ST. LOUIS, April 28.--The United States Grand Jury returned 13 indictments in the election fraud cases to-day.

Corporation Counsel Lacombe has decided that the brushing of dust or rubbish alreay on the sidewalks into the gutters is not illegal.
CHICAGO, April 28.--Dispatches received here to-day reported the finding of two valuable mines in the northern part of Mexico.
Mr. GLADSTONE'S account of Mr. PARNELL'S letter to him, written just after the murders of the Phoenix Park, is declared to have caused "an absorbing sensation" in London.

WASHINGTON, April 28.--At the meeting to-day of the Baltimore Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, which is in session here, the Rev. Mr. Handy introduced resolutions of regret at the death of Gen. John A. Logan, with a fitting tribute to his life and character.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, April 28.--At this morning's session of the Grand Army of the Republic, Ohio Department Encampment, the election of officers was held, resulting as follows: D.C. Putnam, of this city, Department Commander; C.H. Jones, Waynesburg, Senior Vice-Commander; John W. Byron, Soldiers' Home, Dayton, Junior Vice-Commander.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 28.--The Grand Jury of Christian County, which has for two weeks been investigating the night raids of the Bald Knobbers completed their work yesterday and handed 15 more bills to Judge Hubbard, and were then discharged.

The sixty-eighth anniversary of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows was celebrated by the Odd Fellows' Literary Society with an entertainment in the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon and evening.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 28.--Joseph Smith, head of the reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of the Latter-Day Saints, otherwise known as monogomous Mormons, began his missionary work here tonight, lecturing in Music Hall. He expects to scatter broadcast the seeds of his sect, and contemplates an extended tour.

Holders of copper mine stock are a good deal worried over the disclosures that contracts have been made by the Calumet and Hecla Company, of Michigan, for the delivery of about 8,000,000 pounds of copper, at 10 cents a pound, between June and September.

Yesterday was the day fixed for the opening of Fleetwood Park, with the proviso of "good day and track." It was not a good day, and the track was heavy, and so the opening day was fixed for next Wednesday.

Cedarhurst will be the scene of some good racing on Saturday next, and a brilliant opening of the racing season is certain, if the weather is pleasant. The grounds are in splendid condition, new jumps have been placed, and the stands put in good condition for the accommodation of such as may wish to enjoy the sport.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 28.--Several vessels which put into this port to-day showed the effects of the heavy gale on Tuesday.

LONDON, April 28.--A dispatch from Perth, the capital of Western Australia, says: "A hurricane swept the northeast coast on the 22d inst. The pearl-fishing fleet, numbering 40 boats, was destroyed and 550 persons perished."

The stables at Third-avenue and Thirtyfourth-street having become useless to the Third-avenue Railroad Company with the discontinuance of the Lexington-avenue line of cars, were put up at auction yesterday in the Real Estate Exchange.
In the heart of the furniture district, on the western edge of Harry Howard-square, there was a fire last night which kept a large force of firemen busy for three hours.
BOSTON, April 28.--The Gaston Schoolhouse, situated on L-street, between Fifth and Sixth streets, South Boston, was partially destroyed by fire this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 28.--Advices from Kodiak, Alaska, bearing the date of April 5, state that the schooner Flying Scud, hailing from that port, was recently lost at sea. There were on board the owner, H. Anderson; the Captain, Nels Hansen; Vassili Grignoff, his son, and 14 native hunters. All were lost. It is supposed that the vessel shifted her ballast and capsized in a gale in Shelikoff Straits.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28.--The Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchange have informally agreed to make no change in the present line and city and harbor prices of coal during May.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 28.--The arrest of Mrs. Elmina D. Slenker in the pretty little village of Snowville, Pulaski County, by United States Marshal J.R. Jordan created quite a sensation in that peaceful community.
In a very informal way Canon Wilberforce, of Southampton, England, met his clerical and lay friends in the parlors of the Broadway Tabernacle last night.

LONDON, April 28.--The Cambridge University Boat Club has appointed a committee to make arrangements with the Harvard University Boat Club for a race between the Cambridge and Harvard crews to take place in America some time during the month of September.

Police Commissioner Voorhis accompanied Mr. Henry R. Beekman, the President of the Board of Aldermen, on a tour through the city on Wednesday night, visited certain places of unsavory reputation to see whether they were really closed, as reported by the police.

ALBANY, April 28.--In spite of the stubborn opposition offered by the Democrats an extension of time until May 5 was granted by the Assembly to-day to the Bacon committee, which has been unearthing frauds in Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, April 28.--To-day's wheat market was less excited and its fluctuations were not so sharp as Wednesday's but the volume of trade was large, and commission men congratulated themselves at the receipt of considerable new business.

WORCHESTER, Mass., April 28.--Last night the barn of Sexton Douglas at West Brookfield, together with its contents, was burned by an incendiary. The loss is $2,000; partly insured.

MONTEREY, Cal., April 29.--The preliminary examination of E.T.M. Simmons, late manager of the Hotel Del Monte, charged with having set fire to the hotel on April 1, was concluded yesterday. The accused was held in $25,000 bail to answer before the Superior Court.
MOBILE, Ala., April 29.--The Inter-State Commission arrived in this city at 2:20 P.M. and met at 4 in the United States court room. Representative men were present from Mobile, Selma, Greenville ...
TRENTON, N.J., April 29.--For several years past, up to 1884, the Supervisors and Marshals of Elections throughout New-Jersey were allowed by the Government fees varying from $10 to $50 per man.

WASHINGTON, April 29.--Major Richard H. Jackson, Fifth Artillery, has been detailed to attend the annual encampment of the First Brigage NewHampshire National Guard, to be held at the State Camp Ground at Concord, beginning May 31. He will inspect the troops taking part, under instructions from the Adjutant-General.
The closing exercises of the term at the Metropolitan Museum Art School were held last evening in the school building, 214 East Thirtyfourth-street.
The first article of the constitution of the Harvard Club has read: "This club shall be perpetual." Last night this sentence was flatly transgressed at a meeting of the club held at Delmonico's.
Civil Engineer Asserson, who has been at the head of the Yards and Docks Department of the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was reduced yesterday, and Capt. Cook was made the presiding officer of the yard.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 29.--Edward E. Samuels, of the firm of Samuels Jarnegan, St. Louis, leaped from the railroad bridge at this city this evening, and was rescued after floating 600 yards. He had been addicted to the use of liquor, and became despondent. He will likely recover. The distance from the bridge to the water is 75 feet.

The Columbia Seniors held their last regular meeting yesterday. The Memorial Committee reported that the Trustees had refused to accept the memorial fireplace the class had proposed to place in the library.

Further railroad earnings for the third week of April were reported in Wall-street yesterday. Two roads showed decreases. The St. Paul and Duluth fell off $2,302, to $20,535, and the Ohio and Mississippi fell off $12,552, to $65,205.
POUGHKEEPSIE, April 29.--Thirteen years ago Capt. William Platto and Miss Fannie M. Clark were married in this city.
BALTIMORE, April 29.--Henry Mielziner was arrested here to-day on the charge of robbery committed in New-York.

SAVANNAH, GA., April 29.--The Pilot boat Odell arrived in port to-day with Capt. Patrick Doyle and 18 of the crew of the British steamer Ben Hope, which was burned early yesterday morning 40 miles off the coast.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 29.--Foster's Opera House was burned this afternoon, and only the side walls and front offices remain. It was one of the finest theatres in the State.
College rowing in this country has advanced very greatly since a Harvard four underwent an exemplary defeat on the Thames eighteen years ago.

Horace J. Young, a good-looking young dealer in hay and feed at the foot of West Eleventh-street, was arrested yesterday morning at his residence, 412 West Fifty-eighthstreet, on a charge of abandoning his wife, Clara, now living at 171 Macdougal-street.
GRENADA, Miss., April 29.--The preliminary trial of Capt. W.P. Fowler for the killing of the Rev. C.F. Stivers was postponed to-day and may not come up till Monday.
The Hon. Thomas C. Acton and his friends are rapidly arranging preliminary details for establishing the new national bank, of which Mr. Acton is to be President.
Gov. David B. Hill is at the Hoffman House. Ex-Senator William B. Woodin, of Auburn, N.Y., is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.
A squad of 20 members of the First Hussars last evening donned their gay uniforms and gave an exhibition drill at Dickel's Riding Academy, in West Forty-sixth-street.
MONTREAL, April 29.--Another difficulty has arisen between the Montreal and the Great Northwestern Telegraph Companies.
BERLIN, April 29.--Prince Bismarck has informed M. Herbette, the French Ambassador, that he will to-day submit for the Emperor's signature an order for the release of M. Schnaebeles.

LISBON, N.H., April 29.--John Hauser and Henry Goshnel, shoemakers, while out in a boat on a mill pond in the village to-day, were carried over the dam and drowned. Neither body has yet been found. Each man leaves a widow and one child.
The significance of the recent deliberations and deliverances of the Vatican on the labor question has not escaped the attention of French journalists.

A committee from the Brooklyn Temperance Union, consisting of Philo W. Schofield and E.P. Ide, called on Mayor Whitney yesterday and presented a communication in regard to the violation of the Sunday law by liquor sellers.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 29.--Recently the Melchor Ocumpo, probably the strongest political club in the city, called a meeting for the avowed purpose of discussing the constitutional amendment for re-election of President.

PARIS, April 29.--A view this afternoon of the Salon exhibition for this year emphasizes the number of disproportionately large canvases, of the extent of which there have been rumors at once alarming and frequent.
Quite a number of ingenious (but not very ingenuous) writers have been trying to force President Cleveland into a declaration that he will not accept a nomination for a second term.
The body of a man was found on Thursday night lying in the highway at Corona, Long Island.

The Philolexian Society of Columbia College has awarded the annual prizes for excellence in literary work. The first Mills-Bull prize for orginal orations, $30, went to J.M. Rector. '90, who spoke on "High License:" the second, $20, to E. McK. Whiting, '87, on "The Debt we Owe to Thomas Jefferson."

BALTIMORE, April 29.--The reformers held a meeting to-night. Gratifying reports were read and several strong speeches were made. The reformers will go into the Gubernatorial campaign, and will make a vigorous contest all through the State. The fight is directed against Senator German and machine politics. All the prominent members of it are leading Democrats.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 29.--The Methodist congregation of Scott Township, a short distance from Scranton, is having a stormy time over the anti-license crusade which has been raging in this county the past few weeks.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 29.--The sale of thoroughbred colts and fillies, the property of Charles Reed and Capt. Franklin, at Fairview and Kennesaw Stud Farms, near Gallatin, Sumner County, to-day, was attended by several hundred people.

LOUISVILLE, April 29.--Soon after 1 o'clock this morning a mob of about 500 men and boys, armed with a section of a telegraph pole, marched down Jefferson-street in a body to charge the jail, in order to lynch the two negroes who assailed the girl, Jennie Bowman.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 29.--While Daniel Garron and his son, of Harmony, were drilling rocks yesterday, using a steel tamper a charge exploded prematurely while they were sitting on the stone. The rock was blown into atoms, and father and son thrown a considerable distance, and both badly hurt. Mr. Garron was injured internally and is not expected to live.
A conveyance of all the residuary estate of Samuel J. Tilden, exceeding, probably, $9,000,000, has been made to the Tilden trust.

The Eighth Regiment, N. G.S.N. Y., accompanied by the veterans of that organization moved last evening from the old armory at Ninth-avenue and Twenty-seventh-street to its temporary headquarters at Broadway and Thirty-fifth-street, which was at the same time vacated by the Seventy-first Regiment.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 29.--The Canadian Pacific Railroad is becoming a formidable rival of the American transcontinental line. To-day it took 2,000 barrels of sugar to Port Moody by steamer, to be shipped thence to eastern points.

Whenever Matthew Cohen, a young man employed by W.G. Lederie, at Grand-street and the Bowery, got into trouble, domestic or other, he has always attempted, or pretended to attempt, suicide, Yesterday he made his fifth attempt, and this time he will probably die.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, April 29.--More fishing vessels arrived at this port to-day, all having suffered more or less in the storm of Tuesday last. The Captain of the Portland schooner William Keene reports the gale as something terrific.
BERNE, April 29.--The lists of the Landsturm formed under the new law show an enrollment of 300,000 men.

John E. Gill, John Foster, George F. Worley, James McDonald, and John A. Campbell, members of the Executive Committee of Assembly No. 91 of the Knights of Labor. Were held for trial at General Sessions in $500 each yesterday,
CHICAGO, April 29.--Judge Garnett, in the Circuit Court, to-day delivered a decision in the case of William A. Tyler against his son, John B. Tyler.
Just about the time the steamship Aller was poking her nose into the North German Lloyd's slip, at Hoboken last evening, a cutter puffed up to the Battery and ran in toward the Barge Office landing.

Mayor Hewitt some days ago announced that he would reappoint Tax Commissioner Edward C. Donnelly when his term of office expired, May 1. Since then persons who have more or less interest in getting Mr. Donnelly out have sought to change the Mayor's views.
ALBANY, N.Y., April 29.--Arrangements are being perfected to mark the grave of President Arthur in the Rural Cemetery with an appropriate monument.
CITY OF MEXICO, April 29.--An English syndicate is about to purchase the Mulatto's mine, their offer of $660,000 having been accepted.

CHICAGO, April 29.--On April 12 Stephen Carlyle, a stock yards employe, who lived with his wife at 3,316 South Halsted-street, came home drunk and brutally beat his wife, Bridget, a little woman, weighing scarcely 100 pounds.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 29.--The novelty of a bull fight by electric light drew an immense crowd to the Colon Plaza last night. Among the spectators were President Diaz and several members of his Cabinet.

CHEBOYGAN, Mich., April 29.--The large steel steamship Susquehanna, upward bound with coal, was cut through by ice in the straits, and is now lying at anchor off that port with her forward compartment filling with water.

The racing season in this vicinity opens to-day at Cedarhurst, where six races are to be run under the auspices of the Rockaway Steeplechase Association. Should the day be pleasant the opening of the meeting will be a delightful one, for a number of jolly parties have been made up to drive to the hunt grounds.

WASHINGTON, April 29.--Some time ago Secretary Endicott overruled Lieut.-Gen. Sheridan in the matter of the appointment of a regimental staff officer. Gen. Sheridan approved the nomination of an officer on light battery duty for a regimental staff office.
PHILADELPHIA, April 29.--Sadie Cummings, a young woman living at 2,325 Wallacestreet, attempted to take her life last night because the young man whom she loved did not reciprocate the affection.

The Brooklyns and Athletics will play in Brooklyn to-day the game scheduled for Oct. 9. The third game between the New-Yorks and the Philadelphia will be played to-day in Philadelphia.

The New-Yorks and Philadelphias played their second League championship game yesterday on the Polo Grounds. It was a more interesting game than the first, and was witnessed by nearly as many spectators.

CHICAGO, April 29.--There is a possibility of a serious strike in the building trades on Monday. Several months ago the Hod Carriers' Union announced that on May 1 they would demand 25 cents an hour for bricklayers' laborers and 30 cents for plasterers' laborers.
Judge Donohue yesterday appointed Thomas W. Pearsall a Trustee of the estate of the late Paul Spofford, requiring him to give a bond of $50,000. Mr. Spofford was a prominent shipping merchant.

LANSING, Mich., April 29.--The Bates liquor bill appeared this morning. It provides a tax of $500 for manufacturing, selling, or keeping for sale spirituous and malt liquors, with a bond of from $3,000 to $6,000. No official or person engaged as principal, agent, or servant in the sale of liquor shall be accepted as surety.

BELVIDERE, N.J., April 29.--A number of cows on the Rutherford farm, near Allamuchy, have been attacked with pleuro-pneumonia. The disease has spread to a neighboring farm, a number of cattle belonging to George Wilson being affected. The cattle are under strict quarantine, and it is thought further spreading will be prevented. Cattle owners in the vicinity are greatly excited.
To-night Miss Helen Dauvray and her company will close their season at the Lyceum Theatre with a benefit performance for the Ninth Regiment Gettysburg Monument fund.

LYNCHBURG, Va., April 29.--An additional chapter in the Slenker scandal was recorded to-day in the preliminary hearing of Mrs. Slenker before United States Commissioner Tinsley. District Attorney A.C. Allen represented the Government.

ALBANY, April 29.--The backers of the New-York Subway Construction Company are evidently determined to pass the bill extending the term of the Subway Commissioners and legalizing the contract decided by Judge Van Hoesen to be invalid.

President Charles Francis Adams prefaced his testimony before the Pacific Railroad Commission yesterday with a personal explanation. There seemed to be a disposition, he said, on the part of the newspapers to criticise him for not knowing all about the accounts of the Union Pacific system. He had to repeat that he had not time to go into all the details, but was forced to rely upon the Controller.
Jay Gould gets his securities listed on the Stock Exchange much more expeditiously than some other folks.

LONDON, April 29.--The House of Commons this afternoon went into committee on the Irish Crimes Act Amendment bill. Mr. T.M. Healy proposed that the word offense in the act should be changed to the word crime. Mr. Dillon and Mr. Bradlaugh supported the proposal.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., April 29.--The oyster steamer Joshua Bedell, Capt. Barnes, left her dock in this city this morning with one of her owners, Capt. Henry Barnes, and four guests aboard, who were going to look over the latter's extensive oyster beds.
PARIS, April 29.--Wagner's opera "Lohengrin," the performance of which was postponed on account of the Schnaebeles incident, will be given here on Tuesday next.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29.--Although an international race between Cambridge and Harvard would be an important event in college boating, little interest seems to be manifested by Harvard in the proposal of the English University crew to visit this country.

ANDERSON, Ind., April 29.--Six tramps became engaged in a fight at the natural gas well near here yesterday. Two of them were pushed into the flame of the burning gas. One, whose name is said to be Donovan, inhaled the flame and died almost instantly. George Dwyer, of Erie, Penn., is burned almost beyond recognition and cannot recover. Three of the tramps are in jail.

LONDON, April 29.--There were 12 starters in the race for the One Thousand Guineas Stakes, for 3-year-old fillies, at Newmarket to-day. The Duke of Beaufort's ch. f. Reve d'Or won. C. Perkins's b.f. Porcelain came in second, and the Duke of Westminster's ch. f. Freedom third.

CHARLESTON, West Va., April 29.--The Senate consumed the day in discussing a motion to adjourn without electing a United States Senator. A letter from Mr. Lucas, Gov. Wilson's appointee, informed the Legislature that it would not be a lawful act to elect a Senator, and that a contest would result should the Legislature elect. A ballot will be taken on Tuesday.
The first annual banquet of the Manufacturing Furriers' Association of New-York will be bad at the Hoffman House this evening.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 29.--The Rev. J.W. Hoyte, a noted revivalist, dropped dead to-night just as he was on his way to open his evening services at the Presbyterian Church at Carollton. He had been here but a short time and met with great success. He had a family at Nashville, Tenn.

BENSON, Arizona, April 29.--Intelligence has been received that the men who robbed the westbound express train over the Southern Pacific Road Wednesday night have been "spotted," and that it will be only a question of time before they are captured.

CHICAGO, April 29.--Dr. J.N. Cadieux was arrested to-day at the instance of Mrs. Menard, of 404 Margaret-street, who charges the doctor with threats against her daughter Annie a pretty girl of about 17.
Harry Hill was before Recorder Smyth in Part II. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, and pleaded guilty to four indictments, two under the theatrical and two under the excise law.
BUFFALO, April 29.--The Supreme Court Grand Jury, which is hearing evidence relating to abuses at the State Insane Asylum, seems to be making a thorough investigation.

All the lawyers and their clients, excepting Dr. Smith, were present. The 11 jurors (one juror was excused during the trial on account of illness) were led in by an officer.
PITTSBURG, April 29.--Marker Rush, a well known character of this city, who was a few years ago worth $500,000, died at the City Poor Farm this afternoon of softening of the brain.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 29.--There was a very large attendance at the races to-day. The weather was clear and bright and the track a little heavy from dust.

The will of James Wood, the millionaire of Harlem, was filed and admitted to probate yesterday. He leaves to Mrs. Elizabeth Wood, his wife, his house, 341 East One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, and the furniture, for life.

OTTAWA, April 29.--A deputation representing the fruit merchants of the Dominion waited to-day upon Sir Charles Tupper, Minister of Finance, to press for a reduction of the duties upon American fruit. In support of their request they argue that no Canadian industries will be affected by a reduction, and that the perishable nature of the goods makes it very difficult to profitably handle imported fruit with the present duties.

Collector Magone has ordered an inquiry into the system of transfers from storehouses to warehouses. The material thus transferred is called "overflow," and represents goods that have laid at the stores as long as there is room.

J.H. Temple and W.H. Crawford, the latter having charge of the famous trotting gelding Arab, record 2:17 , met Nathan Straus yesterday and arranged for a race between the California pet and Mr. Straus's Majolica, record, 2:15.

BALTIMORE, April 29.--The Rev. A.M. Morrison stole a horse and buggy in this city on April 5 and a few days ago was arrested in Brockton, Mass. He returned to Baltimore on Wednesday in charge of a detective and was put on trial to-day. Conviction followed and he was sentenced to seven years in the penitentiary with hard labor.

FARMINGTON, Me., April 29.--It rained hard here all last night and to-day and the river is now higher than for eight years past.

Judge Van Brunt refsued yesterday to quash the "Fullgraff indictment" against Jacob sharp. The Court of Oyer and Terminer was not besieged by the crowd which collected when Sharp was called to have a day set for his trial, but a sufficient number of people were there to full its seats.

There was a lively twist in the stock market in the last hour of business on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The bulls had a merry time. It didn't last long, but while it did last it kept all Wall-street bent over the tickers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Apirl 30.--Superintendent Shanahan arrived in town to-day for a tour of inspection of the Erie Canal. He reports the improved locks ready and the canal in good condition for open ing on Saturday, May 7.

LOCKPORT STATION, N.Y., April 30.--William J. Dunton was crushed between the cars at Suspension Bridge yesterday afternoon and killed. He was an Englishman, aged 23 years, in the employ of the New-York Central Railroad.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30.--Everything is quiet this morning about the jail and Court House square. The meeting agreed upon by the mob leaders last evening has not materialized, andit is generally allowed that all danger of mob violence has passed.

The Society to Befriend Working Girls will hold a kaffee Klatsch at Primrose House 356 West Thirty-third-street, on Thursday between the hours of 2 and 6 in the afternoon and 8 and 11 in the evening. Tickets will be $1 each, and the cups and saucers used will be presented to the visitors.

LONDON, April 30.--Still the song is of Ireland, and this time Erin's harp gives forth a note which will reverberate across the American Continent. BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., April 30.--The ship Mary L. Cushing, from New-York for Hong-Kong, with 59,000 cases of oil and 230 tons of ballast, came ashore on the west side of Block Island at 10 o'clock this morning. A heavy sea is running and the vessel is pounding and leaking.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 30.--The General Society of the Cincinnati of the United States will hold its triennial session in this city on July 27, and will probably remain here several days. The Hon. Hamilton Fish is President and Mr. Asa Bird Gardner Secretary.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 30.--This was the sixth and last day of the Spring meeting of the Memphis Jockey Club. The weather was threatening, and a light shower began falling just before the first race, which, however, was not sufficent to lay the dust. The attendance was fair.

RED BANK, N. J., April 30.--At Trenton to-day the Court of Errors and Appeals decided the libel suit of Emma and Joseph Patterson against the Mercantile Agency of R. G. Dun Co., of New-York, in favor of the plaintiffs, giving judgment for $3,000, with interest and costs of suit, which amount to $450.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 30.--Thomas Durning, who was convicted for murder in the second degree for the killing of Peter Martin, was sentenced to-day to 12 years' solitary imprisonment in the Eastern Penitentiary. The interest in this case is intense, owing to the heartless nature of the crime, and there was a large crowd present when sentence was pronounced.

PALESTINE, Texas, April 30.--At a picnic gathering held two miles south of the city to-day Senator John H. Reagan addressed the citizens, and in his address he pronounced himself in favor of a prohibition amendment, and clearly defined his position and views with reference to all the principles involved.
